OLAGING: THE BATTLE OF NALANDANGAN

Published 1979. Transcriber, Ludivina R. Opeña. In Kinaadman 1:151-227.

Agyu is the epic of the Arakan-Arumanen or the Ilianon of northern Cotabato in Mindanao. It is closely related to the Ulahingan of the Livunganen-Arumanen, with both epics having identical characters, because the two groups used to be one, called Arumanen. Agyu is chanted without the accompaniment of music or dance. The likuen (melody) is usually determined by the incidents being narrated. In battle scenes, for instance, the rhythm quickens and the singer is said to be abmanna-hansang—that is, chanting his lines in a staccato manner.

The Agyu is divided into two parts: the pemahra/pamara, or an invocation, and the ulahingon, or narrative proper. The ulahingon, in turn, consists of two parts: a kepu-unpu-un and a sengedurug. The kepu-un-pu-un is a standard narrative, although slightly different versions of it exist, about the history of Agyu’s family and how they fled to Nalandangan and became immortal. It is usually recited rather than chanted. The sengedurug, the part that is chanted, continues the history and narrates the continuing adventures of Agyu and his relatives in Nalandangan. There is no single standard narrative for the sengedurug nor limit to the number of stories that can be told; hence, the multiplicity of Agyu stories. Epic conventions that can be found in Agyu are stock epithets, including multiple names for one character or place; elaborate similes; hyperbole; the transformation of commonplace objects into magical ones, including the use of boats and kerchiefs as flying vehicles; the repetition of set descriptions; and the catalog of names.

In 1913, Fay-Cooper Cole published stories of Agyu, which he described as a “bed time chant.” Tranquilino Sitoy of Misamis Oriental discovered another Agyu song and published it in English prose in 1937. In 1969, E. Arsenio Manuel transcribed the epic and titled it Agyu: The Ilianon Epic of Mindanao. His principal source was Blagtas Pandakan, then living in Lumut, Kallinan, Davao City. Blagtas Pandakan learned the epic from his uncle Sugalan, who had learned it from his father, Ampalid. Blagtas Pandakan was about 42 when, covering himself with a white blanket, he chanted the epic on the night of 9 May 1963. Assisted by Batooy Ambag, a son-in-law of a datu, and Pilisianu Tisio, Manuel recorded the epic from 21 Nov to 25 Nov. Manuel’s version of Agyu follows.

Living at the rivermouth of Ayuman/Sinimbulan are the three sons of Pemulaw, the brothers Kuyasu aka Banlak, Agyu aka Bagyasan / Datu Lungba, and Matilom aka Panganlawon/Lono. Agyu has four sisters, but only Yambungan and Ikwangan are mentioned in the Manuel version. Banlak’s wife, named Mungan aka Paniguan, is badly afflicted with a consuming disease, leprosy. One of the subsistence occupations of the Ilianon people is the gathering of beeswax, which they trade with the Maguindanao, their distant neighbors, for articles and goods that they need. Although these goods and articles are not mentioned in the epic, they have been identified as cloth, blanket, swords, betel nut and lime containers, salt, and coconut oil. The Maguindanaon depend much on other peoples for their supply of beeswax for caulking their vessels.

One day Agyu sends his brother, Kuyasu/Banlak, to deliver nine kamu, or lumps of beeswax, to a Maguindanaon datu who is his trading partner. The Maguindanaon datu is irked at the meanness of the payment; and he hurls the beeswax at Kuyasu, hurting the latter’s foot, which has an ulcer. Kuyasu retaliates instantly by spearing the Maguindanao datu in the chest.

Banlak/Kuyasu hurries back to Ayuman to warn Agyu that the Maguindanao enemies are coming because he has slain the datu. Agyu decides they must depart at once for Mount Ilian/Mabpung, where Agyu orders his people to gather logs and a hundred stones each that will crush their pursuing enemies. They build houses and wait. Soon, the day darkens as thousands of Maguindanao warriors arrive, but Agyu and his people decimate them.

After this victory, Agyu chooses the land of Pinamatun, aka Maladamal, to settle in. After they have built their shelters once again, Agyu leaves for Sandawa mountain (Mount Apo) to hunt with his brother Matilom, who cuts a path on the side of the mountain. Their two sisters, Yambungan Pignayuan aka Paniguan and Ikwangan aka Kabuyawanon, are each carried on a hammock as they go into the forest to search for honey, which they find inside a palm tree. Agyu arrives with a wild piglet. The animal is cut into equal pieces, as are the honeycombs, and these are distributed among the people. Agyu suggests to Banlak that he give some to his wife, Mungan, whom Banlak has abandoned in Ayuman because of her affliction. Banlak refuses, and so Matilom volunteers to deliver Mungan’s share of the food. Arriving at Ayuman, Matilom/Panganlawon hears what sounds like the shouting of thousands. He finds Mungan/Paniguan now fully healed and offering him a golden betel chew and pinipi (young rice).

Learning of his wife’s recovery, Banlak decides to return to her. Agyu sternly forbids him, for he has already forsaken her. The betel nut and pinipi are distributed, and the people feel a new life coming to them. Agyu and his people return to Ayuman, but Mungan is gone, having already ascended to heaven and leaving behind her house of gold.

Agyu and his people sail for 10 days until they reach Tigyandang aka Nalandangan. Here, they build their houses and declare it their new country. Agyu and his people are attacked. The men descend to the battlefield while performing the war dance. They fight the enemy by the bay of Linayangon. As they are losing men by the thousands, Tanagyaw, Agyu’s youngest son and a mere boy, offers to meet the invaders himself. By the fourth day, all the enemies are slain. The defeated leader invites Tanagyaw, the boy, to come home with him, but the boy only mocks him for his defeat. When the datu arrives at his home, he finds Tanagyaw in his house after all. The datu has his daughter, Buy’anon, dress up and come out of her room. He bids her sit beside Tanagyaw, give him betel chew, and consider him for a prospective husband. Buy’anon invites him to sit on her lap, but the boy refuses, saying he is merely a boy and, as such, still in search of adventure.

Reaching the country of Baklayon, Tanagyaw finds the people troubled because they are about to be attacked. Tanagyaw is well received and is offered the datu’s young daughter, named Paniguan (not to be confused with Banlak’s wife, also named Paniguan). She appears, offers him betel chew, and asks him to be her husband, saying he will be their savior. Tanagyaw slays the invaders, but the datu’s son, Bagili, challenges him to a duel. Tanagyaw defeats him and leads the people in a victory cry. The defeated datu departs in shame. Tanagyaw is offered betel chew and marriage to Paniguan but he now decides to go home, promising to come to this country’s rescue whenever it is needed. But Paniguan accompanies him home. Asked about her identity, Paniguan insists on marrying Tanagyaw, who, after his initial resistance, is joyfully wedded to her.

After some time, Agyu calls all his people to an assembly to announce that invaders are coming from across the sea. The old man Yugang/Layunlayun declares his intention to flee, but his fearless wife calls him a foolish coward and declares her intention to stay. The enemies besiege the country of Tigyandang aka Nalandangan. All the men, including the younger ones, descend to the enemy camp to fight but are defeated. Old man Yugang/Layunlayun again predicts their doom. Tanagyaw chastises him, puts on his breastplate of 10 layers, and picks up his shield and unbreakable spear. Then he slays the invaders, and their corpses pile up like mountains. The leader of the invaders invites Tanagyaw to his country. But Tanagyaw boasts that he has defeated the leader. The leader’s son fights him, using a bar of gold. Tanagyaw in turn uses his tanigid (golden cane) and pounds the challenger to a pulp. The leader returns to his homeland, lamenting his own son’s death. Agyu assigns the country of Sunglawon to his victorious son, who settles there with his wife.

Knowledge about Agyu has been enriched with the publication of more episodes. In 1972, the Xavier Folklife Museum and Archives published “Battle of Nalandangan,” transcribed by Ludivina R. Opeña, as it was sung by Luis Pasal of Banud, Malaybalay, Bukidnon. She was assisted by Ametta Suarez Taguchi, Felipe Ando, and Antonio Magana. Opeña also discovered a song which she titled “Agyu Gets a Husband for His Sister,” in which Agyu searches for an underworld deity, Tumpas Namapiyaw, whom his sister Matabagka/Tabagka has dreamt of and wants as a husband. The deity pays no bride-price for Matabagka/Tabagka, although he wants to, because he was abducted while he was sleeping. He later saves Nalandangan from invaders while Agyu and the menfolk are away.

“The Battle of Nalandangan,” earlier discovered by Opeña, was also recorded by Carmen Ching-Unabia, as sung by Luis Pasal. However, Pasal added a description of Nalandangan, a genealogy of Agyu and his relatives, and a history of the sky before the actual narrative. Ching-Unabia’s thesis includes three other episodes which she titled “The Marriage of Tabagka,” “Tagyakuwa and the Black Datu,” and “Capture of Nalandangan.” Besides Pasal, her informants were Jose de la Mance of Silae, Malaybalay; Manuel Himaus of Maluko, Manolo Fortich; and Anastasio Saway of Sungko, Lantapan.

The latest addition to Agyu scholarship is Corazon Manuel’s thesis, “The Epic of Nalandangan: A Study of Two Songs,” 1976, which includes the songs that she titled “The Warriors of Saliga Attack Nalandangan” and “Matabagka Searches for the Deity of the Wind.” In these episodes, Agyu’s sister Matabagka is the hero. In the first song, Matabagka saves Nalandangan from invaders while Agyu and the men are away. When the enemies land, Matabagka puts on her breastplate, takes her spear and shield, and marches to the shore, while the rest of the women cry in panic. The leader of the invading Sagila is surprised to see a woman approaching them. He tells his men to drop their arms so that Matabagka may not be scared away. He plans to marry her. Matabagka seizes her chance and attacks the invaders. For some time she is successful, but her hair becomes her undoing. The leader grabs her by it, and she turns livid. Agyu arrives and sends her home, while he fights the surviving invaders. His spear magically fights on its own until it meets the leader, who challenges Agyu. Agyu kills him, but Agyu, too, dies. Agyu’s shield guards his corpse until he is resurrected by the gods.

In “Matabagka Searches for the Deity of the Wind,” Matabagka is again instrumental in saving Nalandangan from destruction. Agyu’s tumanod, or guardian spirit, predicts that Imbununga, the god of the wind and thunder, is about to invade Nalandangan. Being less powerful than the wind god, Agyu is restless. Matabagka senses this and, learning about the prophecy, she rides her sulindaay, or floating hat, to look for the wind god. When Agyu finds this out, he sends Lumuganod, his military chief, to look for her. Matabagka reaches Imbununga’s place. Imbununga is enchanted by her beauty and takes her as his mistress. Later, she charms him to sleep with a special betel chew. While he is sleeping, Matabagka steals his baklaw, in which he stores his powers. She escapes in her sulindaay. But Imbununga soon awakens and sends his warriors after her. Imbununga tells the wind to send the sulindaay to ground, so that his men can pursue Matabagka. She defends herself with her dagger. When his men ask Imbununga to allow them to burn her, he refuses. The fighting lasts for days, and Matabagka’s skin turns dark. Lumuganod saves her and sends her to Nalandangan. There she tells Agyu what she has done and shows him the baklaw. She also tells him how Imbununga protected her from his own men.

Agyu assures her that he will persuade Imbununga to join them, for his powers will be useful for Nalandangan’s defense. Agyu meets Imbununga by the shore and bargains for peace. Imbununga, admiring Matabagka’s courage, marries her. Peace is restored to Nalandangan.

It is suggested by critic Patricia Melendrez-Cruz that the Agyu epic bears utopian suggestions. In an introduction to the epic, she notes that the description of Nalandangan is in the first-person plural and in the present tense, although the narrative itself is in the past tense and in the third person. Nalandangan, therefore, is both “a mythic past and a future yearning” (Castro et al. 1983, 191). Each time the epic is sung, the utopia that is Nalandangan is brought to mind.  Written by E. Arsenio Manuel and Jonathan Chua.

text:
(To the Filipino Youth). Published 1879. Author, Jose Rizal. Revista del Liceo Artistico y Literario, 1879. Anthologized in Poesias de Rizal (Poems of Rizal). Compiler, Jaime C. de Veyra, Manila: Bureau of Printing, 1946. English translation, “To the Filipino Youth” by Charles Derbyshire in Jose Rizal, Life, Works and Writings by Gregorio F. Zaide, Manila: Villanueva Book Store, 1970. Tagalog translation, “Sa mga Kabataang Filipino” by Vicente de Jesus in Mga Tula ni Jose Rizal (The Poems of Jose Rizal), Manila: Pambansang Komisyon ng Ikasandaang Taon ni Jose Rizal, 1962.

Awarded the silver pen by the Liceo Artistico y Literario, this is the first poem written by a Filipino to be acclaimed by Spanish literary authorities.

“Crece o Timida Flor” (Grow, O Timid Flower) is the theme of the poem, composed of 10 rhyming quintillas, or five-line stanzas. Rizal challenges the Filipina youth to free themselves from the bondage of ignorance and to develop their potential in the arts: poetry, music, sculpture, and painting. He ends with an exhortation and a thanksgiving.

A nationalistic strain is evident in the opening lines (trans. Charles Derbyshire):

¡Alza tu tersa frente,

Juventud Filipina, en este dia!

¡Luce resplandeciente

tu rica gallardia

belle esperanza de la Patria mia!

 

(Hold high the brow serene,

O youth, where now you stand.

Let the bright sheen

Of your grace be seen,

Fair hope of the Fatherland!)

By referring to the youth as “juventud Filipina,” Rizal was addressing not only the young Spaniards born in the Philippines but also the mestizos or half-breeds and the native Filipinos. Moreover, Rizal saw the Philippines as his fatherland, a view which during Spanish rule was frowned upon, for only Spain was the fatherland. The poem would be used against Rizal in his trial in 1896 as evidence that he harbored separatist ideas even in his youth.  Written by Ambeth Ocampo

article.value: (To the Filipino Youth). Published 1879. Author, Jose Rizal. Revista del Liceo Artistico y Literario, 1879. Anthologized in Poesias de Rizal (Poems of Rizal). Compiler, Jaime C. de Veyra, Manila: Bureau of Printing, 1946. English translation, “To the Filipino Youth” by Charles Derbyshire in Jose Rizal, Life, Works and Writings by Gregorio F. Zaide, Manila: Villanueva Book Store, 1970. Tagalog translation, “Sa mga Kabataang Filipino” by Vicente de Jesus in Mga Tula ni Jose Rizal (The Poems of Jose Rizal), Manila: Pambansang Komisyon ng Ikasandaang Taon ni Jose Rizal, 1962.
Awarded the silver pen by the Liceo Artistico y Literario, this is the first poem written by a Filipino to be acclaimed by Spanish literary authorities.

“Crece o Timida Flor” (Grow, O Timid Flower) is the theme of the poem, composed of 10 rhyming quintillas, or five-line stanzas. Rizal challenges the Filipina youth to free themselves from the bondage of ignorance and to develop their potential in the arts: poetry, music, sculpture, and painting. He ends with an exhortation and a thanksgiving.
A nationalistic strain is evident in the opening lines (trans. Charles Derbyshire):

¡Alza tu tersa frente,

Juventud Filipina, en este dia!

¡Luce resplandeciente

tu rica gallardia

belle esperanza de la Patria mia!

 

(Hold high the brow serene,

O youth, where now you stand.

Let the bright sheen

Of your grace be seen,

Fair hope of the Fatherland!)

text:
(To the Fatherland). Written 1897. Dimas-Ilaw (pseud. of Emilio Jacinto ). Included in “Emilio Jacinto” by Epifanio de los Santos, Revista Filipina, Jun 1918. Tagalog translation, “Sa Bayang Tinubuan” by Jose Villa Panganiban in Panitikan ng Pilipinas (Literature of the Philippines), edited by Jose Villa Panganiban and Consuelo T. Panganiban, Quezon City: Bede’s Publishing House Inc, 1954. English translation, “To the Fatherland” by Gregorio Nieva in The Revolutionists: Aguinaldo, Bonifacio, Jacinto, edited with an introduction and notes by Teodoro A. Agoncillo, Manila: National Historical Commission, 1973, from the biography in Spanish, “Emilio Jacinto,” by Epifanio de los Santos published in Revista Filipina, Jun 1918.

Jacinto composed this poem on 8 Oct 1897 in Santa Cruz, Laguna, and published it under the pseudonym “Dimas-Ilaw.” Deemed to be his most important work in Spanish, it is an ode inspired by Jose Rizal ’s “Mi Ultimo Adios” (My Last Farewell). The poem depicts the conditions that brought about the revolution and ends with a promise to fight for the country’s redemption until it is won.

The poem, composed of 21 quintillas or five-line stanzas of 16 syllables per line, may be divided into four parts: the invocation (stanzas 1-3), the persona’s declaration of compassion for the native land (stanzas 4-9), the persona’s resolve to fight for his country’s freedom (stanzas 10-20), and the persona’s reiteration of his love for his country (stanza 21).

Some of the poem’s metaphors and ideas, such as the epithet “eden esplendoroso” (splendid Eden), echo Rizal’s. Unlike Rizal, however, Jacinto relies less on nostalgic or poignant imagery to convey his patriotism than on forceful, more direct rhetorical questions, such as the following (trans. Gregorio Nieva):

De que sirve que cubran tus campos tantas flores,

que en tus selvas, se oiga al pajaro trinar

si el aire que transporta sus cantos, sus olores

en alas tambien lleva quejido y clamores

que el alma sobrecogen y al hombre hacen pensar?

 

(And what avail thee the flowers covering thy smiling meadows,

What the birds’ carols that sweetly in your forests resound?

Ah, the same breeze that their fragrance bears and their songs harmonious,

Bears on its ways cries and sobbing, weeping and bitter complaints,

That fill the soul with anguish and the mind with sad thoughts.)

The frequent use of this device, coupled with the personification of the country as a woman, stresses that what is ultimately valuable is neither beauty nor wealth, but the independence of one’s will.  Written by Edgardo Tiamson and Jonathan Chua

text:
(To the Flowers of Heidelberg). Written 1886. Author, Jose Rizal. Anthologized in Poesias de Rizal (Poems of Rizal), compiled by Jaime C. de Veyra, Manila: Bureau of Printing, 1946. English translation, “To the Flowers of Heidelberg” by Charles Derbyshire in Jose Rizal, Life, Works and Writings by Gregorio F. Zaide, Manila: Villanueva Book Store, 1970. Tagalog translation, “Sa mga Bulaklak sa Heidelberg” by Vicente de Jesus in Mga Tula ni Jose Rizal (The Poems of Jose Rizal), Manila: Pambansang Komisyon ng Ikasandaang Taon ni Jose Rizal, 1962.

This poem was written while Rizal was in Germany. During one of his trips to the outskirts of the ancient city of Heidelberg, he passed by the banks of the river Neckar and saw a host of flowers, including his favorite “forget-me-not.” In a moment of longing and nostalgia, Rizal composed this lyric.

The beautiful flowers are instructed by the persona, a lonely traveler, to be the messengers to the persona’s distant country. In the first stanza, they are told to relate how at dawn, while admiring the flowers for their beauty and fragrance, the persona murmurs love songs in the native language; and that, reminded of the sun in the native land, the persona greets the less fiery German sunrise. In the next stanzas, the flowers are asked to relay the love that the persona feels for his or her country folk; it is hoped that the kisses the persona bestows upon the petals will be blown by the wind to the homeland and be felt by the native folk. The last stanza makes an implied identification between the persona and the flowers. Just as their fragrance remains in Heidelberg even though they go to a foreign land (the persona’s), so also the persona will always be present in his or her own native land.

Scholars and writers have been unanimous in their praise of this poem by Rizal. Rafael Palma comments that the poem is one of Rizal’s best, remarkable for its graceful language and for its ardent sentiment.  Written by Ruby Alcantara

article_title: Ako ang Daigdig at Iba Pang Mga Tula
text:
(I Am the World and Other Poems). Published 1955. Author, Alejandro G. Abadilla. With an introduction by Francisco Arcellana, a preface by the author, and a study guide by Hilda L. Coronel. Manila: (F. B. S.) Silangan Publishing House.

This collection of poems is divided into three sections: “Sa Panitikan” (To Literature), “Sa Buhay” (To Life), and “Sa Bathala” (To God).

The title poem is a landmark in the history of Tagalog poetry because of its deliberate subversion of traditional poetry as exemplified in the works of Lope K. Santos and Jose Corazon de Jesus. When it was first published in Liwayway magazine in 1940, the poem provoked strong reactions not only from the more established poets but even from Abadilla’s own contemporaries like Clodualdo del Mundo, who dismissed it as a non-poem. This poem is a celebration of “ako”— the free, independent, dynamic self, which constitutes a world of its own. Its subject matter is the art of poetry and the role of the poet in this act of creation; hence, unlike traditional poetry, it is not meant to convey a moral. Moreover, like most of the other poems in this collection, it is written in a manner which violates all the rules of traditional poetry, especially those of rhyme and meter, so that its publication signaled the emergence of a new kind of poetry bearing the imprint of modernism imported from the West.

In theme and form, Abadilla’s iconoclasm threads through the collection. The first section, “Sa Panitikan,” revolves around the theme of the self and the poet’s creative power as conveyed in such poems as “Awit ng Sarili” (Song of the Self), “Sanaysay ng Sarili” (Essay of the Self), “Dilim, Mutyang Dilim” (Darkness, Beloved Darkness), “Magsusupling Ako sa Iyong Kawalan” (I Will Create from Your Loss), and “Hindi Ako” (Not I). Abadilla’s disdain for scientific knowledge is expressed in “Oo, Marunong Ka” (Yes, So You Know) and “Kaalamang Makaagham” (Scientific Knowledge). He ridicules poets’ strict obedience to a regular rhyme-and-meter scheme and the rules of the balarila (grammar) in “Talipapa” (Wet Market) and urges poets to stand firm in their convictions in “Tumindig Ka” (Stand Up). He offers his definition of poetry in “Kadakilaan: O Tula” (Nobility: Oh Poem) and “Ang Tula” (The Poem).

The second section, “Sa Buhay,” begins with “Sa Katauhang Lagalag” (To the Wandering Person), a reproachful comment on the modern person’s search for and failure to find true happiness, which, according to the poet, only lies within the self. The section closes with the patriotic “Lupang Tinubuan” (Native Land), which, in very direct language, affirms the persona’s identification with the common symbols of the nation, such as the brown race, language, flag, national anthem, and kundiman, a type of local love song.

In the third section, “Sa Bathala,” the poet defines his concept of God, with whom he identifies. Other poems, on the other hand, stress the distance between God and person. In “Bagong Magdalena” (New Magdalene), the country under neocolonial and post-World War II conditions is likened to the Biblical Magdalene.

Included in this collection are some of Abadilla’s first poems, published in 1932, such as “Mandaragat” (Fisher) and “Tatlong Katha” (Three Works).  Written by Soledad Reyes and Rosario Cruz-Lucero

text:
(Ardor: Poems). Published 1983. Author, Edgardo B. Maranan. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Asian Center.

This collection of poems brings together works written by the poet between 1974 and 1982. Some were written while the poet was detained as a political prisoner at RECAD 6 in Camp Crame and Camp Bagong Diwa in Bicutan. The book is divided into four groups of poems: “Balada sa Baklad” (Ballad of the Fishpens), “Sunog sa Ilang Pook ng Maynila” (Fire in Some Parts of Manila), “Dagitab sa Pagitan ng Rehas na Bakal” (Neon Light between Iron Bars), and “Awit sa Sigwang Nagdaan” (Song to a Storm of the Past).

The poetic tone in Maranan’s works ranges across a wide register. It is meditative in poems such as “Habang Nakasalampak sa Labas ng Modernong Aklatan sa Los Baños sa Isang Dapithapon ng Tag-araw” (While Slumped outside the Modern Library in Los Baños at Dusk One Summer) or “Kontemplasyon sa Maputik na Bungo ng Isang Guatemalteco” (Contemplation on the Muddy Skull of a Guatemalan); elegiac, as in the poems commemorating the deaths of Valerio N. Nofuente (an activist-teacher), Liza Balando (a working-class hero), and Maria Lorena Barros (a New People’s Army leader); philosophical, as in “Makata” (Poet) and “Kasabihan” (Sayings); humorous, as in “Syuting sa Makiling” (A Filmshoot on Makiling) and “Kapalaran” (Fate); polemical, as in “Di Ako Mapasikdo ng Bali-balita” (The News Don’t Faze Me) and “Mga Aso ng Chile” (Dogs of Chile); grim, as in “Pirapirasong Balita sa Araw na Ito” (Today’s News Tidbits); and celebratory, as in the poems addressed to Otto Rene Castillo, Stephen Biko, and Dennis Brutus.

The book ends with a short poem, “ Wala Na Sila” (They Are Gone), a poetic farewell to Pablo Neruda, Mao Tse-tung, Emmanuel Lacaba, and Lorena Barros, heroes in the pantheon of Filipino activists.  Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero

article_title: Alit: Dalit, Halit, Ngalit, Palit at Salit
text:
(Quarrel: Psalm, Rent, Gnashing of Teeth, Exchange and Interspersion). Published 1993. Author, V. E. Carmelo Nadera. Pasig City: Anvil Publishing, Inc.

This is a collection of 47 poems which are the poet’s reinventions of traditional forms of poetry, such as the tanaga, dalit, fable, proverb, parable, pasyon, and balagtasan, to serve as vehicles of contemporary themes. It appears back-to-back with Ariel Dim. Borlongan’s poetry collection, Pasintabi ng Kayumanggi (Apologia of the Brown Race).

The first poem, “Magsipag! Magsipagdiwang!” (Get Cracking! Celebrate!), in the first section titled “Dalit” (Psalm) is an exhilarating celebration of life as it urges the reader to constantly question tradition and conventional thought. To this end, allusions to the Bible, Catholic prayers, Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), sayings, idioms, and Hermano Puli are placed side by side. “Talatanagaan,” in the section termed “Ngalit” (Gnashing of Teeth), is a suite of 21 titled quatrains deriving from the tanaga, an indigenous Tagalog form. They are satires on topics such as economic sabotage (“Kartel” [Cartel]), the commodification of women (“Ba-bay Boracay!” [Bye-Bye Boracay!]), education (“Abakada” [ABC]), international leaders (“I.O.U”), and dictators (“Ilang Manlilinlang” [Some Conmen])

The section called “Malit” has a single-page poem, “Kenkoy En/Or Rosing” (Kenkoy and/or Rosing), which, in content and form, is a duet between the title characters. It draws on the komiks serial, Tony Velasquez’s Kenkoy, to satirize the Filipinos’ peculiar use of English.

In the penultimate section, “Palit” (Exchange), the poems are positioned every which way, and each one is a set of permutations of a basic design; yet, every line makes sense. In “Balimbing” (Two-Faced), the letters of the Tagalog alphabet are laid out in eight vertical lines, their bottom letters horizontally spelling “balimbing.” The poem’s epigraph is the alphabet song by the musician Florante. A more adventurous experiment with typography is “Tularo,” the word a pun on “tula” (poem), “laro” (play or game), and “tuliro” (dazed). An epigraph from Nick Joaquin characterizes “vernacular” literature as “a song that is sung, / a poem that is recited.” What follows is a suite of 21 concrete poems, each of which visually mimics its one-word content, such as “hatsing” (sneeze), “hikab” (yawn), “hilik” (snore), “sinok” (hiccup), and “dighay” (burp).

The final section is composed of seven songs printed with chord symbols above the lyrics. Although no notes are given to provide the melody, the music is credited to Paul Val Peña, Teta Tulay, Cynthia Afable, and Nadera himself. These songs are more traditionally poignant and sentimental. “Katoto” (Comrade) evokes countryside images in its tribute to missing persons like student activist Albert Enriquez, to whom this poem is dedicated. “Dating Tipanan” (Old Engagement) celebrates the union of two lovers, whereas in “Biyudang Saudi” (Widow of Saudi), the male persona anxiously waits for word from his wife, who is an overseas contract worker.

In this collection, Nadera mixes the old and the new and thus succeeds in introducing a new voice and a refreshingly novel way of seeing the world.  Written by Soledad Reyes

text:
Published 2004. Author, Myrna Peña-Reyes. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

The book, the second poetry collection of Peña-Reyes, has 68 poems, divided into seven sections, with a glossary of cultural references to Visayan folk life. The opening section, “The Sea Where It Began,” is a suite of several poems inspired by myth and folklore, evoking archetypes of births and beginnings. The second section, “Children of War,” intimates painful discoveries in lyrical vignettes of the Pacific War, an uncommon subject in Philippine poetry. The third, “Other Regions Other Seasons,” gathers the poet’s impressions about foreign places, most notably about everyday life abroad.

The fourth part, “Sojourner’s Housekeeping Journal,” serves as a contemporary pillow-book about finding one’s place in a foreign culture. This section allows for a more personalized articulation of the immigrant’s life. The fifth section, “Detours and Cul-de-Sacs,” probes into illness and death. In the sixth, “Directions for Departures,” the poet confronts mortality through philosophical lenses. The last, “Caught in the Eddy,” reels the reader in back to the present, where survival demands that one be vigilant amid natural catastrophes and the quest for personal epiphanies.

As is the case with her first collection, The River Singing Stone, 1994, the poems are achievements in irony, their insights, humor, and piquant commentary made memorable precisely because they emerge with indirection. In “Kite Morning,” a grandfather, in the twilight of a failed life, accedes to the children’s clamor for them to fly a kite. The old man makes a crude kite, but it is his kite that soars the highest. He has brought into it the practical wisdom that his elders had given him and the flying secrets that he has learned. The old man’s small victory is figuratively his redemption.

“The Raftsman That Never Looked Back” draws on a child’s memory of a dog that her family abandoned during World War II. The rumored cruelty of the Japanese creates a terror-filled atmosphere. The child’s plea that the dog be fetched falls upon deaf ears. The persona values the object lesson—on the risks of flight and the cruelty of forsaking affections when the concern for safety prevails—only in hindsight.

In “Women’s Auxiliary,” a ladies circle invites a poet to read, but her moment is overtaken by the women’s endless chatter about their domestic woes. Choosing to be polite, the persona gives in to the mundane noises and sets aside her lofty concerns—the guest ironically playing the host.

“Morendo” paints a twilight portrait of friends abroad. They sing songs that stir up homeland longings. The persona rues how her once-strong, resonant voice has weakened over time though a fund of passions remains undiminished. “Hands that cannot form a fist / cannot make music,” the persona thinks, suggesting how vibrancy proceeds from the tension between humanity’s tough and tender cores. The musical notation morendo means a decrease in volume and tempo and is suggestive of fading or dying away.

The book was published after Peña-Reyes’s return to Negros Oriental from long residency in the United States, a fact which may help account for the poems in the third and fourth sections. More important, however, the collection is evidence of Peña-Reyes’s fine poetic craftsmanship and an exemplar of the Silliman school of writing.  Written by Danilo Francisco M. Reyes

text:
Published 1966. Author, Emmanuel Torres. Manila: Bookmark.

This is Torres’s first volume of poetry, which consists of 13 poems previously published in the Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature anthologies of winning entries.

In these early works, several dominant themes and images emerge. Notable among these are images of people attempting to impose order on objects and natural situations that defy such order. For example, a quiet, tastefully furnished room in “Out of the Parrot Cage” is disturbed by Pierre, the parrot, with its gaudy plumes and noisy squawks. Likewise, the builders of “The Great Wall of China” seek to contain their

… loves, animals in cages, rock gardens, and scrolls,

Against our neighbors with feet of mud

Whose shadows are raising armies

At our loves, animals in cages, rock gardens, and scrolls.

Counterpointing these images are those that highlight the sterility of an ordering that ultimately leaves us with only “the desert … blowing its own dust and alone / Aerial like a huge needle … pulsing strange signals.” In the face of the intense vitality displayed by such unruly objects as a bouquet of scraggly, ferocious blooms in “Sunflowers by Van Gogh,” the impotence of the artist’s attempts at symmetry and clarity is exposed.

Poetry, Torres declares in “Them,” is “not the light you switch on to find a room. / It is the incandescence dark bodies give off.” The collection displays carefully crafted poems that reflect both the elegance and intensity of these aesthetic concerns. They are typical of poetry in English in the 1960s and early 1970s, and reveal the influence of the Iowa Writers’ Workshops on Philippine poetry.  Written by Elena Rivera Mirano

article_title: Antisipasyon asin Iba Pang Rawitdawit sa Bikol asin Ingles
text:
(Anticipation and Other Poems in Bikol and English). Published 2007. Author, Victor Dennis Nierva. Naga City: Goldprint Pub. House. Reprinted, 2012. Naga City: Ateneo de Naga University Press. Manila Critics Circle’s National Book Award for poetry, 2008.

Antisipasyon is Vic Nierva’s debut collection of poems, some of which come with English translations by poets Francisco Peñones Jr and Marne Kilates. Nostalgia is the general subject matter of the poems. In “An Pagpoon kan Kamawotan” (The Birth of Longing) and “Kamunduan” (Sorrow), the persona revisits his hometown Lupi in the landscape of his memories. He calls forth the images of his immediate environment: from the town’s surroundings in the two poems titled “Paghalat” (Waiting) and “Pagsakay sa Tren” (Before Boarding the Train), to its people and their everyday experiences in “Pagpuli” (Coming Home) and “Odto” (Noon).

However, the poems are also the persona’s meditation on his relationship with his hometown and with its enchanting beauty. The awe and wonder he feels at the beauty of his hometown are expressed in each poem, but especially in “An Pagkahapon sa Sakong Banwaan” (Afternoon in My Homeland), “Payong Baha” (Flood Head), and “Sa Matanga” (At Midnight).

The first section, “Paghalat” (Waiting), uses the motifs of motion and stillness. The persona shows gentle restraint as he anticipates the arrival of something which seems overwhelming, magnificent, and almost ethereal.

The second section, “Pagrani” (Coming Closer), starts with “Kami Ata Nang Mauragon” (We Real Cool), an adaptation of Gwendolyn Brooks’s poem “Pool Players. Seven at the Golden Shovel.” The poem sets the tone for this section: more movement and interaction. One feels this movement in the three poems “An Dawani” (The Rainbow), “Sa Malabsay” (In Malabsay), and “Tuog” (The Rosewood Tree). “Paghanap sa Sulong” (Looking for Sulong), though tinged with nostalgia, contains the persona’s reflection on environment and change, a theme found also in “An Birtud kan Banggi” (Power of the Night). On the other hand, the poems “Pag Minasabatan an Duwang Skates” (When Two Rail Skates Come Face-to-Face) and “Alulunti” (Earthworm), charming and witty as they are, are charged with social commentary, as is “Tabernakulo” (Tabernacle). Notable also in the section are his poems on love: “An Pagpadangatasin an Paggulaynin Natong” (Loving and Cooking Yam Leaves) and “An Piling Linanta” (Blanched Pili).

The third section, “Pagdakit” (Crossing Rivers), consists of Nierva’s Bikol translations of poems by Gerard Manley Hopkins, Marne Kilates, Constantine Cavafy, Emily Dickinson, and Pablo Neruda.  Written by Jay Salvosa

article_title: Ayaw Pagpudla an Tuog ug Iba Pa nga Mga Siday
text:
(Don’t Cut Down the Tuog Tree and Other Poems). Published 2010. Author, Phil Harold L. Mercurio. Editor, Timothy R. Montes. With an introduction by the editor and selected English translations by Merlie M. Alunan, Janis Claire B. Salvacion, and Phil Harold L. Mercurio. Manila: National Commission for Culture and the Arts, National Committee on Literary Arts, and Ateneo Institute of Literary Arts and Practice.

Mercurio’s first book contains 29 poems in the patois of the Western Samareño speaker of Waray. Mercurio comes from the city of Calbayog, an old and historic settlement in the Samar Island. He writes about life in his community with affection and understanding of the rhythm of the land and sea by which the people thrive.

Mercurio’s poems deal with the necessity of human beings’ living in harmony with one another and with nature. The persona of “May ’Da Ko Bonoan” (I Have a Fish Corral) is a fisherman who talks about the difficulty of harvesting fish from his corral, but he is grateful that the sea never fails to provide for his everyday needs. “Pusdaki Uran” (Come, Rain) is a farmer’s prayer for the rain to quench the thirsty fields, sate the river’s longing, soften the earth for the farmer’s plow, give life to the hungry roots, and make the rice grow pregnant with grain. The title piece, “Ayaw Pagpudla an Tuog” (Don’t Cut Down the Tuog Tree), speaks of the responsibility of humans as stewards of nature. The poet adjures the human being not to fell the tuog, a guardian tree in the community, for it is home to natural creatures and other spirits of nature. The tuog is a Philippine hardwood threatened by extinction. The storms that batter Samar necessitate community bonding, exemplified in “Pamadlos” (Storm), where a man opens his home to a passing stranger as a storm rages outside, and thus earns the stranger’s gratitude.

Mercurio’s love poems are fresh and charmingly naive, deriving their figures from the fishing and farming life of his community. In “Dalan san Gugma” (Love’s Path), a young swain waits, apprehensive and excited, under the talisay tree for his intended to pass by; in “Kirom-Kirom” (Touch-Me-Not), a young man compares his beloved to the touch-me-not, which closes up quickly at his touch.

Mercurio also comments on the social scene. In “Ginkawat san Balud” (Stolen by the Waves), a woman recounts how she lost her child to a storm surge because her husband was too drunk to take care of his family. Drunkenness is a common domestic problem in Samar where coconut plantations—and hence, tuba (palm wine)—abound. In “Bugiot san Parag-uma” (A Farmer’s Outburst), a farmer waiting in vain for rain recalls a politician’s promise of having a water system built. The violence attending elections in Samar is treated ironically as “Pasalida” (Showtime), with election-related murders likened to twists in the plot of a TV serial. “Panhayhay san Usa nga OFW” (An OFW’s Lament) expresses a domestic helper’s longing to go home to Calbayog.

Mercurio’s poetry is written in the Waray spoken in the northwest part of Samar. This dialectal distinction adds charm to the poems. Moreover, the use of the dialect asserts the legitimacy of dialectal variances as a creative medium and demonstrates the versatility of the language that can mirror the many facets of life in Samar. Following the siday tradition, Mercurio observes rhyme and meter, but he does not adhere to the stanzaic form. In tone and attitude, Mercurio is very much a poet of the contemporary age.  Written by Merlie M. Alunan and Firie Jill Ramos

article_title: Azucarera: Mga Tula sa Pilipino at Ingles
text:
(Sugar Mill: Poems in Filipino and English). Published 1994. Author, Gelacio Guillermo. Quezon City: Publikasyong Sipat.

This 49-poem anthology is divided into four parts according to themes: class consciousness, the personal versus political, international issues, and national democracy. The heading of each section bears the same title as that of its opening poem: “Azucarera,” “Utter Only the Name of the Night,” “The Presidential Proclamation,” and “Sa Panahon ng Pakikibaka” (In the Time of Struggle).

Of the 13 poems in “Azucarera,” 11 are in English and two in Filipino. The title poem, “Azucarera,” describes the persona’s youth as a worker in the Central Azucarera de Tarlac, near Barrio Obrero, where he was born. The two poems in Filipino are “Ama” (Father), which questions the wages received by the workers; and “Kung Kami’y Magkakapit-Bisig,” which is the author’s translation into Filipino of his poem originally written in English, “With Our Arms Joined Together.” It affirms the power of collective action against the landed class.

The 15 poems in the second section chronicle the stage in the poet’s life when he was preoccupied with existential questions. In “Utter Only the Name of the Night,” dual images of the heavens, such as the sun and the moon, and of the earth, such as water and land, are dominant. The villanelle “He Goes with Each Descending Root” is the poet’s search for a higher, even universal, truth as he contemplates the heavens even as he keeps his feet firmly planted on the ground.

The eight poems in “The Presidential Proclamation” are explicit commentaries on political power and global affairs. “Nixon,” a poem in Filipino, shows in graphic detail the cost of an imperialist war and the iron will of the Vietnamese people to fight for their freedom. In “The Strong Man,” the central image of the local tyrant is that of a scarecrow, which thus belittles the imagined power that this tyrant possesses.

Most of the 13 poems in the last section were published in STR: Mga Tula ng Digmang Bayan sa Pilipinas (STR: Poems of the People’s War in the Philippines), 1989, under the pseudonym Kris Montañez. The section’s title poem, “Sa Panahon ng Pakikibaka,” dated 1973, and “1081,” 1972, both assert the people’s determination to resist aggressive state repression brought about by then president Ferdinand Marcos’s declaration of martial law through Proclamation 1081.

The poems in Azucarera were written between the 1960s and 1980s and are a testament to Guillermo’s evolution from his working-class origins, to his middle-class intellectualism borne by his academic and literary affiliations, and his return to his identification with the working-class, this time as a revolutionary poet aiming to serve the people.  Written by Arbeen Acuña

text:
(Under the Coconut Trees). Published 1911. Author, Claro M. Recto. With a prologue by Femando Ma. Guerrero, a eulogy by Cecilio Apostol, and an epilogue by Teodoro M. Kalaw. Manila: Libreria Manila Filatelica.

This is a collection of poems originally published between 1909 and 1911 in the nationalist paper El Renacimiento. Written during the first decade of American rule, the collection in greater part exudes nationalism. “La Lengua del Terruño” (The Native Tongue) praises Tagalog. “El Alma de la Raza” (The Spirit of the Race) is a tribute to the Filipino race. “Las Dalagas Filipinas” (The Filipino Maidens) is a tribute to Filipino women. A group of poems concerns Jose Rizal. “Ante el Martir” (Before the Martyr) pays homage to the national hero; “ Rosas a Maria Clara” (Roses for Maria Clara), to the heroine of the Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not); and “Simoun,” to the revolutionary. A section brings to life, in all their color, the local scenes: fiestas in “Luglugan”; the Philippine landscape in “Banahaw,” “Pansol,” and “Laguna de Bombon”; in “Crepusculo provinciano” (Sunset in the Province); and “La Selva Filipina” (The Philippine Forest). Still another section describes the native flowers: the kamuning, sampaguita, champaka, and others, with delicate tenderness yet admirable accuracy. The other poems speak of romantic love and of sensual, passionate love; of the bohemian life; of love for sale; of death and sorrow, sunset and shadows.

The last part pays a tribute to the heroes of the revolution and glorifies Rizal the apostle. The poems arouse love of country and freedom and are open and fearless expressions of Recto’s anti-Americanism. Thus, Guerrero, himself a foremost Filipino poet in Spanish, comments in his prologue that Recto’s patriotic cries are, as in Shelley’s words, “trumpets that call to arms.”

Of his style, Guerrero remarks, here in English translation, “His poems show a vague pantheistic adoration, above all when he expresses his fervor and emotions when speaking of the beauty of his native land.” Antonio M. Abad , another writer in Spanish, in his Lira Filipina (Philippine Lyre), 1958, praises Recto’s ability to suit style to subject. He is idyllic and romantic when he depicts Philippine scenes, fiery and forceful when he writes about Philippine heroism.

Written in correct classical style, with sonorous rhyme and meter, Recto’s verses abound with vivid tropes, especially the metaphor, simile, and personification, as this excerpt from “El Alma de la Raza” demonstrates:

Mi raza tiene un alma que es alma de titanes

Sangre de Solimanes

corre por sus arterias que siempre latiran.

Tiene el pecho templado al fragor de la guerra.

Bajo sus pies de atleta se estremece la tierra,

porque enciende sus nervios la flama de un volcan.

…

Fuerte, como el “tamaraw” de las selvas malayas,

como el caiman enorme que custodia sus playas,

cual las eternas fraguas del Apo y del Taal.

 

(My race has the soul of titans

The blood of Soliman

Flows in its veins, constantly beating

Its breast is tempered in the din of battle

Beneath his feet the earth trembles

Fired by the flame of volcanoes.

…

Strong as the tamaraw of the Malayan forests

As the enormous crocodile that guards its shores

Like the eternal flames of the Apo and the Taal.)  Written by Lilia H. Laurel

article.value: (Under the Coconut Trees). Published 1911. Author, Claro M. Recto. With a prologue by Femando Ma. Guerrero, a eulogy by Cecilio Apostol, and an epilogue by Teodoro M. Kalaw. Manila: Libreria Manila Filatelica.

This is a collection of poems originally published between 1909 and 1911 in the nationalist paper El Renacimiento. Written during the first decade of American rule, the collection in greater part exudes nationalism. “La Lengua del Terruño” (The Native Tongue) praises Tagalog. “El Alma de la Raza” (The Spirit of the Race) is a tribute to the Filipino race. “Las Dalagas Filipinas” (The Filipino Maidens) is a tribute to Filipino women. A group of poems concerns Jose Rizal. “Ante el Martir” (Before the Martyr) pays homage to the national hero; “ Rosas a Maria Clara” (Roses for Maria Clara), to the heroine of the Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not); and “Simoun,” to the revolutionary. A section brings to life, in all their color, the local scenes: fiestas in “Luglugan”; the Philippine landscape in “Banahaw,” “Pansol,” and “Laguna de Bombon”; in “Crepusculo provinciano” (Sunset in the Province); and “La Selva Filipina” (The Philippine Forest). Still another section describes the native flowers: the kamuning, sampaguita, champaka, and others, with delicate tenderness yet admirable accuracy. The other poems speak of romantic love and of sensual, passionate love; of the bohemian life; of love for sale; of death and sorrow, sunset and shadows.

The last part pays a tribute to the heroes of the revolution and glorifies Rizal the apostle. The poems arouse love of country and freedom and are open and fearless expressions of Recto’s anti-Americanism. Thus, Guerrero, himself a foremost Filipino poet in Spanish, comments in his prologue that Recto’s patriotic cries are, as in Shelley’s words, “trumpets that call to arms.”

Of his style, Guerrero remarks, here in English translation, “His poems show a vague pantheistic adoration, above all when he expresses his fervor and emotions when speaking of the beauty of his native land.” Antonio M. Abad , another writer in Spanish, in his Lira Filipina (Philippine Lyre), 1958, praises Recto’s ability to suit style to subject. He is idyllic and romantic when he depicts Philippine scenes, fiery and forceful when he writes about Philippine heroism.

Written in correct classical style, with sonorous rhyme and meter, Recto’s verses abound with vivid tropes, especially the metaphor, simile, and personification, as this excerpt from “El Alma de la Raza” demonstrates:

Mi raza tiene un alma que es alma de titanes

Sangre de Solimanes

corre por sus arterias que siempre latiran.

Tiene el pecho templado al fragor de la guerra.

Bajo sus pies de atleta se estremece la tierra,

porque enciende sus nervios la flama de un volcan.

…

Fuerte, como el “tamaraw” de las selvas malayas,

como el caiman enorme que custodia sus playas,

cual las eternas fraguas del Apo y del Taal.

 

(My race has the soul of titans

The blood of Soliman

Flows in its veins, constantly beating

Its breast is tempered in the din of battle

Beneath his feet the earth trembles

Fired by the flame of volcanoes.

…

Strong as the tamaraw of the Malayan forests

As the enormous crocodile that guards its shores

Like the eternal flames of the Apo and the Taal.)  Written by Lilia H. Laurel

article_title: Balaybay, Mga Tulang Lunot at Manibalang
text:
(A Fruit-Laden Branch, Poems Mellow and Newly Ripened). Published 2002. Author, Bienvenido L. Lumbera. With a preface by the author. Marikina: Talingdao Publishing House.

The word balaybay means “branches heavy with fruit”; and manibalang, by which word Lumbera called his new poems, “newly ripened.” The collection consists of the poems in Filipino previously published in Lumbera’s earlier collection, Likhang Dila, Likhang Diwa (Creations of the Tongue, Creations of the Spirit), 1993, which had gone out of print, plus previously unpublished poems. Included here are poems written in the manner of traditional poetry, such as tanaga and uyayi. There are also experimental poems, autobiographical poems, occasional poetry inspired by the deaths of political icons or rallies, song lyrics from his plays, and translations of three English texts.

In his preface, Lumbera recounts the story of his development as a writer. The diverse forces that influenced his direction as a poet are an education and work environment that privileged English; developments in Western literature; encounters with the best writers and critics of Tagalog literature in the 1950s and 1960s, like Alejandro G. Abadilla; and campus activism in the United States and the Philippines.

The additional 20 poems in this anthology reiterate the themes that Lumbera explored in Likhang Dila, Likhang Diwa. “Alay sa Guro” (Offering to a Teacher) and “Awit Tagumpay” (Victory Song) reprise a familiar tune—the eventual triumph of the oppressed after a struggle. His personal tributes to the nationalist historian Renato Constantino, activist-rebel Emmanuel Lacaba, and expatriate writer Bienvenido Santos are gripping depictions of heroism.

“Ang Bahay ng Nanay, Isang Kasaysayan” (Mother’s House, a History) is a poignant poem depicting a mother’s faith and courage, which helped her raise a family. Her house was a mute witness to her life until the war devastated it. Now old and broken, the old woman leaves the ruins of the house and turns her back on the promise of a new dawn that the American liberators have pledged. She is thus the poet’s version of Inang Bayan (Motherland), which personifies the country.

The ironic tone that sometimes effected a coldness in the poems written in the 1950s and 1960s is still evident in the new poems. However, the objectivity and self-conscious restraint in “Voyagers on Recto Avenue” have given way to a less harsh and truly more compassionate treatment of homeless children in the poem “Mga Batang Grasa sa Gilid ng Fly-over sa Tandang Sora” (The Street Urchins on the Edge of the Fly-over on Tandang Sora). In this poem, the persona allows himself to be open and vulnerable to the flow of experience swirling around him. Thus, he is able to delve more deeply into the personal and societal forces which have conspired to bring so much misery on these young ones.

“Laro” (Game) celebrates the fleeting moments in the life of a grandfather and his grandchild. It presents the tender emotions evoked by such encounters—the panic that overwhelms the persona after an accident, his subsequent relief, and the apparent nonchalance with which he speaks to the child to hide his fear. Physical sensation is captured by visual imagery, such as the dizzying movements of a child chasing after ducks.

The anthology ends with Lumbera’s translation of three poems: “Katahimikan” (Silence), “Kagabi Paglayo” (Last Night, Departing), and “Mandirigmang Bundok ng Santa Catalina” (Warrior Mountain of Santa Catalina), the originals written by Joel Toledo, Vincenz Serrano, and Merlie Alunan, respectively.  Written by Soledad Reyes

text:
(Raft: Chavacano Poems). Published 2011. Author, Francis Macansantos. Manila: National Commission for Culture and the Arts.

This is a bilingual collection of poetry. The Chabacano poems are placed side by side with the English translations provided by the poet himself. The first poem, “Balsa” (Raft), uses the metaphor of the raft to describe how one who is not anchored in an uncertain world is simply carried by the current. Hence, one must turn back to his or her roots to stay afloat and retain one’s identity.

Most of the poems belong to the tradition of Romantic poetry. Macansantos begins many of his poems with scenes of nature, which he then uses to create emotional effects. In between the nature scenes and the emotional effects or responses, the poet interposes rhetorical devices, most of which deal with abstract and grand ideas about the nature of memory, the eternal pull of family ties, and the search for identity. Some of these poems also gracefully weave the influence that his family has had on him.

“Na Pantalan” (At the Wharf) describes the general ambience of the wharf—including the strength of the winds, and the island of Basilan that looms in the distance. “Contra Biento” (Against the Wind) describes the experience of being trapped inside a hotel while a storm is raging outside. Macansantos draws a contrast between the peace within and the chaos outside. He then links this to his father’s bravery and how his father tried to instill the same bravery in him.

There are also poems about particular places in Zamboanga City. “El Birhen del Lodasal” (The Virgin of the Boggy Fields) describes a marshland and the statue of the Virgin Mary looking out beyond her fort. The poem becomes a metaphor for the hope that we keep within us when we get bogged down by the marshlands of our lives. “Cesar” is about the slain mayor of the city, Cesar Climaco. It describes the mayor’s resting place, up in the hills of the city, and how now even in death, he still looks after the city he loved and served.

One of the best poems in this collection is “Cruzando con el Rio” (Crossing the River), which describes the persona’s childhood memory of himself and his father taking a small boat to cross a river. There is another young boy who rows them to the other side. The persona muses on the stark contrast between their lives, yet he feels envious of the boy’s abilities and the confidence that the boy’s father has placed upon him. His own father, in contrast, tries to keep him away from the water throughout the trip.

For the poet, the greatest pain is the loss of one’s roots—one’s history or family. Without a past, one has no identity; it is what keeps one afloat as one attempts to navigate the treacherous seas of life.  Written by Jose Miguel Arguelles

text:
(A Nation Free). Written 1955. Author, Amado V. Hernandez. Serialized in Liwayway, 1955. Reprinted as a book, Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press, 1969, 1974.

This long narrative poem consists of 5,526 lines, each stanza having six lines of 12-12-6-12-6-12 syllables.

The poem unfolds the epic story of a rural village called Pinagbangunan, where peasants living in feudal conditions manifest strong bonds among themselves, finding real kinship in shared poverty. Most of them work as tenants for the few small and big landowners. It is the eve of World War II, but the danger seems distant as they prepare for the harvest. For untold ages, the peasants have been chafing under the oppressive policies of the landlords, but they have chosen to remain silent and stoic. In a confrontation with an abusive landlord, the young peasant leader Tanggol finally gives voice to the pent-up grievances of the peasants. Emboldened, the peasants present their demands to the landlord Laki. They want a just sharing of the costs of agricultural production and a more reasonable interest on loans.

They begin organizing, and they draw up an agenda for the local government to carry out. Before the struggle against the landlords can escalate, the war breaks out. The organized tenants join the resistance and heroically fight the Japanese aggressors. Tanggol is killed, and his beloved Tala is taken prisoner. A well-known and respected nationalist newspaperman, Lantay, is imprisoned by the Japanese for refusing to collaborate. He escapes, but his two comrades are killed. Tala also escapes and manages to link up with a guerrilla group led by the resistance leader Dupil.

At war’s end, there is much devastation everywhere, but the peasants of Pinagbangunan have gained invaluable political and military experience. Many peasant leaders would emerge from the anti-Japanese resistance and later head the mass movement against feudalism. Lantay is acclaimed as the leader of a movement of workers and peasants demanding reforms in society. The landlord and the government respond with more repression and violence. Lantay is imprisoned, dealing the movement a major setback. But Dupil and his armed followers are gathering strength in the countryside, posing a real threat to the oppressive system. In an exchange of letters, Lantay and Dupil come to a meeting of minds: people’s war is inevitable, and it is the only correct path to follow toward the liberation of workers and peasants, and the making of a free nation.

Writing about his ordeal in Muntinlupa where he was a political prisoner, Hernandez said that Bayang Malaya was written as a tribute to the heroism of the Filipino guerrillas who fought for freedom, and to prove to his jailers that they had not succeeded in suppressing his ideas and his beliefs. Noteworthy in the narrative is the transparent symbolism of the names used: Pinagbangunan (the place of rising), Tanggol (defense), Laki (hugeness), Tala (star), Lantay (purity), and Dupil (amulet). The Lantay character reminds us of Hernandez’s own career as a nationalist newspaperman and labor leader.

Bayang Malaya received the distinguished Balagtas Memorial Award in 1969 for its nationalist worldview, as well as for its poetic merit. This poem and the author’s other works have been held in high esteem side by side with the works of Francisco "Balagtas" Baltazar and Lope K. Santos. As a poet for the masses, Hernandez is a bulwark in the radical tradition of Philippine literature.  Written by Rosario Torres-Yu and Edgardo Maranan

article_title: Berinareu: The Religious Epic of the Tirurais
text:
Published 1989. Editor, Clement Wein, SVD. Transcriber, Rogelio Adamat. Translators, Rogelio Adamat and Amado Tirurai. With a foreword and an introduction by the editor and an appendix of character and place names by the translators and editor. Manila: Divine Word Publications.

Berinareu is an epic of the Tiruray tribe in Cotabato, Mindanao. It was recorded by Fr Clement Wein in 1984. Its singer, Andau Tinorio Angel, who was born in 1920, learned the epic from his aunt Ideng Aga. Wein mentions three other versions, all centering on a great battle albeit with some differences in details, particularly names of the major characters. In his book Wisdom from the Rainforest, 1999, Stuart A. Schlegel mentions an “immensely long cosmological epic” called Berinarew, which takes 80 hours to chant.

The epic begins with an Invocation, in which the chanter prays to the spirits for guidance so that his memory will not fail him. The epic is then summarized in a few lines: the hero, a belian (shaman), as yet unnamed, long ago, underwent suffering before he left this world to pay his respects to the Supreme Being in behalf of his people. The story proper commences with the shaman Lagei Lengkuos, aka Seonomon, instructing his followers on swidden farming, which is the terasai (suffering) they should undergo to attain happiness.

Lukes Libun interrupts them to announce that eight datus have abducted her daughter Seangkaien at the river. She holds Seonomon responsible because he is betrothed to Seangkaien. Seonomon consults his palm and shield but to no avail; it is the highest tail feather in his headdress who names the eight datus.

Seonomon sends the wind to gather his forces. A catalog of his allies’ names is given as they arrive. They pray for a sign of victory, and deafening thunderclaps and a strong earthquake are the response. Seonomon flies on his shield, following the sound of the missing lady’s weeping to the place of her abductors. One of them, Tuko Fenuo, sends his sister to serve betel chew to Seonomon, who attacks her instead. A battle with Tuko Fenuo and his people ensues, and Seonomon is victorious. He proceeds to Gentanga Lawai’s place, where they parley on the violation of rights and their restoration. Gentanga Lawai’s followers agree on their leader’s wrongdoing.

Seangkaien gives Seonomon a special betel chew, offering to “enter the tassel of his necklace.” Seonomon takes the chew but must resume the fight. He tells her to put on her best clothes and watch the battle from her window. His allies arrive and they form an impenetrable wall with their shields standing side by side. Gentanga Lawai strikes several times but fails to hit Seonomon, whose shield reproaches Gentanga Lawai for having claimed what was not his. Seonomon’s allies join the fray but a goddess appears and commands Gentanga Lawai to return Seangkaien to Seonomon. Disgraced, Gentanga Lawai asks Seonomon to kill him; soon after, one of Seonomon’s allies kill all of Gentanga Lawai’s people.

Seangkaien offers Seonomon her 10-meter long heirloom necklace as a sign that she wants their betrothal renewed. After serving betel chew to all of Seonomon’s allies, Seangkaien walks home because riding on the shield with any of them would be improper. She comes upon Mo Legu, Seonomon’s brother who resides at the tadgeher, the tree that is as old as earth, its top like gold and its branches like a rainbow. Seangkaien learns that he has arranged Seonomon’s marriage with Datu Kadeg Teresang’s daughter, Linauan Kadeg. Hence, when Seonomon pays her a visit, Seangkaien refuses to serve him betel chew. They argue over rights: his rescue of her has earned him the right to take her to his home, but she claims her right to be spared of humiliation.

Upset, Seonomon journeys through several levels toward Fulu-fulu, the Supreme Being (who is female), to ask for a bracelet with eight knots, which signifies passage from this world to the next. Menggerayur, a lower deity, advises him not to give up so easily. Fulu-fulu reminds him that whomever he gives the bracelet to will be his partner in leading the Tiruray to the land of happiness, and it is Seangkaien’s destiny to be that partner. Seonomon despondently swears he would rather die than take betel chew from Seangkaien.

Seonomon is smitten by Linauan Kadeg. He gives her the bracelet with eight knots for her bride-price and they marry. Meanwhile, Seangkaien journeys through many levels, including Fulu-fulu’s place, seeking aid to get Seonomon back and the bracelet. All the lundaan (spirits) reproach her for misjudging Seonomon. She finds a spirit-guide, her uncle Mangimfangalen. He summons his allies, who are datus and mountain spirits, whom Seangkaien leads into battle against Linauan Kadeg. She wins the friendship of Seonomon’s sister, Lenolouon, and together they fly on a shield to Mount Keroon Kedataran, to plead for aid from Datu Fenrebangar, an ally of Seonomon. After reproaching Seangkaien for doubting Seonomon, he agrees that the bracelet must be for Seangkaien only. Three ladies—Seangkaien, Lenolouon, and Tama Talun, all flying on a shield—lead the fight, together with the datus.

Seangkaien turns into a dove and joins Linauan Kadeg’s seven other doves to recover the bracelet. When Linauan Kadeg feeds them, Seangkaien snatches the bracelet, which is concealed in Linauan Kadeg’s diamond ring. Linauan laments its loss, and Seonomon tearfully reproaches her for having insisted on taking it as her bride-price.

Seangkaien’s allies penetrate Seonomon’s fort of boulders and are victorious. Seangkaien offers Seonomon betel chew, and he reluctantly takes it. After chewing it, Seonomon dies. Seangkaien travels to the places of the dead to ask the guardians there not to welcome Seonomon’s soul. She takes him to her house on Mount Lunggun Menurer and tries to revive him, but his corpse turns into liquid. Before it seeps into the ground, Seangkaien catches it in a bamboo container. She goes in search of his soul, finds it inside the tadgeher, and puts it in the tassel of her necklace. She takes him to her home and, with her brother’s help, revives Seonomon.

Reunited, Seonomon and Seangkaien return to Mount Lengkous, where he tells his people that they must first suffer—that is, engage in swidden farming. On the eighth night, he dances with stamping feet and arms outstretched. The spirits of Linamasan come down to give a piece of land that all the people will ride on to the other world. Seonomon, however, chooses to walk. When they reach the gate of heaven, Seonomon tricks its guardian by giving him eight betel chews instead of eight persons as gifts. They cross the boundary and wash their bodies away in the Ligoden river. They walk past the land of “continuous lightnings” and of “rainbows one over the other” until they are finally welcomed by Fulufulu, who says: “(Now) you have no more to worry.”

In Berinareu the tribes of Seonomon and Seangkaien unite and engage in a war for the sake of sefebenal or “the right to seek revenge” but in practice it means the right to restore a right transgressed by their common enemy. Berinareu is the only epic so far recorded that makes explicit statements about the defense and restoration of human rights.  Written by Emmanuel V. Dumlao and Rosario Cruz-Lucero

The epic is then summarized in a few lines: the hero, a belian (shaman), as yet unnamed, long ago, underwent suffering before he left this world to pay his respects to the Supreme Being in behalf of his people. The story proper commences with the shaman Lagei Lengkuos, aka Seonomon, instructing his followers on swidden farming, which is the terasai (suffering) they should undergo to attain happiness.

Lukes Libun interrupts them to announce that eight datus have abducted her daughter Seangkaien at the river. She holds Seonomon responsible because he is betrothed to Seangkaien. Seonomon consults his palm and shield but to no avail; it is the highest tail feather in his headdress who names the eight datus.

Seonomon sends the wind to gather his forces. A catalog of his allies’ names is given as they arrive. They pray for a sign of victory, and deafening thunderclaps and a strong earthquake are the response. Seonomon flies on his shield, following the sound of the missing lady’s weeping to the place of her abductors. One of them, Tuko Fenuo, sends his sister to serve betel chew to Seonomon, who attacks her instead. A battle with Tuko Fenuo and his people ensues, and Seonomon is victorious. He proceeds to Gentanga Lawai’s place, where they parley on the violation of rights and their restoration. Gentanga Lawai’s followers agree on their leader’s wrongdoing.

Seangkaien gives Seonomon a special betel chew, offering to “enter the tassel of his necklace.” Seonomon takes the chew but must resume the fight. He tells her to put on her best clothes and watch the battle from her window. His allies arrive and they form an impenetrable wall with their shields standing side by side. Gentanga Lawai strikes several times but fails to hit Seonomon, whose shield reproaches Gentanga Lawai for having claimed what was not his. Seonomon’s allies join the fray but a goddess appears and commands Gentanga Lawai to return Seangkaien to Seonomon. Disgraced, Gentanga Lawai asks Seonomon to kill him; soon after, one of Seonomon’s allies kill all of Gentanga Lawai’s people.

Seangkaien offers Seonomon her 10-meter long heirloom necklace as a sign that she wants their betrothal renewed. After serving betel chew to all of Seonomon’s allies, Seangkaien walks home because riding on the shield with any of them would be improper. She comes upon Mo Legu, Seonomon’s brother who resides at the tadgeher, the tree that is as old as earth, its top like gold and its branches like a rainbow. Seangkaien learns that he has arranged Seonomon’s marriage with Datu Kadeg Teresang’s daughter, Linauan Kadeg. Hence, when Seonomon pays her a visit, Seangkaien refuses to serve him betel chew. They argue over rights: his rescue of her has earned him the right to take her to his home, but she claims her right to be spared of humiliation.

Upset, Seonomon journeys through several levels toward Fulu-fulu, the Supreme Being (who is female), to ask for a bracelet with eight knots, which signifies passage from this world to the next. Menggerayur, a lower deity, advises him not to give up so easily. Fulu-fulu reminds him that whomever he gives the bracelet to will be his partner in leading the Tiruray to the land of happiness, and it is Seangkaien’s destiny to be that partner. Seonomon despondently swears he would rather die than take betel chew from Seangkaien.

Seonomon is smitten by Linauan Kadeg. He gives her the bracelet with eight knots for her bride-price and they marry. Meanwhile, Seangkaien journeys through many levels, including Fulu-fulu’s place, seeking aid to get Seonomon back and the bracelet. All the lundaan (spirits) reproach her for misjudging Seonomon. She finds a spirit-guide, her uncle Mangimfangalen. He summons his allies, who are datus and mountain spirits, whom Seangkaien leads into battle against Linauan Kadeg. She wins the friendship of Seonomon’s sister, Lenolouon, and together they fly on a shield to Mount Keroon Kedataran, to plead for aid from Datu Fenrebangar, an ally of Seonomon. After reproaching Seangkaien for doubting Seonomon, he agrees that the bracelet must be for Seangkaien only. Three ladies—Seangkaien, Lenolouon, and Tama Talun, all flying on a shield—lead the fight, together with the datus.

Seangkaien turns into a dove and joins Linauan Kadeg’s seven other doves to recover the bracelet. When Linauan Kadeg feeds them, Seangkaien snatches the bracelet, which is concealed in Linauan Kadeg’s diamond ring. Linauan laments its loss, and Seonomon tearfully reproaches her for having insisted on taking it as her bride-price.

Seangkaien’s allies penetrate Seonomon’s fort of boulders and are victorious. Seangkaien offers Seonomon betel chew, and he reluctantly takes it. After chewing it, Seonomon dies. Seangkaien travels to the places of the dead to ask the guardians there not to welcome Seonomon’s soul. She takes him to her house on Mount Lunggun Menurer and tries to revive him, but his corpse turns into liquid. Before it seeps into the ground, Seangkaien catches it in a bamboo container. She goes in search of his soul, finds it inside the tadgeher, and puts it in the tassel of her necklace. She takes him to her home and, with her brother’s help, revives Seonomon.

Reunited, Seonomon and Seangkaien return to Mount Lengkous, where he tells his people that they must first suffer—that is, engage in swidden farming. On the eighth night, he dances with stamping feet and arms outstretched. The spirits of Linamasan come down to give a piece of land that all the people will ride on to the other world. Seonomon, however, chooses to walk. When they reach the gate of heaven, Seonomon tricks its guardian by giving him eight betel chews instead of eight persons as gifts. They cross the boundary and wash their bodies away in the Ligoden river. They walk past the land of “continuous lightnings” and of “rainbows one over the other” until they are finally welcomed by Fulufulu, who says: “(Now) you have no more to worry.”

In Berinareu the tribes of Seonomon and Seangkaien unite and engage in a war for the sake of sefebenal or “the right to seek revenge” but in practice it means the right to restore a right transgressed by their common enemy. Berinareu is the only epic so far recorded that makes explicit statements about the defense and restoration of human rights.  Written by Emmanuel V. Dumlao and Rosario Cruz-Lucero

text:
Aka Historia Famosa ni Bernardo Carpio sa Reinong España, na Anac ni D. Sancho Diaz at ni Doña Jimena (Famous Life of Bernardo Carpio in the Kingdom of Spain, Son of Don Sancho Diaz and Doña Jimena). Written ca 18th century. Attributed to Jose de la Cruz aka Huseng Sisiw. Published 1949. Editor, Simplicio Flores. Manila: Philippine Book Company. Five Tagalog editions, the oldest dated 1860. Also available in Bikol, Ilonggo, and Ilocano (the last in five editions).

When Alfonso comes of age, he becomes king of Spain after the death of his father. Alfonso appoints Don Sancho as general of the army and Don Rubio as captain. Unfortunately, both Don Sancho and Don Rubio fall in love with Jimena, Alfonso’s sister. When Jimena spurns Don Rubio, he vows revenge. Don Rubio gets his chance when the love child of Don Sancho and Doña Jimena is born. He betrays the lovers to the king, who imprisons and blinds Don Sancho and confines Doña Jimena in a convent. The king entrusts the child to Don Rubio, with instructions to have the child baptized and brought up as he would his own son.

The child, named Bernardo, shows signs of extraordinary strength. As a boy of seven, he can kill any animal with his bare hands. The king forbids Don Rubio from telling the child who his parents are and orders everyone in the kingdom, on pain of death, to do likewise.

Bernardo realizes that Don Rubio is not his real father when he tells Don Rubio to ask the king to knight him so that he can wipe out idolatry in the kingdom. Don Rubio scolds him for being too ambitious for his dim origins. Bernardo weeps, but the king adopts him and knights him soon after. Bernardo challenges Don Rubio to a fencing match and cuts him in two, thus unwittingly avenging his father. He also replaces Don Rubio as general of the Spanish army.

At this time, a powerful emperor named Carpio sends an emissary to Spain, demanding its surrender. Bernardo singlehandedly wipes out the enemy. He asks, as his reward, for some information about his true parents, but the king sends him to attack Emperor Carpio’s castle, hoping that he will be killed in the fighting. However, Bernardo conquers all the 19 castles of Emperor Carpio, who then confers on him the name “Don Bernardo Carpio” in recognition of his prowess.

Later, Bernardo is told the truth about his parents. Bernardo resolves to go to his father and mother, but first he conquers France. Bernardo is reunited with his father who, after blessing him and begging him not to harm the king, dies in his arms. Bernardo keeps his father’s death a secret. He fetches his mother from the convent and takes her to the palace. Then Bernardo brings his father, covered with cloth on the pretext that he must not be exposed to the cold air, to the palace, where he is married to Doña Jimena by the archbishop. Only after the wedding ceremony does Bernardo pretend to discover that his father is dead. Jimena laments. After the funeral, she returns to the convent, and Bernardo, despite the king’s pleas for him to stay as his heir, goes away to conquer all non-Christian kingdoms and to eradicate idolatry.

After traveling for some time, Bernardo arrives before a church-like structure with two lion statues guarding its entrance. Bernardo kneels to pray, when lightning strikes one of the lions. Bernardo vows to destroy the lightning. Not far away, he sees two mountains hitting each other. An angel tells him that God has sent him to tell Bernardo that the lightning has gone into the mountain, and that Bernardo can neither see nor capture it. When the angel takes the path of the lightning, Bernardo arrogantly follows, and the mountains close in upon him. The romance ends here, but legend supplies a coda, according to which Bernardo lies on a marble bed inside a cave. He tells a stranger who wanders into the cave that he will rise someday to save his oppressed people.

Bernardo Carpio is the only hero of Philippine metrical romance who has so captivated the imagination of the masses that they have adopted him as a kind of culture hero. Thus Bernardo Carpio has passed from the realm of romance to the common everyday world of Philippine legend, with places as far apart as Rizal and Cagayan province claiming that the mountain in which Bernardo lies is located there.

Bernardo Carpio has been made into a movie, starring Cesar Ramirez and Alicia Vergel, 1951; into a musical by Virgilio Almario and Tito Climaco in 1976; and into children’s stories.  Written by Damiana Eugenio

 

Sources

Balmaseda, Julian Cruz. (1947) 1972. Ang Tatlong Panahon ng Tulang Tagalog. Manila: Institute of National Language.

Eugenio, Damiana. 1987. Awit and Corrido: Philippine Metrical Romances. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

Ileto, Reynaldo. 1980. Perceptions of the Past in Southeast Asia. Singapore: Heinemann.

Villa, Lilia. 1952. “Romance and Corrido: A Comparison of Some Folktale Motifs in English and Philippine Metrical Romances.” Philippine Social Sciences and Humanities Review 17 (Sep): 247-79.
