Published 2010. Editors, Ricardo M. de Ungria, Macario D. Tiu, Jhoanna Lynn B. Cruz, and Dominique Gerald M. Cimafranca. Davao City: Tubao Book Series and National Commission for Culture and the Arts.

This is an anthology of 12 stories, 69 poems, 15 essays, and a play, chosen by the editors as the best of the pieces published between 2007 and 2009 in the literary journal of the Davao Writers Guild, Dagmay. The works are in three languages: English, Filipino, and Cebuano. Nine stories, 34 poems, 1 play, and 14 prose pieces are in English; 3 stories and 16 poems in Cebuano; and 19 poems in Filipino.

Three stories feature women struggling against oppression in various forms: In Pam Bitang’s “The Accused,” a single mother is wrongly accused of embezzlement. She loses her job and the separation pay is not enough to cover her daughter’s hospital bills. In Arifah Jamil’s “In Thy Glory,” a Muslim woman is pressured by her family into marrying into Muslim royalty instead of a man who, although hailing from a prominent family, has a Christian grandmother. “Bukog” (Bone) by Rosalia Gajo is a Cebuano story about a wife whose superstitious husband’s idea of helping her as she is choking on a fishbone is to brush a cat’s paw against her neck. Thus, she realizes that his dependence on irrational beliefs is the bone she has to pick with him.

In the essay “Tilting at Windmills,” Cecille La Verne dela Cruz explores how communities differ in their treatment of the village idiot—as someone to be shunned or just as a regular person. In “Of Bombs and the Sun,” Jezereel Camangeg-Billano juxtaposes the beauty of the setting sun in her hometown of Tacurong with those other balls of light—the bombs that explode there time and again. In “Memoirs of a ‘Gay-Sha’” by Ram Botero, a young boy who would rather play house than basketball finds shelter away from his repressive mother in the grotto of the other mother, the Virgin Mary. “Kronika ng Isang Biyaherong Pinoy” (Chronicle of a Filipino Traveler), by Switzerland-based Edgar Bacong, recounts the difficulties that Filipinos go through to get travel visas.

The poems in this anthology evoke images of these young writers’ milieu. “Cotabato,” by Allen Samsuya, is about a student who resolves to stay away from the boredom of living in his hometown, Cotabato. As he enumerates the activities in a sleepy Cotabato town—“hoarding pirated DVDs / at Barter Trade, or pigging out on litson manok at Kitok’s”—the picture turns grimmer (ruins of bombed buildings and the sooty chassis of burned buses) until it is one not of idleness but of violence. In “Mga Bala sa Sulu” (Bullets in Sulu) by Yul AV Olaya, bullets are personified as nerve-wracked and crammed in their magazines, waiting for someone to pull the trigger, and clueless about whom they will hit. In “Mingaw” (literally, “missing,” but here meaning “homesickness”), Gutierrez Mangansakan II uses pidgin Davao to juxtapose an expatriate’s memories of his hometown, Davao City, with the concerns of the United States.

These pieces give voice to a generation of Mindanaoans still grappling with their identity in a setting characterized by a mix of regional languages and religions.  Written by Julian dela Cerna

Published 1983. Editors, Merito B. Espinas, Caesar C. Altarejos, and Carlos S. Gegantoca. Legazpi City: Bicol University.

This anthology of Bikol literature is divided into four parts: “Pamana” (Legacy), “Rawitdawit” (Poems), “Osipon” (Stories), and “Kutangkutang” (Miscellany).

Part 1 contains folk literary texts such as a Bikol epic-fragment, texts of Catholic folk rituals such as the Awrora and Kagharong, song-poems, tigsik (toast in verse), riddles, proverbs, and a quaint “folk virginal test” about the kadlum (patchouli) written in Spanish. Two plays, Justino Nuyda’s Anti-Cristo (Anti-Christ) and Jose Ofracio’s comic Sumpang Parasugal, can also be found in this important collection of Bikol literary texts.

The second part collects Bikol poems in English, and the third has one text in Bikol—Ana Calixto’s “Maimon”—one story in Filipino, summaries of legends, and contemporary stories in English. The fourth contains essays and letters on history, culture, and literature.

The book has both the faults and merits of a pioneering work, which it is. On the one hand, the accounts of legends could have been written in Bikol and transferred to the first section of the book. Some items might better have been dropped from part 4. Main editor Espinas himself states that more texts in Bikol should have been included in parts 2 and 3, but they were not readily available, because most archival material had been relocated to libraries in Manila.

On the other hand, the book’s definition of Bikol literature in the introductory essay clarifies for researchers the parameters of the field. Most importantly, this book provides access to texts which had not been available to students and researchers in the past three decades. Here, for the first time, one fiiound, in the region, the complete text of the Bikol epic-fragment in Spanish, with English and Bikol translations, the play Anti-Cristo for teaching and performance, the tigsik, rawitdawit, legends, and folktales of yore.  Written by Paz Verdades M. Santos

article_title: Body English: A Book of Poems
text:
Published 1996. Author, Ricardo M. de Ungria. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

The 56 poems in this collection, de Ungria’s fifth, are alphabetically organized. All the letters of the English alphabet are represented. De Ungria takes up themes of foreignness, alienation, loves lost, and loneliness.

The first poem, “Apartment: Cleaning the Vacated,” launches the themes of estrangement and regret: intents mix with grime, spaces are like old sins, and shadows stay close to paint. In the third poem, “Ark: September Evening, Hawthornden,” a poet is adjusting to his new surroundings, intentionally misremembering the sound of trees around Hawthornden Castle as huge cavans of rice being poured into their bins back in the Philippines. De Ungria rhythmically subverts the poem’s eight tercets by making the second lines one-word fulcrums on which hangs the balance of the reader’s breath and the poet’s manipulated language, the place one is in and the place one wants to remember.

Hawthornden, site of the poet’s writing fellowship in Midlothian, Scotland, figures prominently as place in this collection. In “Midnight: Walking Back to Hawthornden,” de Ungria gives an almost Rilkean account of having slipped on a sidewalk. So unnerved, the poet turns the minor incident into a passage for a meditation on giggling stars and sizzling fires. There is great dis-ease throughout the poems, as though the poet wanted to remind the reader of what is foreign; therefore, a sense of distance and detachment suffuses the personae’s attitudes.

Place then (or being mis-placed) is the true thesis of Body English. In “Cure,” de Ungria begs, almost admonishes, an unseen editor (presumably foreign) to publish his poetry precisely because it comes from a different place and is written in a different English. In “Jam: Taxi,” de Ungria listens to a Filipino taxi driver he encounters overseas soliloquize. The driver enumerates places like Paco and the Coca-Cola plant; at the same time and in the same tone he confides that the next block is where the bodies of the extrajudicially executed are dropped off. The sentimental longing for home is nipped in the bud by the mention of unsavory physical, cultural, and social realities. In “Chiaroscuro,” terror liberates, violence reveals, but meanings wave from a far-off place.

De Ungria begins with his strongest lines, relaxes, and then gradually builds to a crescendo by cataloguing until a well-deserved, if sometimes clipped, epiphany is reached. One finds this cataloguing habit in several poems: in “Exits: Arriving at a Notion Of,” a list of things to do and not do at a tourist spot; in “Mass: Ode to the St. Thomas More Chapel,” a rundown of the priests at the Ateneo chapel; in “Xylograph,” a series of short, almost treacle tercets cataloguing the items etched on wood engravings.

The last poem, “Zense: Inside English,” is a nod to Jose Garcia Villa (“Am here inside. Have come …”), a playful exploration of a poet’s sense of Zen, and a coming home of sorts into the colonial language English. “Zense” is a place, a home in complete contrast to the sense of doom in the earlier “Chiaroscuro.” Home is “buried in me / like the sunsmell / on my skin.”  Written by Arvin Abejo Mangohig

In the third poem, “Ark: September Evening, Hawthornden,” a poet is adjusting to his new surroundings, intentionally misremembering the sound of trees around Hawthornden Castle as huge cavans of rice being poured into their bins back in the Philippines. De Ungria rhythmically subverts the poem’s eight tercets by making the second lines one-word fulcrums on which hangs the balance of the reader’s breath and the poet’s manipulated language, the place one is in and the place one wants to remember.

Hawthornden, site of the poet’s writing fellowship in Midlothian, Scotland, figures prominently as place in this collection. In “Midnight: Walking Back to Hawthornden,” de Ungria gives an almost Rilkean account of having slipped on a sidewalk. So unnerved, the poet turns the minor incident into a passage for a meditation on giggling stars and sizzling fires. There is great dis-ease throughout the poems, as though the poet wanted to remind the reader of what is foreign; therefore, a sense of distance and detachment suffuses the personae’s attitudes.

Place then (or being mis-placed) is the true thesis of Body English. In “Cure,” de Ungria begs, almost admonishes, an unseen editor (presumably foreign) to publish his poetry precisely because it comes from a different place and is written in a different English. In “Jam: Taxi,” de Ungria listens to a Filipino taxi driver he encounters overseas soliloquize. The driver enumerates places like Paco and the Coca-Cola plant; at the same time and in the same tone he confides that the next block is where the bodies of the extrajudicially executed are dropped off. The sentimental longing for home is nipped in the bud by the mention of unsavory physical, cultural, and social realities. In “Chiaroscuro,” terror liberates, violence reveals, but meanings wave from a far-off place.

De Ungria begins with his strongest lines, relaxes, and then gradually builds to a crescendo by cataloguing until a well-deserved, if sometimes clipped, epiphany is reached. One finds this cataloguing habit in several poems: in “Exits: Arriving at a Notion Of,” a list of things to do and not do at a tourist spot; in “Mass: Ode to the St. Thomas More Chapel,” a rundown of the priests at the Ateneo chapel; in “Xylograph,” a series of short, almost treacle tercets cataloguing the items etched on wood engravings.

The last poem, “Zense: Inside English,” is a nod to Jose Garcia Villa (“Am here inside. Have come …”), a playful exploration of a poet’s sense of Zen, and a coming home of sorts into the colonial language English. “Zense” is a place, a home in complete contrast to the sense of doom in the earlier “Chiaroscuro.” Home is “buried in me / like the sunsmell / on my skin.”  Written by Arvin Abejo Mangohig

text:
(The Misfortune). Published 1915. Author, Felix Galura. First issued on 22 Oct 1915 in 500 copies; reissued on 10 Nov 1915 in 1,000 copies.

Ing Cabiguan is a long Kapampangan verse narrative which was so well received it was sold out within a week. It was written with the express purpose of awakening readers from the stupor induced by the kuriru or Pampango metrical romances and the kumidya, the Kapampangan komedya, or plays about Christian and Muslims. Its preliminary matter includes a versified foreword indicting the kumidya as a threat to the morals of the people.

In this work, Galura satirizes the improbable, absurd plots of the kuriru and kumidya. Interestingly enough, he wrote in the same 12-syllable quatrain of the awit or metrical romance form. He may have chosen this form precisely because he wanted to address himself to the readers who had become addicted to these metrical romances. It is clear from the preface that Galura intended Ing Cabiguan to be a new type of verse narrative, one that would be as realistic as the kurirus were fantastic. He attempted to do this by telling a commonplace story of two ordinary people living in a familiar rural setting. Its protagonists, Jaime and Momay, are star-crossed lovers whose plans for elopement are frustrated by Momay’s mother, Rosa, who files a legal suit against Jaime on the grounds of abducting a minor. Jaime is sentenced to prison for eight months, during which he consoles himself with the thought that, the delay notwithstanding, he and Momay will eventually be reunited. Unknown to him, Momay dies just 10 days before his release from prison. His joyful homecoming is short-lived when he hears the news of Momay’s death. A final scene in the narrative takes place in the graveyard, where Jaime leaves a crown of flowers at Momay’s tomb.  Written by Edna Zapanta Manlapaz

text:
Published 1993. Author, Edith L. Tiempo. Manila: De La Salle University Press. Manila Critics Circle’s National Book Award for poetry, 1994.

Tiempo’s second poetry collection, the book contains 50 poems, divided into five sections. The first section presents philosophical poems styled in the manner of modern metaphysicals like Dickinson, Frost, and Yeats. The second engages the writer’s family, the persona in the intimate guises of wife, mother, elder, and wisdom giver. The third pursues social portraits and reflections on community life. The fourth contains lyrical reflections on faith and the spirit. The last section consists of political poems.

The book’s title comes from “Serpent from the Charmer’s Box.” The persona sees on the leaves of garden trees a whimsical apparition of the city. She wonders whether the experience is a vision, a conundrum, or a sacred revelation. For Tiempo, the definitive revelations leading to greater awareness lie not in rarefied moments but in the mindful apprehension of everyday things.

The perceptive gardener in “The Rhythm of Violets” acknowledges the life force through its steady beat but allows the changing seasons to qualify it. All moments are equally important, the gardener admits, not just the storied hour of flowering but also the fallow season when the inner forces work, paving the way for another spring.

“Bonsai” is the collection’s most popular poem. Its wise-mother persona offers an unusual definition of love by reference to small things: a bonsai, a photograph, a tie, a note. She feels her family’s affection in things that have been scaled down. In turn, she believes that love can be conveyed through things small enough for a child to hold. Even the artless mind of children can fully fathom love’s profundity.

Clearly alluding to Debussy and Mallarme, “Afternoon of a Sea Faun” explores a way of valuing through negative assertion: love is not only the sum of definitive choices; the obscured realities that lovers shun also underscore its weight. Ironically, life choices gain more value only when the lovers acknowledge this unspoken side, accounting, too, for what one has relinquished or consigned to compromise.

“Belief” asserts an ontological truth: both eye and the human heart must affirm reality. The unfinished creation finds completion only when consciousness admits that the world exists.

“A Ballad of Flowers and the Councilman” undertakes a paradoxical consideration of freedom. A beleaguered village official evades extortion and death threats by turning his land into a flower garden. By dint of fate, his seemingly useless flowers reach EDSA, gracing a people’s revolution.

In both style and content, this book signals a marked departure from the author’s first collection, published 27 years earlier. Still present is Tiempo’s superior command of form, but her diction is simpler, making her accessible to a wider readership. The dramatic situation in the poems is also more directly established, leaving the reader with fewer ambiguities to settle. Moreover, the book’s subjects, while admirably diverse, are near and familiar: potted flowers, a forest stag, clouds, crocodiles, a ballerina, the rain. These stand as figural extensions of daily life, plucked from common spaces like a garden, a lake, forest heartland, a couple’s bedroom, or a temple. In turn, the emergent insights are never taxingly cerebral but are homespun, artless, practical wisdom.  Written by Danilo Francisco M. Reyes

text:
(Chrysalides). Published 1914. Author, Fernando Ma. Guerrero. Manila: Philippine Education Foundation Inc. Reprinted, 1952.

This collection of poetry, the first of three by Guerrero, consists of 70 poems, written between 1898 and 1913. The other two collections are Aves y Flores (Birds and Flowers) and Inquietudes Espirituales (Spiritual Anxieties). Guerrero was acknowledged as the foremost Filipino lyricist by his fellow poets in Spanish Cecilio Apostol and Jose Palma, and by scholar Jaime C. de Veyra. He was referred to as “El Perfecto” (The Perfect One) and “El Maestro” (The Master) by Claro M. Recto, Jesus Balmori, Jose Teotico, and others who were his pupils or mentees in the art of versification. Known as the “Principe de la Lirica Hispano-Filipino” (Prince of the Spanish-Filipino Lyric), Guerrero was also the most prolific of his contemporaries, his three collections having a total of about 200 poems.

Crisalidas contains three types of poetry: patriotic or nationalistic poems, nature poems descriptive of the Philippine landscape, and love poems. “Mi Patria” (My Country) sings praises to the native land in perfect octosyllabic decimas of cadence and rhythm. It describes the scenic natural beauty of its landscapes and seascapes, the virtues of its people, the tenderness and passion, as well as the innocent faith of the country’s women. Finally, the poet expresses his fear that this beloved land should fall into foreign hands. “Maria Clara” recalls and recreates the attributes of the heroine in Jose Rizal’s Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1887. Describing her innocence and spiritual beauty, the author sees her as the symbol and incarnation of his country in that era of the revolution against Spain. A tragic beauty, she is a victim of voracious designs. In quatrains of 11 syllables per line, Guerrero laments that morning liberty has not yet dawned for his beloved country and that “todavia lloramos en la sombra” (we still weep in the shadows). “A Rizal” (To Rizal), 1899, was written on the third death anniversary of the great martyr. He describes the sufferings of the Filipinos in the “claws of the voracious eagles,” with the guns and cannons of the revolution still booming in the distance. “Tu Eres la Gloria” (You Are the Glory) was written on the occasion of Rizal’s birth anniversary, 19 Jun 1906, and dedicated to the Filipino youth. It is an impassioned and inspiring call to rise and fight in defense of their cultural heritage, to stand stalwart against those who have tried to impose foreign customs, culture, and language. The poem warns of the impending danger to the native Filipino soul, for submission would mean the prostitution of the soul of the race, a slavery more terrible than that which whips and muzzles. “Una Fe y Una Corazon” (One Faith and One Heart) is a call to unity addressed to the country’s politicians, warning them against the division being wrought by the barbarians, whom the poem identifies as the American colonizers. Invoking the old traditions, he counsels them not to scatter seeds of discord among the people, giving as example the heroic insurgents of the revolution, who died crying “Union for Liberty!”

A poem dedicated to his wife is “Petalos: A Carmen” (Petals: To Carmen), which describes the pain of their separation during the days of the revolution and the passionate bliss of their reunions. It affirms that absence or distance heightens the rapture of reunion. The poet uses vivid imagery, metaphors, similes, and personifications to make this a sensual piece. “Claro de Luna” (Moonlight) is another love poem in quatrains of rima perfecta (perfect rhyme), flowing euphonic verses, depicting a pure, powerful passion between man and woman.

Guerrero’s poems demonstrate his definition of poetry as stated in his autobiography included in Aves y Flores, here in English translation: “Poetry should vibrate with the trembling of the thoughts and emotions, a trepidation which can be born only from a deep sincerity. Sincere poetry is beautiful poetry.”  Written by Lilia H. Laurel

article_title: Crowns and Oranges: Works by Young Philippine Poets
text:
Published 2009. Editors, Cirilo F. Bautista and Ken Ishikawa. Pasig City: Anvil Publishing, Inc.

Most of the poems in this collection utilize the confessional voice and are written in free verse. Even the introduction by the editors points this out. Thus, the reader is easily drawn into the small snapshots of the poet’s lives. These may range from mundane events, such as passing through a national park (“At Quezon National Park” by Jennifer Cariño) or musings about the houses we live in (“A House” by Mikael de Lara Co), to deep philosophical and political conundrums, such as an uncle telling his niece that reality is so much more than the abbreviations she uses to communicate with people (“Life Is a Wait-to-Be-Seated Café[:} Lines for a Teen-age Niece” by Jun dela Rosa), or warnings to a country often on the brink of disaster (“Foreword to a Nation About to Crumble” by Joseph Saguid). As the editors rightly claim, there is something in this collection for everyone. Most poems embed a private or shared transgression—real or imagined—and proceed to develop ways on how the persona attempts to deal with it. In some poems, a sort of penance is offered. A guilty tone is often present in the collection, as is the persona’s need for absolution.

“Excerpts from Vox Pangasinense” consists of two poems by Santiago Villafania. The first poem talks about the Tumatahaumen, or the storytellers of Pangasinan, and how these cultural gatekeepers gradually vanished as the world changed. The persona in the two poems laments the vanishing of these storytellers, in a tone that seems to blame the storytellers, but the persona is, in fact, making an indictment of the generations which have willfully abandoned their rich cultural heritage. The shift from the third person in the first poem to the second and first persons in the second poem, for instance, suggests the persona assigning collective blame for the abandonment of the old ways.

Joel Toledo’s poems “Persona,” “The Cave,” and “The Zoo” deal with issues regarding identity, memory, and possibility. In “Persona,” a meta-poem of sorts, Toledo tells the reader not to mind the transformation of the speaker into an animal, this move being simply what he needs to negotiate with the world. He even volunteers to introduce us to his other selves. In “The Cave,” the persona refers to small-village gossip about a cave which once housed Japanese soldiers. No one wants to go there anymore, but his grandmother insists that there is nothing left there but memories. In “The Zoo,” the persona is a young girl who is frightened by the noises made by the caged animals and can find comfort only in the birds—an irony, as the birds themselves are trapped in the zoo. But even at a young age, she recognizes the possibility of flight, of freedom, of making her own path.

There are also poems which deal with love. In Keith Cortez’s “Collect Them All,” the persona literally gives parts of himself to his beloved. He starts with his limbs and proceeds to his innards—an expression of a relationship that is built on installments. Anna Bernaldo-Romulo’s “Jasper” is about how the persona makes up the reasons for staying with her beloved despite the fact that one or even both of them are broken.

The voices and themes in this collection are diverse, yet there is a certain sameness that runs through the poets: the largely urban settings, the preoccupation with romantic situations, the presence of alcoholic beverages, and a buried plea for the reader’s understanding. The poems are mostly bereft of anger and are loaded with melancholia. The speakers confess their sins, real or imagined, and the reader is the confessor who has no choice but to absolve them. After all, their transgressions are our transgressions too.  Written by Jose Miguel Arguelles

article_title: Dal-lang ti Amianan wenno Kapipintasan a Dandaniw Kailokuan
text:
(Song of the North or the Most Beautiful Poems from Ilocandia). Published 1934. Compiler, Leon C. Pichay. San Fernando, La Union: Ilocano Printing Co.

This collection of 187 Ilocano poems brings together the works of 112 poets from the ancient times to the present century. Included are poems by Pedro Bucaneg, Pablo Inis, Jacinto Kawili, Leona Florentino, Isabelo de los Reyes, Mena Pecson Crisologo, Marcelino Crisologo Peña, Mauro Peña, Jose Brillantes, Pascual Agcaoili, Jose B. Sumangil, Felix Abalos, Cecilio Agustin, Pedro C. Ubungen, Efraim Fa. Ordinario, Felix Dumo, Macario P. Arce, Tomas Abrejano, and Leon C. Pichay. Short biographies of 50 of the poets are included.

One important feature of the book is the coronation poetry, samples of which are by Mariano N. Gaerlan, Facundo Madriaga, Ursula Villanueva, Eleuterio Guirnalda, and Leon C. Pichay. Considered an innovation in Ilocano poetry, a coronation poem is delivered by well-known poets during the coronation ceremonies of fiesta queens.

Dal-lang ti Amianan is also an important document in the field of linguistics. Pichay tried to wean Ilocano from its original Spanish orthography and developed one of his own, not unlike what Lope K. Santos did to Tagalog. He discarded the letters c, f, j, ll, ñ, q, v, x, and z, so that an Ilocano orthography would be rid of its colonial vestiges. Thus, “comedia” was spelled as “komedia,” “fraile” became “prayle,” and “dollar” became “doliar.” On the other hand, Pichay coined new words, many of which are to be found in the book. For example, he introduced the word “tuleramid,” from the phrase “tulad nga aramid” (copied action) to mean drama.  Written by Reynaldo Duque

Thus, “comedia” was spelled as “komedia,” “fraile” became “prayle,” and “dollar” became “doliar.” On the other hand, Pichay coined new words, many of which are to be found in the book. For example, he introduced the word “tuleramid,” from the phrase “tulad nga aramid” (copied action) to mean drama.  Written by Reynaldo Duque

Published 1986; 1987; 1988; 1990; 1992; 1993; 1995. Eight volumes. Translation into English, Sister Maria Delia Coronel, ICM. Marawi: Folklore Division, University Research Center, Mindanao State University.

The Darangen is a body of songs or poems chronicling events in the ancient history of the Maranao, a people of Mindanao. It is one of the two types of epics sung among the Maranao. The other type, which recounts the relatively newer exploits of Muslim warriors against Spanish and American colonizers, is called daramoke-a-babay.

The American missionary and teacher Frank Laubach recorded and published one episode from the Darangen for the first time in 1930. Since then, more parts of the epic have been gradually discovered and appreciated by non-Muslim societies. In 1902, a summary of an episode was made in the Journal of American Folklore by a US Army medical officer assigned to Mindanao. Eight volumes of the epic have come out since 1986; two volumes in 1992, featuring the original Maranao text and an English translation, compiled by Mamitua Saber and Sister Maria Delia Coronel, ICM, under the foreign-funded Darangen Project of Mindanao State University. To date, 17 episodes have been identified.

The events chronicled in the Darangen are about the lives and times of royal families in ancient mythical Maranao kingdoms, which include Bembaran/Borantakan, Pangensayan a Rogong, Nataengcopan a Ragat, and Minirigi a Rogon. Bembaran is the most important of these kingdoms. The narratives are set in towns like Madaraba Kalinan, Bagomba-o Samakaet, Kodarangan a Lena, and Ondi-ayan a Tina. The epic unfolds through the complex genealogical interactions of the characters, with various episodes occurring as cycles identified with each Maranao clan.

The most important character in the Darangen is Bantogen/Bantugan, whose journeys and marriages and those of his sons are the subjects of most of the songs in the epic. The other major characters occupy leading positions in the royal genealogy: Diwata Ndaw Gibon, the first ruler; Tominaman sa Rogong, the eldest son of Diwata Ndaw Gibon and the father of Paramata Bantogen, the hero; Mangondaya Boisan, the second son of Diwata Ndaw Gibon; and Pasandalan a Morog, the eldest son of Tominaman sa Rogong.

The epic’s first song, only the English title of which is available, “The First Ruler, or Diwata Ndaw Gibon of Iliyan a Bembaran,” recounts the immediate lineage of all the major characters, the beginnings of the kingdom of Diwata Ndaw Gibon in the small settlement called Bembaran, and the names of the other kingdoms and of the kings who rule over them. The first marriage in the epic takes place between Datu Gibon and the princess Aya Paganay Bai from the kingdom of Minangoaw a Rogong, who is found after a long quest. Datu Gibon transforms the settlement into a kingdom by taking five other wives from neighboring kingdoms. The first wife resigns herself to her lot and leads the musical ensemble to welcome the other wives.

Years pass and Datu Gibon dies. Tominaman sa Rogong, his son with Aya Paganay Bai, is proclaimed his successor. He ends up with eight wives. He sires 15 children, one of whom is Bantogen, who appears in the third song “Kapmadali” (The Story of Madali, one of the grandsons of Datu Gibon). Bantogen has just returned from his many forays into foreign lands, courting and winning women. One of his loves, Lawanen, turns out to be one of his sisters. Totally distraught, Lawanen is convinced by Bantogen that the tragedy has been willed by the gods.

Then a fight ensues between Bantogen and Madali. Bantogen thinks that Madali is responsible for the destruction of Bembaran, while Madali thinks that Bantogen has come to take Princess Danangkap. They later recognize each other as first cousins, and they embrace.

Two songs narrate the exploits of Bantogen: “How Bantogen Died below the Mountain by the Sea” and “How Bantogen Came Back from Heaven.” The king of Bembaran learns that his brother Bantogen has been courting Babali Anonan. He decrees that no subject should ever talk to Bantogen when he returns. The members of the royal council think that the edict is too cruel, but they submit to it anyway. Except for his son and his sister, no one else talks to Bantogen when he arrives in the kingdom. He makes his farewells to everyone and women weep.

Despondent, Bantogen runs in the heavy rain, removes his clothing, lays aside his blade, and lies down under a balete or banyan tree. He summons Magaw, his guardian spirit, who brings him to All the Land between Two Seas. There, Bantogen is nursed by Princess Timbang, who gives him a hammock and betel chew. She calls for a healer to bring him back to health, but Bantogen dies.

The king of All the Land between Two Seas has Bantogen’s body placed in a royal bed, adorned with flags and flowers, at the center of a great hall. Since he is a stranger to the people of All the Land between Two Seas, gongs are beaten to summon people who can identify him. Although 10,000 come in answer to the call, none of them knows him.

Finally, Bantogen’s parrot arrives, grieves over its fallen master, and faints. Revived with water, the bird identifies the dead man. The king places the body in a ship, while the princess sends the parrot back to Bembaran to make the sad announcement. The king of Bembaran faints upon hearing the news; the people are struck with grief.

When Mabaning and Madali learn about Bantogen’s death, they ride their magic shields and fly to the sky world to retrieve the dead warrior. Mabaning disguises himself as a beautiful woman to make the Angel of Death think he has been given a wife by the gods. He asks the Angel where he can find korna, the fruit of heaven. As the Angel leaves him to obtain one, Mabaning loudly asks where Bantogen is. A tiny voice floats from a corked bottle, where Bantogen’s soul is kept. Mabaning grabs the bottle and rejoins Madali. They zoom back to Bembaran. The hero’s soul is released, and Bantogen is brought back to life. There is great rejoicing in the kingdom.

Later, Bembaran is invaded by enemies who think that Bantogen is dead. With magic, he defeats the invaders. The war being over, he sails to distant lands and kingdoms, and marries several women: Maginar, Princess Minoyod, Princess Maginawan, Princess Timbang of All the Land between the Two Seas, Bolontai a Pisigi, and 40 other lovely ladies. Sailing back to Bembaran, he is met by his wildly admiring people, but he escapes and hides from them.

Another song in the Darangen, called “Kambagombayan,” recounts the bloody battles fought in Bagombayan a Luna, where the sons of Bantogen undergo a test of courage. Bantogen and Bolontai Mingginaon, sister of the ayonan or ruler of Bagombayan, are engaged to be married. While Bantogen is in Bembaran, Misoyao, the second son of the ayonan of another kingdom, invades Bagombayan to kidnap Bolontai Mingginaon. Bantogen arrives and engages Misoyao’s forces. Despite his powers, Bantogen tires. His sons—Alongan Pisunyanan, Daidaimairinindo, Watakaiabarat, Barobarosaragat, Ginaasanaorai, Misunaiasasabai, and Monasuman-payongan—arrive in time to the rescue. A savage battle ensues, which leaves Misoyao with only five wounded warriors alive. He retreats with them, leaving behind a great army of corpses.  Written by Edgardo Maranan and E. Arsenio Manuel

 

Sources

Manuel, E. Arsenio. 1963. “A Survey of Philippine Epics.” Asian Folklore Studies 22:1-76.

Miura, Taro. 1989. Review of Darangen by Mamitua Saber and Ma. Delia Coronel, ICM. Asian Folklore Series 48:319-22.

Saber, Mamitua, and Maria Delia Coronel, ICM. 1986-88. Darangen: In Original Maranao Verse, with English Translation. 3 vols. Marawi: Folklore Division, University Research Center, Mindanao State University.

text:
Published 2005. Author, Conchitina Cruz. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press. Reprinted, Youth & Beauty Brigade, 2015. Manila Critics Circle’s National Book Award for poetry, 2006.

An exploration of an unnamed city as desolate space, Cruz’s debut collection features her many formal innovations which embody her reflections on human experience and on the art of writing. Most of the poems are written in prose and are self-reflexive.

Consisting of 31 poems divided into seven sections, the collection begins with “Dear City,” a letter from a collective “we” to a city rendered bleak by unbridled urbanization. It accuses the city of, among other things, turning pristine elements like rain into dirty flood water.

The second section consists of seven poems which continue to explore the theme of confined space. Space here can be either physical, as in a landscape or a body, or abstract, like psychological and emotional space. In “Move Your Hand Over Here,” a nun instructs a child to make the sign of a cross. The repeated instructions are interspersed with violent images.

“Geography Lessons” parallels two different tragedies: a woman with a cheating husband and the 2000 Payatas tragedy. The self-referential quality of the poem, evidenced in the repeated phrase “Inside the story” and references to literary devices like foreshadowing, understatement, image, and symbol, locates the poem as “space” in itself—in this case, in stories of sadness and despair.

The third section is composed of a poem also titled “Geography Lessons.” Composed entirely of footnotes across eight pages, the poem alludes to the other poems in the collection. The absence of a “main” text raises questions about the materiality of poetry on the page and dramatizes an idea of space.

The fourth section is composed of 10 poems on identity and its temporality. “Autobiography” follows a “you” whose story oscillates between a main narrative and one inside the book this “you” is reading. “Alunsina Takes a Walk in the Rain” situates the legend of the alienated goddess in a modern setting. “Elegy” is about a disconnected relationship, where “a city is a house full of rooms”; the speaker shifts back and forth through time and space to rebuild the connection.

“News of the Train” makes up the fifth section. It is also a poem in the form of footnotes. Alongside recurring elements are trains, railroads, and movement, it mentions the Luzon-wide blackout in 1999 triggered by large numbers of jellyfish clogging up a major power plant near Manila.

The sixth section is composed of 10 poems that explore anonymity and departures. “Disappear” is a sequence of six poems that probe the idea of shadows to map the demise of a relationship. Composed of 10 numbered stanzas, “Notes on the Recurring Dream” is the only lineated poem in the collection, but a second column of italicized lines interrupts the reading process.

The final section is composed of a poem titled “Ashfall,” which memorializes the 1991 Mount Pinatubo eruption. Returning to the idea of “rain” in the first poem, Cruz captures the ambiguity of the shower of volcanic ash, which she likens to “rain without drops, without sound … attempting tenderness,” at the moment that it is still unidentified and falls lightly on one’s lashes.

While the voice in Dark Hours is still that of the conventional lyric, the technical mindfulness in the poems—from the footnotes and prose lines to the self-reflexive elements—marks a notable departure from the dominant mode in Philippine poetry in English, which has been mimetic and is characterized by organic unity, clarity, and keenness of insight. It thus introduces a transitional figure in the country’s poetic tradition, who recalls, on the one hand, the technical astuteness of Jose Garcia Villa’s modernist poetry and, on the other, the emotive resonance of the mimetic mode, often derived from powerful images and statements.  Written by Jeffrey Javier

DAVAO HARVEST: AN ANTHOLOGY

Published 1979. Editors, Tita Lacambra-Ayala and Alfrredo N. Salanga. With a foreword by the editors. Davao City: Leonilo Claudio. Reprinted, Davao City: Road Map Series, 2010.

This anthology gathers the literary works and prints of visual art by writers and artists in and from Davao. The book is divided into six sections: “Poetry in English,” “Poetry in Pilipino,” “Short Stories,” “Art Folio,” “Biography,” and “Essays and Editorials.” Capsule biographies of the 47 contributors are provided at the end of each volume.

“Eight Poems” by Salanga relies on simple imagery: rain is the image for the writing process; old storytellers, for mortality; the moviehouse, for American hegemony; a clothes closet, for aging love; birds’ nests, for words that fly; mountains, for constant self-searching; the sky, for the masks that people wear; and ocean beds, for the passing of time. Among Lacambra-Ayala’s three poems is “Lost: One Rebel,” a mother’s deeply interiorized dirge for a child whose life has been sacrificed for a political cause. Paradoxical imagery is the main device in Lilia Lopez Chua’s poems: “Without Reaching” muses on the paradox of things that stay out of reach when one waits for them but come closer when one stops waiting; in “Departure,” farewells are a preparation for forgetting.

Seven of the nine poems in Filipino are untitled and have as their common denominators a stone, fire, a kite, and an ocean wave. Zelie Lorenzana, Gus Miclat, Jose Ayala, and Sonia Solido all use the kite to represent aspects of human nature. Gwenn Bundalian depicts the life of the bato (stone), and Aida Cunanan likens apoy (fire) to a man’s love for woman. The eighth poem, titled “Gabi” (Evening), is Mae Monteclaro’s six-line description of evening; and the ninth, Wenzl Bautista’s “Singkamas” (Turnip), likens this food item, dipped in vinegar and salt, to the process of falling in love. It is Nic Gabunada, however, who derives his imagery from a lumad (indigenous people) concept; his poem is a prayer that the alon (wave) would wash away the world’s sins into the pusod ng dagat (navel of the sea).

Two tales in English are Jorge Sabino’s fable, “The Sheep,” and Jose V. Ayala’s absurdist satire on education, “Away, Going Home.” Leoncio Deriada’s story, “Daba-Daba” (Blaze), dramatizes in simple, childlike sentences, the violent displacement of Davao’s lumad by venture capitalists. Jose V. Ayala’s “Bestiary” may be read as a political allegory, about a nun named Filipinas, who suffers from a delusional skin disease caused by her sexual liaison with the friar Ramirez (Spanish colonialism); but she is also attached to Teddy Bear (American hegemony), whose damned soul she must save. Macario Tiu’s “I Am One of the Mountain People” features a lumad chief’s son caught between Christian ways and his own people’s culture.

The book’s center pages feature black-and-white reprints of artworks by Victorio Edades, Ang Kiukok, Jose V. Ayala Jr, Lydia Ingle, Anna Ferrazini, Manuel Pañares, Victor Secuya, Joan Cuadra, Ludwig Ilio, Javy Villacin, Cynthia Ayala, and Alfredo Liongoren. Subjects specific to Mindanao are Jun Alfon’s sketches of a Bagobo elder and a Badjao house-on-stilts; Ruben de Vera’s Peak of Mt. Apo and his study of a man poised to hurl a spear; Carlota de Pio’s evocative close-up of a lumad woman’s face, titled Native Maja; Isabelo Quiles’s detail of a Badjao boathouse, Shellvendor; and Brenda Barba’s portraits of mother-and-child against a backdrop of stilt-houses standing in sea water.

Three biographical pieces are Lydia Ingle’s “The Edades Story: Two Beginnings,” which traces Victorio Edades’s journey to the United States and depicts his retirement in Davao; Jean Edades’s “A Women of Intellect,” a profile of a former teacher whose intellect impressed her; and Manuela Marfori’s “The City Charter Father Is Badoy,” a tribute to Romualdo C. Quimpo, the first elected assemblyman of Davao and author of the Davao city charter.

The essays are informal pieces on theater, visual art, a Gable movie, history, a Manobo festival, an orphanage, the death of a grandmother, love, an embarrassing childhood photo, and, by way of a book review, ecology. Among the essayists are Horacio Paredes, Connie Jayme, Jo Bacani Angeles, and Aida Rivera Ford, besides those who contributed pieces in the other genres.  Written by Jhoanna Lynn Cruz and Rosario Cruz-Lucero

Ayala’s “Bestiary” may be read as a political allegory, about a nun named Filipinas, who suffers from a delusional skin disease caused by her sexual liaison with the friar Ramirez (Spanish colonialism); but she is also attached to Teddy Bear (American hegemony), whose damned soul she must save. Macario Tiu’s “I Am One of the Mountain People” features a lumad chief’s son caught between Christian ways and his own people’s culture.

The book’s center pages feature black-and-white reprints of artworks by Victorio Edades, Ang Kiukok, Jose V. Ayala Jr, Lydia Ingle, Anna Ferrazini, Manuel Pañares, Victor Secuya, Joan Cuadra, Ludwig Ilio, Javy Villacin, Cynthia Ayala, and Alfredo Liongoren. Subjects specific to Mindanao are Jun Alfon’s sketches of a Bagobo elder and a Badjao house-on-stilts; Ruben de Vera’s Peak of Mt. Apo and his study of a man poised to hurl a spear; Carlota de Pio’s evocative close-up of a lumad woman’s face, titled Native Maja; Isabelo Quiles’s detail of a Badjao boathouse, Shellvendor; and Brenda Barba’s portraits of mother-and-child against a backdrop of stilt-houses standing in sea water.

Three biographical pieces are Lydia Ingle’s “The Edades Story: Two Beginnings,” which traces Victorio Edades’s journey to the United States and depicts his retirement in Davao; Jean Edades’s “A Women of Intellect,” a profile of a former teacher whose intellect impressed her; and Manuela Marfori’s “The City Charter Father Is Badoy,” a tribute to Romualdo C. Quimpo, the first elected assemblyman of Davao and author of the Davao city charter.

The essays are informal pieces on theater, visual art, a Gable movie, history, a Manobo festival, an orphanage, the death of a grandmother, love, an embarrassing childhood photo, and, by way of a book review, ecology. Among the essayists are Horacio Paredes, Connie Jayme, Jo Bacani Angeles, and Aida Rivera Ford, besides those who contributed pieces in the other genres.  Written by Jhoanna Lynn Cruz and Rosario Cruz-Lucero

text:
(From Mactan to Tirad). Published 1941. Author, Flavio Cano Zaragoza. Manila: Kanlaon Press. This epic poem won second prize at the first Commonwealth Literary Contests, 1940.

This poem of more than 4,200 lines is believed to be the best Filipino epic in Spanish. It celebrates the Filipinos’ innate love for freedom and their persistent struggle for independence. It recounts three great battles: the Battle of Mactan, the religious rebellion in Panay, and the battle of Tirad Pass. Lapulapu’s resistance against the incursion of the Spanish and his defeat of Ferdinand Magellan are glorified as a “rebelion historical” (historical rebellion). The religious revolt in Panay was led by the great priest Bongotbanua, who willingly gave up his life. Armed and organized resistance faced the Spanish soldiers who tried to arrest him and suspend the religious ceremonies in the jungles of Balabago. Finally, the evocation of the heroic defense of Tirad Pass brings us from Kakaron, Angat, Mambog, Paombong, to Caloocan and Mambog Zapote.

Woven into the poems are historical events rendered dramatically. The length and the meticulously researched cataloging of the customs and traditions, especially in the Mactan and Panay portions, instill in the poem an epic feel. The author’s mastery of Spanish allows him to exploit lexical richness and, at the same time, to introduce a number of Filipinisms. The unmistakable influence of the Spanish poet Jose de Espronceda is evident in many of the epic’s lines.

Zaragoza protested the jury’s decision to award the Commonwealth Literary Contest’s major prize for the epic to Jesus Balmori’s “Mi Casa de Nipa” (My Nipa Hut), 1941. As a sign of protest, he tore up the diploma of merit as he descended from the stage where Pres Manuel Quezon and other high officials were present. Because of the incident, Zaragoza was suspended for two months. He explained later that he did not mean to offend the president. When a detailed reexamination of the contest rules was done, the opinion came out that Zaragoza should have won. The contest rules required an epic; Balmori’s work was a collection of poems revolving around love, woman, and nature, subjects very different from Zaragoza’s: Filipino heroism.  Written by Edgardo Tiamson

 

Source

Mariñas, Luis. 1974. Literatura Filipina en Castellano. Madrid: Editorial Nacional.

text:
(Not All That Drops Falls). Published 2008. Author, Adonis Durado. Translator, Merlie A. Alunan. With a preface by Vicente Bandillo and a translator’s note by Merlie A. Alunan. Cebu City: Aistemus.

Composed of 61 poems, this book is divided into six sections: “Nahumod sa Salibo” (Drenched by Rain), “Gibug-aton sa Panahon” (The Weight of Time), “Hilab sa Gakutoy nga Dughan” (Desire of the Hungry Heart), “Buhakhak sa Amang” (The Mute Giggles), and “Ang Kinabuhi Usa ka Bangkang Way Katig” (Life Is a Boat without Outriggers). Each sequence contains 12 poems written in different styles, voices, and forms.

The first section “Nahumod sa Salibo” contains poems that use rain as motif. It appears as drizzle, mist, and downpour. Passengers in a jeepney are lost in thought as rain begins to fall in “Salibo” (Drizzle). In “Uwan sa Disyerto” (Desert Rain), rain is personified and then likened to a prudent cat. In “Balaki Ko, Day, Samtang Gasakay Tag Habalhabal” (A Poem, Babe, While We’re on This Fuckin’ Ride), a motorcycle driver courts his female passenger by asking her to recite a poem as they look forward to the blessing of rain.

In the second sequence “Gibug-aton sa Panahon,” Durado presents poems that describe the “weight” of instances and the space which time occupies. The poem “Kadlawon sa Pasil” (Pasil, Dawn) captures the morning rush in a marketplace. Time is suspended in “Pagkaugdaw” (After the Fire), a poem that describes a neighborhood’s daily routine violently disrupted by a fire. In “Alang Kang Yana” (For Yana), a father awaiting the birth of his daughter compares the moment to the lashing of waves against an island shore and the unfolding of dragonfly wings.

The third sequence “Hilab sa Gakutoy nga Dughan” features humorous and sensual love poems. An old man woos a young woman in “Gurang Blues” (Old Man Blues) by showing her his dentures. In “Nganong ang Pizza Di Angay sa mga Tawng Lonely?” (Why Pizza Is Not Good for Lonely Guys), a young man in a pizza parlor envies a pair of lovers. In “Ang Babayng Way Bilbil” (No-Fat Woman), Durado pays tribute to voluptuous women whose figure holds the mysteries of nature. In “Ngano Man Diayg Bayulit ang Barikus ni Violeta” (Violeta Has Purple Varicosities? So What?), a man dismisses his beloved’s insecurity over her purple varicose veins, in the end reminding her that the tip of his penis is also purple.

The poems in the fourth section “Buhakhak sa Amang” break away from the usual structure of lyrical verse and take on experimental forms. In the darkly humorous “Usa ka Gabiing Way Sud-an ug Way Bituon ug sa Akong Nasabtan ang Angay Basulon Mao ang Kulafung Gilaklak ni Papa” (One Evening Nothing for Dinner and No Stars in the Sky and as Far as I Can See the One to Blame Is the Kulafu That Papa Glugged), a son witnesses a fight between his mother and drunk father, which ends with the mother butchering the father and cooking the different parts of his body. When they are through with him, the mother looks for a new husband.

In the last section “Ang Kinabuhi Usa ka Bangkang Way Katig,” the poems are meditations on fear, courage, and human suffering. In the title poem “Dili Tanang Matagak Mahagbong” (Not All That Drops Falls), Durado describes a state of being in perpetual postponement.

Durado commands a range of personas, poetic devices, and forms influenced by Cebuano radio dramas, the romantic Cebuano balak, and modernist and surrealist poetry. Fusing emotion and intellect, he searches for answers to philosophical questions in the lives of ordinary people. Durado employs colloquial orthography, terms, and idioms to create compassionate and impeccably crafted poems.  Written by Jeffrey Javier

text:
Published 1955. Author, Dominador Ilio. Quezon City: Guinhalinan Press.

Many of the poems in this collection were written when Ilio was in Iowa City, taking up a master’s degree in hydraulics science at the University of Iowa. On the side, he enrolled at the prestigious writers’ workshop conducted by Paul Engle.

His poems reveal an incongruous juxtaposition of ancient figures and modern environs. Saint John wanders around Chicago City on Holy Saturday, wondering “if [he] alone bears this world’s bereavement.” Icarus appears in a catechism class, wishing only to “escape from this dark labyrinth.” Narcissus comes running to the lagoon at Burnham Park one summer midnight, adoring his singular beauty:

And each gray line adorning his dark brow

Becomes a virgin grace to reflect and admire.

Alas, to be defiled by his own tears.

Also included in this collection is Ilio’s most anthologized poem, “Diplomat Listening to Speech of Another Diplomat.” In the diplomat’s mind run images of the wife and children “long unloved,” and he thinks how “it will be fun there in the summer sea.” But he has work to do—the business of diplomacy. In this poem, Ilio uses the diplomat to stand for all of us trapped in a world that forces us to do things we do not want to do, to eke out a meager existence, wringing the creative juices out of life itself.

Some of the poems in this collection are included in Collected Poems, published in 1989 by the College of Engineering in the University of the Philippines, where Ilio taught for half a century.  Written by Danton Remoto

text:
(Twelve Peers of France) aka Salita at Buhay nang Doce Pares sa Francia na Kampon ng Emperador Carlo Magno hangga nang Ipagkanulo ni Galalon na Nangapatay sa Roncesvalles (History and Life of the Twelve Peers of France, Followers of Emperor Charlemagne, until They Were Betrayed by Galalon and Killed in Roncesvalles). Published 1949. Author, T.L.C.G. Manila: Philippine Book Company. Five Tagalog editions. Also available in Kapampangan, Bikol, and Ilonggo.

This is an extended account of the exploits of Emperor Carlo Magno or Charlemagne and his lieges, the Twelve Peers of France, in the service of the Church. They help the Patriarch Aaron, ruler of Jerusalem, to retake his throne, which had been captured by Moors from Zaragosa.

The emperor plans to attack Alexandria, ruled by Balan, emperor of the Turks. Fierabras, son of Balan, sacks Rome and Jerusalem. Carlo Magno sends Gui de Borgoña to retake the city, but the latter does not see Fierabras. Instead, he sees Balan and his lovely daughter Floripes. Peer and fair maiden fall in love with each other. Gui reports back to the emperor, who, displeased, sends him back. Gui is met by Floripes with her army, and he refuses to fight her. Gui returns to Carlo Magno, saying the enemy wants a truce. An impatient emperor sends Roldan and eight other peers to demand that the Turks leave Rome. Balan sends his brother Corsubel to the city with 50,000 soldiers. War erupts and Corsubel is killed. The peers return to France to offer their victory to Carlo Magno, but Rome remains in Turkish hands, and they are repulsed.

Fierabras rides to Mormondia, where the peers are camped, to avenge Corsubel’s death. Carlo Magno orders Roldan to fight, but the latter refuses. Oliveiros is sent instead, who succeeds in defeating Fierabras and then persuades him to be baptized. Oliveiros is attacked and taken prisoner. Carlo Magno joins the battle with his forces, but four peers are captured. The five peers are then taken to Turkey, where they are thrown into a dungeon directly under Floripes’s tower. Out of love for Gui de Borgoña, she lets them into her tower, nurses Oliveiros’s wounds, and arms them.

Carlo Magno sends the remaining seven peers to demand the freedom of the prisoners. Meanwhile, Balan has sent 15 kings to negotiate the exchange of the peers for Fierabras. The two delegations meet at Mentible bridge, where a fight erupts. The peers kill and behead 14 of the 15 kings, then proceed to Turkey where they are welcomed by Balan, who is unaware of his emissaries’ fate. The remaining king who has managed to escape arrives to report to Balan, and the emperor orders the seven peers tied up. All 12 peers are sentenced to death, but Floripes has the sentence stayed. The 12 peers are reunited. With Floripes’s help, they frustrate Balan’s efforts to get at them. But they lose Floripes’s magic girdle which staves off hunger, and they begin to feel hungry. They decide to hunt for food. Gui de Borgoña is captured and is about to be executed when he is rescued by the 11 peers. One of them, Ricarte, is sent to Carlo Magno to ask for reinforcements. Guided by a magical white deer, Ricarte hurdles obstacles and reaches France. Carlo Magno heads an expedition to rescue the peers. Balan is defeated and, because he refuses to be baptized, is executed. Gui de Borgoña and Floripes are married and inherit Balan’s kingdom.

One day, Santiago the Apostle appears to Carlo Magno in the form of a young man and tells him to conquer Galicia for the faith. The emperor and his peers invade Spain, where they defeat the Moors in Pamplona and Galicia, and baptize them afterward. They build churches and wage more wars, defeating King Aigolante, Prince Furra, and the giant Farragus. They fight their last battles against the kings of Cordova and Castille.

The final and most tragic adventure of Carlo Magno and the 12 peers is the battle against Marsirius of Roncesvalles of Mauritius. Carlo Magno sends an officer, Galalon, to this king to demand that he forsake Islam, be baptized, and render tribute. But instead Galalon plots with Marsirius to destroy Carlo Magno and his peers. They trick the emperor into sending the peers to Roncesvalles, where they are surrounded and attacked. All are killed except for three. A mortally wounded Roldan kills Marsirius, then flees to the mountains with Baldovino and Tietri. Carlo Magno learns about Roldan’s death from the archbishop who hears angels saying that they are taking the peer’s body to heaven. Baldovino arrives and confirms Roldan’s death. Carlo Magno travels to Roncesvalles and buries his dead lieges. He has Galalon arrested and executed by quartering. Afterward, Carlo Magno entrusts all his wealth to churches and retires to Aquisgran, where he dies on 16 Feb 1012. His soul goes to heaven because of his good works and service rendered to his faith.

Doce Pares was made into a movie by LVN in 1954, starring Jaime de la Rosa, Lilia Dizon, Mario Montenegro, Delia Razon, among others, under the direction of Lou Salvador  Written by Sr. Damiana Eugenio

 

Source

Eugenio, Damiana. 1987. Awit and Corrido: Philippine Metrical Romances. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

text:
(The Doctrine of the Working Class). Published 1979. Author, Rio Alma (pseud. of Virgilio S. Almario). Manila: Aklat Peskador.

This is Rio Alma’s third volume of poetry, written in the early 1970s, during a time of social and political turmoil in the country, and covering a wide range of themes reflective of the poet’s complex experience.

The title is a clear message of the poet’s intent: to project a worldview that is rooted in the earth, anchored to the social realities of his time. The poems, directly expressive of this worldview, are set against the background of his intellectual engagement in the cultural activism that flourished during the years preceding the declaration of martial law. The world of Doktrinang Anakpawis contains fresh and brilliant metaphors, with a delightful mixture of tones closely identified with the poetry of modern American and Latin American poets, always filtered with irony and detachment.

The collection consists of 12 books. As a whole, it presents the poet’s changing perceptions of a society radically questioning itself. The first book, “Sa Pagitan ng Hininga’t Kamatayan” (Between Breathing and Dying), locates the lives and deaths of people within those spaces which hardly call attention to themselves, overwhelmed by the power struggles of the privileged in an unequal society. “Lakbay-Nilay” (Ruminations), the second book, conveys the motif of journey, a pilgrim’s progress through sights and impressions making up the poet’s past. The third and fourth books oscillate from the very personal “Pangungulila” (Loneliness) to the deceptively charming evocation of bucolic peace in “Tumatabal ang Talahib sa Taglamig at Tag-init” (The Grass Grows Wild in the Cold and Hot Seasons), which seethes with subdued anger and violence.

Love in its various manifestations is the theme of the fifth book, “Katekismo ng Puso” (Catechism of the Heart). Here Alma experiments with different poetic forms (villanelle, sonnet, and the kundiman) in presenting a gallery of assorted characters, such as Citizen Juan, the bored society girl, the American GI turned millionaire, and the famous movie director. Notable is the effortless weaving in and out of traditional forms such as the oyayi (cradle song), ambahan (Mangyan oral poetry), and the folk song to create the different portraits.

The ninth and tenth books are composed of very short poems which contain vignettes of life, terse comments on society’s lifestyles and mores. The eleventh book embodies the poet’s doctrine of the common person. Here he articulates his view on poetry and its function in uplifting the human condition. The final book contains the manifesto of the working-class poet. For the poet, poetry assumes the dimension of a sacred and binding oath uttered by a writer who has finally realized the importance of politics in his aesthetics.

The book is a milestone not only in the career of Alma but also in the development of Tagalog poetry. article.value: (The Doctrine of the Working Class). Published 1979. Author, Rio Alma (pseud. of Virgilio S. Almario). Manila: Aklat Peskador.

This is Rio Alma’s third volume of poetry, written in the early 1970s, during a time of social and political turmoil in the country, and covering a wide range of themes reflective of the poet’s complex experience.

The title is a clear message of the poet’s intent: to project a worldview that is rooted in the earth, anchored to the social realities of his time. The poems, directly expressive of this worldview, are set against the background of his intellectual engagement in the cultural activism that flourished during the years preceding the declaration of martial law. The world of Doktrinang Anakpawis contains fresh and brilliant metaphors, with a delightful mixture of tones closely identified with the poetry of modern American and Latin American poets, always filtered with irony and detachment.

The collection consists of 12 books. As a whole, it presents the poet’s changing perceptions of a society radically questioning itself. The first book, “Sa Pagitan ng Hininga’t Kamatayan” (Between Breathing and Dying), locates the lives and deaths of people within those spaces which hardly call attention to themselves, overwhelmed by the power struggles of the privileged in an unequal society. “Lakbay-Nilay” (Ruminations), the second book, conveys the motif of journey, a pilgrim’s progress through sights and impressions making up the poet’s past. The third and fourth books oscillate from the very personal “Pangungulila” (Loneliness) to the deceptively charming evocation of bucolic peace in “Tumatabal ang Talahib sa Taglamig at Tag-init” (The Grass Grows Wild in the Cold and Hot Seasons), which seethes with subdued anger and violence.

text:
(Don Juan the Dead King) aka Salita at Buhay na Pinagdaanan nang Haring Patay na si Don Juan Sampo nang Kanyang Kapatid na si Don Pedro sa Kahariang Ungria, at ang Prinsesang Anak nang Haring Gonzalo sa Reynong Alejandria (Story and Life Experienced by the Dead King Don Juan and His Brother Don Pedro in the Kingdom of Hungary, and the Princess, Daughter of Don Gonzalo of the Kingdom of Alexandria). Published 1901.

Anonymous. Establicimiento Tipografico de Modesto Reyes y Cia. Six Tagalog versions by four publishing houses. Aklatang Lunas edition, edited by Simplicio Flores. Also available in Kapampangan, Bikol, and Ilocano.

Don Juan is the younger son of the king of Hungary. His older brother, Don Pedro, marries the princess of Navarre and becomes king there. When the king of Hungary dies, Don Juan becomes the king of Hungary. The death of his father so grieves Don Juan that he falls ill.

One day, he prays to God that he be allowed to undergo part of the suffering of his father in Purgatory. A voice tells him that he will be allowed to undergo a tenth of the sufferings. The voice tells him to issue a proclamation ordering all his subjects to gather in the palace carrying one pin each. One by one, they are to stick their pins into his body. He will “die,” the kingdom will sink, only the palace will remain above water, and only his body will remain in the palace. He prepares a royal bed adorned with pearls, emeralds, and diamonds. Then he dresses himself in rich robes. He vows to marry the first woman he sees upon waking. The king “dies” and the kingdom sinks.

Meanwhile, in the kingdom of Alexandria, it is prophesied that King Gonzalo’s beautiful daughter Maria will marry a dead king. The king is so shocked that he gets sick. The princess resigns herself to her fate. In the kingdom of Navarre, a voice informs Don Pedro about the “death” of his brother and instructs him to go to Hungary, put the dead king in a box, take him to Alexandria, marry him to the king’s daughter, and, afterward, take him back to Hungary. The king of Alexandria has also been warned by an old man about the coming of his daughter’s “dead” groom. When Don Pedro arrives with the body, therefore, they are welcomed, and the wedding is held. Maria goes to Hungary with her husband, but Don Pedro leaves a female Negro servant with Maria to keep her company. This girl is very ugly and is perverse in her ways.

Juan’s time to awaken arrives. As the heads of the pins begin to show, Maria pulls them out one by one. When only the pins on his head remain, Maria thinks of preparing food for her husband. She instructs the Negro servant to watch over the king and not to pull any of the pins. She disobeys. Juan wakes up to see the girl and promises to marry her. She is overjoyed and begins to treat Maria as a servant.

Juan goes to Alexandria to buy the wedding dress. Before he leaves, he asks all the servants what gift they want him to bring them. Maria asks him to get her a branch with three flowers on it from a shopkeeper who lives under the palace. After much trouble, Juan gets it and presents it to Maria. A parrot in a cage sings, saying that the king is blinded and mistaken about Maria and the Negro servant. Juan is happy to hear this.

One night, Maria takes out her magic branch and orders 12 ladies-in-waiting to dress her in royal robes. The night watchman sees her in her splendor and tells the king, who keeps watch the next night. He sees Maria and hears her tell her sad story. As she is about to kill herself, Juan comes out of hiding. Maria faints; Don Juan laments and also faints. Don Pedro arrives and sees the pair, both unconscious. Learning of the guilt of the Negro servant, he orders her executed. He then revives the couple and blesses them. A big feast is held, in which Maria’s father is given a royal welcome. The two visiting kings stay in Hungary for some time and then return home, leaving the couple to rule Hungary.

This romance is the Philippine version of a folktale that combines two widely known tale types: “The Supplanted Bride” and “The Treacherous Slave Girl.” It enjoyed great popularity, as evidenced by the many reprintings it has undergone. Don Juan’s filial piety and his faithful commitment to a religious vow seem to have appealed to the religious sense of its readers.  Written by Damiana Eugenio

 

Sources

Dawkins, Richard M. 1949. “The Story of Griselda.” Folklore 60:363-74.

Eugenio, Damiana. 1987. Awit and Corrido: Philippine Metrical Romances. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

text:
Chanter, Baket Kinya Infiel (d. 1997). Transcriber and translator, Norma Respicio. “Apo ni Bolinayen (Bolinayen’s Lady Master)” and “Istolya ni Gumigiteng” (The Story of Gumigiteng). Philippine Epics and Ballads Archive, Ateneo de Manila University. http://epics.ateneo.edu/epics/.

Dulimaman consists of 13 songs, or cycles, the male hero of which is Ligi Wadagan, and the female hero, Ayo, aka Babey. Ten of these songs were agmaman (chanted) by Baket Kinya Infiel, whom Norma Respicio recorded between 1985 and 1996 in Pagpag-on, Nueva Era, Ilocos Norte. The epic is sung in Inlaud, one of five major Itneg languages. It is the language of the Itneg in Nueva Era, Ilocos Norte, and Cabugao, Ilocos Sur. The same chanter translated the songs into Ilocano, which Respicio translated to English. The two songs that have been published online were recorded, transcribed, and translated from 1988 to 1990. Three others have been summarized by Respicio and included in The Literature of Voice, 2005: “Agimlang,” “Si Babey a Dulimaman” (The Maiden Dulimaman), and “Ti Paspasyal ni Ligi Wadagan ken ti Ay-ayam na nga Dumaygawan” (The Adventure of Ligi Wadagan and His Dumaygawan Toy/Plaything).

The epic is sung as part of the ritual preparations for cultural activities, such as textile and basket weaving, or for community celebrations. It may be sung after lunch or before bedtime. The chanter and her audience sit on the floor, the chanter folding her legs up against her chest, her feet close together and flat on the floor. One song takes between an hour and an hour-and-40 minutes to chant.

In the Itneg social structure, the dulimaman is a class whose members have supernatural powers and thus are of a higher status than the babaknang (traditional class). The principal characters of the epic are of this class. Additionally, as in many indigenous societies across the country, there are women who are kept isolated from the rest of the community until they are married. Among the Itneg, they are called alimban, just as among the Visayans they are called binukot. Alimban characters figure prominently in the Dulimaman songs.

In “Apo ni Bolinayen,” Ligi Wadagan is a persistent suitor of Ayo, the mistress of the servant, Bolinayen. The reluctant Ayo flees him by first going to the Ilocos town of Santa. The wind sweeps her Itneg-woven basket away from her hand, and she is forced to replace it with the plainer Ilocos basket from the town market. She travels farther north to the town of Paoay, where she is taken in by a kindly but impoverished, old woman.

Ligi goes in pursuit of Ayo and arrives in Paoay. At the market, he recognizes the designs on the blankets that Ayo has been weaving for the old woman to sell. He follows the old woman, who invites him in for a meal. Seeing that the table is laid for three, he persuades the old woman to bring out the third person. After much pleading from Ligi and with the kindly woman’s persuasion, Ayo finally accepts him, and the two live together as husband and wife.

The couple’s abundant harvests from their swidden field become the envy of the Ilocano people of Paoay. Claiming that only Ilocano people should live in Paoay, they get Ligi jailed in Laoag. Ayo overpowers the jail guards and breaks Ligi out of jail. They flee toward Nueva Era, where they dig a well at the riverbank for the tired and thirsty Ayo. Then they resume their journey into the mountains of Abra.

“Istolya ni Gumigiteng” (The Story of Gumigiteng) opens with the happily married couple, Ligi and Ayo, of Kadallayapan. The pregnant Ayo has a craving for the egg of the lablabugauen (wild fowl), which is in Gumigiteng’s keeping in Namsangan. Ligi sets off to obtain the lablabugauen’s egg. On the way, he encounters two alimban, who warn him of the fatal dangers ahead. He is resolute, so they give him a binassaan (richly brocaded wraparound cloth), which will fly him across the turbulent waters of the river and toward Namsangan. The women at the river direct him to Gumigiteng’s house, the roof of which is of human hair, and they merrily predict that there will be a feast tonight. Gumigiteng and his wife, Donya Madilakan, eagerly welcome Ligi in, for their favorite dish is human fingers. Gumigiteng permits Ligi to go and get the lablabugauen’s egg, but this is because it is caged by a fence with a saw’s edge and atop a ladder with rungs made of knives. A friendly spider offers its web for Ligi to walk on, but on his way back, with lablabugauen’s egg in hand, Ligi falls from the spider’s web and onto the knives below. Gumigiteng gleefully calls on his townmates to help him chop Ligi to pieces for a feast. They use his genitals for the drumskin and stick. Ayo hears with foreboding the sound of the drums. She sees that her betel tree has wilted and realizes that Ligi is dead.

Years later, Ligi’s son, Balballokanag, and his cousin Dumnaw take the same route to Namsangan to avenge Ligi’s death. The two alimban who had helped Ligi before likewise give the two cousins each a binassaan to help them cross the same river. The cousins kill the man-eating couple. They put Ligi’s bones together, and Balballokanag restores his life. The cousins slaughter the people of Namsangan and the river runs red. On their way home, they pay court to the two alimban, who, after some initial resistance, consent to leave their village and marry the youths. The village celebrates the recovery of Ligi Wadagan by the two youths and their joint wedding with the two alimban.  Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero

 

Source

Respicio, Norma A. 2005. “Dulimaman, the Itneg Epic.” In The Literature of Voice, ed. Nicole Revel, 125-46. Quezon City: Office of the President, Ateneo de Manila University.

text:
(Pedantry). Published 1975. Author, Rolando S. Tinio. n.p.: Heart-Throbs and Other Beats.

The 45 poems in this book are grouped into four sections. The first section “Bagay-bagay” (Things) opens with “Alitaptap” (Firefly), which states the unifying theme of the section and the book: intelligence is like handcuffs preventing one from discovering the wonders of life, here symbolized by the night air filled with fireflies. Tinio seems to set up an opposition between purely conceptual thinking, on the one hand, and immersion in sensory experience or interaction with actual things, on the other. In “Ang Bentilador” (The Electric Fan), the cool breeze from a fan provokes the persona into thinking about perception. A longer poem with a similar subject, “Pagkamulat ng Makata” (Poet’s Enlightenment) describes in detail the goings-on inside the mind of a writer from the moment he wakes up in the morning. By the end of the poem, the writer realizes that only by interacting with the real world can one experience life to the fullest. In these philosophical poems, Tinio turns to everyday objects and experiences and uses ordinary language—characteristics of bagay poetry, with which Tinio is identified.

The second section, titled “Mga Kuwadrong Panlipunan” (Portraits of Society), consists of seven poems presenting historical events, such as the Vietnam War, an eclipse in Africa, and the bombing of Hiroshima. Many of the poems, like “Ang Maestra” (The Female Teacher) and “Eklipse sa Aprika” (Eclipse in Africa), are studies of human character in extreme situations. In “Alaala ng Hiroshima” (Remembering Hiroshima), the poet vividly but impersonally describes the bombing of the city in Aug 1946. The tension between the object of description—the catalog of victims—and the method of description adds to the reader’s sense of horror at that event.

Tinio’s lyricism is given space in the third section of the book, “Mga Awit ng Pagmamahal” (Love Songs). The poems are about lovers’ experiences as they go through a romantic relationship, from the euphoria of finding an apparent soul mate to the despondency of affection ending. Tinio proves himself capable of writing in traditional forms without sinking into sentimentality or resorting to worn-out expressions. “Irog na Napasaan” (Lost Beloved) is in the tanaga stanza, a heptasyllabic monorhyming quatrain, but Tinio leaves one line unrhymed in every stanza, a note of dissonance that is appropriate to the theme of disaffection. He uses mostly rhetorical questions and ends with the image of a setting moon instead of using direct statements, which is the traditional way.

In the fourth section, Tinio reflects on the ideas of philosophers. Most of the poems, like in “Mga Ehersisyong Analitiko” (Analytical Exercises) and “Mga Solilokyong Hango kay Sartre” (Sartre-Inspired Soliloquies), are serious in tone; but “Payo sa Bumabasa ng Tula” (Advice to the Reader of Poems), in likening the act of reading to eating a mango, can be humorous. In either case, the richness of language and varied rhythms are employed here.

The fifth section consists of the lyrics of the 12 songs in Tinio’s play May Katwiran ang Katwiran (Reason Has Its Reason). These have the qualities of the other poems in the collection. The songs are very witty and show the funny predicament that the rich and the miserable Filipinos find themselves in as they confront the issue of social justice. The songs depict the disadvantages and benefits of being either wealthy or poor. In the song “Pambungad na Awit ng mga Aktor” (Opening Song for the Actors), the poor are encouargaed to improve their abject life while the rich are told to help correct social inequity.

In Dunung-dunungan, Tinio continues what he began in an earlier collection Sitsit sa Kuliglig (Calling the Cricket), 1972, writing poems that are marked by objectivity, economy of phrasing, concrete imagery, and irony, without losing sight of social issues and realities. By so doing, he creates an original voice that remains unmatched in Filipino poetry.  Written by Romulo Baquiran Jr
