Most of the poems, like in “Mga Ehersisyong Analitiko” (Analytical Exercises) and “Mga Solilokyong Hango kay Sartre” (Sartre-Inspired Soliloquies), are serious in tone; but “Payo sa Bumabasa ng Tula” (Advice to the Reader of Poems), in likening the act of reading to eating a mango, can be humorous. In either case, the richness of language and varied rhythms are employed here.

The fifth section consists of the lyrics of the 12 songs in Tinio’s play May Katwiran ang Katwiran (Reason Has Its Reason). These have the qualities of the other poems in the collection. The songs are very witty and show the funny predicament that the rich and the miserable Filipinos find themselves in as they confront the issue of social justice. The songs depict the disadvantages and benefits of being either wealthy or poor. In the song “Pambungad na Awit ng mga Aktor” (Opening Song for the Actors), the poor are encouargaed to improve their abject life while the rich are told to help correct social inequity.

In Dunung-dunungan, Tinio continues what he began in an earlier collection Sitsit sa Kuliglig (Calling the Cricket), 1972, writing poems that are marked by objectivity, economy of phrasing, concrete imagery, and irony, without losing sight of social issues and realities. By so doing, he creates an original voice that remains unmatched in Filipino poetry.  Written by Romulo Baquiran Jr

text:
Published 2004. Author, Dinah Roma. Manila: University of Santo Tomas Publishing House. Manila Critics Circle’s National Book Award for poetry, 2005.

Roma’s first collection articulates in lyric poetry the questions raised by various personae en route to tentative answers gleaned from a journey either away from, or back to, origins. The 50 poems are grouped into three sections—namely, “A Reveller’s Song,” “Solace of Fruition,” and “Pure Cadence Pulsating.”

In the first section, the poems “Unseen Photographs” and “Photographer’s Creed” spring from the language of photography, but they focus not on what is brought to light but on what remains in the dark. There is a tone of anxiety in each of the poems; the image or picture revealed in a photograph or a poem is not all there is to the real. The sharp clarity of images is at once blurred by the human voice aware of the sheer tentativeness of life itself.

The theme of human desolation finds poignant expression in poems of blood that run thick in everyone who has a mother, father, brother, sister, or child. In “My Brother-Soldier,” the persona’s brother-soldier confronts not only his comrade’s death but also his own. The image of the river in the poem’s epigraph, which is a fragment of the brother’s letter, runs parallel to the river of laughter in the persona’s memory of the times before the war. Yet remembering good times cannot stave off death or give any comfort.

“Greenhouse,” in the second section, can be read as an ars poetica and ars vita. The persona declares herself garden and gardener, both. The poem’s affect leaves the reader with tangled threads of dread and hope. Many of the poems in this section and in the next were written during and after the poet’s residency in Japan as a Monbusho scholar pursuing graduate studies in literature and cinema. “Unlearning Origami,” “Circe in Tokyo,” “Ise Shrine,” “Calligraphy,” “To Love Unknown,” “Tsukimi,” “Basho, In Memory,” “The Hiroshima Open Exhibit,” and “Urban Haiku Quartet” appropriate elements of Japanese culture and are informed by Japanese aesthetics. In “Tsukimi,” the erotic spirituality evoked in the work of Heian tanka masters Ono No Komachi and Izumi Shikibu is distilled in the rendering of female passion.

The last section circles back to the powerful archetypal origin of the mother. The space negotiated by the mother-poems like “Viewing Death,” “Of Rashes, Saints, and Cancer,” and “Pantalan” (Wharf) is the ever-narrowing gap between the mother’s life and her death. In “The Linens,” the persona confronts the white shroud that covers the dead body by recalling the mother who used to welcome into her home her returning grown-up children with the finest linens. Death unmoors the child-persona from the safe harbor of a mother’s love and catapults her into the deeper and darker waters of her own fears. In “The Meal,” a daughter feeds her ailing father in the absence of the mother. The poem’s language roots both daughter and father in the basic daily ritual of the giving and taking of food. The gap between the body’s sure deterioration and hard-wired obstinate survival is yoked to the daughter’s wish for the father to go on living, embodied by the gesture of offering him a spoonful of soft rice.

Roma’s collection concludes with poems that connect her poetics with its Southeast Asian cultural roots. In “Tok Dalang,” the persona enters the backlit world of the master shadow puppeteer of the wayang kulit, which delineates the place of origins as the realm of shadows. In the last poem “Pura Besakih,” the persona sings the festive affirmation that is the pure power of poetry: “Something else is alive again.”  Written by Marjorie Evasco

text:
MAN OF EARTH: AN ANTHOLOGY OF FILIPINO POETRY AND VERSE FROM ENGLISH, 1905
TO THE MID-50s.

Published 1989. Editors, Gemino H. Abad and Edna Z. Manlapaz. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

 

A NATIVE CLEARING: FILIPINO POETRY AND VERSE FROM ENGLISH SINCE THE ’50S TO THE PRESENT; EDITH L. TIEMPO
TO CIRILO F. BAUTISTA.

Published 1993. Editor, Gemino H. Abad. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

 

A HABIT OF SHORES: FILIPINO POETRY AND VERSE FROM ENGLISH, 60’s TO THE 90’s; THE SEQUEL
TO A NATIVE CLEARING

Published 1999. Editor, Gemino H. Abad. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

The series of anthologies provides a comprehensive overview of the development of Philippine poetry and Abad’s theory of poetry as an act of writing from a language.

The first anthology covers verse and poetry written between 1905 and the mid-1950s, although the first poem, “Where Is My May?” by Fernando Ma. Guerrero, is dated 1912. Abad and Manlapaz chose 330 poems by 80 poets from a corpus of some 10,000. Abad’s essay “Rereading Past Writ: An Introduction” explains the book’s title, principle of organization, and ultimate criterion. He cites the difference between poem and verse as the critical turn in how Filipino poets came to write from English, rather than in English: an awareness of poetry as an utterance that artfully makes use of a language as guided by a unique sensibility.

The poets are all Filipinos except for one. Poems were chosen with the following in mind: the poem itself; the possible reader; its reflection of the poet’s work and development; the total range of poetic forms and experiments; evidence of relations between poet and milieu. The choice and arrangement are, as Abad says, “already a reading of the poems.” Part 1, “Clearing the Ground,” includes such poets as Fernando Ma. Guerrero, Juan F. Salazar, Fernando M. Maramag, M. de Gracia Concepcion, Natividad Marquez, Francisco B. Icasiano, Vicente L. del Fierro, and Jose M. Hernandez. Part 2, “Tradition and Individual Talent,” includes Luis G. Dato, Angela Manalang-Gloria, Cornelio Faigao, A. E. Litiatco, S. P. Lopez, Trinidad L. Tarrosa-Subido, Abelardo Subido, Aurelio S. Alvero, Narciso G. Reyes, Leon Ma. Guerrero Jr, N. V. M. Gonzalez, R. Zulueta da Costa, and Horacio de la Costa. Part 3, “Toward a New Clearing,” starts with Jose Garcia Villa, who has the most poems in the book, and includes Bienvenido N. Santos, H. R. Ocampo, Carlos Bulosan, Amador T. Daguio, Oscar de Zuñiga, Dominador Ilio, Francisco Arcellana, Toribia Mano, and Nick Joaquin.

The sequel, A Native Clearing, 1993, starts from the same premise as Man of Earth—that is, that Filipino poets shaped the English language as they struggled to express the native sensibility. Citing Daguio’s poem “Man of Earth” as a turning point, Abad argues that Filipino poets, by virtue of their reality and own agency, began to write from, rather than in, English. Revisiting the myth of the Filipino as originating from the bamboo, the persona in the poem ultimately rejects the comparison, instead asserting that he “will be a man.” For Abad, the poem illustrates how English is used to affirm the Filipinos’ sense of themselves and their reality.

A Native Clearing presents 49 poets and 383 poems. The book is divided into two parts. “The Persevering Muse” consists of poems by transitional figures already in the first anthology: C. V. Pedroche, Bienvenido N. Santos, Dominador I. Ilio, Manuel A. Viray, Nick Joaquin, and Benjamin Pascual. As the section title suggests, “Through the ’50s and the ’60s to the Present” consists of poems by poets who began to be published in the 1950s and 1960s, although many of them continued to write in the decades that followed. They include Edith L. Tiempo, Ricaredo Demetillo, Carlos A. Angeles, Virginia Moreno, Alejandrino Hufana, Hilario S. Francia, Tita Lacambra Ayala, Emmanuel Torres, Ophelia Alcantara Dimalanta, Ernesto Manalo, Rolando S. Tinio, E. San Juan Jr, Alfredo O. Cuenca Jr, Jolico Cuadra, Federico Licsi Espino, Gelacio Y. Guillermo, and Cirilo F. Bautista.

The poems in this section bear the influence of the New Criticism—a bias for irony, paradox, and tension. Tiempo and Demetillo are credited for heralding the New Critical phase of Philippine poetry in English, so they head the roster. But Abad also notes other influences, including Villa, the French Symbolists, Chinese and Japanese poets, and the Iowa Writers’ Workshop, with which the Filipino poets engaged in the practice of their craft.

The series is concluded in A Habit of Shores, 1999. Abad presents a “historical cartography” of Philippine poetry, in which he divides it into three broad and overlapping phases or strains: “an inveterate Romantic spirit … then, an enduring formalist or ‘New Critical’ concern … and finally, an open, liberative or post-structuralist space.”

The anthology proper consists of 96 poets—the eldest (Luis Cabalquinto) of them born in 1935 and the youngest (Conchitina R. Cruz) in 1976—and 388 poems, and is illustrative of the last phase in Abad’s classification. The poems from the 1970s evince a loosening of the New Critical grip, at least in its the preoccupation with figures and the its assumption that the poem is an autonomous verbal icon. Extending a line that goes back to Ponciano Reyes’s “The Flood,” 1905, the poems also reflect the political upheavals and social realities of the time, such as are described in the works of Mila D. Aguilar, Jose F. Lacaba, and Emmanuel Lacaba. The trend was already reflected in the works published in the late 1960s and the 1970s of some of the poets included in A Native Clearing.

The 1980s show that the poets were being infected by critical theories of structuralism and post-structuralism. Abad also notes the increase in the number of women poets, 30 in this anthology compared to 5 in the second. They include Merlie M. Alunan, Marra PL. Lanot, Elsa Martinez Coscolluela, Rowena Tiempo Torrevillas, and Marjorie Evasco. There are also a number of expatriate writers—Cabalquinto, Myrna Peña-Reyes, Ma. Luisa B. Aguilar Cariño, Luis H. Francia, and Eric Gamalinda. Among the other poets represented are Alfrredo Navarro Salanga, Wilfredo Pascua Sanchez, Erwin E. Castillo, Alfred A. Yuson, Ricardo M. de Ungria, Marne Kilates, Ramon C. Sunico, Fidelito C. Cortes, Ma. Fatima V. Lim-Wilson, and J. Neil C. Garcia.

The value of the three anthologies lies not only in that they give readers access to the poems but also in that they provide a scholarly apparatus. The biographical notes, sources, and notes on the poems, running close to 200 pages in each volume, is veritably a book in itself. This series is the first of its kind in coverage and purpose: to reread past writ, works largely unavailable and thus long unread. To the scholar, it gives evidence for literary history; to the critic, the context against which to evaluate; and to the poet, an indication of heritage. The handmaid, as it were, to the anthologies is Abad’s Our Scene So Fair: Filipino Poetry in English, 1905-1955, 2008, a collection of his critical essays.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez and Jonathan Chua

text:
(Florante and Laura) aka Pinagdaanang Buhay ni Florante at Laura sa Cahariang Albania—Quinuha sa Madlang Cuadro Historico o Pinturang Nagsasabi nang manga Nangyayari nang Unang Panahon sa Imperio nang Grecia—At Tinula nang Isang Matouain sa Versong Tagalog (Life Experienced by Florante and Laura in the kingdom of Albania—Based on Various Historical Scenes or Portraits Relating to Events in Olden Times in the Greek Empire—And Written in Verse by One Who Delights in Tagalog Verse). Written ca 1838. Author, Francisco Baltazar aka Balagtas.

The book underwent 24 Tagalog editions from 1853 to 1939. Various subsequent editions. Also available in Kapampangan, Bikol, Pangasinan, as well as English, Spanish, and German. A famous edition is that handwritten by Apolinario Mabini in Tagalog, with a preface by Carlos Quirino and an English translation by Trinidad Tarrosa-Subido of the 1861 edition, Manila: National Heroes Commission, 1964. An important translation is that into Spanish of the 1838 edition by Epifanio de los Santos, Manila: Philippine Review, 1916.

This metrical romance in dodecasyllabic lines was signed with the initials F. B. and was dedicated to one “Selya.” Florante at Laura is the most artistically written of all Philippine metrical romances, and many of its aphoristic passages are also the most often quoted. In the process, it entered folk consciousness with the force of transmitted wisdom. The greatness of the work rests on the author’s ability to comply with the accepted technical conventions of the awit or metrical romance while at the same time introducing innovations which improved on the genre. These include using a dedicatory poem to a woman instead of the usual religious invocation; the use of flashback instead of strict chronological sequencing of events; the use of classical allusions which are not stereotyped or inaccurate but are apt and carefully explained in footnotes; the absence of magic objects and occurrences; and, perhaps the most significant, the unconventional portrayal of Muslim characters—Aladin and Flerida—as male and female heroes comparable in virtue to their Christian counterparts Florante and Laura.

The opening scene is a dark forest, where Florante has been tied to a tree and exposed to the predators of the wild. While lamenting his fate, he is threatened by two lions. A brave Persian warrior, Aladin, arrives in time to rescue the helpless Florante. Aladin is a fugitive, his beloved Flerida having been taken away from him by his own father. The two warriors become friends, and they unravel to each other the story of their lives.

Florante is the son of Duke Briseo and Princess Floresca of the kingdom of Albania. After spending a happy childhood in Albania, he is sent to Athens to be educated. Here Florante so excels in his studies that he incurs the envy and ire of countryman Adolfo, who attempts to kill him but is thwarted by the timely intervention of Menandro, the hero’s bosom friend. Called home to Albania by the death of his mother, Florante is taken into the service of the king as general of the army. In the royal court, he meets and falls in love with Laura, the king’s beautiful daughter. Inspired by Laura and aided by Menandro, Florante wins his first big battle against the Persian army invading Krotona. Returning, they find Albania under Persian occupation. They rescue Laura from her captors, recover the kingdom, and release the king, the duke, and the other nobles, including Adolfo, from prison. Laura bestows her love on Florante.

Albania enjoys peace only briefly. A Turkish army invades, led by the renowned Miramolin. Florante defeats him, then goes on an all-out crusade against the Moors. While he is away, Adolfo usurps the throne, has the king and his father killed, and tries to force Laura to marry him. Recalled home by a letter forged by Adolfo, Florante is seized and imprisoned. Laura intervenes, and instead of being beheaded, Florante is taken to the dark forest and bound to a tree, where Aladin finds him. The two live in the forest for five months, at the end of which they are reunited with their sweethearts, who also happen to be there. Flerida has escaped from Persia on the eve of her wedding to Aladin’s father. In her wanderings, she comes upon Adolfo about to ravish Laura, and she kills the tyrant with her arrow. The happiness of the four lovers is made complete by the arrival of Menandro, who has recovered Albania from the forces of Adolfo. Florante and Laura take Aladin and Flerida to Albania where the two Persians are baptized as Christians. A double wedding ensues. Florante ascends to the Albanian throne and with Laura rules long and peacefully. The Albanians live happily ever after.

As in other Philippine metrical romances, the didactic element in Florante at Laura is deliberately emphasized and accounts greatly for the work’s popularity. The work abounds in precepts and proverb-like passages for a great many themes in human society—friendship, betrayal, the rearing of children, the power of love, the perversion of love, the evils of tyranny expressed in beautiful and memorable assonantal couplets and quatrains, and in majestic dodesyllabic meter. The most popular include the following: “Ang laki sa layaw, karaniwa’y hubad / Sa bait at muni’t, sa hatol ay salat” (Reared in ease, one is deficient / In good sense and judgment); “O pagsintang labis na makapangyarihan / Sampung mag-aama’y iyong nasasaklaw / Pag ikaw ang nasok sa puso ninuman / Hahamaking lahat masunod ka lamang” (Love, your allure’s overpowering / And you rule over both fathers and sons / When you enter the heart of anyone / He would defy all to follow your bidding); “Sa loob at labas ng bayan kong sawi / Kaliluha’y siyang nangyayaring hari / Kagalinga’t bait ay nalulugami / Ininis sa hukay ng dusa’t pighati” (Throughout my pitiful country / Everything’s fallen to vile tyranny / All goodness and wisdom are given no mercy / Strangled to the grave by dire misery).

Florante at Laura has been studied in high school for decades. It has been made into film at least twice: in 1939 with Carlos Padilla and Lila Luna; and in 1949 by LVN with Leopoldo Salcedo and Celia Flor. It was made into a komedya in San Dionisio, Parañaque, and Pakil, Laguna, in the 20th century; an opera by Lucino T. Sacramento in 1970; a play by Rene O. Villanueva for Bulwagang Gantimpala in 1987; and a musical by Tony Perez and Nonong Buencamino for Tanghalang Pilipino in 1988.  Written by Damiana Eugenio and Edgardo Maranan

 

Sources

Castro, Jovita Ventura, Antolina Antonio, Patricia Melendrez-Cruz, Josefina Mariano, and Rosella Jean Makasiar-Puno, eds. 1983. Anthology of ASEAN Literatures: Epics of the Philippines. Manila: ASEAN Committee on Culture and Information.

Cruz, Hermenegildo. 1906. Kung Sino ang Kumatha ng “Florante.” Manila: Libreria Manila Filatelica.

article.value: (Florante and Laura) aka Pinagdaanang Buhay ni Florante at Laura sa Cahariang Albania—Quinuha sa Madlang Cuadro Historico o Pinturang Nagsasabi nang manga Nangyayari nang Unang Panahon sa Imperio nang Grecia—At Tinula nang Isang Matouain sa Versong Tagalog (Life Experienced by Florante and Laura in the kingdom of Albania—Based on Various Historical Scenes or Portraits Relating to Events in Olden Times in the Greek Empire—And Written in Verse by One Who Delights in Tagalog Verse). Written ca 1838. Author, Francisco Baltazar aka Balagtas.

The book underwent 24 Tagalog editions from 1853 to 1939. Various subsequent editions. Also available in Kapampangan, Bikol, Pangasinan, as well as English, Spanish, and German. A famous edition is that handwritten by Apolinario Mabini in Tagalog, with a preface by Carlos Quirino and an English translation by Trinidad Tarrosa-Subido of the 1861 edition, Manila: National Heroes Commission, 1964. An important translation is that into Spanish of the 1838 edition by Epifanio de los Santos, Manila: Philippine Review, 1916.

This metrical romance in dodecasyllabic lines was signed with the initials F. B. and was dedicated to one “Selya.” Florante at Laura is the most artistically written of all Philippine metrical romances, and many of its aphoristic passages are also the most often quoted. In the process, it entered folk consciousness with the force of transmitted wisdom. The greatness of the work rests on the author’s ability to comply with the accepted technical conventions of the awit or metrical romance while at the same time introducing innovations which improved on the genre. These include using a dedicatory poem to a woman instead of the usual religious invocation; the use of flashback instead of strict chronological sequencing of events; the use of classical allusions which are not stereotyped or inaccurate but are apt and carefully explained in footnotes; the absence of magic objects and occurrences; and, perhaps the most significant, the unconventional portrayal of Muslim characters—Aladin and Flerida—as male and female heroes comparable in virtue to their Christian counterparts Florante and Laura.

The opening scene is a dark forest, where Florante has been tied to a tree and exposed to the predators of the wild. While lamenting his fate, he is threatened by two lions. A brave Persian warrior, Aladin, arrives in time to rescue the helpless Florante. Aladin is a fugitive, his beloved Flerida having been taken away from him by his own father. The two warriors become friends, and they unravel to each other the story of their lives.

Florante is the son of Duke Briseo and Princess Floresca of the kingdom of Albania. After spending a happy childhood in Albania, he is sent to Athens to be educated. Here Florante so excels in his studies that he incurs the envy and ire of countryman Adolfo, who attempts to kill him but is thwarted by the timely intervention of Menandro, the hero’s bosom friend. Called home to Albania by the death of his mother, Florante is taken into the service of the king as general of the army. In the royal court, he meets and falls in love with Laura, the king’s beautiful daughter. Inspired by Laura and aided by Menandro, Florante wins his first big battle against the Persian army invading Krotona. Returning, they find Albania under Persian occupation. They rescue Laura from her captors, recover the kingdom, and release the king, the duke, and the other nobles, including Adolfo, from prison. Laura bestows her love on Florante.

Albania enjoys peace only briefly. A Turkish army invades, led by the renowned Miramolin. Florante defeats him, then goes on an all-out crusade against the Moors. While he is away, Adolfo usurps the throne, has the king and his father killed, and tries to force Laura to marry him. Recalled home by a letter forged by Adolfo, Florante is seized and imprisoned. Laura intervenes, and instead of being beheaded, Florante is taken to the dark forest and bound to a tree, where Aladin finds him. The two live in the forest for five months, at the end of which they are reunited with their sweethearts, who also happen to be there. Flerida has escaped from Persia on the eve of her wedding to Aladin’s father. In her wanderings, she comes upon Adolfo about to ravish Laura, and she kills the tyrant with her arrow. The happiness of the four lovers is made complete by the arrival of Menandro, who has recovered Albania from the forces of Adolfo. Florante and Laura take Aladin and Flerida to Albania where the two Persians are baptized as Christians. A double wedding ensues. Florante ascends to the Albanian throne and with Laura rules long and peacefully. The Albanians live happily ever after.

As in other Philippine metrical romances, the didactic element in Florante at Laura is deliberately emphasized and accounts greatly for the work’s popularity. The work abounds in precepts and proverb-like passages for a great many themes in human society—friendship, betrayal, the rearing of children, the power of love, the perversion of love, the evils of tyranny expressed in beautiful and memorable assonantal couplets and quatrains, and in majestic dodesyllabic meter. The most popular include the following: “Ang laki sa layaw, karaniwa’y hubad / Sa bait at muni’t, sa hatol ay salat” (Reared in ease, one is deficient / In good sense and judgment); “O pagsintang labis na makapangyarihan / Sampung mag-aama’y iyong nasasaklaw / Pag ikaw ang nasok sa puso ninuman / Hahamaking lahat masunod ka lamang” (Love, your allure’s overpowering / And you rule over both fathers and sons / When you enter the heart of anyone / He would defy all to follow your bidding); “Sa loob at labas ng bayan kong sawi / Kaliluha’y siyang nangyayaring hari / Kagalinga’t bait ay nalulugami / Ininis sa hukay ng dusa’t pighati” (Throughout my pitiful country / Everything’s fallen to vile tyranny / All goodness and wisdom are given no mercy / Strangled to the grave by dire misery).

Florante at Laura has been studied in high school for decades. It has been made into film at least twice: in 1939 with Carlos Padilla and Lila Luna; and in 1949 by LVN with Leopoldo Salcedo and Celia Flor. It was made into a komedya in San Dionisio, Parañaque, and Pakil, Laguna, in the 20th century; an opera by Lucino T. Sacramento in 1970; a play by Rene O. Villanueva for Bulwagang Gantimpala in 1987; and a musical by Tony Perez and Nonong Buencamino for Tanghalang Pilipino in 1988.  Written by Damiana Eugenio and Edgardo Maranan

article_title: Galian: Mga Akda sa Panahon ng Krisis
text:
(Galian: Works in a Time of Crisis). Published 1983. Editors, Virgilio S. Almario, Mike L. Bigornia, and Rene O. Villanueva. Quezon City: Aklat Peskador.

This is the first anthology in book form published by the Galian sa Arte at Tula. Included here are the works of the first generation of the literary organization’s members. Earlier, in 1975, the group had put out a collection of poems by its leading writers, in mimeographed form. This 1983 anthology features an essay, short stories, poems, songs, plays, and translations of foreign poems.

The lone essay is by Delfin Tolentino Jr. The short stories are by Fanny Garcia, Jun Cruz Reyes, and Lilia Quindoza-Santiago. The poems, comprising the biggest group of entries, are by Tomas F. Agulto, Lamberto E. Antonio, Mike L. Bigornia, Federico Licsi Espino Jr, Rogelio G. Mangahas, Edgardo B. Maranan, Manuel Pambid, Fidel D. Rillo Jr, Alfrredo Navarro Salanga, Romulo A. Sandoval, Jesus Manuel Santiago, Ramon Villegas, and Virgilio Vitug. The songs are by Heber Bartolome, Ananias Montano, Jesus Manuel Santiago, and Nonilon Queaño. The plays are by Reuel Molina Aguila, Nonilon Queaño, and Rene O. Villanueva. The translations of poems from the Middle East, Iran, Africa, South Asia, Puerto Rico, and Latin America are by Hermino S. Beltran Jr, Danilo A. Consumido, Dong de los Reyes, Rodolfo H. Desuasido, Marne Kilates, Jose F. Lacaba, and Perfecto T. Martin.

Tolentino’s essay provides not only an overview of Philippine poetics but also a clue to the theme and aesthetics of the whole collection: “Eskapismo at Pakikisangkot sa Panulaang Pilipino, 1945-1972” (Escapism and Engagement in Philippine Poetry, 1945-1972). The whole panoply of ideological and cultural influences on the socially committed Filipino writer, evident since the activist years from the late 1960s up to the martial law period, and summed up in the phrase “social realism,” is the informing quality of most of the works.

One finds a radically changed presentation of reality in the Galian works, compared to the prose and poetry of an earlier literary period. Quindoza-Santiago’s “Ang Manggagamot ng Salay-Salay” (The Doctor of Salay-Salay) describes a new kind of doctor created by the era of revolution: a middle-class professional who joins the armed struggle in the countryside to minister to sick peasants and is slain by the government’s counterinsurgency forces. Aguila’s full-length play “Satirika” (Satire) has become a contemporary classic for its witty, acerbic, and ultimately discomfiting deconstruction of the petite bourgeoisie’s revolving-door involvement with social revolution. Santiago’s deceptively simple “Kung ang Tula’y Isa Lamang” (If a Poem Were a Mere) is a creative distillation of a poet’s worldview and a partisan’s ars poetica. Bartolome’s song “Nena” tells the haunting story of a woman’s journey from childhood poverty to early prostitution, the fate of many Filipinas.

Images abound of Philippine society in crisis, with allusions to the broader context of poverty in the Third World. What ultimately emerges from this collection is the picture of a writer confronting a social reality and interpreting it by using metaphor as a social reflection on life and on the times. The effect of this collective reflection upon reality is a complex, turbulent canvas, a general impression accurately captured by the artist Manuel Baldemor in his illustration for the book’s cover: a flame-rimmed mural of feudal, underdeveloped Philippine society, with social and political forces in violent confrontation.  Written by Edgardo Maranan

(Epic) aka Guman of Dumalinao. Published 1980. Transcriber, Esterlinda Mendoza-Malagar, “The Guman of Dumalinao: A Suban-on Epic,” Kinaadman 2 (1980): 275-380.

Guman is the generic term for epic among the Subanon, a sub-Visayan mountain folk of the Zamboanga Peninsula. However, it is also the title given to the first full-length Subanon epic to be recovered and published. It has over 4,000 lines.

Esterlinda Mendoza-Malagar recorded the epic in 1971. Her sources were Cabao Talpis, who served as her informant, and Pilar Talpis, who chanted the guman. Both hail from Dumalinao, Zamboanga del Sur. Her work was submitted to the Graduate School of Xavier University in Cagayan de Oro in 1972 and was later published in Kinaadman, 1980. Portions of the text and its English translation also appeared in an anthology of Philippine folk literature by Damiana Eugenio in 1981.

The epic has two similar plots, which vary only in the names of the characters and in some minor details. The kingdom of Mount Dliyagn is set in the mountainous regions of the Zamboanga Peninsula, which is drained by a straight river whose bottom is lined with porcelain and beads of gold, and whose banks are bordered by flowering plants. Datu Pombnwa, his wife Baysalaga, and their young daughter rule the kingdom. They live in an eight-room mansion with furniture made of gold. Datu Pombnwa and Baysalaga used to have other children, but their daughters drowned in the river, and their sons, venturing out in search of them, failed to return. The other members of the household are Sampilakn and Tinayobo.

One day, while Datu Pombnwa is making a shield, he hears disturbing sounds from the sea. War vessels are coming. Tinayobo sounds the magical gong, and as she beats them, the mast and the outriggers of the invading ships are shattered. After six days, the enemies, sent by three evil queens, land. They start to scale the mountain to reach the kingdom, but because the mountain keeps growing taller, it takes the invaders a month and a half to reach the summit.

When they reach the royal household, the invaders are met by Tinayobo. They strike her with a kampilan or blade, but the blow lands on the porch, damaging it. Tinayobo restores it in a flash. Datu Pombnwa and Sampilakn join in the fight. After a month, however, the two old warriors grow exhausted, and they fall to the ground. This prompts their daughter, Ba-e ri Dliyagn, to fight. Initially, she successfully battles the enemies, but after a month, she is bathed in blood. Thinking her dead, the enemies abandon her.

A young man, Sakandal, told that Dliyagn is under attack, comes to help. He restores the princess’s spirit and beauty. As he goes to the mansion with her, the strength of Datu Pombnwa and Sampilakn is restored. The ba-e’s parents take notice of the young man and hope that he will propose to their daughter someday. The daughter is then given a name, Pailalam ri Bolak, for she has come of age. She is also given a chewing box. As she chews, her beauty increases. She then learns about her brothers and sisters.

Meanwhile, Sakandal goes to battle in the kingdom of Tomanong. For days, Pailalam ri Bolak observes him from the mansion’s porch as he fights. Sakandal meets the chief of the Tomanong. As they fight with their kampilan, the enemy causes the river to be overrun by fire, but Sakandal extinguishes it with a flood. After two weeks of fighting, the chief of Tomanong retreats almost lifeless. Sakandal, too, is exhausted, but Pailalam ri Bolak fans him and restores his strength.

Pailalam ri Bolak receives a message from the maiden of Patola, who is asking whether she should go with a stranger who has come to Mount Patola. Sakandal takes his ring and gives it to Pailalam ri Bolak, telling her to knot it in the kerchief and send it to the maiden of Patola. The invaders arrive ahead of Sakandal’s ring. The ring drops and becomes unknotted. Out of the ring comes a man named Salilayan. He helps defeat the invaders. The kerchief returns to the mansion, and Sakandal asks Pailalam what else he can do for her. She asks him to lend her his magical powers. She is given a kerchief with 18 rings knotted to it. She disappears from the spot.

The guman shifts to the kingdom of Pagkatologon. The kingdom is in the same situation as Dliyagn. With no fighting men, the women of the kingdom are inspired to fight. A man named Madlawe helps them, just as Sakandal has helped Pailalam ri Bolak. The second part, however, may be said to be more magical than the first. Pailalam ri Bolak reappears to take an important role. The guman ends with the return of the missing children. A traditional buklog or feast is held to celebrate the union of the two kingdoms.  Written by Servando Halili Jr

 

Sources

Malagar, Esterlina Mendoza. 1980. “The Guman of Dumalinao: A Suban-on Epic.” Kinaadman 2:275-380.

article_title: Gumising Ka, Aking Bayan: Mga Piling Tula
text:
(Awaken, My Country: Collected Poems). Published 1998. Author, Benigno Ramos. With a preface and an introduction by Delfin Tolentino Jr. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

The book is a collection of 87 poems spanning the three periods of Ramos’s career: as a professional writer in Manila, as a bureaucrat, and as a founding member of the Sakdalista movement, an organization that he named after his weekly paper, Sakdal. Ramos’s poetry belongs to a category of Philippine poetry described by Virgilio S. Almario as “balagtasismo,” which is characterized by its adherence to traditional Tagalog versification and its strong nationalistic and sentimental tendencies.

The book’s first 28 poems, 1911-12, represent Ramos’s early works, which established him as one of the youngest major poets of his time. “Katas-Diwa” (Essential Spirit), published when he was 19 years old, exemplifies his interventions in versification, with his use of compound words and a meter of 18 syllables per line.

Ramos’s early poems also demonstrate the young poet’s fearless engagement with social realities. In “Bulkan!” (Volcano), the brewing anger of the oppressed masses is likened to a rumbling volcano warning colonial officials of an impending eruption. In “Cine-Renacimiento” (Renaissance Cinema), the reader is invited to scrutinize four “films,” each featuring the villain as devoid of honor and integrity: a proud but worthless writer, a wealthy politician who turns away a pauper asking for help, a priest feigning holiness, and a cunning suitor who wins the leading lady by threatening the life of his rival.

Poems published in 1923-30 hew to the conventions of traditional Tagalog poetry, which is typically didactic, conservative, and sentimental. Ramos deliberately uses such conventions to deliver his most polemical pieces, which became increasingly anti-American. “Panulat” (Pen) is an emotional apostrophe that likens the act of writing to the wielding of a weapon in defense of the nation in a time of war. In “Independence Congress,” the persona satirizes the collusion between his fellow politicians and the American colonial government to impede the nation’s struggle for independence. In “Bonifacio,” the hero rebukes those who put themselves first before their own country, calling them cowards.

The conviction that poetry’s function is to fight for social justice and emancipate the people from colonial tyranny would be crystallized in Ramos’s poems of 1930-36. The title poem is a dramatic monologue calling for the nation to end its subservience, lest this lead to its being “sans land, pride, or sovereignty” (walang lupa’t walang puri, walang bandila at bayan). Here, Ramos clearly fulfills the poet’s responsibility to incite the masses to act and thus create their own destiny.

In his introduction, Tolentino fortifies Ramos’s reputation as a poeta revolucionario (revolutionary poet) of his time. That this poetry collection still bears witness to the nation’s present condition attests to the poet’s astute foresight.  Written by Om Narayan Velasco

In his introduction, Tolentino fortifies Ramos’s reputation as a poeta revolucionario (revolutionary poet) of his time. That this poetry collection still bears witness to the nation’s present condition attests to the poet’s astute foresight.  Written by Om Narayan Velasco

(The Cry of the Cogon). Published 1980. Author, Lamberto Antonio. Quezon City: Aklat Peskador.

This is Antonio’s first book of poems. Like his contemporaries, notably RioAlma (pseud. of Virgilio S. Almario) and Rogelio Mangahas, Antonio was influenced in the early 1960s by T. S. Eliot, Pablo Neruda, Rainer Maria Rilke, Salvatore Quasimodo, and other modern poets. The political developments of the succeeding decades further sharpened the literary craft of Antonio by imbuing it with a critical outlook on social phenomena, particularly on the harsh conditions obtaining in the Philippines. The book’s title suggests both the social origins of the poet—he grew up in the peasant countryside of Nueva Ecija—and his poetic reflections on liberation.

Hagkis is composed of five sections, each dealing with various aspects of contemporary Philippine society. Wielding metaphor, sound, sight, and insight together, Antonio succeeds in creating portraits of a social milieu wracked by violence, absurdity, repression, and resistance. The personae in his poems are drawn from peasants with whose life he is familiar, as well as from characters he has encountered living in the vast jungle of the city-workers, prostitutes, beggars, activists, and others.

The poet confronts the plight of a worker who has lost an arm, a young movie actor forced to provide cheap thrills to her audience, a construction worker overwhelmed with despair, and children growing up without hope. In poems formed from rural experience, poverty is unrelieved and life is a heavy burden to bear, with the poet assuming the role of a persona who interrogates, narrates, participates in the unfolding narrative, or who criticizes the social phenomenon that has brought about the condition of oppression. Sardonic humor is present as poetic device in evoking tragicomic characters, such as Mariang Beha, Islaw Palitaw, and Pedro Penduko.

Modernist techniques are apparent in Antonio’s metaphorical addresses about love, birthing, dying, nature, and life in the city and countryside. But what endows his poems with lyricism and expressiveness is the poet’s view of the world as deeply flawed, but worthy and needing of change. In no uncertain terms, Antonio speaks of forces that could bring about society’s transformation, historical forces which have always emanated from the rural landscape overgrown with talahib.  Written by Soledad Reyes

THE SAGA OF PUMBAKHAYON

Published 1931. Transcriber, Fr Francis Lambrecht, CICM. In The Little Apostle of the Mountain Province.

Published 1967. Transcriber, Fr Francis Lambrecht. In Saint Louis Quarterly 5, nos. 3-4.

 

HUDHUD HI ALIGUYON

Published 1983. Transcriber, Amador Daguio. In Anthology of ASEAN Literatures: Epics of the Philippines, edited by Jovita Ventura Castro et al., Manila: Nalandangan Inc.

Hudhud is the term for epic among the Ifugao, one of the mountain tribes in northern Luzon. Like most Philippine epics, the hudhud is performed during communal affairs, such as wedding feasts and wakes, but it is most often performed during harvest. Hudhud literally means “harvest-song.” In contrast to most Philippine epics, which are chanted, the hudhud is sung. Traditionally, only women can sing the epic.

There are legends surrounding the practice. Some folks believe that while a group of women were singing about the adventures of the hero Pumbakhayon one harvest season, he appeared to them and taught them to sing new hudhud, revolving around other characters such as Aliguyon and Bugan. At dusk he disappeared, and all those who saw him died. Two female harvesters who heard but did not see him survived to spread the new hudhud.

Different hudhud have been transcribed, but they all deal with the hero Aliguyon and his kin. In 1902, an unknown Gaddang transcribed a hudhud as it was recited by Leon Kutug in Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. William Beyer recorded about 40 songs, but to date, these have not been transcribed. Rufino Chungalao transcribed and translated “Bugan Inaliguyon” (Bugan, Wife of Aliguyon) in 1950 but has not published it yet.

Fr Francis Lambrecht, CICM, is the most prolific transcriber of the hudhud. He transcribed four hudhud from the 1930s to the 1950s. In the 1960s, he transcribed two hudhud: Hudhud of Aliguyon Who Was Bored by the Rustle of the Palm Tree at Aladugan and Hudhud of Bugan with Whom the Ravens Flew Away at Gonhadan.

Lambrecht’s source for Hudhud of Aliguyon Who Was Bored was Margarita B. Gimbatan, a native of Lagawe. Lambrecht was assisted by Fr Emiliano Madangeng, a native of Hapao. In this hudhud, Aliguyon, disguised as an old man, wins himself a wife. Bored by the rustle of the leaves of the palm tree in their yard, Aliguyon informs his mother that he will journey to neighboring villages. He meets an old man who offers him betel to chew. The old man asks to be slain. Aliguyon kills him, dries the old man’s skin in the sun, and wears it. Disguised as an old man, he reaches Tulaling where lives Bugan, a beautiful maiden who pities him and feeds him warm cooked rice. Bugan bejewels herself and goes to Makawayan, where she is well received. There, she dances with Dadyaahon and drinks rice wine with him. When she comes home tipsy, she pines for him. A month and a half pass, and Bugan visits another village. Aliguyon disguises himself as Intuliktik, the wife of Dadyaahon. Bugan dances with Aliguyon, who is in disguise, and drinks rice wine with him. At sundown, Bugan returns home, still pining for Dadyaahon. Aliguyon, still disguised, goes to Bugan’s mother and proposes that she hold a feast to attract boys from neighboring villages. During the feast, Pinayudan seems to be the best match for Bugan, but Aliguyon, as an old man, wrestles with Pinayudan and unmasks himself. His disguise—the old man’s skin—is torn apart. Bugan and Aliguyon are married. After the wedding feast, Aliguyon returns to his village with Bugan. He learns that his mother felled the palm tree in their yard some time ago.

Hudhud of Bugan with Whom the Ravens Flew Away at Gonhadan is another story of Aliguyon’s romance with Bugan. After feeding the chicken and pigs, Indangunay goes to the granaries while carrying her daughter Bugan in a blanket, which she slings on her back. She opens the 10th granary and lets Bugan down. While they are eating, ravens snatch Bugan and drop her on the crest of a mountain at Habungan. An older girl Indamolnay discovers Bugan and rears her, both of them feeding on guava fruit and berries. When they look down at the rice fields of Hananga, they yearn for rice. Indamolnay leaves Bugan in their house and goes down to Hananga to help the harvesters. At noon, the harvesters are told to carry bundles of rice to the granary pavement and to eat. Indamolnay hides a part of her share in her sleeve for Bugan. Malinayu, who divides the shares at the close of the day, gives but two bundles to Indamolnay, who carries the rice up to the mountain crest. Chickens and pigs meet her and eat the grains of rice.

The same events happen over the next two days. On the fourth day, Bugan wants to go with Indamolnay, but Indamolnay advises against it. Stubborn, Bugan later goes out alone and picks droppings of rice ears. Rice carriers and other boys see her and inform Aliguyon, who looks for her. When he finds her, he tells her to come with him. She refuses at first but later consents. Arriving at Hananga, she introduces Indamolnay to Aliguyon. Aliguyon disposes of his wife and decides to marry Bugan. Indangunay hears of the wedding and, wondering whether Bugan is her lost daughter, goes to Hananga. Mother and daughter are reunited. Indangunay recounts how she lost Bugan. She then fetches Pangaiwan, her husband. The epic ends with a double wedding at the house of Indangunay and Pangaiwan: Aliguyon marries Bugan, and Indamolnay marries Daulayan, Bugan’s brother.

Besides Lambrecht, the fictionist Amador Daguio also studied the hudhud. For his thesis at Stanford University, he wrote an English translation of one sung by Hinayup Bantayan of Burnay and transcribed in Ifugao prose by Pio B. Abdul. Called Hudhud hi Aliguyon (Hudhud of Aliguyon), Hinayup Bantayan’s version centers on the feud between two heroes, Pumbakhayon and Aliguyon, and their eventual friendship.

Aliguyon of Hananga gathers friends of his age to play tops with them. Forcefully, he throws his top, which bounds across the yard and spins inside his house, hitting his father’s bangiban, a piece of wood shaped like a boomerang. He goes up the house to look for his top. Not locating it, he picks up the bangiban and throws it away. Aliguyon brings a rooster down the house and calls his friends to watch what it will foretell about his plan to fight the Daligdigan, enemies of the Hananga. When the rooster augurs success, Aliguyon summons his comrades to camp at the yard, despite his mother’s protestations. The next day, he asks his father for the whereabouts of the idao, a bird of augury. His father counsels him against battling the Daligdigan and suggests that he bring home a woman instead, but to no avail. His father tests Aliguyon’s skill by throwing a spear at him. Aliguyon catches it very easily. He and his comrades proceed to Daligdigan, the chirping of the idao bird strengthening him.

Upon reaching Daligdigan, Aliguyon challenges the Daligdigan led by Pumbakhayon, who responds that, as his men have not eaten yet, Aliguyon must wait. Pumbakhayon takes a rooster and opens it up to consult its bile sac for a sign. It foretells good luck. Calling all his men, he tells them to shake the soot from their shields. When the Hananga warriors hear the beating of the shields, they think of retreating, but Aliguyon assures them that their enemies are only cleaning their shields. Pumbakhayon crosses the village and comes to the rice path where Aliguyon meets him. Not wanting to fight in the rice fields and spoil their harvest, Pumbakhayon invites Aliguyon to fight him on the riverbed. Aliguyon refuses; he shall fight Pumbakhayon in the fields until bamboo and alimit trees grow there. The duel starts after sunrise and continues till noon. From a distance, the women of Daligdigan cheer for Pumbakhayon, but he tells them that Aliguyon is his equal in battle. Dangunay, Pumbakhayon’s mother, arrives at the scene of the battle, bringing her baby daughter Bugan with her. Aliguyon notices them. Dangunay raises a bolo to stop the fight so that Pumbakhayon may eat. Aliguyon returns to his camp and eats. After the meal, Aliguyon and Pumbakhayon resume the combat.

The seesaw battle lasts for a year and a half, pausing at evenings and at mealtimes. One day, Aliguyon notices that bamboo and alimit trees have grown on the rice terraces. He tells Pumbakhayon that he will return home, but Pumbakhayon says he shall come after Aliguyon afterward. When Aliguyon and his comrades reach Hananga at night, he asks his mother why the rice has not yet been harvested. Dumulaw, his mother, replies that they have enough rice on reserve. When dawn breaks, Aliguyon tells his comrades to hold a feast. Then he heads for the riverbank to meet Pumbakhayon. Aliguyon wants to save Hananga’s harvest by fighting at the riverbank. Pumbakhayon sees the harvesters of Hananga and angrily spears Aliguyon’s companions. He makes his way to the rice fields where Aliguyon fights him. Aliguyon’s companions root for him, but Aliguyon tells them that Pumbakhayon is an equal and worthy opponent. Worried, Dumilaw goes to the ricefields with her daughter Aginaya. She breaks the fight so that Aliguyon may eat. Pumbakhayon notices Dumulaw and Aginaya, and asks Aliguyon about them. Out of respect, Pumbakhayon allows Aliguyon to eat. Afterward, the two chew betel nut. The battle resumes, the opponents hurling one spear between them. Their companions join in the fight, which lasts for another year and a half, with neither side victorious.

When Pumbakhayon notices that bamboo and alimit trees have grown on the terraces, he and his forces withdraw. Aliguyon says he shall follow them to Daligdigan. The next day, Aliguyon and his comrades leave Hananga for Daligdigan, where another protracted battle happens.

Rumors of Pumbakhayon’s death reach the neighboring villages. Daulayan, who has been betrothed to Pumbakhayon’s sister, decides to fight for Pumbakhayon despite his mother Maggapid’s warning. When he arrives at the scene of the battle, he finds Pumbakhayon alive, trading spear throws with Aliguyon. Daulayan says that he will take Pumbakhayon’s place and explains that they will become brothers-in-law, for his mother Maggapid and Pumbakhayon’s mother Dangunay have exchanged beads. Pumbakhayon advises him against fighting Aliguyon, but Daulayan is insistent. With a spear, Aliguyon wounds Daulayan. As he is about to be beheaded, Daulayan begs for mercy and offers Aliguyon all his beads in exchange for his life. Aliguyon spares him, but Pumbakhayon has been so shamed that he rejects Daulayan as his kin.

Instead, he thinks Aliguyon will make a better brother-in-law than Daulayan. Daulayan returns home to his unsympathetic mother.

The two warriors Aliguyon and Pumbakhayon make peace. Pangaiwan, Pumbakhayon’s father, divides a betel nut between them and offers each a cup of wine. The next morning, Aliguyon woos Bugan and takes Bugan to Hananga where they celebrate the wedding. In turn, Pumbakhayon marries Aginaya, Aliguyon’s sister. He brings her to Daligdigan where they enjoy a life of renown.

The epic is structurally symmetrical. It opens with something comparable to an invocation, the rooster prayer. The first major episode, Aliguyon’s invasion of Daligdigan, follows. The action subsides with the arrival of the mother and daughter. The second major episode, Pumbakhayon’s invasion of Hananga, parallels the first major episode, and, as with the first part, it is the female figures who break the battle. The epic ends with another rooster prayer, giving it a sense of closure and balance.

Parallelisms in the details of the two episodes can be established. Aliguyon and Pumbakhayon, for example, describe each other in almost identical terms. The description of the battle fields in either episode is also similar. The repetitions climax in the resolution of the epic, a double wedding between members of opposing tribes, which, according to Josefina Mariano, 1983, in an introduction to the hudhud, leads readers to the theme of the epic: self-preservation.

Like many other epics, Hudhud hi Aliguyon presents much of the culture of the people it comes from. Fighting by trading spear shots, consulting the rooster’s bile sac for signs, and chewing betel nut are often depicted in the epic.  Written by E. Arsenio Manuel and Jonathan Chua

Demetrio, Francisco. 1979. “An Overview of Philippine Epics.” Kinaadman 1:9-28.

She breaks the fight so that Aliguyon may eat. Pumbakhayon notices Dumulaw and Aginaya, and asks Aliguyon about them. Out of respect, Pumbakhayon allows Aliguyon to eat. Afterward, the two chew betel nut. The battle resumes, the opponents hurling one spear between them. Their companions join in the fight, which lasts for another year and a half, with neither side victorious.

When Pumbakhayon notices that bamboo and alimit trees have grown on the terraces, he and his forces withdraw. Aliguyon says he shall follow them to Daligdigan. The next day, Aliguyon and his comrades leave Hananga for Daligdigan, where another protracted battle happens.

Rumors of Pumbakhayon’s death reach the neighboring villages. Daulayan, who has been betrothed to Pumbakhayon’s sister, decides to fight for Pumbakhayon despite his mother Maggapid’s warning. When he arrives at the scene of the battle, he finds Pumbakhayon alive, trading spear throws with Aliguyon. Daulayan says that he will take Pumbakhayon’s place and explains that they will become brothers-in-law, for his mother Maggapid and Pumbakhayon’s mother Dangunay have exchanged beads. Pumbakhayon advises him against fighting Aliguyon, but Daulayan is insistent. With a spear, Aliguyon wounds Daulayan. As he is about to be beheaded, Daulayan begs for mercy and offers Aliguyon all his beads in exchange for his life. Aliguyon spares him, but Pumbakhayon has been so shamed that he rejects Daulayan as his kin.
Instead, he thinks Aliguyon will make a better brother-in-law than Daulayan. Daulayan returns home to his unsympathetic mother.

The two warriors Aliguyon and Pumbakhayon make peace. Pangaiwan, Pumbakhayon’s father, divides a betel nut between them and offers each a cup of wine. The next morning, Aliguyon woos Bugan and takes Bugan to Hananga where they celebrate the wedding. In turn, Pumbakhayon marries Aginaya, Aliguyon’s sister. He brings her to Daligdigan where they enjoy a life of renown.

The epic is structurally symmetrical. It opens with something comparable to an invocation, the rooster prayer. The first major episode, Aliguyon’s invasion of Daligdigan, follows. The action subsides with the arrival of the mother and daughter. The second major episode, Pumbakhayon’s invasion of Hananga, parallels the first major episode, and, as with the first part, it is the female figures who break the battle. The epic ends with another rooster prayer, giving it a sense of closure and balance.

Parallelisms in the details of the two episodes can be established. Aliguyon and Pumbakhayon, for example, describe each other in almost identical terms. The description of the battle fields in either episode is also similar. The repetitions climax in the resolution of the epic, a double wedding between members of opposing tribes, which, according to Josefina Mariano, 1983, in an introduction to the hudhud, leads readers to the theme of the epic: self-preservation.

Like many other epics, Hudhud hi Aliguyon presents much of the culture of the people it comes from. Fighting by trading spear shots, consulting the rooster’s bile sac for signs, and chewing betel nut are often depicted in the epic.  Written by E. Arsenio Manuel and Jonathan Chua

HINILAWOD: THE ADVENTURES OF HUMADAPNON (TARANGBAN I)

Published 2001. Chanter, Hugan-an. Transcriber and translator, F. Landa Jocano. Quezon City: PUNLAD Research House Inc.

 

HINILAWOD: THE ADVENTURES OF HUMADAPNON (TARANGBAN II)

Published 2011. Chanter, Hugan-an. Transcriber and translator, F. Landa Jocano. With a preface and an introduction by F. Landa Jocano. Quezon City: PUNLAD Research House Inc.

 

HUMADAPNON

Typescript 1964. Chanter, Ulang Udig of Lambunao, Iloilo. Recorder, transcriber, and translator, Felipe Landa Jocano.

 

HUMADAPNON

Typescript 1985. Transcriber, Gina Barte.

This entry on the epic of Humadapnon comes from four different sources: two books edited by F. Landa Jocano, a typescript also by F. Landa Jocano, and a typescript by Gina Barte.

Humadapnon is one of two cycles of the oldest known epic of Panay, Hinilawod, which belongs to the oral tradition of the Sulod mountain people living near the headwaters of the rivers Jalaur (or Halawod), Aklan, and Antique. The other cycle is Labaw Donggon. It is sung in Karay-a, which is the language of the Sulod. Each of the two cycles is generally considered an epic in its own right, and each centers on one of the two heroes: Labaw Donggon and Humadapnon, although in the Humadapnon cycle, Dumalapdap becomes an equally important figure.

Tarangban I, 2000, is divided into four sugidanon (narrations): pangayaw (travel), tarangban (cave), bihag (captivity), and pagbawi (rescue). The pahunawa (introduction) presents Humadapnon as the world’s pillar and strength, a great leader and counselor in the realm of Pan-ay. The epic action begins with Humadapnon realizing that it is time for him to find someone to marry, and she must be equal to his stature and ability. His spirit friends, Taghuy and Duwindi, confirm that such a maiden is Nagmalitong Yawa, daughter of Buyong Labaw Donggon and Uwa Matan-ayon.

Humadapnon asks his sister Uwa Labing-Anyag to create a man to assist him in his search for Nagmalitong Yawa. Labing-Anyag creates a man with the following elements: drops of blood taken from Humadapnon, their parents Ginbitinan and Burulakaw, and herself; ginhawa (the breath of existence); domdom (reason); tingug (voice); and bo-ot (conscience). The new man, who is also Humadapnon’s brother, springs to life full grown. They name him Dumalapdap.

After much training and preparation, the two brothers, with their uripon (helpers), set out on a golden boat to the mouth of the Halawod River. The journey is fraught with various trials. Humadapnon and Dumalapdap barely escape being crushed between two boulders colliding with one another. Thereafter, the golden boat traverses a sea where the water is sticky and the foam is like human blood. Their first stop is the promontory of their uncle, Buyong Sarandihon, to whom Humadapnon pays his respects. Buyong Sarandihon warns Humadapnon away from the enchanted and fearful island cave of Tarangban.

Thousands of binukot (well-kept maidens) inhabit Tarangban, which is headed by the most beautiful of them all, Sinagkating Bulawan. She is strolling on the beach when Humadapnon’s golden boat sails by. She calls to the travelers to drop in and chew some betel nut. Mindful of their mission, Dumalapdap ignores her, and Humadapnon respectfully declines, though he promises to stop on his return journey. Sinagkating Bulawan insists but Humadapnon declines again.

Malubay Hanginon, Sinagkating Bulawan’s youngest sister, lives in the seventh room of Tarangban, out of anyone’s sight, where she weaves fabric from threads of gold. After Sinagkating Bulawan tells her of Humadapnon’s snub, she puts on her best garments and all her jewelry. At the cave entrance where “millions, thousands, and hundreds” of well-kept maidens have gathered, Malubay Hanginon gracefully walks to the center and asks Humadapnon to stay for a visit. Despite her persistence, Humadapnon refuses. Malubay Hanginon, through her spirit friends, casts a powerful spell on Humadapnon. He loses his reason, will, and judgment. Over Dumalapdap’s protests, Humadapnon enters the Tarangban. At first, Dumalapdap stays on the golden boat but soon takes his spear and shield and looks for Humadapnon inside the cave.

Inside the Tarangban, the other well-kept maidens welcome Humadapnon. Lying on a hammock made of cloth of many colors, Humadapnon caresses and makes love to the well-kept maidens. He is deaf to Dumalapdap’s pleas for them to resume their journey and finds Malubay Hanginon on a hammock in the seventh room. He apologizes to her and joins her in the hammock. In frustration, Dumalapdap shouts and calls for Humadapnon, who finally bids Malubay Hanginon farewell. She is enraged but Humadapnon casts a sleeping spell on her. Before he can reach his boat, Malubay Hanginon awakens, bewitches him again and imprisons him in the cave. At Humadapnon’s bidding, Dumalapdap returns to Pan-ay to get help from their parents, Burulakaw and Ginbitinan, and to call on their people to free him. Any man who would succeed would be rewarded pots of silver and gold. If his rescuer were to be a maiden, Humadapnon would offer her his hand.

Hangin Hugayong, the wind, flies Burulakaw and Ginbitinan to Tarangban to free Humadapnon but they are unable to. Neither can all the powerful babaylan (shaman) throughout the land. Humadapnon’s two spirit friends, Taghuy and Duwindi, tell Dumalapdap of the one maiden who can match the powers of the binukot of Tarangban. She is Nagmalitong Yawa, who is also the lady whom Humadapnon wishes to marry. Dumalapdap, borne by Hangin Hugayong, flies to her island. Knowing that she will probably refuse to rescue Humadapnon, who means nothing to her, Dumalapdap tells Nagmalitong Yawa that it is her brother Buyong Ginlawudan who is imprisoned in the Tarangban. As they are flying to Tarangban, Hangin Hugayong confesses the truth to Nagmalitong Yawa, who, aggrieved, returns to her kingdom. Taghuy, Duwindi, and Hangin Hugayong, with the help of Nagmalitong Yawa’s musical instruments, the bidya (guitar) and kudyapi (lute), again entreat her to rescue Humadapnon. She grudgingly relents but only on the condition that she would transform into a man. She assumes the name of Buyong Sunmasakay.

Sunmasakay lands at the cave’s door, which the people are still trying to open. He uses his pamlang (psychic powers) to strike it open with the dalugdug (thunder). The well-kept maidens are thus exposed, and their leader, Sinagkating Bulawan, engages in a terrible battle with Buyong Sunmasakay. All the well-kept maidens of Tarangban are killed.

In the seventh room, Buyong Sunmasakay comes upon Malubay Hanginon, and they fight. Malubay Hanginon seeks help from Humadapnon, who gives it because he is still bewitched. In the end, Buyong Sunmasakay’s pamlang overpowers those of Malubay Hanginon and Humadapnon, and he frees Humadapnon from the cave. Father Burulakaw, Mother Ginbitinan, Buyong Dumalapdap, and their subjects from Pan-ay dance with joy. However, Humadapnon remains in a trance.

Sunmasakay prepares for home but is persuaded to stay to awaken Humadapnon. Sunmasakay sends his spirit friends to the urugan (the highest point in the sky) to fetch the water of life and happiness. He conducts a ritual that breaks the spell on Humadapnon. Sunmasakay bids farewell and requests Humadapnon’s parents and brother not to reveal his real identity to him. He transforms himself back into Nagmalitong Yawa and walks through the admiring crowd to where her stone binanugan (hawk’s resting place) waits. She sits on it and crosses her legs as everyone leaves her content in her solitude.

In Tarangban II, Humadapnon must recapture the heirloom biday (boat), named Timpara Alimuon, as a requisite to winning the approval of Nagmalitung Yawa’s parents for her hand in marriage. Nagmalitung Yawa agrees to accompany him on the sea voyage on condition that he never forces himself on her. In the course of their journey, Humadapnon politely refuses Balanakon’s invitation to drop by, resists the challenge to fight Dampig Piliw with the help of Nagmalitung Yawa’s magic charms, sails by the place of the dead, and reaches Paglambuhan’s fortress. It is Paglambuhan who keeps Timpara Alimuon in his fortress and is thus the person that Humadapnon must fight.

Throughout the voyage, Humadapnon has tried to seduce Nagmalitong Yawa, to no avail. But as he prepares for battle with Paglambuhan, Nagmalitong Yawa relents and allows some foreplay. She soon stops him, promising that they would resume their lovemaking after he kills Paglambuhan.

The first battle is between Dumalapdap and Paglambuhan’s son, Sumagulung, who is killed by Dumalapdap. The next battle is between the enraged Paglambuhan and Humadapnon, and it lasts for months until Humadapnon weakens. He flies up to the goddess, Ulang Santunilyu, who gives him more courage, strength, and charm. The duel resumes, but it appears that it will last indefinitely until Nagmalitong Yawa distracts Paglambuhan with her fragrance. Humadapnon kills him. The victors now journey back to Halawod, with the heads of the two enemies displayed on the biday’s stern. Humadapnon again tries to make love to Nagmalitong Yawa. She reminds him of the warrior’s code requiring the victor to bed the dead enemy’s widow. Humadapnon accedes, but when he stays more than an hour with the widow, Nagmalitong Yawa leaves him, manning the biday herself. Dumalapdap shouts for Humadapnon, and Hangin flies Humadapnon back to the biday on his shield.

The journey resumes but tension prevails between the two epic heroes. As the biday nears Halawod, Nagmalitong Yawa puts everyone to sleep, covers the biday with a shield of invisibility, and flies back to Halawod. In Halawod, Humadapnon and Dumalapdap meet Nagmalitong Yawa’s parents, Labaw Donggon and Matan-ayon. Their own parents, Burulakaw and Ginbitinan, arrive for the patingog, which is the grand feast for a marriage proposal.

Dumalapdap falls in love with Sibyang Alon, who is forbidden to him because she is a goddess. After the wedding, Humadapnon leaves Nagmalitong Yawa to accompany Dumalapdap on a journey for Huyung Adlaw’s hand in marriage.

Meanwhile, Paglambuhan and Sumagulung, who have come back to life, tell Matan-ayon that Humadapnon is dead. Matan-ayon compels the reluctant Nagmalitong Yawa to marry Sumagulung by making her pregnant. Humadapnon returns to Halawod and kills Sumagulung, Paglambuhan, and Nagmalitong Yawa. The grieving Humadapnon returns to Panay. At Humadapnon’s remorseful pleading, Labing Anyag brings Nagmalitong Yawa back to life by endowing her with the breath of life, strength of existence, conscience, feelings, intelligence, and compassion. After some resistance, she agrees to return to Humadapnon. Humadapnon receives Labaw Donggon and Matan-ayon’s blessing. Labing Anyag returns to Ginlawudan. The epic ends as Humadapnon and Namaglitong Yawa enter their chamber and close the door behind them.

In the Ulang Udig–Jocano typescript version, Humadapnon is chieftain of the Sulod people and has two brothers: Labaw Donggon and Dumalapdap. He embarks on a journey fraught with trials as he seeks Nagmalitong Yawa, whom he wants for a wife. The rest of the epic recounts how he wins, loses, and again wins Nagmalitong Yawa. These events happen at seven-year intervals, during which he must pass a series of trials. Dumalapdap, his brother, is instrumental in Humadapnon’s first separation from Nagmalitong Yawa, but they also fight shoulder to shoulder at a wedding feast where Nagmalitong Yawa is about to be wed to another man.

In the Barte version, Humadapnon and Dumalapdap are nephews instead of brother to Labaw Donggon, who is a first-generation hero. Humadapnon plays a less aggressive role than his brother Dumalapdap and his wife Nagmalitong Yawa. Here, she takes on a central role as her husband’s rescuer and as mediator in conflicts between the two brothers. In one instance, she engages his enemies in a hand-to-hand combat. Barte’s version of the Humadapnon cycle follows.

Humadapnon dreams of a beautiful woman named Tubigon Daligan-Umis Kuyam-isan, a binukot, who lives in a golden tower surrounded with bamboo thickets. He wakens with the resolve to search for this woman to marry her. His mother Anggoy Imbitinan protests that there are numerous binukot in their own village; but he is adamant, and he prepares for a 10-year journey. Shortly before he leaves, Dumalapdap, his younger brother, is born and insists on accompanying Humadapnon. The brothers anoint their vessel with herbs. From their home at Halawod River, they sail to other places, frequently beset by difficulties, which Dumalapdap overcomes. They reach the river Mabkad, ruled by two datus named Mamang Mangalayo, the prince, and Mamang Dumadakung Dagat, the supreme ruler. Mangalayo occupies the upstream portion, while Dumadakung Dagat occupies the portion at the mouth of the river. The datus block Humadapnon and Dumalapdap’s sailing course. Dumalapdap and Humadapnon introduce themselves as the offspring of Harong Buruwisan, the supreme deity of the seventh layer of the skies, and Anggoy Imbitinan. The two datus, on the other hand, reveal that they are descendants of Pagbuaya, the ruler of the underworld. A battle ensues between the datus when Mangalayo learns that Humadapnon plans to get a binukot. They fight for days, and Humadapnon wins. Mangalayo begs for his life and promises not to block the brothers’ way again. Dumadakang Dagat then engages Humadapnon in a battle in the air, which lasts for several days. Weakened, Humadapnon asks for water from Banogon, the eagle who is his constant companion.

Dumalapdap, left on earth, sees his brother weakening and flies to his rescue. Meanwhile, along the shores of the river Makutay-kutay, Abyang Baranogon and his younger brother Padanong Palinti are having a drink. They are the sons of Labaw Donggon and cousins of Humadapnon and Dumalapdap. Pandanong Palinti goes down to the river to catch fish only to find it overflowing with blood. When he casts his net, he catches a stranger’s head. He rushes to his brother to recount the incident. Thinking that their cousins are in trouble, the brothers rush to the scene of the battle. Baranogon takes Dumalapdap’s place against Dumadakung Dagat. With the help of their ancestors in heaven, Baranogon defeats Dumadakung Dagat. Having killed Dumadakung Dagat, Baranogon asks Dumalapdap to give him Tubigan Daligan, Dumadakung Dagat’s binukot, in exchange for his sister Malitong Yawa. Dumalapdap refers Baranogon to Humadapnon, who consents.

Dumalapdap decides to go on his own journey. Humadapnon refuses to accompany him, for he has not yet met his binukot. Dumalapdap goes to the house of Mamang Tumpong Langit, the ruler of the river Mabun-ag. Finding him asleep, Dumalapdap casts a spell over him to make him go on sleeping and enters the room of the binukot Huyohuyong Adlaw. When Tumpong Langit discovers that his binukot has been stolen, he appeals to his brothers for help. He challenges Dumalapdap to a combat, which lasts for many days and nights.

Meanwhile, Baronogon and Padanog Palinti reach the river Maragkot where Abyang Mangalayo, whom Humadapnon defeated, blocks their path. Baranogon and Mangalayo fight, but this time Mangalayo’s life is not spared. Baranogon claims Mangalayo’s binukot but refrains from laying a hand on her, because he still has great obligations to meet. The two datus reach the place of Abyang Lumbanglantang at Mabun-ag river. There they threaten to kill Lumbanglantang if he does not give them his binukot Labi-labing Anyang. Fearing for his life, Lumbanglantang does not resist the datus. Later, the datus reach the river Baliwagan, where they demand the binukot Layalayang Sukla. Abyang Sumagorong gives her up without a fight. However, Sumagorong journeys to win the hand of Malitong Yawa, Baranogon’s sister. By the time Baranogon returns to his place, Sumagorong has already offered his bridal gifts. Realizing that Sumagorong may have gained an edge over Humadapnon in winning his sister’s hand, Baranogon makes a copy of Malitong Yawa shaped out of dough made from powdered rice. He then instructs his sister to go to Humadapnon’s younger sister at the Halawod River. The following day, Humadapnon presents his suit for the hand of Malitong Yawa. Malitong Yawa’s mother Matanayon favors Sumagorong. However, as Sumagorong and the replica are spending their honeymoon, Baranogon tells Humadapnon that the real Malitong Yawa is still his. Meanwhile, Dumalapdap weakens in his battle with Mamang Tumpong Langit. He sends a messenger to inform Humadapnon about his plight. Humadapnon rushes to his aid and takes his place, but it is the ancestors who again settle the match. Dumalapdap expresses his gratitude and tells Baronogon that on his way he has seen Labaw Donggon, Baronogon’s father, being kept a prisoner by Mamang Magtangub, a malignant spirit residing in the mountain caves. Dumalapdap, Humadapnon, and Baranogon head for Magtangub’s mountain fortress to free Labaw Donggon, only to find him a heap of bones. Baranogon demands that Magtangub return his father to life. Revived, Labaw Donggon engages Magtangub in a combat that lasts for many days. Labaw Donggon triumphs with the help of his ancestors.

The datus sail home. On their way, however, they pass by caves inhabited by enchanted spirits. Humadapnon is seduced and decides to stay awhile. He is bewitched and imprisoned by the spirits. Dumalapdap asks for help from his mother, Anggoy Imbitinan, to rescue Humadapnon. All the binukot respond to the call for help, but Malitong Yawa alone succeeds in opening the cave’s stone door. Malitong Yawa kills all the spirits with her bolo. She also kills Humadapnon and would have left him dead had Anggoy Imbitinan not insisted that she bring him back to life. Humadapnon revived, they all board their biday and sail for home by the Halawod River. There they celebrate the wedding of Malitong Yawa and Humadapnon.

One version of this epic, chanted by Elena Gardoce, was made into a dance drama by the Dagyaw Theater Group of Iloilo City, with choreography by Agnes Locsin and Edwin Duero in 1992.  Written by Gina Barte, Edwin Duero, and Ma. Cecilia Locsin-Nava, updated by Jay Jomar F. Quintos and Peñafrancia Raniela E. Barbaza

 

Sources
