Hangin Hugayong, the wind, flies Burulakaw and Ginbitinan to Tarangban to free Humadapnon but they are unable to. Neither can all the powerful babaylan (shaman) throughout the land. Humadapnon’s two spirit friends, Taghuy and Duwindi, tell Dumalapdap of the one maiden who can match the powers of the binukot of Tarangban. She is Nagmalitong Yawa, who is also the lady whom Humadapnon wishes to marry. Dumalapdap, borne by Hangin Hugayong, flies to her island. Knowing that she will probably refuse to rescue Humadapnon, who means nothing to her, Dumalapdap tells Nagmalitong Yawa that it is her brother Buyong Ginlawudan who is imprisoned in the Tarangban. As they are flying to Tarangban, Hangin Hugayong confesses the truth to Nagmalitong Yawa, who, aggrieved, returns to her kingdom. Taghuy, Duwindi, and Hangin Hugayong, with the help of Nagmalitong Yawa’s musical instruments, the bidya (guitar) and kudyapi (lute), again entreat her to rescue Humadapnon. She grudgingly relents but only on the condition that she would transform into a man. She assumes the name of Buyong Sunmasakay.

Sunmasakay lands at the cave’s door, which the people are still trying to open. He uses his pamlang (psychic powers) to strike it open with the dalugdug (thunder). The well-kept maidens are thus exposed, and their leader, Sinagkating Bulawan, engages in a terrible battle with Buyong Sunmasakay. All the well-kept maidens of Tarangban are killed.

In the seventh room, Buyong Sunmasakay comes upon Malubay Hanginon, and they fight. Malubay Hanginon seeks help from Humadapnon, who gives it because he is still bewitched. In the end, Buyong Sunmasakay’s pamlang overpowers those of Malubay Hanginon and Humadapnon, and he frees Humadapnon from the cave. Father Burulakaw, Mother Ginbitinan, Buyong Dumalapdap, and their subjects from Pan-ay dance with joy. However, Humadapnon remains in a trance.

Sunmasakay prepares for home but is persuaded to stay to awaken Humadapnon. Sunmasakay sends his spirit friends to the urugan (the highest point in the sky) to fetch the water of life and happiness. He conducts a ritual that breaks the spell on Humadapnon. Sunmasakay bids farewell and requests Humadapnon’s parents and brother not to reveal his real identity to him. He transforms himself back into Nagmalitong Yawa and walks through the admiring crowd to where her stone binanugan (hawk’s resting place) waits. She sits on it and crosses her legs as everyone leaves her content in her solitude.

In Tarangban II, Humadapnon must recapture the heirloom biday (boat), named Timpara Alimuon, as a requisite to winning the approval of Nagmalitung Yawa’s parents for her hand in marriage. Nagmalitung Yawa agrees to accompany him on the sea voyage on condition that he never forces himself on her. In the course of their journey, Humadapnon politely refuses Balanakon’s invitation to drop by, resists the challenge to fight Dampig Piliw with the help of Nagmalitung Yawa’s magic charms, sails by the place of the dead, and reaches Paglambuhan’s fortress. It is Paglambuhan who keeps Timpara Alimuon in his fortress and is thus the person that Humadapnon must fight.

Throughout the voyage, Humadapnon has tried to seduce Nagmalitong Yawa, to no avail. But as he prepares for battle with Paglambuhan, Nagmalitong Yawa relents and allows some foreplay. She soon stops him, promising that they would resume their lovemaking after he kills Paglambuhan.

The first battle is between Dumalapdap and Paglambuhan’s son, Sumagulung, who is killed by Dumalapdap. The next battle is between the enraged Paglambuhan and Humadapnon, and it lasts for months until Humadapnon weakens. He flies up to the goddess, Ulang Santunilyu, who gives him more courage, strength, and charm. The duel resumes, but it appears that it will last indefinitely until Nagmalitong Yawa distracts Paglambuhan with her fragrance. Humadapnon kills him. The victors now journey back to Halawod, with the heads of the two enemies displayed on the biday’s stern. Humadapnon again tries to make love to Nagmalitong Yawa. She reminds him of the warrior’s code requiring the victor to bed the dead enemy’s widow. Humadapnon accedes, but when he stays more than an hour with the widow, Nagmalitong Yawa leaves him, manning the biday herself. Dumalapdap shouts for Humadapnon, and Hangin flies Humadapnon back to the biday on his shield.

The journey resumes but tension prevails between the two epic heroes. As the biday nears Halawod, Nagmalitong Yawa puts everyone to sleep, covers the biday with a shield of invisibility, and flies back to Halawod. In Halawod, Humadapnon and Dumalapdap meet Nagmalitong Yawa’s parents, Labaw Donggon and Matan-ayon. Their own parents, Burulakaw and Ginbitinan, arrive for the patingog, which is the grand feast for a marriage proposal.

Dumalapdap falls in love with Sibyang Alon, who is forbidden to him because she is a goddess. After the wedding, Humadapnon leaves Nagmalitong Yawa to accompany Dumalapdap on a journey for Huyung Adlaw’s hand in marriage.

Meanwhile, Paglambuhan and Sumagulung, who have come back to life, tell Matan-ayon that Humadapnon is dead. Matan-ayon compels the reluctant Nagmalitong Yawa to marry Sumagulung by making her pregnant. Humadapnon returns to Halawod and kills Sumagulung, Paglambuhan, and Nagmalitong Yawa. The grieving Humadapnon returns to Panay. At Humadapnon’s remorseful pleading, Labing Anyag brings Nagmalitong Yawa back to life by endowing her with the breath of life, strength of existence, conscience, feelings, intelligence, and compassion. After some resistance, she agrees to return to Humadapnon. Humadapnon receives Labaw Donggon and Matan-ayon’s blessing. Labing Anyag returns to Ginlawudan. The epic ends as Humadapnon and Namaglitong Yawa enter their chamber and close the door behind them.

In the Ulang Udig–Jocano typescript version, Humadapnon is chieftain of the Sulod people and has two brothers: Labaw Donggon and Dumalapdap. He embarks on a journey fraught with trials as he seeks Nagmalitong Yawa, whom he wants for a wife. The rest of the epic recounts how he wins, loses, and again wins Nagmalitong Yawa. These events happen at seven-year intervals, during which he must pass a series of trials. Dumalapdap, his brother, is instrumental in Humadapnon’s first separation from Nagmalitong Yawa, but they also fight shoulder to shoulder at a wedding feast where Nagmalitong Yawa is about to be wed to another man.

In the Barte version, Humadapnon and Dumalapdap are nephews instead of brother to Labaw Donggon, who is a first-generation hero. Humadapnon plays a less aggressive role than his brother Dumalapdap and his wife Nagmalitong Yawa. Here, she takes on a central role as her husband’s rescuer and as mediator in conflicts between the two brothers. In one instance, she engages his enemies in a hand-to-hand combat. Barte’s version of the Humadapnon cycle follows.

Humadapnon dreams of a beautiful woman named Tubigon Daligan-Umis Kuyam-isan, a binukot, who lives in a golden tower surrounded with bamboo thickets. He wakens with the resolve to search for this woman to marry her. His mother Anggoy Imbitinan protests that there are numerous binukot in their own village; but he is adamant, and he prepares for a 10-year journey. Shortly before he leaves, Dumalapdap, his younger brother, is born and insists on accompanying Humadapnon. The brothers anoint their vessel with herbs. From their home at Halawod River, they sail to other places, frequently beset by difficulties, which Dumalapdap overcomes. They reach the river Mabkad, ruled by two datus named Mamang Mangalayo, the prince, and Mamang Dumadakung Dagat, the supreme ruler. Mangalayo occupies the upstream portion, while Dumadakung Dagat occupies the portion at the mouth of the river. The datus block Humadapnon and Dumalapdap’s sailing course. Dumalapdap and Humadapnon introduce themselves as the offspring of Harong Buruwisan, the supreme deity of the seventh layer of the skies, and Anggoy Imbitinan. The two datus, on the other hand, reveal that they are descendants of Pagbuaya, the ruler of the underworld. A battle ensues between the datus when Mangalayo learns that Humadapnon plans to get a binukot. They fight for days, and Humadapnon wins. Mangalayo begs for his life and promises not to block the brothers’ way again. Dumadakang Dagat then engages Humadapnon in a battle in the air, which lasts for several days. Weakened, Humadapnon asks for water from Banogon, the eagle who is his constant companion.

Dumalapdap, left on earth, sees his brother weakening and flies to his rescue. Meanwhile, along the shores of the river Makutay-kutay, Abyang Baranogon and his younger brother Padanong Palinti are having a drink. They are the sons of Labaw Donggon and cousins of Humadapnon and Dumalapdap. Pandanong Palinti goes down to the river to catch fish only to find it overflowing with blood. When he casts his net, he catches a stranger’s head. He rushes to his brother to recount the incident. Thinking that their cousins are in trouble, the brothers rush to the scene of the battle. Baranogon takes Dumalapdap’s place against Dumadakung Dagat. With the help of their ancestors in heaven, Baranogon defeats Dumadakung Dagat. Having killed Dumadakung Dagat, Baranogon asks Dumalapdap to give him Tubigan Daligan, Dumadakung Dagat’s binukot, in exchange for his sister Malitong Yawa. Dumalapdap refers Baranogon to Humadapnon, who consents.

Dumalapdap decides to go on his own journey. Humadapnon refuses to accompany him, for he has not yet met his binukot. Dumalapdap goes to the house of Mamang Tumpong Langit, the ruler of the river Mabun-ag. Finding him asleep, Dumalapdap casts a spell over him to make him go on sleeping and enters the room of the binukot Huyohuyong Adlaw. When Tumpong Langit discovers that his binukot has been stolen, he appeals to his brothers for help. He challenges Dumalapdap to a combat, which lasts for many days and nights.

Meanwhile, Baronogon and Padanog Palinti reach the river Maragkot where Abyang Mangalayo, whom Humadapnon defeated, blocks their path. Baranogon and Mangalayo fight, but this time Mangalayo’s life is not spared. Baranogon claims Mangalayo’s binukot but refrains from laying a hand on her, because he still has great obligations to meet. The two datus reach the place of Abyang Lumbanglantang at Mabun-ag river. There they threaten to kill Lumbanglantang if he does not give them his binukot Labi-labing Anyang. Fearing for his life, Lumbanglantang does not resist the datus. Later, the datus reach the river Baliwagan, where they demand the binukot Layalayang Sukla. Abyang Sumagorong gives her up without a fight. However, Sumagorong journeys to win the hand of Malitong Yawa, Baranogon’s sister. By the time Baranogon returns to his place, Sumagorong has already offered his bridal gifts. Realizing that Sumagorong may have gained an edge over Humadapnon in winning his sister’s hand, Baranogon makes a copy of Malitong Yawa shaped out of dough made from powdered rice. He then instructs his sister to go to Humadapnon’s younger sister at the Halawod River. The following day, Humadapnon presents his suit for the hand of Malitong Yawa. Malitong Yawa’s mother Matanayon favors Sumagorong. However, as Sumagorong and the replica are spending their honeymoon, Baranogon tells Humadapnon that the real Malitong Yawa is still his. Meanwhile, Dumalapdap weakens in his battle with Mamang Tumpong Langit. He sends a messenger to inform Humadapnon about his plight. Humadapnon rushes to his aid and takes his place, but it is the ancestors who again settle the match. Dumalapdap expresses his gratitude and tells Baronogon that on his way he has seen Labaw Donggon, Baronogon’s father, being kept a prisoner by Mamang Magtangub, a malignant spirit residing in the mountain caves. Dumalapdap, Humadapnon, and Baranogon head for Magtangub’s mountain fortress to free Labaw Donggon, only to find him a heap of bones. Baranogon demands that Magtangub return his father to life. Revived, Labaw Donggon engages Magtangub in a combat that lasts for many days. Labaw Donggon triumphs with the help of his ancestors.

The datus sail home. On their way, however, they pass by caves inhabited by enchanted spirits. Humadapnon is seduced and decides to stay awhile. He is bewitched and imprisoned by the spirits. Dumalapdap asks for help from his mother, Anggoy Imbitinan, to rescue Humadapnon. All the binukot respond to the call for help, but Malitong Yawa alone succeeds in opening the cave’s stone door. Malitong Yawa kills all the spirits with her bolo. She also kills Humadapnon and would have left him dead had Anggoy Imbitinan not insisted that she bring him back to life. Humadapnon revived, they all board their biday and sail for home by the Halawod River. There they celebrate the wedding of Malitong Yawa and Humadapnon.

One version of this epic, chanted by Elena Gardoce, was made into a dance drama by the Dagyaw Theater Group of Iloilo City, with choreography by Agnes Locsin and Edwin Duero in 1992.  Written by Gina Barte, Edwin Duero, and Ma. Cecilia Locsin-Nava, updated by Jay Jomar F. Quintos and Peñafrancia Raniela E. Barbaza

text:
(Change). Published 2000. Author, Allan Popa. Quezon City: Artista Publications.

The 43 poems in this collection deal with mortality, transcendence, and loss of innocence, framed in dramatic situations. Many are set in Catanduanes, Popa’s birthplace. Some foreground rituals and events rooted in Catholicism and call for knowledge of local space, folklore, and religion for their proper understanding.

The opening poem, “Signos” (Sign), introduces the theme of human vulnerability to external and internal crises using the storm as a symbol. The threat that a storm poses is magnified further by the poem’s likening it to an eagle about to snatch an unsuspecting prey. Layered and complex symbols are common to the poems and are of a piece with the motif of change or metamorphosis that runs through the collection.

Poems about the connection between death and resurrection follow, three of which are “Lazaro” (Lazarus), “Tinatawag Minsan na Rosas ang Sugat sa Tagiliran ni Kristo” (The Wound on the Side of Christ Is Sometimes Called a Rose), and “La Muwerte” (Death). The first poem dramatizes the moment of Lazarus’s resurrection and emphasizes the irony that Christ, who performs the miracle, will himself confront death soon. The second poem describes Christ’s superhuman struggle with death as he hangs on the cross. Only the roselike wound on his side, the poem proposes, enables him finally to break free and rise to heaven’s light and to eternity. The third poem has a young boy watching in fascination, as he holds on to his mother’s skirt, the figure of Death leading Christ’s funeral procession during the Lenten season in his hometown.

Hunos has a playful section, titled “Mga Dila ng Apoy” (Tongues of Fire), which consists of five poems. These are apostrophes made by anthropomorphic firecrackers—watusi, kuwitis, perminante, sinturon ni Hudas, and luses—addressed to a divine being, presumably God. All of them wish to reunite with the One or God. Each of them reflects on the significance of its light, all the while knowing that death is the only way to make real its aspirations.

Popa becomes personal in “Ang Bata sa Likod Bahay” (The Sibling at the Backyard) and “Sayaw ng Puting Panyo” (Dance of the White Kerchief). He presents his thoughts on mortality to a dead elder sibling buried in the backyard and to a playmate who died during the long summer vacation and is sorely missed during a game. Popa reimagines the dying moments of two writers—Sylvia Plath and Arthur Rimbaud—in the poems “Kay Sylvia Plath” (To Sylvia Plath) and “Ang Tawag” (The Call). In the first poem, suicide is depicted as an acrobatic act, a performance considered horrific by the very society that provokes it. In the second poem, death becomes the sea, a mirage that invites the writer to let go of all earthly struggle and to surrender to the beautiful invitation from eternity itself.

Popa’s first collection of poems evinces his remarkable talent, which subsequent collections would confirm. His poems are a subtle revelation of insights into mortality and transcendence. Popa belongs to the modernist school and is informed by contemporary literary theory, consciously veering away from the direct and didactic style of his immediate predecessors. He used rhyme and meter only in two poems: “Terza Rima” and “Tinatawag Minsan na Rosas ang Sugat sa Tagiliran ni Kristo.” Popa brings new cadences to Tagalog poetry and a fresh approach to old themes.  Written by Romulo Baquiran Jr

text:
(Adarna Bird) aka Salita at Buhay na Pinagdaanan nang Tatlong Principeng Magkakapatid na Anak nang Haring Fernando at nang Reina Valeriana sa Kahariang Berbania (History and Life Experienced by Three Princes Brothers Who Are Sons of King Fernando and Queen Valeriana in the Kingdom of Berbania). Published 1900. Anonymous. Editor, Marcelo Garcia. Manila:

Limabagan nang La Democracia. A later edition in Manila: Philippine Book Company, 1947. Three other Tagalog editions published by other publishing houses. Also available in Kapampangan, Bikol, Ilocano, and Ilonggo.

This is an awit (metrical romance), about the search for a magic bird by three princes—Don Pedro, Don Diego, and Don Juan—sons of King Fernando and Queen Valeriana of the kingdom of Berbania. One night the king dreams that his youngest son, his favorite, is killed treacherously and then thrown into a deep well. This dream grieves the king so much he falls ill. One doctor tells the king that only the singing of the Adarna bird can cure him. This bird can be found on Mount Tabor and perches on a tree called Piedras Platas. The eldest brother sets out to look for this magic bird but after three months’ wandering, his horse falls from exhaustion after the steep climb to Mount Tabor. He finds the tree and keeps watch by it. At midnight the bird comes. It molts and its feathers change to a beautiful color. Then it sings so sweetly that the weary prince, reclining on the tree trunk, falls asleep. The bird sings seven times, its feathers changing color before each song. After singing, the bird defecates, and its droppings fall on the prince, who turns to stone. The second prince follows a year later, but the same fate befalls him.

Only the kind and pious youngest son Don Juan, who is also the king’s favorite, succeeds in catching the Adarna bird because he passes the test of kindness set upon him by a leper, who turns out to be a hermit. This old man instructs him on how to remain awake during the singing of the bird. He gave Juan seven calamansi and a razor blade. Juan is to cut himself and squeeze some calamansi juice to the wound every time the bird sings. He is to avoid having the bird’s droppings fall on him so that he will not turn to stone. The hermit then gives Juan a golden strap with which to tie the bird after he catches it. Juan does as the hermit instructs, and he is successful. The hermit further instructs him to pour water on the two slabs of stone lying under the tree, and the stones come to life as Don Pedro and Don Diego.

As the three brothers journey home, the two older brothers fall upon Juan and leave him almost dead by the roadside. When they reach home, the bird refuses to sing and loses its feathers. The king becomes even more ill. Meanwhile, Juan is cured by an old man who sends him home after telling him that his father is still sick. When Don Juan arrives home, the bird sings and the king gets well. The two older brothers are saved from punishment by Juan who pleads clemency for them.

The king charges his three sons with the guarding of the bird. Once more, the older brothers plot against Juan. They release the bird when it is Juan’s turn to guard it. Juan is so afraid of his father’s wrath that he sets out to look for the bird. When the king discovers the loss of the bird, he sends out his two older sons to look for Juan. They find Juan in the mountain of Armenia and decide to stay there with him. One day the three brothers discover a well with a long rope lying beside it. They decide to descend into the well to explore it. Only Don Juan reaches the bottom and discovers another world there. He rescues two captive princesses: Doña Juana from a giant, and her sister Doña Leonora from a seven-headed serpent. Don Pedro and Don Diego pull the three of them up. When they are about to go, Leonora discovers that she has left her ring below. Don Juan goes back for it but Don Pedro, who has fallen in love with Leonora, cuts the rope to the well. The grieving Leonora releases her pet wolf to look for Juan and heal him.

In Berbania, the two brothers fabricate a story of how they never found Juan but instead rescued two princesses. Don Diego and Juana are married, but Leonora asks for a delay of seven years on the pretext that she has to fulfill a vow. Meanwhile, the magic wolf finds Juan and heals him. With the aid of Leonora’s ring, the wolf, and the Blessed Virgin, Juan is able to get out of the well.

He rests under a tree, on which the Adarna bird alights and sings to him of Princess Maria, lovelier than Princess Leonora and the youngest daughter of King Salermo of the kingdom of Crystal. He sets out to find her and is helped first by an old man who feeds him wondrous food and then instructs him to go to the seventh mountain. The old man also hands him a piece of garment. Two hermits in succession, each older than the preceding one, recognize the piece of cloth as a remnant of Jesus’s clothing. Each summons the animals in his dominion to inquire about the kingdom of Crystal but no animal can help, until an eagle, arriving late, remarks that he has just come from the kingdom of Crystal. The eagle flies Juan there.

Juan is instructed by the eagle to hide near the princesses’ bathrooms. They soon arrive, dressed in dove feathers. After they have been undressed and entered their respective bathrooms, Juan takes Maria’s feathers. He succeeds in winning Maria’s love, but she points to piles of stones surrounding the palace, telling him that they are suitors whom her father has defeated and enchanted. She instructs him on how he is to deal with her father. The king gives Juan seven impossible tasks, all of which Maria, by the power of her white magic, actually performs. When the king decides to have Juan killed by his brother in England, Maria suggests that she and Juan flee to Berbania. They are pursued by the king, but Maria throws objects, which become obstacles. The couple escapes, but the father puts a curse on Maria so that Juan will not remember her.

Sure enough, when Juan leaves Maria outside the city to get a carriage, he forgets her. Preparations are made for Juan’s wedding to Leonora. Maria, however, arrives on the day of the wedding and tries to reawaken Juan’s memory by means of two Negro puppets who are made to converse and dance. Juan finally remembers Maria. Both Maria and Leonora lay claim on him. After much debate, Leonora is persuaded to marry Don Pedro. A double wedding is held, after which Don Pedro is crowned king of Berbania while Juan goes home with Maria to the kingdom of Crystal. There they find out that Maria’s father and two sisters have died. Maria then releases from enchantment all her father’s victims, and the kingdom becomes populous once more. The couple is crowned king and queen.

Ibong Adarna is one of the greatest favorites among Philippine metrical romances. This is also the reason no analogue to the whole story has been found but only to the three main parts into which the plot is divided: the quest for a magic bird, the descent into a well and the rescue of two captive maiden, and the obstacle flight and the forgotten fiancée.

Ibong Adarna has been made into film at least twice: by Vicente Salumbides, starring Mila del Sol and Fred Cortez for LVN in 1941, and by Manuel Conde, starring Nida Blanca and Nestorde Villa for LVN in 1955; into ballets, by Remedios de Oteyza and Inday Gaston-Mañosa for Hariraya Dance Company in 1970, and by Edna Vida for Ballet Philippines in 1990; into a play by Rene O. Villanueva for Bulwagang Gantimpala in 1989; and a puppet play by Rene O. Villanueva for Black Theater Philippines in 1984.  Written by Damiana Eugenio

 

 

Sources

Eugenio, Damiana. 1987. Awit and Corrido: Philippine Metrical Romances. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

Fansler, Dean. 1921. Filipino Popular Tales. Philadelphia: American Folklore Society

He finds the tree and keeps watch by it. At midnight the bird comes. It molts and its feathers change to a beautiful color. Then it sings so sweetly that the weary prince, reclining on the tree trunk, falls asleep. The bird sings seven times, its feathers changing color before each song. After singing, the bird defecates, and its droppings fall on the prince, who turns to stone. The second prince follows a year later, but the same fate befalls him.

Only the kind and pious youngest son Don Juan, who is also the king’s favorite, succeeds in catching the Adarna bird because he passes the test of kindness set upon him by a leper, who turns out to be a hermit. This old man instructs him on how to remain awake during the singing of the bird. He gave Juan seven calamansi and a razor blade. Juan is to cut himself and squeeze some calamansi juice to the wound every time the bird sings. He is to avoid having the bird’s droppings fall on him so that he will not turn to stone. The hermit then gives Juan a golden strap with which to tie the bird after he catches it. Juan does as the hermit instructs, and he is successful. The hermit further instructs him to pour water on the two slabs of stone lying under the tree, and the stones come to life as Don Pedro and Don Diego.

As the three brothers journey home, the two older brothers fall upon Juan and leave him almost dead by the roadside. When they reach home, the bird refuses to sing and loses its feathers. The king becomes even more ill. Meanwhile, Juan is cured by an old man who sends him home after telling him that his father is still sick. When Don Juan arrives home, the bird sings and the king gets well. The two older brothers are saved from punishment by Juan who pleads clemency for them.

The king charges his three sons with the guarding of the bird. Once more, the older brothers plot against Juan. They release the bird when it is Juan’s turn to guard it. Juan is so afraid of his father’s wrath that he sets out to look for the bird. When the king discovers the loss of the bird, he sends out his two older sons to look for Juan. They find Juan in the mountain of Armenia and decide to stay there with him. One day the three brothers discover a well with a long rope lying beside it. They decide to descend into the well to explore it. Only Don Juan reaches the bottom and discovers another world there. He rescues two captive princesses: Doña Juana from a giant, and her sister Doña Leonora from a seven-headed serpent. Don Pedro and Don Diego pull the three of them up. When they are about to go, Leonora discovers that she has left her ring below. Don Juan goes back for it but Don Pedro, who has fallen in love with Leonora, cuts the rope to the well. The grieving Leonora releases her pet wolf to look for Juan and heal him.

In Berbania, the two brothers fabricate a story of how they never found Juan but instead rescued two princesses. Don Diego and Juana are married, but Leonora asks for a delay of seven years on the pretext that she has to fulfill a vow. Meanwhile, the magic wolf finds Juan and heals him. With the aid of Leonora’s ring, the wolf, and the Blessed Virgin, Juan is able to get out of the well.

He rests under a tree, on which the Adarna bird alights and sings to him of Princess Maria, lovelier than Princess Leonora and the youngest daughter of King Salermo of the kingdom of Crystal. He sets out to find her and is helped first by an old man who feeds him wondrous food and then instructs him to go to the seventh mountain. The old man also hands him a piece of garment. Two hermits in succession, each older than the preceding one, recognize the piece of cloth as a remnant of Jesus’s clothing. Each summons the animals in his dominion to inquire about the kingdom of Crystal but no animal can help, until an eagle, arriving late, remarks that he has just come from the kingdom of Crystal. The eagle flies Juan there.

Juan is instructed by the eagle to hide near the princesses’ bathrooms. They soon arrive, dressed in dove feathers. After they have been undressed and entered their respective bathrooms, Juan takes Maria’s feathers. He succeeds in winning Maria’s love, but she points to piles of stones surrounding the palace, telling him that they are suitors whom her father has defeated and enchanted. She instructs him on how he is to deal with her father. The king gives Juan seven impossible tasks, all of which Maria, by the power of her white magic, actually performs. When the king decides to have Juan killed by his brother in England, Maria suggests that she and Juan flee to Berbania. They are pursued by the king, but Maria throws objects, which become obstacles. The couple escapes, but the father puts a curse on Maria so that Juan will not remember her.

Sure enough, when Juan leaves Maria outside the city to get a carriage, he forgets her. Preparations are made for Juan’s wedding to Leonora. Maria, however, arrives on the day of the wedding and tries to reawaken Juan’s memory by means of two Negro puppets who are made to converse and dance. Juan finally remembers Maria. Both Maria and Leonora lay claim on him. After much debate, Leonora is persuaded to marry Don Pedro. A double wedding is held, after which Don Pedro is crowned king of Berbania while Juan goes home with Maria to the kingdom of Crystal. There they find out that Maria’s father and two sisters have died. Maria then releases from enchantment all her father’s victims, and the kingdom becomes populous once more. The couple is crowned king and queen.

Ibong Adarna is one of the greatest favorites among Philippine metrical romances. This is also the reason no analogue to the whole story has been found but only to the three main parts into which the plot is divided: the quest for a magic bird, the descent into a well and the rescue of two captive maiden, and the obstacle flight and the forgotten fiancée.

Ibong Adarna has been made into film at least twice: by Vicente Salumbides, starring Mila del Sol and Fred Cortez for LVN in 1941, and by Manuel Conde, starring Nida Blanca and Nestorde Villa for LVN in 1955; into ballets, by Remedios de Oteyza and Inday Gaston-Mañosa for Hariraya Dance Company in 1970, and by Edna Vida for Ballet Philippines in 1990; into a play by Rene O. Villanueva for Bulwagang Gantimpala in 1989; and a puppet play by Rene O. Villanueva for Black Theater Philippines in 1984.  Written by Damiana Eugenio

text:
(Knocked on the Head). Published 2008. Author, Victor N. Sugbo. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

The poems in Inintokan might be said to describe the poetic journey which begins with the spark that triggers the poetic act. The title, the poet explains, derives from the root word intok, “to knock against or into something,” and the process of writing a poem “is similar to that of being hit by something—a thought, a memory, or a wave of feeling—that takes a small chip out of our humanity and changes us.” The person who experiences intok goes through three stages: nasabud, when she or he knocks against something; natinggiran, when something of the person is chipped off as a result of being nasabud; and nakalambre, when she or he is “knocked into something to the point of breaking.” The poems are arranged into three parts, corresponding to these three stages.

“Nasabud” contains eight poems dealing with momentary sensations that leave a powerful imprint on the consciousness. In “Hingyap” (Desire), the poet talks about his impossible wish to attain the world so he may possess the beloved. In “Banabana” (Approximations), the lover calculates the cost of attaining the object of desire and realizes that not distance nor time but fear is his enemy. In “Alok” (Witch), Sugbo depicts the poetic impulse as a fearsome and powerful witch who ambushes one with fireflies and scintillating lights when one’s defenses are down.

In the second part, “Natinggiran,” the poet becomes more contemplative. A complex metaphor appears in the poem “Paghipos han Rosal” (To Keep a Gardenia). After a flower blossoms and its fragrance disperses in the air, one realizes that the loss has made him its captive forever.

The third section is titled “Nakalambre,” an extreme state of agitation that impels the poetic expression. “Engkantada” (Enchanted) expresses sadness at the flight of wonder. The poet personifies wonder as a spirit, whose absence from the land causes all living things to shrink and wither, and people to become restless and lose harmony among themselves and with nature. The poet appeals to the lost spirit to return.

There is a homey feel to the book for the Waray reader, who will readily recognize Sugbo’s personae, names he calls out with such warmth—Inse Medying, Apoy Mundo, Islaw, Apoy Toyong, Na Talina, Manoy Intek, Ingko Goyong—and places smelling of earth and morning dew, like Marrokporok, Hindang, Borongan, Balangiga, Calbiga. These are sites of the native memory.

To be sure, it is not always all sweetness and light in these beloved landscapes. In “Dalan nga Langitnon” (Heaven’s Road), Sugbo sarcastically puts down the pretentiousness of a holier-than-thou society. “An Tawo nga Tamsi nga Sinmayaw Didto han Dinagyang ha Iloilo” (The Birdman Who Danced during the Dinagyang Festival in Iloilo) details the poet’s insight into the physical effort required to make a myth come alive and to feed the cloddish popular imagination with it.

These occasional outbursts, however, are apropos to Sugbo’s primary insight: healing and redemption are immanent in nature and communal interrelationship. Inintokan is a poet’s paean as he journeys through the landscapes of his known home in his own native shore.  Written by Merlie M. Alunan

text:
(A Stretch of Sky). Published 1961. Author, Amado V. Hernandez. Manila: Makabayan News Feature. Included in Amado V. Hernandez: Tudla at Tudling, edited by Rosario Torres-Yu. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press, 1986.

This is a collection of 179 poems, which earned for the writer the Republic Cultural Heritage Award for Literature in 1962. The title poem, “Isang Dipang Langit,” is a meditation on the poet’s prison experience, as well as an affirmation of his boundless faith in the cause of freedom. Hernandez was jailed in the 1950s by the Philippine government for the crime of “rebellion complex,” a conviction later overturned by the Supreme Court for being unconstitutional. Released after having served his term, Hernandez became active again in the political movement of the 1960s and 1970s. By that time, the poems he had written during his career as activist, labor leader, and proletarian writer were enjoying wide popularity. Some of his works were favored declamation pieces in rallies and demonstrations, while others were set to music.

The imagery in the poems alludes to the narrow slice of the sky which the prisoner sees as he languishes in the cramped bartolina or maximum security cell. The poems in this collection are presented in nine thematic sections: humanity, things, time, love, prison, freedom, experience, mother tongue, and Parnassus, the last consisting of Pilipino translations of foreign poems. The collection offers an insight into the wide range of Hernandez’s poetic diction ranging across several traditions—from the romantic strain traceable to Francisco "Balagtas" Baltazar to the polemical voice of social criticism that began with Jose Rizal and the revolutionary writer of the past.

In deciding to bestow the Cultural Heritage Award on Hernandez for Isang Dipang Langit, the subcommittee on literature declared that “Hernandez’s achievement is often equal to Villa’s and sometimes greater” and that his poetry “does not blink from the facts of life in the most sordid sense possible of that cliché, and yet affirms the prevalence of spirit.”

The award was a recognition of Hernandez’s worth as a citizen whose best literary works and lifelong engagement with social issues gave “committed literature” new heights of respectability and potency in this country. Hernandez has been immortalized by poems other than the title poem, such as “Panata sa Kalayaan” (Oath to Freedom), “Bilanggo” (Prisoner), and “Kung Tuyo Na ang Luha Mo, Inang Bayan” (When Your Tears Run Dry, My Country). That his poems continue to be recited or sung and inspire a new generation of Filipino writers may well be his greatest recognition.  Written by Rosario Torres-Yu and Edgardo Maranan

text:
Published 2003. Author, Paolo Manalo. With notes by the author. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press. Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature, first prize, poetry in English.

This collection of poetry is a testament to the fluidity and importance of language. The poet mixes Filipino expressions within his English poems, satirizing the way Filipinos garble the two languages and view such deviations from the standard. Manalo reproduces the language of the jolog, the uncool segment of the population who are deliberately, even defiantly, so. In thus demonstrating how this language functions within a different set of rules, he points out the method in the madness of language and the arbitrariness of signifiers.

On the other hand, the poems’ many-layered meanings, hence their texture, are actually created by the jolog language. Manalo replaces the metaphor in poetry with metonymy. The result can sometimes be hilarious and other times poignant. In the poem “Peksman” (Promise), he uses the homonyms “hilaw,” “hilo,” and “hello” in one line, making readers appreciate their sonic and visual qualities, on the one hand, and their varied semantic values, on the other. The poem “Echolalia” pokes fun at filler words that Filipinos often use in speech like “bale,” “kwan,” and “ano.”

The poems therefore defy literal translation because they are themselves literal translations of Filipino slang and idiomatic expressions into English. Any earnest attempt to translate them faithfully back into Filipino would only miss the intended joke of the original and thus cause unintentional hilarity.

The collection has two poetic sequences. The first one is “Nosi Balasi” (an inversion of “sino ba sila,” slang for “who are they”), which is about the Italian master Giotto’s vain attempts at capturing the life of Christ in his paintings. The sequence includes a joke about believers trying to determine who the true god is and the problems posed by the Immaculate Conception to both mother and son, and refers to Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), Jose Rizal’s masterpiece. The sequence ends with a reference to Japanese painter Shusaku Arakawa, known for his technique of including diagrams in his paintings which pose philosophical theories, but in this poem he decides to leave the canvas blank.

This theme is continued in the sequence titled “The Little Cancer Cells,” a group of poems showing the many problems associated with Rizal’s status as national hero and with attempts to capture his life and times accurately. The sequence—which is in a mix of English, Spanish, and German—begins with the declaration, “That which I read but could not contain.” It is a reference to the futility of rendering in art or poetry a person whose mystery deepens with every revelation about him. In the end, even artists can only imagine what Rizal must have been like.

The poems in this collection are language games; but, very much like the diagrams in Shusaku Arakawa’s paintings, they too are philosophical notes on the nature of art, poetry, and life.  Written by Jose Miguel Arguelles

article_title: Mga Kagila-gilalas na Pakikipagsapalaran: Mga Tulang Nahalungkat sa Bukbuking Baul
text:
(The Amazing Adventures: Poems Retrieved from a Woodtick-Ridden Chest). Published 1979. Author, Jose F. Lacaba. Manila: Kabbala.

The poet was a member of the group of Ateneo poets called bagay (literally, “thing”), who championed a “minimalist” approach to poetry by writing in spare style or on “objectivist”—as opposed to metaphorical—themes. Lacaba eventually became identified with politicized literature, but the deceptive simplicity that was the hallmark of bagay poetry became the signature style of his social-realist poems, most of which are in this collection.

Lacaba’s poems speak of common people, familiar places, ordinary relationships, commonplace events, familiar objects and animals, folktales, religious beliefs and practices, and the like. But in Lacaba, the treatment of the commonplace is uncommon. It is replete with acerbic wit, raunchy humor, or bitter irony. When Lacaba turns on a disturbing, unusual event, such as in “Santong Paspasan” (By Force), a poem about a gang-raped virgin, the matter-of-fact juxtaposition of grim humor, naturalistic images, political news, and human cruelty takes on surrealist proportions and climaxes in a scathing, yet understated, indictment of human behavior and the system.

The collection has three sections. Each section has a brief time frame and a popular quotation from Balagtas for its title, thus: “1962-1964: ‘Sa Isang Madilim, Gubat na Mapanglaw’” (1962-1964: In a Forest, Dark and Primeval); “1965-1969: ‘At Dito sa Laot ng Dusa’t Hinagpis’” (And Here in the Sea of Suffering and Remorse); “1970-1972: ‘Sa Loob at Labas ng Bayan Kong Sawi’” (1970-1972: Throughout My Pitiful Country).

Included in the book is “Paksiw na Ayungin” (Vinegar-Cooked Fish). A 23-line heptasyllabic poem, this piece wittily assumes an aphoristic and didactic tone in ostensibly teaching the reader the aesthetics and economics of eating the ayungin, a poor person’s fish cooked in vinegar and ginger. The poem’s last two lines resonate like a proverb on poverty: “Payat man ang ayungin, pabigat din sa tiyan” (Though the ayungin be scanty, it fills a space in the tummy).

In the last poem in the collection, “Ang mga Kagila-gilalas na Pakikipagsapalaran ni Juan de la Cruz” (The Amazing Adventures of Juan de la Cruz), the Filipino Everyperson, a penniless, well-dressed but hungry vagabond, encounters various social types and attitudes on a surreal odyssey one dark night: a bus conductor curses him for smoking, a wall tells him not to urinate on the wayside, a Chinese restaurant fills up his tummy with scents from its delicacies, a theater refuses to honor his movie pass. In Congress a siga or bully tells him to beware of the dog, the palace guard and gardener keep him off the grass, and a pimp drives him away unsated because he has no money for a whore. Juan attempts suicide, but the sea by the boulevard says it does not accept garbage; he enters a church to seek some answers and, finding none, Juan, now dressed in tatters, still penniless and unspeakably hungry, goes up the mountain of Arayat, the legendary lair of rebels and social bandits. The poem ends with the military blaming the student activists for agitating peaceful citizens like Juan de la Cruz to become insurgents.

The “amazing adventures” in Lacaba’s poetry refers as much to the writer’s uncommon ways of dealing with protest, as to the lives of the simple folk whom he situates in conditions of common and uncommon pain. This poem was dramatized by the UP Repertory Company, setting the form for the so-called dula-tula or play-poem in the 1970s.   Written by Edgardo Maranan

text:
(Fist: Protest Literature 1970-1986; Poetry). Published 1987. Editors, Reuel Molina Aguila, Herminio S. Beltran Jr, Alfrredo Navarro Salanga, Marra PL. Lanot, and Lilia Quindoza-Santiago. With an introduction by Lilia Quindoza-Santiago. Manila: Cultural Center of the Philippines.

Kamao, the clenched fist of protest, is the title of a series of anthologies (poetry, short story, drama) of the literature of protest in the Philippines. This is the first, and in it are the foreword and introduction that apply to all three. The foreword reveals the occasion for publication: the first anniversary of the fall of the Marcos regime, and the end of the First CCP Festival of the Arts in Feb 1987, underscoring “the major role that Filipino artists played from 1969 to February 1986” by highlighting “the arts of protest” once banned as “subversive.”

The introduction by Lilia Quindoza-Santiago, “Panitikan ng Protesta: Istorya at Estetika” (Literature of Protest: History and Aesthetics), explains the periodization: 1970-72 opens with the First Quarter Storm, but is backgrounded by the new writing heralded by Mga Agos sa Disyerto (Streams in the Desert), 1964, the bagay poets of Ateneo, and the manlilikha group of the University of the East, who met in the founding of Panulat para sa Kaunlaran ng Sambayanan (PAKSA), and its declaration of the writers’ involvement in the politics of the time. The second period opens with the declaration of martial law in 1972 and ends with the Aquino assassination in 1983, and is filled with poems published or circulated even under the regime’s supervision and suppression, as creative “literature of circumvention.” The years 1983-86 cover the Aquino assassination—and open protest—to the EDSA event and a new political regime, in which the writers included many who had not previously acknowledged “the value of political issues in poetry.”

The aesthetics of this literature of protest has three major characteristics: first, innovations in the structure of language, Filipino, proceeding from the demands of time and society; second, a clear political stance; and third, a rejection of traditional viewpoints, manners, poetics. The mark of the writer of protest literature, says Quindoza-Santiago, is the placing of self “on the other side,” and thus against the establishment and its set perceptions and power structures.

The 1970-72 period includes such poets as Lamberto Antonio, Bienvenido L. Lumbera, Gelacio Guillermo, Jose Lacaba, Rogelio Mangahas, Epifanio SanJuan Jr, Rolando S. Tinio, Emmanuel Torres, and Cirilo Bautista. Among those in the 1972-83 era are some in the first, and Mila D. Aguilar, Ma. Lorena Barros, Tomas F. Agulto, Emmanuel Lacaba, Valerio Nofuente, Francisco “Soc” Rodrigo, Romulo Sandoval, Jose Ma. Sison, Jesus Manuel Santiago, Virgilio Vitug, Don Pagusara, Teo Antonio, and the pseudonymous “underground” poets Clarita Roja, Kris Montañez, Mano de Verdades Posadas, Ruben Cuevas, and Servando Magbanua. The 1983-86 period includes many of the above, as well as Gemino Abad, Albert Alejo, SJ, Juaniyo Arcellana, Joey Ayala, Ed de la Torre, Ricardo de Ungria, Eric Gamalinda, Alan Jazmines, Jason Montana, Marne Kilates, Ma. Fatima Lim, Danton Remoto, Lina S. Reyes, Benilda Santos, Ramon Vicente Sunico, and Alfred Yuson.

The names and their recurrence or emergence in particular periods tell their own story. The 210 works on events, people, structures, and feelings—in prison, in hiding, individually and in sum—document the effects of society on the poet, and the poet’s on society, as well as express potently the spirit and poetics of protest in contemporary Philippines.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez

text:
(Crystal Universe). Published 1989. Author, Rolando S. Tinio. With a preface by the author. Quezon City: Office of Research and Publications, Ateneo de Manila University.

According to the poet’s preface, this collection of poems, his third, marks his return to the old Philippine poetic tradition, which he describes as “malambing” (affectionately demonstrative) and sentimental. It was a visit to the Soviet Union in 1974 and 1975 that inspired him when he discovered that, contrary to stereotype, the Russian poets exalted love as the beginning and end of all poetry. However, the period in which he wrote these poems, 1974-79, was also the height of the martial law regime, when explicit protest, not personal or private literature, was the dominant mode. Hence, the poems waited 10 years before publication.

The collection is divided into five sections: poems of Tinio’s Russian sojourn; domestic poems; poems of parting and regret; love songs, including Tagalog translations of popular love songs in English; and original lyrics with the lilt and spirit of folk songs.

The opening poem, “Paglapag ng Eroplano sa Moskba” (Upon Landing at Moscow), begins with images so familiar we feel we are at home, especially with similes deriving from Philippine scenes. He likens the airport’s passport control area to cinema or circus ticket booths, fenced by giant fans or seashells of aluminum. It is also a universe of cement and iron and guards in fatigue, not unlike Manila then and even now. Hence, we are surprised when the middle stanza suddenly announces: “Ito na ang Rusya” (This is Russia at last). But the ordinariness continues, with Tinio describing the cacophony of human voices. Tinio singles out some people: two incomprehensible “Bumbay” (Indians) and a blond, scraggly-haired, one-armed Italian. The poem ends with the persona’s apprehension at being in a strange land, but reassurance comes with the sound of someone’s belly laugh.

In “Mula sa Leningrad” (From Leningrad), the persona’s anxiety at missing a rendezvous is heightened by a “diorama” of pine trees unfolding too slowly as he looks out from his train window, and the shattering of a coffee cup that not even its ear-shaped handle can hear above the rumbling of the train. The last line of the poem, which is also the title of the book, captures the fragility of a cosmic order that requires planets to take separate paths to avoid collision.

The first section also includes poems of homesickness, which are addressed to his family: his wife Ella and his two children Tonchi and Bibi. The book’s second section continues Tinio’s expressions of love for his family. Here, the persona as husband and father bares his vulnerability and helplessness, anger and remorse, wonder and awe at the frailty and power of familial love. The first poem, “Pasalitang Awit” (Spoken Song), dedicated to Ella, demonstrates a love so inexpressible it can only be approximated by the magical language of poetry. The last poem in this section is a lullaby to Bibi, in which the tinkle of the ice cream vendor’s bell is a sound of foreboding about the life that awaits every child.

The poems in the third section cover a gamut of conditions and circumstances causing only anguish: a mother dying of cancer, a boulevard and a lost love, an abandoned house, time flying too quickly, an irredeemable mistake, and a departing angel. Despite such subjects, the poet achieves restraint by his control of language and the delicate balance between solid imagery and vaporous feeling.

In this book, Tinio, notwithstanding his declared return to Philippine romantic poetry, adheres consistently to the poetics of the bagay (thing) group, founded in the 1960s by Tagalog modernist poets, of which he was a leading representative. The bagay poem is identifiable by its concrete and surprising imagery, colloquial language, and ordinary scenes, all aimed at producing a minimalist effect. By such means does the title, “Kristal na Uniberso,” appropriately signify the many facets of “love” that Tinio explores in these 49 poems.   Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero

text:
KUDAMAN

Published 1988. Translators, Nicole Revel-Macdonald and Edgardo B. Maranan. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

This is one of the 63 epics of Palawan. Recorded and translated into French by Nicole Revel-Macdonald, it is composed of six songs. To date, only the second song, sung by the bard Usuy, has been translated to Tagalog. It takes seven nights to perform the epic. The first night is used to introduce the epic; each of the six songs takes a night to perform. The hero Kudaman appears after the introductory chant.

By the river Tabunganan is a spring, which is the abode of an evil spirit. Tuwan Putli, accompanied by her cousin Ambaynan, goes there to fish. As they are about to leave, Tuwan Putli sees a river lobster with golden pincers. Ambaynan waits for her, but Tuwan Putli disappears. There is blood in her fish basket. Ambaynan goes home and reports the incident.

Mu-Muta, Tuwan Putli’s father, orders her husband (and his son-in-law) Muta-Muta to search for her, but the man disobeys. Muta-Muta finds help in the person of the Young Man of the Clouds. It is agreed that if the Young Man of the Clouds can find Tuwan Putli, she will be his. With the help of a crocodile, the Young Man of the Clouds finds a fragment of Tuwan Putli’s toenail nestled inside a molar of an old crocodile. The old crocodile had accidentally eaten Tuwan Putli. Retrieving the nail, he sees Mu-Muta, who tells him to bring home the nail fragment. The Young Man puts the nail inside a golden chest. In the afternoon, Tuwan Putli’s voice is heard inside the chest, pleading to be let out. The chest breaks open like a bamboo, filling the house with golden light. Tuwan Putli emerges and asks for a betel nut. Learning that the Young Man has rescued her, she consents to live with him.

Soon, the Young Man falls in love with the Lady of the Sea-Beings, the wife of Kudaman. The Young Man wins her love, forcing his wife, Tuwan Putli, to leave him. Kudaman decides to bring the Lady of the Sea-Beings to her father Surutan Tamparan, the Sultan of the Seacoast. On his journey back aboard Linggisan the Purple Heron, Kudaman meets Tuwan Putli and offers her a betel nut. She accepts, and she becomes his puun or principal wife. When Surutan Tamparan discovers that his daughter has left Kudaman for the Young Man of the Clouds, he beheads her at the place called Scissors of the World. But she emerges from the ordeal lovelier than ever.

Muta-Muta, Tuwan Putli’s first husband, and his brother, the Datu of Ligayan, visit Kudaman to offer a blood compact. Kudaman reminds Muta-Muta that Tuwan Putli is now his wife. Having become Kudaman’s blood brother, Muta-Muta asks to stay in his place. Kudaman agrees, and he has a big house built. Kudaman gathers his relatives and friends and offers to host a big feast of tabad (rice beer).

Kudaman goes on a journey to look for beautiful garments for Tuwan Putli, whom he entrusts to Muta-Muta. Riding on Linggisan, his pet bird, Kudaman travels for seven years. The Lady of the Wild Green Pigeon falls in love with him. The attraction is mutual, so Kudaman promises to return for her. Reaching the house of the Sultan of the Seacoast, Kudaman buys the garments he wants. His former wife expresses renewed yearning for him and his bird, so she is transported to Kudaman’s house, where she is welcomed by Tuwan Putli as sister and co-wife. As he has promised, Kudaman passes by the place of the Lady of the Wild Green Pigeon on his way back. He asks for betel nut, and she offers him her betel-nut container. When she agrees to come with him, he puts her inside his betel container for safekeeping. Tuwan Putli meets him with the news that the Lady of the Sea-Beings has come. Kudaman shows her what he has brought home: a new sister.

Kudaman goes on another journey, entrusting the two women to his principal wife. He encounters the Lady of the Ginuu Tree, who is gripped with admiration for his magnificent bird. Kudaman obtains her, as he did the Lady of the Wild Green Pigeon, but the Lady of the Ginuu Tree makes it clear to the other women that she has no desire to win the hero away from them, and that she has come with him only because she loves his bird.

Having put up his new kolongbanwa or big house, Kudaman wishes to offer a celebration in honor of Ampu, the Master of the Rice. Muta-Muta, Datu Ligayan, and the four linamin or ladies are in agreement. He lays his hands over the mouths of the jars of tabad, and right away, the rice beer ferments. Muta-Muta and Datu Ligayan play their gongs, for this is the music beloved of the Master of the Rice, who bestows sweetness and fragrance to the rice beer. Clad in wondrous garments and ornaments of gold, Kudaman’s four wives dance the tarok, and they prepare the betel chew for their guests. The Young Man of the Clouds hears the music from the feast, and he hastens to join Kudaman. But far away, the dreaded Ilanun also hear the gongs, and they decide to test the mettle of Kudaman and get his wives. Informed through a dream, Kudaman orders the gong music to stop. He does not want violence, for it is an affront to Ampu, the Supreme Master, who is also Nagsalad, the Weaver of the World. He is the picture of calm as he awaits the Ilanun’s arrival, chewing betel as he sits. He invites the Ilanun to come to the house, but they harshly reject the offer.

Muta-Muta loses his restraint and attacks. The Young Man of the Clouds joins him. The leader of the Ilanun and the Young Man of the Clouds duel in the heavens for seven years. Moved by the Young Man’s spirit, Kudaman joins the fray. He entrusts to his grieving wives a bouquet of basil flowers whose wilting or blossoming will signal his state. The ladies plead that Linggasan watch over its master; the bird itself is anguished over Kudaman’s decision to fight. Up in the clouds, astride a ray of sunlight, Kudaman merely observes at first. But when the Young Man of the Clouds falls, he comes to the Young Man’s rescue and puts the Young Man inside his betel container. Then he confronts the Ilanun leader, Apo Tugbu. A battle between them lasts for many years, taking them to several levels of the world. Finally, Kudaman wins. The Ilanun are wiped out.

On their way home, Kudaman and the Young Man of the Clouds pass by the house of Limbuhanan, the hero’s first cousin. They meet the Lady of the Agoho Tree, Limbuhanan’s wife. The couple apologize to Kudaman for having gotten married without notifying him. The Young Man of the Clouds relates the war he and Kudaman have just been through. The Lady of the Agoho Tree offers to accompany the two back home.

Muta-Muta, Datu Ligayan, and the four wives are overjoyed when Kudaman arrives. The interrupted feast resumes. A jural discussion is held, regarding harmonious relationship in marriage, the duties of relatives, and other points of the adat or custom law. Among the guests are the Datu and Lady of the Edge of the World, the Datu and Lady of the Surrounding World, the Datu and Lady of Median Space, the Chief Judge Pinagsaraan and his wife, the Lady of the Luray Tree, the Lady of the Sails, the Lady of the Western Wind, and the Lady of the Atmosphere. The Sultan of the Seacoast arrives with his seven wives, and he is offered the first sip of the tabad. The merriment lasts for three days, but no violence nor rowdiness occurs. Kudaman finds himself in a state of stupor. His being is transported, it seems, to another universe, and the heavens have been cindered by his drunkenness. But he is brought back to consciousness, and, seeing the face of the Lady of the Hooks, he proposes to marry her. Revived, Kudaman chews betel and spits at the dead army of the Ilanun. They are resurrected, and they surrender their weapons as a sign of compact.

Earlier, during the start of the feast, an old conflict over Tuwan Putli between Kudaman and the Chief Judge Pinagsaraan took place. The Lady of the Luray Tree, wife of Pinagsaraan, proposed that Tuwan Putli be cut in two so that the two men could each have half of her. Kudaman takes a blade and slices her. Each half of her becomes a lovelier Tuwan Putli. The Sultan of the Seacoast takes his leave, and the others follow suit, but not before everyone has agreed that there must be another feast in the future.

The rest of the epic contains episodes about Kudaman’s odysseys to distant lands and visitations of friends and relatives, during which great feasts are held. In one of his drunken revelries, having gulped down 180 jars of tabad, Kudaman plummets into the navel of the world and wrestles with himself. In his drunken state, he meets the Lady of the Young Men, who fans his face to bring him back to his senses and offers him betel chew. She becomes his fifth wife. Riding his heron to the ends of the world, Kudaman wins his other wives who are all uniformly described as falling into a swoon at the sight of his magnificent bird. They are the Lady of the Sandbar, who leaves her husband to go with the hero; the Lady of the Last Level of the Universe; the Lady of the Oil of the World; the Lady of the Maiden Space, also married; and the Lady of the Hooks, to whom he had earlier proposed.

Kudaman ends with a final celebration of Kudaman’s marriage to 10 women. At the same time, the Young Man of the Clouds takes the Sultan’s seventh daughter in marriage, and the dowry he gives is a river which begins from the skies and flows right beside the Sultan’s house, while a makopa tree and a pomelo tree bear fruit the whole year round.  Written by Edgardo Maranan

 

Source

Macdonald, Nicole Revel, and Edgardo Maranan. 1988. Kudaman. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

But when the Young Man of the Clouds falls, he comes to the Young Man’s rescue and puts the Young Man inside his betel container. Then he confronts the Ilanun leader, Apo Tugbu. A battle between them lasts for many years, taking them to several levels of the world. Finally, Kudaman wins. The Ilanun are wiped out.

On their way home, Kudaman and the Young Man of the Clouds pass by the house of Limbuhanan, the hero’s first cousin. They meet the Lady of the Agoho Tree, Limbuhanan’s wife. The couple apologize to Kudaman for having gotten married without notifying him. The Young Man of the Clouds relates the war he and Kudaman have just been through. The Lady of the Agoho Tree offers to accompany the two back home.

Muta-Muta, Datu Ligayan, and the four wives are overjoyed when Kudaman arrives. The interrupted feast resumes. A jural discussion is held, regarding harmonious relationship in marriage, the duties of relatives, and other points of the adat or custom law. Among the guests are the Datu and Lady of the Edge of the World, the Datu and Lady of the Surrounding World, the Datu and Lady of Median Space, the Chief Judge Pinagsaraan and his wife, the Lady of the Luray Tree, the Lady of the Sails, the Lady of the Western Wind, and the Lady of the Atmosphere. The Sultan of the Seacoast arrives with his seven wives, and he is offered the first sip of the tabad. The merriment lasts for three days, but no violence nor rowdiness occurs. Kudaman finds himself in a state of stupor. His being is transported, it seems, to another universe, and the heavens have been cindered by his drunkenness. But he is brought back to consciousness, and, seeing the face of the Lady of the Hooks, he proposes to marry her. Revived, Kudaman chews betel and spits at the dead army of the Ilanun. They are resurrected, and they surrender their weapons as a sign of compact.

Earlier, during the start of the feast, an old conflict over Tuwan Putli between Kudaman and the Chief Judge Pinagsaraan took place. The Lady of the Luray Tree, wife of Pinagsaraan, proposed that Tuwan Putli be cut in two so that the two men could each have half of her. Kudaman takes a blade and slices her. Each half of her becomes a lovelier Tuwan Putli. The Sultan of the Seacoast takes his leave, and the others follow suit, but not before everyone has agreed that there must be another feast in the future.

The rest of the epic contains episodes about Kudaman’s odysseys to distant lands and visitations of friends and relatives, during which great feasts are held. In one of his drunken revelries, having gulped down 180 jars of tabad, Kudaman plummets into the navel of the world and wrestles with himself. In his drunken state, he meets the Lady of the Young Men, who fans his face to bring him back to his senses and offers him betel chew. She becomes his fifth wife. Riding his heron to the ends of the world, Kudaman wins his other wives who are all uniformly described as falling into a swoon at the sight of his magnificent bird. They are the Lady of the Sandbar, who leaves her husband to go with the hero; the Lady of the Last Level of the Universe; the Lady of the Oil of the World; the Lady of the Maiden Space, also married; and the Lady of the Hooks, to whom he had earlier proposed.

Kudaman ends with a final celebration of Kudaman’s marriage to 10 women. At the same time, the Young Man of the Clouds takes the Sultan’s seventh daughter in marriage, and the dowry he gives is a river which begins from the skies and flows right beside the Sultan’s house, while a makopa tree and a pomelo tree bear fruit the whole year round.  Written by Edgardo Maranan

article_title: Kung Di Man: Mga Tula ng Pag-Ibig, 1970-1992
text:
(If It Weren’t So: Love Poems, 1970-1992). Published 1992. Author, Elynia S. Mabanglo. With a preface by the author and illustrations by Carol Watanabe. Pasig City: Anvil Publishing, Inc.

The book is a collection of 82 poems divided into four sections. Each section opens with a poem and an illustration that draw parallelisms between the different stages of love and a particular season.

The first section compares the possibilities of love to the promises of spring. The persona is a lover who is “nangangarap” (dreaming) and “punong-puno ng pag-asa” (full of hope), whether she is imploring one to partake in a relationship in “Soneto sa Isang Ginoo” (Sonnet for a Gentleman), pining for affection and intimacy in “Iniisip Ka” (Thinking of You) and “Muli” (Again), waiting for a beloved’s return in “Yakap ng Aking Mahal” (My Love’s Embrace), or offering oneself completely to love in “Sapagkat” (Because) and “Sa Anumang Kalagayan” (In Whatever Circumstance).

In the second section, the consummation of this desire becomes the dominant theme. Mabanglo renders love using elements of summer, depicting it as being bright and burning. Such celebratory mood is found in “Kapirasong Silid” (A Little Room), “Tula, Erotika” (Poem, Erotica), and “Lugod” (Pleasure). The poems express unabashed joy in the lovers’ act of discovering each other’s bodies, often through the use of keen imagery and defamiliarization.

In the third section, autumn is used as a simile to express the anxieties and uncertainties associated with love. In “Sapul Nang Mawala Ka” (Since You Left), “Ang mga Araw na Wala Ka Rito” (The Days When You Are Not Here), and “Nagtatago ang Aking Dila” (My Tongue Is Hiding), the absence of the beloved leaves the persona broken and helpless. In “Nangungulila Ako sa Iyo” (Longing for You), the lover feels insecure despite the presence of the beloved. In “Humihiwa ang mga Salita” (Words Are Sharp), the persona warns of the impending demise of love.

The poems in the fourth section portray the “winter” of love; love is an unvisited grave. The poems convey the woman’s sadness and sense of loss, whether in remembering the past in “Sinasakyan Ko ang Aking Sarili” (I’m Getting Along with Myself), “Sa Alaala” (In Memory), and “Hindi Mo Kilala ang Kalupitang Ito” (You Do Not Know This Cruelty), acknowledging the futility of an affair in “Mindanao” and “Huling Tula Ko Sa Iyo” (My Last Poem for You), or letting go of an unrequited love in “Totoo” (True).

In the final poem, “Kung Ibig Mo Akong Makilala” (If You Want to Know Me), which has been popularized as a song by Susan Fernandez Magno in the 1990s, Mabanglo employs anaphora, entreating the reader to resuscitate love. Thus, the poet offers the possibility of the cycle’s starting again.

The poems in this volume differ radically from the traditional love poems written by the likes of Iñigo Ed. Regalado or Jose Corazon de Jesus. Where the older poems were spilling over with too much emotion and tended to be lugubrious in tone, Mabanglo’s poems are taut, precise, and faintly ironic, the insight conveyed in a nuanced manner.

Tagalog poetry is replete with love poems by male writers that saw women in traditional terms, reducing them to objects of idealized beauty or to long-suffering wives and virgins. Like her other poetry books, this collection bears the influence of feminism, especially in the specific ways it images women and her desires. Kung Di Man is an important volume of poetry not only for foregrounding female desire with such deep insight but, as importantly, for being a key document that chronicles the struggles of a feminist writer to occupy a larger space in the history of Philippine literature.  Written by Soledad Reyes and Om Narayan Velasco

text:
Published 1976. Editor, Marcelino A. Foronda Jr. Manila: De La Salle University.

The kutibeng is a five-stringed guitar with which the ancient Ilocano bards used to accompany their poems and songs. This book is a compilation of Ilocano poems presented chronologically from the 17th century to 1971.

The book is divided into five sections: Ilocano poetry in the 17th century; 18th century; 19th century; 20th century, including the American period; and the period since the Independence to 1971. Foronda selects samples from various sources to show the development of Ilocano poetry through historical periods. These sources are anthologies, single-author collections, journals, and popular magazines.

The book includes a long introductory essay by Foronda, summarizing the findings of his 25-year research; a glossary of Ilocano terms and titles of publications; a listing of sources; and brief biographical data on the poets. Except for the poems of Alejandro G. Hufana and Albert B. Casuga, the translations of the poems into English are by Foronda.

The poets included in the collection are Francisco Lopez, Pablo Inis, Jacinto Kawili, Leona Florentino, Ignacio Villamor, Isabelo de los Reyes, Justo Claudio Fojas, Marcelino Crisologo Peña, Mena Crisologo, Victorino Balbin, Jose Castro, Buenaventura J. Bello, Mariano Dacanay, Eleuteria Guirnalda, Mariano N. Gaerlan, Claro Caluya, Antonia Marcos Rubio, Ursula Villanueva, Enriqueta de Peralta, Maura Peña, Sebastian Bersamira, Froilan Donato, Facundo Madriaga, Vicente Llanes, Leon C. Pichay, Tomas Racpan Daradar, Jose Resureccion Calip, Trinidad A. Benito, Godofredo Soledad Reyes, Guillermo L. Pacis, Jeremias Calixto, Hermogenes F. Belen, Peregrino Soledad Reyes, Juan B. Quimba, C. G. Briones, Marcelino A. Foronda Jr, Horencio Ma. Hernando, Alberto Pal Reyes, Luz Flores Bello, Benjamin M. Pascual, Alejandrino G. Hufana, Albert B. Casuga, Juan S. P. Hidalgo Jr, Pelagio A. Alcantara, Jose A. Bragado, Peter La. Julian, Wilfrido C. Aquino, and Andres T. Cocson Jr.

Types of poems covered in this anthology are religious poems, didactic secular lyric poems, greeting poems, eulogies, coronation poems, and modernist poems.  Written by Herminio Beltran Jr, with notes from Priscilla D. Navarro

text:
(Frame Number One). Published 1996. Author, Benilda S. Santos. Pasig City: Anvil Publishing, Inc. Revised edition, 2005, Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press. Manila Critics Circle’s National Book Award for poetry, 1997.

The collection contains 71 poems that are divided into seven sections. The first, “Pitak at Larawan” (Section and Picture) consists of 12 poems presenting images of women in various contexts. In “Kuwadro Numero Uno” (Frame Number One), a woman realizes how she is marginalized because of her gender, yet she surrenders to the dehumanizing systems that have been strengthened by tradition. The same tone of helplessness is seen in the poem “Ang Babae at ang Panahon” (Woman and the Times). In contrast, the persona in “Pagkatapos ng Almusal” (After Breakfast) seemingly jumps out of her skin in the middle of the banal act of brushing her teeth. Suddenly, she sees that she is a unique and able individual, capable of self-possession and empowerment. In “Muni-muni ng Babaeng Mandirigma” (Reflections of a Woman Warrior) and “Sa Unang Gabi ng Iyong Pagdating” (On the First Night of Your Arrival), Santos depicts women’s desires, fantasies, and wishes in sensual language that is both candid and coy.

The section “Rekuwerdong Buwan” (Lunar Remembrance) is an ode to the moon and other celestial bodies. “Buwan sa Tag-ulan” (Moon during the Rainy Season) paints a portrait of the moon against a stormy sky. In poems like “Ang Buwan sa Ayala Heights” (The Moon over Ayala Heights), “Ang Buwan sa Banahaw” (The Moon over Banahaw), and “Ito Rin ang Buwan” (This Too Is the Moon), the moon possesses the power to seduce, wound, comfort, and console any being who comes under its spell.

Water and wind are celebrated in the sections “Ritwal ng Tubig” (Ritual of Water) and “Gayuma ng Hangin” (Charm of the Wind), respectively. Water signals life and hope in “Unang Ulan sa Tag-araw” (First Rain of Summer), “Ang Hardinero” (The Gardener), and “Sa Huling Hapon ng Tag-araw” (The Last Afternoon of Summer). Opening playfully with the image of leaves dancing in the wind, “Pandanggo” ends with a plea that the wind and leaves carry away memories that have been weighing the persona down. “Bagyo” (Storm) gives the reader a sublime description of the devastation wrought by a storm.

“Yugtu-yugto” (Act by Act) revolves around time and the seasons. Some are occasional poems, like “Sa Pagpasok ng Kuwaresma” (As Lent Comes), which is dedicated to the victims of the Ozone Disco fire. “Minsan, sa Malayong Pebrero” (Once upon a February Long Ago) is about missed opportunities, and “Sa Kasintahang Nilimot Na” (To a Forgotten Love), lost love.

“Komentaryo at Dokumentaryo” (Commentary and Documentary) is a sundry mix: observations regarding a sampaguita vendor and a child at play, comments on the character of Florante and the use of the national language inside and outside the classroom, and philosophical musings provoked by reading Albert Camus or eating a watermelon. The seven poems in “Bendisyon ng Umaga” (Morning’s Blessing) are about the various aspects of dawn.

The revised edition of this collection contains five more poems in the seventh section: “Anghel ng Baha” (Angel of Flood), “Ang Kristo ni Kiukok” (Kiukok’s Christ), “Still Life sa Farmer’s Market” (Still Life at Farmer’s Market), “Nang Awitan Ako ng Ibong Adarna” (When the Adarna Bird Sang to Me), and “Ispeys Flayt” (Space Flight).

This collection of poems showcases the poet’s meticulous attention to life and living as her poems present carefully wrought images and thought-through emotions.  Written by Glenda Oris
