text:
Published 1965. Transcriber, Felipe Landa Jocano, “The Epic of Labaw Donggon,” Social Sciences and Humanities Review.

Labaw Donggon is one of the two cycles, generally considered epics in their own right, that compose Hinilawod, the epic of the Sulod, a people of central Panay. The other cycle focuses on the adventures of Humadapnon, Labaw Donggon’s nephew or son. During communal affairs, appropriate parts of the Labaw Donggon are sung in Karay-a by a baylan (shaman), selected for his/her age and reputation.

The 2,325-line epic was recorded by Felipe Landa Jocano, who published it with an English translation in 1964. In typescript, the epic was 3,822 lines long. Jocano’s source was Ulang Udig, who had learned the epic from his grandfather. The recording took place in Barrio Misi in Lambunao, Iloilo. Its rhyme scheme is created by the frequent line endings a, an, un. Its rhythm generally follows an iambic-anapestic combination. However, variation in rhyme and meter does occur, especially as the epic is sung. Although it is part of a larger epic called Hinilawod, Labaw Donggon itself can be divided into two parts. The first part deals with Labaw Donggon’s amorous exploits. In the second part, Labaw Donggon’s son Baranugun plays the leading role.

Labaw Donggon is the son of Anggoy Alunsina, a diwata or goddess who has dominion over the eastern sky, and Buyung Paubari. On the day he is born, Labaw Donggon matures physically and speaks. He asks his mother for magic suits kept in the barugbugan umbaw, a great wooden chest. Dressed in his loose shirt, his embroidered headband, his hat called saramingku, and his metal belt iskumilya, Labaw tells his mother of his intentions. He wants to court the binukot, a kept maiden, Abyang Ginbitinan, who lives by the Halawod River. Anggoy Alunsina reluctantly consents.

When Labaw reaches his beloved’s house, he asks for permission to enter it. He states his purpose for coming, but the girl’s mother, Anggoy Matanayon, replies from within the house that all her daughters have been married to very distinguished personages of the underworld. Only the uripon or slaves accompany her. Labaw disagrees politely and asserts that he saw her daughter near the drinking well and by the window. Labaw then praises her beauty. Labaw asks Matanayon to lower the ladder so that he may go up the house and warm himself from the cold. Anggoy Matanayon refuses, until Labaw agrees to pay a bride-price. As Labaw is ascending the steps, Matanayon tries to discourage him, but Labaw enters the house nonetheless and proceeds to the room of the binukot. Abyang Ginbitinan’s beauty enchants him.

Labaw tells her that he has to return home to consult with his parents regarding his marriage plans. He promises to return after a few days. In hardly a moment’s time, however, Labaw is back at his home and asks his parents to make arrangements with Abyang Ginbitinan’s parents. Soon, Labaw’s parents are in Anggoy Matanayon’s yard. Anggoy Matanayon agrees to a wedding, but only if Labaw presents the bride gift she wants—a great wooden chest filled with treasure and valuable clothes. Buyung Paubari agrees and even offers to build Matanayon a mansion. Labaw calls upon his pamlang (psychic powers) to empower him to build the mansion. The girl’s parents are impressed, and so a wedding ensues. Water is added to rice wine in a large, brown unglazed jar. The rice wine is poured into a cup, which is passed around for the guests to drink of the wine. The bride drinks first, after which the groom takes his share. The marriage is thus consummated, and Buyung Paubari tells his family to return home.

Not long after his first marriage, Labaw’s heart grows restless. He wants another binukot, Anggoy Doronoon of the underworld, of whose beauty he has heard. At first, Ginbitinan rebukes him for his promiscuity, but, finding him resolute, she gives in. Labaw entreats his first wife to bring him his magic suit, as he did the first time with his mother. Like his mother, she reluctantly agrees. Dressed splendidly, he arrives at the yard of Anggoy Doronoon in the underworld. Labaw asks for permission from the master of the house to ascend to their abode. He inquires whether he is trespassing on any charm or prohibition. A voice tells him that he may have bad intentions for coming, so the voice decides to remove the ladder to prevent Labaw from entering the house. Labaw delivers practically the same speech which he used to win Anggoy Gibitinan. Anggoy Doronoon herself answers him this time. She claims that she is already betrothed to an underworld deity, and that she has no sisters but only uripon with her. Labaw does not believe her. Instead, he woos her with flattery. As in his first wooing, he is admitted to the house but only after he promises to pay for every rung of the ladder he steps on in gold and in heirlooms.

Once up, Labaw goes straight to the room of the binukot despite discouragement from the girl’s mother. Labaw and Anggoy Doronoon are married.

Shortly afterward, Labaw is again love sick. He wants another binukot: Malitung Yawa Sinagmaling Diwata, a goddess. Again, he tells his first wife Anggoy Ginbitinan to bring out his magic suit. He rides a boat to look for Malitung Yawa. Labaw is temporarily halted in Dingli, whose stone walls reach high up into the sky and sink deep in the earth. Labaw finds himself enveloped in total darkness. His pamlang, however, helps his boat soar above and beyond the walls. Labaw peers into his crystal ball and sees Malitung Yawa. But he, in turn, is observed by Buyung Saragnayan, Malitung Yawa’s husband, who controls the course of the sun.

Wondering about Labaw’s intentions, Saragnayan plans to challenge him. Labaw’s crystal ball, however, warns him. Labaw tells Saragnayan of his purpose. Saragnayan replies that he can have his wife only in his death, and he challenges Labaw to a duel.

The two first use charms to test whose magic is greater. Saragnayan calls upon his pamlang to destroy Labaw’s oil container, which holds his charms. Labaw’s oil container is shattered; and momentarily, Labaw loses his pride and spirit. But he regains his composure and calls on his pamlang to destroy Saragnayan’s oil container. Labaw’s pamlang fails him. Having been defeated in the battle of charms, Labaw challenges Saragnayan to physical combat. They wrestle. Saragnayan’s followers, however, do not heed the warning. They all die from Baranugun’s arrows. Then Baranugun confronts Saragnayan, but the latter appears invulnerable. Labaw Donggon is one of the two cycles, generally considered epics in their own right, that compose Hinilawod, the epic of the Sulod, a people of central Panay. The other cycle focuses on the adventures of Humadapnon, Labaw Donggon’s nephew or son. During communal affairs, appropriate parts of the Labaw Donggon are sung in Karay-a by a baylan (shaman), selected for his/her age and reputation.

The 2,325-line epic was recorded by Felipe Landa Jocano, who published it with an English translation in 1964. In typescript, the epic was 3,822 lines long. Jocano’s source was Ulang Udig, who had learned the epic from his grandfather. The recording took place in Barrio Misi in Lambunao, Iloilo. Its rhyme scheme is created by the frequent line endings a, an, un. Its rhythm generally follows an iambic-anapestic combination. However, variation in rhyme and meter does occur, especially as the epic is sung. Although it is part of a larger epic called Hinilawod, Labaw Donggon itself can be divided into two parts. The first part deals with Labaw Donggon’s amorous exploits. In the second part, Labaw Donggon’s son Baranugun plays the leading role.

Labaw Donggon is the son of Anggoy Alunsina, a diwata or goddess who has dominion over the eastern sky, and Buyung Paubari. On the day he is born, Labaw Donggon matures physically and speaks. text:
LADLAD: AN ANTHOLOGY OF PHILIPPINE GAY WRITING

(Coming Out: An Anthology of Philippine Gay Writing). Published 1994. Editors, J. Neil C. Garcia and Danton Remoto. Pasig City: Anvil Publishing, Inc.

 

LADLAD 2: AN ANTHOLOGY OF PHILIPPINE GAY WRITING

Published 1996. Editors, J. Neil C. Garcia and Danton Remoto. Pasig City: Anvil Publishing, Inc. Reprinted, 1998.

 

LADLAD 3: AN ANTHOLOGY OF PHILIPPINE GAY WRITING

Published 2007. Editors, J. Neil C. Garcia and Danton Remoto. Pasig City: Anvil Publishing, Inc.

With “representativeness” and “formal excellence” as criteria, these groundbreaking anthologies map out the recurrent concerns of contemporary Philippine gay fiction, poetry, essay, and drama, written in Filipino and English. The first volume consists of the works of 28 writers. Nine of them reappear in the second anthology and 19 debut there. Twelve writers from the first two volumes and 31 others make up the third volume. The catalog suggests that contemporary Philippine gay literature covers a rainbow of political, generational, geographical, and aesthetic colors. Found in the three volumes, then, are closet queens, drag queens, rice queens, and potato queens; gays butch and swishy, predatory, victimized, self-affirming, and self-loathing.

The stories include those about gay men’s dealings with straight men, which can be mercenary (Miguel Castro’s “Lucy” and Danilo R. dela Cruz’s “Ang Lalaking Laging Nakasalaming Itim” [The Man Who’s Always in Shades]) or amicable (Honorio Bartolome de Dios’s “Geyluv” [Gay Love] and Jerry Torres’s “Coming Out”), and with women (Jaime An Lim’s “The Husband” and Garcia’s “Kitty and Vergil”); about gay men’s sexual awakening and exploration (Vicente Groyon’s “Boys Who Like Boys,” Romulo Baquiran’s “Yakap” [Embrace], and Ian Rosales Casocot’s “The Different Rabbit”); and about various dimensions of gay relationships (Danton Remoto’s “Green Rose,” M. Protacio de Guzman’s “Epiphany,” and R. Zamora Linmark’s “Inches”) and gay “lifestyles,” including practices that mainstream society might consider repulsive (Lim’s “Hedonicus,” Jose Claudio Guerrero’s “Essence,” and Xerxes Matza’s “The Collector”).

The poems are equally diverse in theme and style: Ronald Baytan’s “Bottom” and “He Who Sleeps on My Lap” express gay dilemmas in unadorned lines; Jaime Ruiz’s “Ritual ng Eksorsismo sa Multong Bakla” (Ritual to Exorcise the Gay Ghost) is a witty appropriation of a religious exercise; Rody Vera’s “Tip sa Paghahagip” (Tip for Catching Someone) is a coolly understated analysis of the process of cruising; Garcia’s “The Conversion,” Eugene Evasco’s “Hardinero” (Gardener), and Christopher Cahilig’s “Sa Iyong Kaarawan, Itay” (On Your Birthday, Father) depict the strained relationship between gay men and their families; Lim’s “Short Time” and Galan’s “Backroom Love” delineate the hollowness of anonymous sexual encounters; Nicholas Pichay’s “An OCW Tries the Personals” suggests where romance might be found outside of bars and bathhouses; J. Dennis Teodosio’s “Ang Galit Ko kay Eba” (My Beef against Eve) decries the stereotypes that imprison not only gay men but also women; and D. M. Reyes’s “Gypsy Song” meditates on the wisdom of letting go. A good number of poems are erotic, their approach to the subject varying from the graphic to the subtle, among them Glenn Joseph Toscano’s “Underwear” and “Confessional,” Remoto’s “The Ring,” Gary Devilles’s “Pneuma,” and Pichay’s “Karnehan” (Meat Market).

Only the first two volumes contain essays. The more interesting ones include Murphy Red’s “Gayspeak in the Nineties,” a look into gay lingo, with a glossary by Ram Garcia; Baytan’s “Pua Iyam” (Faggot), an account of the prejudices against gays in the Chinese Filipino community and within the gay community; Jaime Ruiz’s “At Nakialam Siya sa Akin” (And He Bothered with Me), a seminarian’s reflections on being both gay and a man of the cloth; Louie Cruz’s “Wanted: Womb,” a provocative inquiry into misogyny, monogamy, and the definition of family; and Michael Tan’s scholarly “Sickness and Sin: Medical and Religious Stigmatization of Homosexuality in the Philippines.”

Ralph Galan’s poem “Bago ang Bading” (Before the Gay Man), inspired by Rebecca Añonuevo’s “Bago ang Babae,” expresses the trajectory that gay writing has taken. Galan’s persona asserts that he is human first before gay.

Whereas the first two volumes had about them the aura of a settler announcing his arrival—the title of the series itself literally means “to unfurl” or “to reveal”—or that of a pioneer laying claim to and ferociously guarding a territory, Galan’s poem suggests a new state of normalcy developing in the nine years that separate the third volume from the second. The question arises, then, of what would constitute Philippine gay literature in the future or what the label would mean. Subsequent installments of the Ladlad series are bound to track the answers.  Written by Jonathan Chua

(Coming Out: An Anthology of Philippine Gay Writing). Published 1994. Editors, J. Neil C. Garcia and Danton Remoto. Pasig City: Anvil Publishing, Inc.
LADLAD 2: AN ANTHOLOGY OF PHILIPPINE GAY WRITING
Published 1996. Editors, J. Neil C. Garcia and Danton Remoto. Pasig City: Anvil Publishing, Inc. Reprinted, 1998.
LADLAD 3: AN ANTHOLOGY OF PHILIPPINE GAY WRITING
Published 2007. Editors, J. Neil C. Garcia and Danton Remoto. Pasig City: Anvil Publishing, Inc.

With “representativeness” and “formal excellence” as criteria, these groundbreaking anthologies map out the recurrent concerns of contemporary Philippine gay fiction, poetry, essay, and drama, written in Filipino and English. The first volume consists of the works of 28 writers. Nine of them reappear in the second anthology and 19 debut there. Twelve writers from the first two volumes and 31 others make up the third volume. The catalog suggests that contemporary Philippine gay literature covers a rainbow of political, generational, geographical, and aesthetic colors. Found in the three volumes, then, are closet queens, drag queens, rice queens, and potato queens; gays butch and swishy, predatory, victimized, self-affirming, and self-loathing.

BIAG NI LAM-ANG

(Life of Lam-ang). Published 1889-90. Transcriber, Fr Gerardo Blanco. Serialized with Spanish translation in El Ilocano, Dec 1889–Feb 1890. Republished in El Folk-Lore Filipino (Philippine Folklore), 1890. English translation of Blanco version by Anastacio B. Gerardo, Mercedes Vega, Andres S. Nicolas, and Mariano L. Mencias, 1916.

 

PANGRUGIAN A PACASARITAAN ITI PANAGBIAG NI LAM-ANG

(The Origin and Life Story of Lam-ang). Published 1906. Transcriber, Canuto Medina. English translation of Medina version by Cornelio N. Valdez, 1919-20.

 

HISTORIA TI PACASARITAAN TI PANAGBIAG NI LAM-ANG ITI ILI TI NALBUAN NGA ASAWA NI DOÑA INES CANNOYAN ITI ILI
A CALANOTIAN

(Life Story of Lam-ang of the Town of Nalbuan, Husband of Doña Ines Cannoyan of the Town of Calanotian). Published 1924. Parayno Hermanos.

 

BIAG NI LAM-ANG: DAAN A SARITA

(Life of Lam-ang: An Ancient Story). Published 1926. Serialized in La Lucha, 29 Feb 1926–5 Jun 1926.

 

THE ILOCANO EPIC

Published 1935. English Translation by Leopoldo Yabes. Manila, Philippines: Carmelo & Bauermann.

 

BIAG NI LAM-ANG

Transcribed 1947. Chanter, Francisco Magana. Transcriber, Jose Llanes.

 

THE LIFE OF LAM-ANG (TI PANAGBIAG NI LAM-ANG): A PHILIPPINE EPIC IN ILOKO.

Published 1955. English translation by Amado M. Yuzon. Manila: Alip and Sons.

 

BIAG NI LAM-ANG

Transcribed ca 1960. Chanter, Domingo Valdez. Transcriber, Carlo Magno Tacdol.

Probably the best known among Philippine epics, Lam-ang is the epic of the Christianized Ilocanos of Ilocos Norte, Ilocos Sur, La Union, and Abra. It is sung in Ilocano during festivals even today.

The epic has six known versions. The earliest is the Isabelo de los Reyes version, so called because its recording was erroneously attributed to de los Reyes. It was actually recorded by Fr Gerardo Blanco. De los Reyes first published it in El Ilocano with a Spanish prose translation in Dec 1889 to Feb 1890 and later in El Folklore Filipino, 1890. Canuto Medina, an Ilocano poet, is said to have recorded an earlier version, but his earliest edition is dated 1906, titled Pangrugian a Pacasaritaan iti Panagbiag ni Lam-ang. The Parayno Hermanos version, titled Historia ti Pacasaritaan ti Panagbiag ni Lam-ang iti ili ti Nalbuan nga Asawa ni Doña Ines Cannoyan iti ili a Calanotian, 1924, is the most popular version, having undergone three reprintings. La Lucha serialized another version, titled Biag ni Lam-ang: Daan a Sarita. Leopoldo Y. Yabes made a composite edition, combining episodes from all previous versions in 1935. He also added some episodes absent from the previous editions; his version is 11 stanzas longer. Two other versions are those by Francisco Magana, also known as the Llanes Transcription, 1947, and by Carlo Magno Tacdol, transcribed by Domingo Valdez in the 1960s.

English translations of the epic date as far back as 1916, with the translation of the Blanco version by Anastacio B. Gerardo, Mercedes Vega, Andres S. Nicolas, and Mariano L. Mencias. The Medina version was translated by Cornelio N. Valdez in 1919-20. Yabes translated the epic twice, once in 1935 and again in 1958. The Kapampangan poet Amado M. Yuzon made an English verse translation in The Life of Lam-ang (Ti Panagbiag ni Lam-ang): A Philippine Epic in Iloko, 1955. The epic was adapted as a stage musical in 2004 by Jose B. Capino and Von de Guzman.

Namongan gives birth to Lam-ang, a baby of incredible strength and courage. The boy asks his mother about his father’s whereabouts and learns that he has gone to fight the Igorot. Lam-ang arms himself with charms and decides to look for his father. From a dream, he learns that his father Don Juan Panganiban has been killed by the Igorot. Later, Lam-ang finds Igorot in a sagang, a feast celebrating a successful head-hunting expedition. His father’s head is displayed in the feast. Lam-ang slays them all with his spear and mutilates the last among them.

When Lam-ang returns home, 99 maidens wash his hair in the river. For his shampoo, he burns so much rice straw that the communities near the river are alarmed by the smoke. The dirt from his hair kills all the fish in the river. He then kills a crocodile and carries it on his shoulder ashore amid the applause of his companions.

Lam-ang hears of a beautiful maiden named Ines Kanoyan, daughter of the richest man of the town of Kalanutian. He tells his mother of his desire to court the maiden. Although his mother discourages him, he goes anyway, dressed in gold and accompanied by his pet rooster and white dog. The giant Sumarang blocks his way and belittles him. Lam-ang defeats him in a duel and hurls him nine hills away. Later, Saridandan tries to seduce him, but Lam-ang rejects her advances.

Reaching Kalanutian, he impresses Ines with his magic. His rooster crows and topples a small outhouse. His dog barks and the outhouse is rebuilt. Ines invites him to the house where the rooster acts as Lam-ang’s spokesperson. Ines’s parents ask for a bride-price, which Lam-ang agrees to give. Lam-ang returns home to prepare for the wedding and the presents. He and his townsfolk sail on two golden ships to Kalanutian where Lam-ang and Ines have a Catholic wedding. The townspeople board the two ships to Nalbuan, Lam-ang’s birthplace, to continue the celebration.

After the celebration, the barangay chief reminds Lam-ang it is his turn to hunt the rarang, a giant shellfish. Lam-ang agrees and is swallowed by the giant fish berkakang, as an earlier dream has foretold. However, a diver recovers his bones. The pet rooster flaps its wings and resurrects Lam-ang thereby. Lam-ang rewards the diver and lives happily with his wife and pets.  Written by Angelito Santos and Filonila Tupas

 

Sources

Castro, Jovita Ventura, Antolina Antonio, Patricia Melendrez-Cruz, Josefina Mariano, and Rosella Jean Makasiar-Puno, eds. 1983. Anthology of ASEAN Literatures: Epics of the Philippines. Manila: ASEAN Committee on Culture and Information.

Manuel, E. Arsenio. 1963. “A Survey of Philippine Epics.” Asian Folklore Studies 22:1-76.

Yabes, Leopoldo. 1935. The Ilocano Epic. Manila: Carmelo and Bauerman.

article_title: Like the Molave and Other Poems
text:
Published 1940. Author, R. Zulueta da Costa. With an introduction by Salvador P. Lopez. Manila: By the author. Reprinted, Manila: Alberto S. Florentino, 1973.

First prize winner at the Commonwealth Literary Contests for poetry in 1940, the collection, particularly the title poem, was considered anti-American. As a result, Zulueta da Costa lost his teaching job at the then De La Salle College.

The title poem, “Like the Molave,” was inspired by a speech of Pres Manuel Quezon on 19 Aug 1938, decrying the decadence of the Filipino youth and urging that they must be “like the molave, strong and resilient … unafraid of the raging flood, the lightning or the storm, confident of its own strength.” The poem is divided into 19 sections and written in irregular stanzas; it begins with the famous apostrophe to Jose Rizal: “Not yet, Rizal, not yet. Sleep not in peace.” The next sections condemn the defects of youth: their effeteness, sanctimoniousness, frivolity, and colonial mentality. The poem also laments the marginalization of artists, thinkers, and the masses. Against this, the speaker presents the ideal in the form of an equation: “The mathematical certainty endures: / Philippines minus (Spain plus America) equals MOLAVE.”

Often faulted for its rhetorical style, excessive didacticism, and the datedness of some parts, the poem remains popular for choral recitation. The influence of Walt Whitman and Carl Sandburg is noticeable; the poem departs from the purely aesthetic poem typified by the works of Jose Garcia Villa. In the end, however, it imparts an aesthetic, because just, human vision.

The other poems in the collection are less controversial. Many of them are divided into different sections, such as “To a Wise Virgin: Sonnets Three” and “A Symphony Concert,” consisting of seven parts. Religious imagery, like the breaking of bread, the cross and thorns, and Lazarus rising from the grave, is used in “Easter Oratorios” and other poems. “Nuances” deals with more personal experiences, such as love and longing; “Alexander Lippay” is a tribute to the late conductor of the Manila Symphony Orchestra. “Impromptu for an Unholy One” describes the struggle against inevitable death through creativity.

Some of the poems read like aphorisms as in a section of “Quatrains”: God, the persona says, must be embarrassed, as opposing peoples all claim that God is on their side. A part of “Etudes” ridicules hack scholarship. Those who read critiques and commentaries but not the book about which the critiques are, have, the persona says, “skipped life.”

Although Zulueta da Costa has often been contrasted with Villa, he also coins words like Villa, as in this line from “We May Sleep”: “We who have arrested instant into everness.”  Written by Jonathan Chua, with notes from Victoria S. Calizo

 

Source

Bernad, Miguel, SJ. 1953. Review of Like the Molave and Collected Poems by Rafael Zulueta da Costa. Philippine Studies 1 (First Quarter): 79-85.

text:
(Creations of the Tongue, Creations of the Spirit). Published 1993. Author, Bienvenido L. Lumbera. Pasig City: Anvil Publishing, Inc.

This collection of 103 poems, written between 1956 and 1992, is divided into three sections: “Paghihintay (1956-1963)” (Waiting [1956-1963]), “Paroo’t Parito (1964-1970)” (Hither and Thither [1964-1970]), and “Paglingon at Pagtanaw (1971-1992)” (Looking Back and Gazing [1971-1992]). The second section, “Paroo’t Parito,” is further grouped into poems in English, subtitled “Pandarayuhan” (Foreign) and Filipino, subtitled “Sa Sariling Wika” (In My Own Language). The section headings frame the anthology as interconnected moments that, together, suggest a life of alternating stillness and movement, journeys, and defining moments leading to illumination worth giving one’s life for.

The influence of modernist tenets—of irony, detachment, and restraint—is discernible in the poems written in the 1950s and 1960s, when Lumbera was a graduate student at Indiana University and a young instructor. In “Anghel na Bato” (Angel of Stone), the persona notes the paradoxical nature of a stone angel, its immobile features holding numerous secrets; but the persona concludes that mystery, after all, is preferable to revelation. “Sangkusing na Awit para kay Gustav Mahler” (Half-Penny Song for Gustav Mahler) is a conceit representing the gradual dissolution of love, which the persona rues. Images of autumn dissolving into winter are the bare, abandoned trees and a beggar wind stretching out its bony hand for a silver-colored raindrop that quickly dissolves on its palm.

Lumbera’s years abroad and the accompanying sense of estrangement they engendered shape a number of his poems, like “Habang Pinanununghan ang Lake Mendota” (On the Way to Lake Mendota), “Pahimakas sa Isang Panahon” (Farewell to One Season), “Taglagas sa Bloomington” (Autumn in Bloomington), “Dialogue in Autumn,” “Pedagogy,” and “The Innkeeper Advises K.” Remembered scenes from home intensify the longing, but this is camouflaged by irony.

His hometown Lipa figures in “Umaga sa Lipa” (Morning in Lipa), “Agaw-dilim sa Lipa” (Dusk in Lipa), “Biyahe” (Trip), and “Pakikipaglibing” (Commiseration), where the scenes and rituals of life are fondly remembered not in an orgy of colors but in carefully measured doses of subtle imagery.

The collection also features some of Lumbera’s often anthologized depictions of the massive poverty, the lethal ugliness of the city, and the tyranny of its idle rich. In such poems, Lumbera displays ironic detachment, steely composure, restraint, and even humor, as evident in his apparent delight at the sight of pesky cockroaches crushed in a “painless death” in “Eulogy of Roaches.” The playfully ironic tone does not, however, hide the ugliness of the plight of children playing along Recto Ave in “Voyagers on Recto Avenue,” or the burden placed on helpless ordinary people in “Ayos Lang ang Buhay sa Maynila” (Life in Manila Is Swell), and “Masikip Daw ang Maynila” (They Say It’s Crowded in Manila), where surface impressions are belied by dark implications.

The poems written in the 1970s and beyond, a period of intense political struggle in which Lumbera was a committed participant, advance a nationalist cause. The first three poems are ballads in response to key events: the series of rallies staged against the Marcos dictatorship, the Corazon Aquino government, and the American military bases.

Another dimension of the poet is revealed in a group of poems—as librettist of some of the most important and acclaimed theatrical productions: Tales of the Manuvu, Ang Palabas Bukas (Tomorrow’s Show), Rama, Hari (Rama, The King), Nasa Puso ang Amerika (America Is in the Heart), Bayani (Hero), all of which are also powerful critiques of society. The last poems offer a glimpse of moments in the personal life of the poet. Rounding out the collection is a series of tributes to individuals: Jose “Ka Pepe” Diokno, Lamberto Avellana, Lerry Nofuente, Ka Tangkad, and Lorena Barros.

Modernism and Marxism have shaped Lumbera’s poetry, a fact which demonstrates that aesthetics and politics are intimately connected, or that art is inextricable from history and ideology. Lumbera achieves this synthesis by the unwavering spirit of nationalism pervading these poems, which he wrote in a span of four decades.  Written by Soledad Reyes

The second section, “Paroo’t Parito,” is further grouped into poems in English, subtitled “Pandarayuhan” (Foreign) and Filipino, subtitled “Sa Sariling Wika” (In My Own Language). The section headings frame the anthology as interconnected moments that, together, suggest a life of alternating stillness and movement, journeys, and defining moments leading to illumination worth giving one’s life for.

The influence of modernist tenets—of irony, detachment, and restraint—is discernible in the poems written in the 1950s and 1960s, when Lumbera was a graduate student at Indiana University and a young instructor. In “Anghel na Bato” (Angel of Stone), the persona notes the paradoxical nature of a stone angel, its immobile features holding numerous secrets; but the persona concludes that mystery, after all, is preferable to revelation. “Sangkusing na Awit para kay Gustav Mahler” (Half-Penny Song for Gustav Mahler) is a conceit representing the gradual dissolution of love, which the persona rues. Images of autumn dissolving into winter are the bare, abandoned trees and a beggar wind stretching out its bony hand for a silver-colored raindrop that quickly dissolves on its palm.

Lumbera’s years abroad and the accompanying sense of estrangement they engendered shape a number of his poems, like “Habang Pinanununghan ang Lake Mendota” (On the Way to Lake Mendota), “Pahimakas sa Isang Panahon” (Farewell to One Season), “Taglagas sa Bloomington” (Autumn in Bloomington), “Dialogue in Autumn,” “Pedagogy,” and “The Innkeeper Advises K.” Remembered scenes from home intensify the longing, but this is camouflaged by irony.

His hometown Lipa figures in “Umaga sa Lipa” (Morning in Lipa), “Agaw-dilim sa Lipa” (Dusk in Lipa), “Biyahe” (Trip), and “Pakikipaglibing” (Commiseration), where the scenes and rituals of life are fondly remembered not in an orgy of colors but in carefully measured doses of subtle imagery.

The collection also features some of Lumbera’s often anthologized depictions of the massive poverty, the lethal ugliness of the city, and the tyranny of its idle rich. In such poems, Lumbera displays ironic detachment, steely composure, restraint, and even humor, as evident in his apparent delight at the sight of pesky cockroaches crushed in a “painless death” in “Eulogy of Roaches.” The playfully ironic tone does not, however, hide the ugliness of the plight of children playing along Recto Ave in “Voyagers on Recto Avenue,” or the burden placed on helpless ordinary people in “Ayos Lang ang Buhay sa Maynila” (Life in Manila Is Swell), and “Masikip Daw ang Maynila” (They Say It’s Crowded in Manila), where surface impressions are belied by dark implications.

The poems written in the 1970s and beyond, a period of intense political struggle in which Lumbera was a committed participant, advance a nationalist cause. The first three poems are ballads in response to key events: the series of rallies staged against the Marcos dictatorship, the Corazon Aquino government, and the American military bases.

Another dimension of the poet is revealed in a group of poems—as librettist of some of the most important and acclaimed theatrical productions: Tales of the Manuvu, Ang Palabas Bukas (Tomorrow’s Show), Rama, Hari (Rama, The King), Nasa Puso ang Amerika (America Is in the Heart), Bayani (Hero), all of which are also powerful critiques of society. The last poems offer a glimpse of moments in the personal life of the poet. Rounding out the collection is a series of tributes to individuals: Jose “Ka Pepe” Diokno, Lamberto Avellana, Lerry Nofuente, Ka Tangkad, and Lorena Barros.

Modernism and Marxism have shaped Lumbera’s poetry, a fact which demonstrates that aesthetics and politics are intimately connected, or that art is inextricable from history and ideology. Lumbera achieves this synthesis by the unwavering spirit of nationalism pervading these poems, which he wrote in a span of four decades.  Written by Soledad Reyes

text:
Published 1974. Compiler, Raymond T. Quetchenbach, SVD. Leyte-Samar Studies. With a prefatory note by Edilberto K. Tiempo. Tacloban City: Divine Word University Graduate School.

This is an anthology of 41 Waray poems written between 1934 and 1961, with their English translation. The poems were previously published in two magazines, An Lantawan and Leyte Courier. Twelve poems are by Iluminado Lucente and eight by Eduardo Makabenta. Makabenta’s poems that were included in this anthology were previously published in his own two collections, Pinarungpong ng mga Siday ug mga Garaygaday (Collected Poems and Light Verse) and Verses.

The poems cover a variety of subjects: love fulfilled and love unrequited, hope, time, sorrow, childhood, love of country, the bucolic rural life, rural scenes and the flora and fauna to be found here, various members of the working class, courtship, Jose Rizal, sunset, and clouds. There are also poems on such commonplace things as the tobacco, the word kuan, and the favorite Filipino wine called tuba.

Many poems have a didactic purpose, such as Gabriel Bañez’s “Mahatungod han Gugma” (On Love), which admonishes the suitor to value virtuous acts rather than temporal beauty, and to learn the art of graciousness should his love be rejected. Jeremias G. Acebedo’s “Tabako” (Tobacco) is an apostrophe to this object, depicted as one of a man’s favorite paraphernalia: “Ginmamahal ka labi pa han bulawan” (He loves you more than gold). However, it also becomes a metaphor for some aspects of human life: the smoke is likened to the human soul reaching for God, the ashes are proud souls falling into the fires of hell.

A cheerful poem is Eduardo Makabenta’s “Mga Tulapos han Kapalaran” (The Unfortunate), which has the following subtitles: “An Mananggiti” (The Tuba Gatherer), “An Parauma” (The Farmer), “An Parapangawil” (The Fisher), “An Karpintero” (The Carpenter), and “An Kaminero” (The Streetcleaner). The difficulties of these members of the working class and their awareness of class differences are overridden by wry humor. For instance:

Ha kumbite an tuba

iniinom nga dubado

han hukom, han abogado …

Mananggiti? By’nala;

diri ngani kumbidad

 

(At the fiesta my tuba

is drunk with chocolate

by the judge and the lawyer …

The tuba gatherer? Shucks

I’m not even invited.)

Other poets included in the anthology are E. Alaba, Francisco V. Alvarado, Luding Austero, Vedasto T. Basas y Nolasco, Nicolas C. Caminto, Marciano E. Cañeda, Pedro C. Daga, Cecilia O. de Achas, Vicente I. de Veyra, Francisco J. Enfectana, Gavino G. Katangkatang, Pesyong C. Margallo, M. Nagad Balihon, Agustin El O’Mora, F. Pamor, and Pe A. P. Sevilla.

Many poems are in dodecasyllabic quatrains, or four-line stanzas of 12 syllables each, and follow a perfect-rhyming scheme. The book fills a gap in Philippine literary history, for its contents offer a portrait of Waray life and worldview, and exemplify the use of poetic conventions that characterize Filipino traditional poetry.  Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero

text:
Published 2009. Author, Isabela Banzon. With an introduction by Dennis Haskell. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

The titular poem “Lola Coqueta” encapsulates this collection’s fixation on love, complicated by socioeconomic and political realities. In the poem, the world-weary grandmother admonishes the presumably young female persona to use her “cocote” (head) and not waste her love on a poor boy. The personas in the 37 poems gathered in the book inhabit clear contexts, including Philippine colonial reality, that inform their engagement with others and the world.

“In the Fifties” matter-of-factly exposes a colonial outlook. The child persona prefers the life of Dick, Jane, and Spot to that of Pepe, Pilar, and Bantay. Scavenging for leftover American goods in “American Dream, 1960s” or for used imported items at a rummage store in “In Cubao” is a logical offshoot of the same mentality. The tone of the poem “Ngek” is one of resignation to the status quo. There is a measure of discontent as the persona says, “I’m too tired to join another EDSA / … my skin / toasted by too much sun on the highway to Pag-asa.”

The beginning pieces in the collection provide the base for the sense of cultural complications in the later poems that show personas burdened by the act of leaving the country. In “DH Sunday, Hong Kong,” a domestic helper speaks, in a well-appropriated broken English, of being Filipino. “Globalization on a Budget” depicts the dislocation of Third World travelers—the budget crowd who stay in cheap hotels and live on buns or noodles while they dream of the lush life. The search of a better life by constant migration is explicitly described in “At the Wake” and strongly suggested in “In Transit,” where it is couched as a failed love affair.

The relationships in the poems in this collection are fraught with complications caused by violence, from the feminist protest poem “Done,” to the tender elegy for a dead family member in “Nineteen Years Later.” Literal geographical distance is the source of tension in “What Will We Do with Lily,” while cruel domestic arrangements are in the center of “Kids Everywhere and You and Me in Nowhere.” In “Rindu,” the language and culture divide is clear when the persona declares, “I want / to love you simply, / without fear, without metaphor, / but it is difficult / in English.” The latter is one of a number of poems with words and phrases in Spanish and in Bahasa.

While the poems’ subjects are often complex and somber, the collection is not wholly without humor. Dennis Haskell, in his introduction to the book, observes Banzon’s demonstration of playfulness, satire, and refusal of sentimentality. This collection displays deft restraint of emotions and subtle presentation of domestic and universal concerns. Banzon executes a gamut of poetic techniques to show how Philippine poetry in English can be not only about love per se, but also about being a Filipino living and loving in an increasingly globalized world.  Written by Shane Carreon

article_title: Mahal na Passion ni Jesu Christong Panginoon Natin na Tola / 211
text:
(Holy Passion of Our Lord Jesus Christ in Verse). Published 1703 or 1704. Author, Gaspar Aquino de Belen. Found in Tomas de Villacastin, Manga Panalanging Pagtatagobilin sa Caloloua nang Tauong Naghihingalo (Prayers of Commendation for the Soul of the Dying). Manila: Imprenta de la Compañia de Jesus, 1760. Reprinted with an introduction and explanatory text by Rene B. Javellana, SJ. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press, 1990.

This is the first Tagalog pasyon, or verse narrative recounting the life of Christ, and most probably the first ever in any Philippine language. The 980-stanza pasyon was first published as the second part of Villacastin’s book of prayers. The first part of the book is based on Tomas de Villacastin’s Recomendacion del Alma (Recommendations for the Soul [of the Dying]), 1613.

The Mahal na Passion was written for the use of the magpapahesus, Filipinos organized and trained by the Spanish friars and missionaries to assist their fellow Christians at the moment of death. This pasyon was apparently also chanted during the wake. As such, it was an exposition on the spiritual import of dying as a Christian. The text exhorts the Christian to remain faithful to Christ until death.

The pasyon is structured according to the journey of Jesus Christ from his Last Supper with his apostles until his death on the cross and subsequent resurrection. Arrayed along the path he takes are different figures who symbolize the possible attitudes the Christian may have toward Jesus. There are Judas who betrays him, and Peter who, out of weakness, loses faith in Jesus and denies him. There is the ever faithful Mary, his mother. There, too, is Longinus who in the beginning is an enemy of Jesus but who gets converted when he witnesses the miracle of the resurrection.

The narrative about the last days of Jesus Christ on earth is interspersed with aral (moral lessons) serving as guidelines to a Christian way of life. Their simple message is fidelity to Jesus Christ as the foundation of bliss and salvation. The world with all its allurements is mere “papel na palara” (tinsel), which easily crumples. What endures is the friendship of Jesus who is one’s “catoto,” a true bosom friend.

Mahal na Passion is the only surviving work of Aquino de Belen, but being the first of its kind in the history of Tagalog literature, it has earned for the author the recognition as “the first great Tagalog poet.” More than its use of motifs drawn from Spanish poetry, the value of Aquino de Belen’s pasyon lies in the intensity with which the poet reconstructed the story of Christ’s passion and death. The poetic quality comes from the writer’s sensuous visual imagination, deep psychological insights, and expert use of rhyme and meter.

In the 18th century, the Mahal na Passion saw at least five printings, the 1760 edition being called “quinta impression.” Whether there was another printing in the 18th century is uncertain; however, inventory of the Jesuit Press, Imprenta de la Compañia in 1768, states that there about 1,000 copies of the work, some bound and others unbound. Some copies were in the possession of Nicolas de la Cruz Bagay, the master printer of Imprenta de la Compañia at the time of the Jesuit expulsion from Manila in May 1768. He had brought the copies to the binder. The copies of the text were sequestered by the government. The Mahal na Passion disappeared from the public for a while, but in 1846 an edition of the text was published in Manila by the Imprenta de los Amigos del Pais. The initiative for reprinting came from a layperson, Miguel Valdibia, who requested the juez provisor or ecclesiastical judge of the Archdiocese of Manila to allow a reprinting of the pasyon popularly known as “de los cuatro evangelistas” (the four evangelists). The appointed ecclesiastical censor, Fr Hilarion Diez, OSA, explains that the name came from the fact that early editions of the text had a frontispiece illustration depicting the four evangelists. Diez had high praises for the text, saying that it was well-written in Tagalog, derived from the gospels themselves, and had sound doctrines and exhortations adapted to daily life. He praised the “energy of the poetic genius [of the writer of the pasyon] as comparable to Virgil’s.”

Despite the censor’s praise, the title page erroneously described the pasyon as a translation by Aquino de Belen of Villacastin’s original. Eighteenth-century editions indeed stated that Aquino de Belen translated from Villacastin, but what those editions were referring to was not the text of the pasyon itself but de Belen’s translation of Villacastin’s Recomendacion del Alma with which the Mahal na Passion was published in 1760. In fact, Recomendacion was no longer included in the 1846 edition; the Mahal na Passion had become an independent work.The question arises: how could the publisher of the 1846 edition have fallen into such error given that both the 1760 and 1846 editions print the approbation given by the ecclesiastical censor, Fr Antonio de Mancilla, SJ, stating that Aquino de Belen has explained in an elegant style the Passion of Christ our Lord, and that for this reason, his compatriots owe him a debt of gratitude for spreading the light of the Gospel through such a work?

This 1846 or other 19th-century edition still unknown of Aquino de Belen may have been the source from which a 19th-century Cebuano version was derived.  Written by Rene Javellana

 

Sources

Balmaseda, Julian Cruz. (1947) 1972. Ang Tatlong Panahon ng Tulang Tagalog. Manila: Institute of National Language.

Lumbera, Bienvenido L. 1986. Tagalog Poetry 1570-1898: Tradition and Influences in Its Development. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

Javellana, Rene, SJ, ed. 1990. Mahal na Passion ni Jesu Christong Panginoon Natin na Tola. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

text:
Published 1969. Transcribers, Juan R. Francisco with Nagasura T. Madale. Quezon City: Philippine Folklore Society.

Juan R. Francisco came across a madrasa (or the Romanized transliteration of the Maranao Arabic writing) of the story of Maharadia Lawana in 1968. It is a long Maranao tale in prose.

Maharadia Lawana, the eight- or seven-headed son of the sultan of Pulu Bandiarmasir, is exiled by his father because his rumor-mongering habit wreaks havoc among the people. He reaches an island, where Diabarail (Angel Gabriel) stops him from committing suicide and tells him that the only instrument that can kill him is a tool sharpened with the whetstone in the palace of Bandiarmasir. Maharadia Lawana then finds his way back to Bandiarmasir, and he is taken back by his parents.

Radia Mangandiri and Radia Mangawarna, sons of the sultan of Agama Niog, prepare for a 10-year journey by boat, to win the hand of the incomparably beautiful Tuwan Potre Malano Tihaia, daughter of the sultan and sultaness of Pulu Nabandai across the sea. But the ship is battered by giant waves, and the two brothers, who are the only survivors, are swept to the island of their destination, where an old woman, Kabaian, rescues them and takes them under her wing. Soon, the two brothers hear that Tuwan Potre’s father, the sultan, is offering her hand in marriage to anyone who will win a sipa (kickball) contest at a festival that the royal family is sponsoring. The two brothers set out to join the contest, and the older brother Mangandiri wins when the ball that he kicks reaches the princess’s room. She places her ring, handkerchief, and betel nut case inside the ball, and these become tokens by which the sipa winner may be identified. Mangandiri takes the ball with the princess’s things but he and his brother quietly slip out of the crowd and return home.

One day the sultan goes for a walk and catches sight of his daughter’s things in Kabaian’s house. Mangandiri serves him betel nut, and he recognizes his daughter’s ring on the young man’s finger. He takes the younger man back to his palace to marry his daughter. However, before Mangandiri can wed the princess, her mother the sultaness imposes another condition—that he kill the giant snake residing on the mountain in the east and thus blocking the sun.

The brothers kill the snake and return to Nabandai. The sultaness waits seven days for proof of the snake’s death. On the seventh day, the stench is so strong the brothers must remove the snake. After another seven days, the sun finally appears and shines brightly, and the wedding takes place.

Time passes. Mangandiri longs for Agama Niog and his parents. Tuwan Potre’s father prevails upon the couple to travel by land instead of crossing the perilous sea. The caravan stops at a fertile area, and they decide to settle there.

One afternoon, they spot a golden-horned deer. After giving his younger brother Mangawarna strict orders to look after his wife, Mangandiri goes after the deer but it injures him. He seeks Mangawarna’s help. Making sure that Tuwan Potre is securely inside their house and admonishing her not to open the door to anyone under any circumstances, Mangawarna reluctantly joins the chase. When darkness falls, the deer splits into two and so the brothers split up to go after the two deer. But both deer disappear. They return home to find the house destroyed and Tuwan Potre gone. They realize that the deer is Maharadia Lawana in disguise, and he has taken Tuwan Potre.

Mangawarna goes in search of his brother, and with some difficulty finds his brother asleep in the forest. He reaches an island, where Diabarail (Angel Gabriel) stops him from committing suicide and tells him that the only instrument that can kill him is a tool sharpened with the whetstone in the palace of Bandiarmasir. text:
WALONG DEKADA NG MAKABAGONG TULANG PILIPINO

(Eight Decades of Modern Poetry in Pilipino). Published 1981. Editor, Virgilio S. Almario. Manila: Philippine Education Company Inc. Revised, expanded edition.

 

SANSIGLONG MAHIGIT NG MAKABAGONG TULA SA FILIPINAS: MGA PILING TULA SA BIKOL, BINISAYA, ESPANYOL, ILUKO, INGLES, FILIPINO, AT KAPAMPANGAN MULANG 1900 HANGGANG KASALUKUYAN

(More Than a Century of Modern Poetry in the Philippines: Selected Poems in Bikol, Visayan, Spanish, Ilocano, English, Filipino, and Pampango from 1900 to the Present). Published 2006. Editor, Virgilio S. Almario. Pasig City: Anvil Publishing, Inc. With translations by various poets.

Walong Dekada ng Makabagong Tulang Pilipino is an anthology of poems by 45 Tagalog poets covering the period 1900-1980. In his introduction titled “Ang Makata sa Panahon ng Makinasyon at Mekanisasyon” (The Poet in the Age of Machination and Mechanization), Almario traces the development of Tagalog poetry in the 20th century in the context of social and political events. His thesis is that the driving force of Philippine poetry was the crisis of Americanization, and that the successive generations of poets were reacting to, as well as helping shape, the developing national consciousness. The aim of the anthology is to project the problematic of form and content engendered by that crisis, by way of presenting the leading poets of each period with their representative works.

The author also discusses the origins of balagtasismo (writing inspired by Balagtas) and modernismo (modernism), the rise of campus poetry, the seething social conditions in contemporary times, and the emergence of protest poetry from the pre-martial law Panulat para sa Kaunlaran ng Sambayanan or PAKSA group to the later Galian sa Arte at Tula or GAT generation of poets. Capsule biographies of all 45 poets are provided at the end of the book. The book is divided into three sections corresponding roughly to three historical periods of writing: 1900-1932, 1932-61, and 1961-80. However, within each of the book’s three sections the poets are arranged alphabetically rather than chronologically.

The best-known poets in all three periods have their most notable works in this anthology, such as “Ang Lumang Simbahan” (The Old Church) by Florentino T. Collantes; “Ang Pagbabalik” (The Return) by Jose Corazon de Jesus; “Three O’Clock in the Morning” by Cirio H. Panganiban; “Ako ang Daigdig” (I Am the World) by Alejandro G. Abadilla; “Kung Tuyo Na ang Luha Mo, Aking Bayan” (When Your Tears Run Dry, My Country) by Amado V. Hernandez; “Panambitan” (Dirge) by Lamberto E. Antonio; “Sa Harap ng Makinilya” (Before the Typewriter) by Teo T. Antonio; “Ang Daigdig ng Sining” (The World of Art) by Federico Licsi Espino; “Paksiw na Ayungin” (Vinegar-Cooked Fish) by Jose F. Lacaba; “Tagulaylay” (Woes) by Romulo Sandoval; “Nagtatanong ang Anak Kung Bakit Kinakailangan ang Rebolusyon” (The Child Is Asking Why a Revolution Must Be) by E. San Juan; and “Ang Burges sa Kanyang Almusal” (The Bourgeois at Breakfast) by Rolando S. Tinio.

Sansiglong Mahigit ng Makabagong Tula sa Filipinas continues where the first book ends in 1980, thus extending the period covered up to 2006, although the second period now ends in 1963 instead of 1961, so that the third period begins with 1963. In his expressed desire to present Philippine poetry with a national scope, Almario includes poetry in the non-Tagalog Philippine languages, including that in the two colonial languages, Spanish and English, and provides translations in Filipino of non-Tagalog poems. However, the languages of the poems are not identified. Moreover, throughout the book, Almario spells the word Pilipinas (Philippines) as “Filipinas,” and Pilipino (Filipino person) as “Filipino,” the use of “F” being his personal preference. There is a significant increase in the number of female poets from one (Elynia Mabanglo) in the first edition to 16 in this edition. Tagalog poets who were in the first edition but excluded here are Reuel Aguila, Aurelio Angeles, Nonilon Queaño, and Aniceto F. Silvestre.

In his introduction, “Mahigit Sansiglo ng Amerikanisasyon at Nasyonalismo” (More Than a Century of Americanization and Nationalism), Almario reiterates the premises that he laid down in his introduction to the previous edition. The first period (1900-1932) opens, aptly enough, with two poems in Spanish by Cecilio Apostol. Others in this language are by Manuel Bernabe, Fernando Ma. Guerrero, and Claro Recto. Poems in non-Tagalog Philippine languages are those in Bikol by Mariano Goyena del Prado; Cebuano by Fernando Buyser, Amando Osorio, and Vicente Ranudo; Hiligaynon by Magdalena Jalandoni and Flavio Zaragoza-Cano; Ilocano by Leon Pichay; Kapampangan by Zoilo Hilario; and Waray by Eduardo Makabenta. The poets in English in this period are Amador Daguio, Trinidad Tarrosa-Subido, and Rafael Zulueta da Costa.

Almario continues to use the term “balagtasismo” to explain the poetics of this period’s non-Tagalog poems, which he observes bear the same traditionalist and nationalistic spirit of balagtasismo. Indeed, the poems of this period express this common spirit in scenic descriptions of nature and the countryside, Filipino customs and habits, peasants and workers, and national symbols like the flag and the molave tree; in political satire and allegory; and in philosophical reflections in the context of Philippine relationships.

The second section shows linguistic innovation thriving in the poetry in English, as seen in Carlos Angeles’s synesthesia, Ricaredo Demetillo’s metaphysical conceits, Alejandro Hufana’s surrealism, and Jose Garcia Villa’s avant-gardism. The female poets Angela Manalang-Gloria and Virginia Moreno assert their female persona’s power and defiance. In contrast, Diosdado P. Macapagal’s Kapampangan poem of rural courtship still places the coy maiden and her bashful suitor at the public faucet; but Godofredo S. Reyes’s Ilocano love poem is a conceit likening the beloved’s heart to a prison and building up to an ironic conclusion.

In the third period, there are 35 Tagalog poets, the new ones numbering 15, who include three women: Rebecca Añonuevo, Joi Barrios, and Benilda Santos. The poets in English number 30 in all, starting alphabetically from Gemino H. Abad, ending with Alfred Yuson, and including nine women. Almario notes the preoccupation with interiority in what he calls the “esoteric allusions” of Roberto Añonuevo, Cirilo F. Bautista, and Allan Popa; and the depiction of extremely subjective reality by Edith Tiempo, Ricardo de Ungria, and Benilda Santos. The continuity of the Balagtas tradition is evident in the subject matter of the poems in the other languages, although technique is more complex and sentiment is withheld: a woman undressing by the sea, in Cebuano by Rene Amper; love in multilayered metaphors, in Aklanon by Melchor Cichon and in Cebuano by Junne Canizares; the prostitute’s double life, in Hiligaynon by Allain Russ Dimzon; a Philippine Armageddon, in Ilocano by Juan S. P. Hidalgo Jr; an irreverent paean to a lady love, in Bikol by Francisco Peñones Jr; and the city-and-countryside dichotomy, in Waray by Victor Sugbo.

While the anthology is meant to unify the various languages of Philippine poetry into one national literature by means of one national language, there are quite a few mistranslations that cannot be dismissed as a matter of interpretation. In Macapagal’s Kapampangan poem, “inugse” (threw away) is translated as “ubusin” (consume); in Villa’s poem, the intransitive verb “lay” (nahiga) is translated as the transitive verb “inihiga” (laid); in Demetillo’s poem, the phrase “lean out” (dumungaw) is translated as “kinikilingan” (being leaned on), and “glancing on” (dumadaplis) is translated as “sumusulyap” (glancing at). Therefore, anyone relying solely on the translations would do well to consult someone knowledgeable in the language of the original.

All in all, these two books allow readers to see the sweep of Philippine poetry—a stream with balagtasismo as its wellspring, enlarged and enriched over the decades by the currents and cross-currents of modernism, formalism, feminism, and other such literary trends and movements.  Written by Edgardo Maranan, Rosario Cruz-Lucero, and Rebecca T. Añonuevo

text:
(Cell Phone Poet). Published 2005. Author, Frank G. Rivera. Editors, Arthur P. Casanova and Rolando S. Esteban. With an introduction by Herminio S. Beltran Jr. Manila: University of Santo Tomas Publishing House.

This is a collection of 257 poems intended for the short message service (SMS) of the cell phone. One hundred eighty-four of them, forming the first section of the book, were entered in SMS poetry contests and are dalit, diona, and tanaga, forms of traditional Tagalog poetry. The dalit is a monorhyming quatrain of octosyllabic lines; the diona and tanaga are stanzas of heptasyllabic lines. The remaining 73 poems are in free verse.

Intended as text messages to friends, the poems are witty and very accessible but also grammatically and orthographically correct. Even when the poems use the Paete dialect, the reader can understand or guess its meaning from the context. According to the opening poem titled “Dalit 1,” the author considers his pieces as “talinghaga” (metaphor), “tala” (star), or “damdaming ginahasa” (ravished emotions).

Like folk poetry, many of the pieces are symbolical. In “Dalit 15,” a mother is compared to a hen which has flown away, leaving its brood hungry and crying. The poem alludes to an old Tagalog poem about nestlings but in the modern contexts refers to a parent who is forced to leave her family to work abroad. The pair of rhymes—“lingap” (tender care) / “pangarap” (dream) and “siyap” (cry) / “lipad” (fly)—effectively and concisely communicate the situation.

Rivera also criticizes American imperialism, corrupt politicians, and Filipino mores. In “Dalit 9,” he calls out Filipino politicians who act as lackeys of the Americans. In a series of diona that use the days of Lent as a framework, politicians are called “pangit” (ugly) or “bugok” (bad egg). A poem puns on the name of former president Gloria Macapagal Arroyo. She is called “maitim na Sabado” (dark Saturday), in contrast to how the holy day is called: “Sabado de Gloria” (Glorious Saturday). In “Dalit 34,” the talkative local official is compared to a broken electric fan: he is noisy and entirely inutile.

Around 50 poems are on romantic love. Most are lyrical and focus on the sadness lovers feel when relationships fail. In “Kasing Amoy Mo ang Ulan” (You Smell like the Rain), every time the speaker remembers his beloved, he cannot help but compare her to the scent of the rain whose effect is like that of sweet kisses on his lips. However, the memories, as numerous as the drops of rain, make him very sad and drive him to tears. In another poem, “Diona 7,” the lover experiences pain but remains stoic. Some of the love poems are witty and funny. The poem beginning “Si Sinag, hiwalay kay Pusikit” (Sinag, who is separated from Pusikit) presents lovers who are opposites, as dark and light or night and day are. They are near each other yet cannot live together. In “Hindi Kayang Tanggalin” (Irremovable), the lover revels in the memory of the previous night’s tryst which neither toothpaste nor soap can wash away. Amorous again but now without a partner, he contents himself with soap bubbles.

Rivera’s contribution to Filipino poetry is his creative revival of traditional forms of Tagalog poetry, using them as vehicles for the expression of contemporary issues and concerns. He also proves that a new technology can be used creatively to disseminate literature without one’s sacrificing literariness or mutilating language.  Written by Romulo Baquiran Jr

In “Kasing Amoy Mo ang Ulan” (You Smell like the Rain), every time the speaker remembers his beloved, he cannot help but compare her to the scent of the rain whose effect is like that of sweet kisses on his lips. However, the memories, as numerous as the drops of rain, make him very sad and drive him to tears. In another poem, “Diona 7,” the lover experiences pain but remains stoic. Some of the love poems are witty and funny. The poem beginning “Si Sinag, hiwalay kay Pusikit” (Sinag, who is separated from Pusikit) presents lovers who are opposites, as dark and light or night and day are. They are near each other yet cannot live together. In “Hindi Kayang Tanggalin” (Irremovable), the lover revels in the memory of the previous night’s tryst which neither toothpaste nor soap can wash away. article_title: An Maupay ha Mga Waray ug Iba Pa nga Mga Siday
text:
(The Good Things about Being Waray and Other Poems). Published 2008. Author, Voltaire Q. Oyzon. With an introduction by Merlie Alunan. Manila: National Commission for Culture and the Arts and UPV Tacloban Creative Writing Program.

Oyzon’s first collection consists of 47 poems in Waray. The poems portray life in his coastal hometown of Barugo with both affection and irony. Oyzon’s poetry represents a new direction that may be taken by the contemporary siday, which tends to be critical and didactic.

The title poem approaches its theme through the persona of a drunk whose singular object in life is to keep himself soused and then to pick a fight and land in jail. In a half-humorous and ironical way, Oyzon decries the idleness and drinking common in rural Waray communities. In the same vein is “An Paghugos ni ’Tay Gayok kan Man’ Uyik nga Parahubog” (’Tay Gayok Brings the Sot, Mano Uyik, to His Grave). Man’ Uyik, wrapped in a mat, gets no elaborate send off, only the tolling of the church bell and the lone mourner leaving quickly for a cockfight where he is to serve as the referee.

The poet casts a critical eye on social and political issues. “Hi Salvador Magsusundalo” (Salvador Will Enter the Army) tells of a young man who joins the military in order to escape starvation but who is coldly aware that he could die just as well from a bullet—a comment on social injustice in the countryside. In “Pagbarol” (Drying Fish), a young woman is splitting fish for drying when two American soldiers come upon her and rape her, a scene symbolizing the entry of the American occupation forces in Balangiga, Samar.

Oyzon’s poetry departs from the established tradition of the siday, which observes meter and rhyme and the pattern of the quatrain. Written in free verse, the poems show how seamlessly the Waray idiom adapts to the usage of contemporary poetics. They also demonstrate Oyzon’s understanding of contemporary poetic craft and his skill at using them. In “Pangadi Human Kumarawat hin Bangaw” (Prayer after Receiving Alms), Oyzon’s persona thanks God for the gift of a piece of rice cake, biko. The host carefully distributes bangaw, or food offering after a prayer or procession, so that each one is served; but gate-crashers, the other meaning of the word, look to have a share of the banquet. The wordplay is the means for a wry and humorous complaint against social and divine injustice. Such irony as Oyzon practices is typical of the Waray attitude.

Oyzon is also capable of tenderness and lyricism. The persona in “Buklara an Imo mga Palad” (Open Your Hands) tells the reader that to hold something beautiful and precious like a white dove, one lets it come freely into one’s hands; then when it is ready to leave, one opens one’s hands to let it fly free. In “Pagtambal ni Apoy Kuwa han Piol ni Anling, an Iya Olitawohay nga Apo” (Apoy Kuwa Invents a Cure for Young Anling’s Broken Heart), an old woman comforts a young man in the throes of his first heartbreak.

The many voices that speak in this book are authentic voices of the Waray. The poems demonstrate Oyzon’s mastery of the idioms of his people.  Written by Merlie M. Alunan and Firie Jill Ramos

text:
(Melancholic Sentiments). Published 1912. Author, Jose Palma. Compilers, Manuel and Rafael Palma. Editor, Cecilio Apostol. With a prologue by Cecilio Apostol. Manila: Libreria Manila Filatelica.

This collection of poems in Spanish by Jose Palma was published posthumously, compiled by the author’s brothers. Fernando Ma. Guerrero’s poem “El Arbol Muerto” (The Dead Tree) was erroneously included in this collection.

Included in the collection are Palma’s first poems “Ilusiones Marchitas” (Faded Dreams), composed when he was 17 years old, and “La Cruz de Sampaguitas” (The Cross of Sampaguitas), which speaks of betrayal. Palma’s love for Florentina Arellano, his colleague in La Independencia, the newspaper of the Philippine Revolution of 1898, led to the writing of a series of romantic poems, which express his desire and frustration: “Mi Regalo de Fiesta” (My Birthday Gift), in which he offers his heart as his gift; “En Confianza” (In Confidence); “Ella!” (She); and “Tu Nido” (Your Nest). Realizing the futility of his love, Palma wrote “Resignacion” (Resignation). A final attempt to win Florentina resulted in his masterpiece, “Mi Caida” (My Downfall), a passionate expression of his undying love. Palma also wrote religious poems: “La Purificacion de Maria” (The Purification of Mary) and “Las Tres Oraciones” (The Three Prayers).

The political situation obtaining at that time inspired the poet to write “En la Trinchera” (Along the Trench). Set in the battlefield, it expresses a soldier’s anxiety for his mother. “Ven, o Paz!” (Come, Oh Peace) is an earnest longing for the war to end. The words in Palma’s “Filipinas” (Philippines) were the first lyrics of the national anthem, “Himno Nacional Filipino” (Philippine National Anthem). His final poems are in homage to Jose Rizal. “Rizal en Capilla” (Rizal in the Chapel) won second place at the Certamen Internacional (International Contest) held on 19 Jun 1902. “En la Ultima Pagina del Noli Me Tangere” (On the Last Page of Noli Me Tangere) and “El Filibusterismo” (Subversion) are on Rizal’s two novels.

Among his poems on love and patriotism, Palma’s sensitivity is best manifested in “De Mi Jardin” (From My Garden). In the guise of a love song, the delicately composed verses equate the sampaguita with the Philippines; and the persona’s refusal to pluck a sampaguita from its branch before it falls on its own affirms the value of freedom and a people’s rootedness in their native soil. “Kundiman” (Love Song) expresses his lamentations.

Sorrow and pain are two elements dominant in the poetry of Palma with the exception of “Himno Nacional Filipino,” which radiates patriotic pride, confidence, optimism, and bravery. According to Cecilio Apostol, another foremost poet in Spanish, the verses of Palma stand out for their brilliance in description and delicacy of sentiment. Other critics have noted the poet’s “feverish” inspiration and find a tone of pessimism along with tenderness and nobility.  Written by E. C. Palma

 

Sources

Benitez, Francisco, and Conrado Benitez. 1930. Stories of Great Filipinos. Manila: National Book Company.

De Veyra, Jaime, and Mariano Ponce. 1941. Efemerides Filipinas. Manila: Imprenta y Libreria de I. R. Morales.

article_title: Mga Duguang Plakard at Iba Pang Tula
text:
(Bloody Placards and Other Poems). Published 1971. Author, Rogelio G. Mangahas. Quezon City: Manlapaz Publishing Co.

This is a collection of four poems by Mangahas: “Sa Pamumulaklak ng mga Diliwariw” (The Blooming of the Acanthus), “Dalit kay Sarhento Gameng” (Elegy for Sergeant Cameng), “Mga Duguang Plakard” (Bloody Placards), and “Bahay-bahayan” (Playhouse). In his preface, Mangahas describes the progression of his consciousness as symbolized by the order in which the four long poems appear: from indecision to commitment to social change. Mangahas’s preface is an ars poetica which asserts that the aim of the engaged poet is to realize the intercalation of politics and art.

Each of the four poems is preceded by an analysis by a critic. Virgilio Almario, aka Rio Alma, uses a formalist framework in his essay on “Sa Pamumulaklak ng mga Diliwariw.” He notes the influence of T. S. Eliot on the poem and points out that while the poem is contemporary in sensibility and orientation, showing a deep awareness of the social milieu and a firm grasp of poetic craft, it invariably carries traces of rural reminiscences, particularly of Nueva Ecija, the poet’s birthplace. This explains the profusion of rustic imagery in the poem and the expression of relief when the persona returns to the province.

“Dalit kay Sarhento Gameng” was inspired by the heroics of a model policeman slain while attempting to foil a pawnshop holdup. Bienvenido Lumbera, in his essay on the poem, notes that it uses the traditional structure of an elegy in unfolding the main theme. The poem has three stages: horror as the details of the crime are recalled, the persona’s empathy with the dying policeman and the onset of peace upon the dead man, and the rising of a deep stoical insight within the persona.

“Mga Duguang Plakard,” dedicated to the fallen demonstrators on Mendiola Bridge, describes scenes from the battle near the presidential palace. It ends with an evocation of apocalyptic forces at work in the juncture of national history: the social volcano, the handwriting on the wall, and other battles to come on that fateful bridge. Of this poem, Epifanio San Juan Jr writes: “Mangahas’ strategy … is dialectical. On the surface, it is a commemorative elegy, with the swing and rhythm not unlike that of Lorca, a style also evident in the elegies of Milton, Arnold, and Whitman. On the whole, this poem stands apart from the usual, with its mixed use of imagism, realism, symbolism, and layered surrealism.”

“Bahay-bahayan” is a treatise on neocolonial relations between the United States and the Philippines, in an ironic and satiric manner. The persona, self-identified only as panauhin (visitor), is speaking to his inferiors, the hosts, and assigns them work to do, now that their “playhouse” is finished. Images of the colonized Filipino are presented: Tikyo, the draught animal; Mihiyong, the slit-eyed vendor; Maso, the digger of wells; and Aryong, a newly circumcised youth dreaming of freedom. Pedro L. Ricarte, in his analysis, uses a combination of formalism, archetypal criticism, and sociological criticism in underscoring its main features: satirical use of folklore; the use of colloquialism and graphic words for shock, recognition, and emphasis; and a radical stance that forbodes apocalypse, violence, and bloodshed.  Written by Edgardo Maranan

text:
(Poems from DYVL). Published 2005. Editors, Merlie M. Alunan, Evelina M. Acebedo, Francisca S. Custodio, and Rosemarie P. Agner. Tacloban: National Commission for Culture and the Arts National Committee on Literature, DYVL Aksyon Radyo, Province of Leyte, and University of the Philippines Tacloban College Writing Workshop (VisWRITE).

Mga Siday han DYVL contains 67 poems selected from winning pieces contributed to the DYVL program Puplonganon over a two-year period.

Puplonganon began as part of the morning news program of DYVL. Francisca “Bebs” C. Custodio, the morning newscaster, started the habit of reading an appropriate quotation in Waray after each newscast. In 1980, after nearly a year of this practice, Custodio invited her listeners to send in quotations of their own. She received not just quotations but complete poems. Some of these poems were probably original compositions, but a number might have been poems or composites of well-loved lines by older writers such as Iluminado Lucente, Eduardo Makabenta, and Vicente de Veyra—a situation typical of a language community whose literature remains largely oral.

So popular did Puplonganon become that DYVL eventually gave it its own airtime after the seven o’clock news. More interest was raised by making it into a contest. Winners of the contest were judged on the aptness of their commentary on the burning issues of the day. Poetic prowess was only a secondary consideration.

The DYVL Puplonganon remains the most reliable and popular literary venue in the region to this day. The book is a result of this realization. The works of 54 poets were selected from the winning entries. An introductory essay describes aspects of the siday canon as practiced by Makabenta and Lucente. At least 10 poets have more than one poem in the book, evidence of the frequency of their participation.

True to its role as news commentary, the DYVL Puplonganon deals with such mundane themes as the error of attending a fiesta banquet on a working day in Ambrosio Canarias’s “Pamatron” (Attending a Fiesta); the proper way of bringing up a child in Kenneth John Dapunan’s “Pagpadako nga Matadong” (Bringing Up Children); destructive envy or jealousy in Norberto Nabablit’s “Crab Mentality”; the best way to deal with women in John B. Simborios’s “Babayi” (Woman); and fatherhood in Maximo Servidad’s “Father’s Day.”

Rogelio Jomadiao, probably the most technically gifted among the DYVL poets, plies his metrics and his rhyme with virtuoso ease. However, he has yet to rise to insight and logical control, poetic traits that one may find in works of such writers as de Veyra and Lucente.

Writing and reading in Waray became the domain of the grassroots functioning mainly from a poorly understood sense of tradition. The canonical works of the Waray poets were no longer in circulation, and later writers modeled their works after them from memory, which was often inaccurate. Moreover, the new generation was also out of touch with new literary developments in the world. The stultification of literature in Waray followed the shift to English in the educational system, the continued rise of Filipino, and the despotic atmosphere of the martial law period. Mga Siday han DYVL demonstrates what happens when a language and its literary traditions fall from grace and are consigned by its users to disuse, neglect, and the usage of the marketplace.

Despite this, the book provides continuity to our fragmentary view of the progress of Waray literary history. It is a way of recognizing the heroic effort of the grassroots poets to keep Waray poetry alive. The Komite ng Sentro ng Wikang Filipino of UP Tacloban College awarded the Gawad Iluminado Lucente to DYVL in 1998 in recognition of Puplonganon’s important role in the survival of Waray literature.  Written by Firie Jill Ramos

article_title: Mga Tulang Tulala: Piling Tula sa Filipino, Bikol at Rinconada
text:
(Dumbfounded Poems: Selected Poems in Filipino, Bikol and Rinconada). Published 2004. Author, Kristian Sendon Cordero. With an introduction by H. Francisco Peñones Jr. Naga City: Goldprint Publishing House.

Of the 82 poems that make up the book, 56 are in Filipino, 15 in Bikol, and 11 in Rinconada. All the poems are in free verse, with gender politics as the common theme.

Cordero’s time in the seminary and his knowledge of the Bible are evident in many poems. In “Alter Christus,” the image of seminarians as holy is revealed as being flatly unrealistic so that it breaks the resolve of young men who aspire to become priests. A priest and a bishop are among the sex offenders and corrupt characters mentioned in “Litanya para sa mga Banal” (Litany for the Holy). In “Ako at si Magdalena” (I and Magdalena), a prostitute sees her reflection on a mirror and is reminded of her New Testament counterpart as well as of the oppression that women suffer in a male-dominated society. A case of hypocrisy is described in “Bakit Ayaw Magsimba ni Magdalena” (Why Magdalena Won’t Go to Mass) in which social restraint prevents a prostitute from attending the ordination of a young priest. He lies prone before God, but she claims that he has lain on top her, too.

Old men are depicted in the poems as sexual predators. In “Kulambo” (Mosquito Net), the speaker feels like a helpless fish caught in his uncle’s net. In “Lihim ni Mister Lim” (Mister Lim’s Secret), the store owner preys on the unwilling cashier. In “Pamahiin” (Superstition), a girl is victimized by her own grandfather. His comeuppance comes in the form of a heart attack, which kills him while he is in the toilet. To show her elation, the girl wears a red skirt during the wake.

The women attribute their misery to patriarchy and to religion. Of the 82 poems that make up the book, 56 are in Filipino, 15 in Bikol, and 11 in Rinconada. All the poems are in free verse, with gender politics as the common theme.

Cordero’s time in the seminary and his knowledge of the Bible are evident in many poems. In “Alter Christus,” the image of seminarians as holy is revealed as being flatly unrealistic so that it breaks the resolve of young men who aspire to become priests. A priest and a bishop are among the sex offenders and corrupt characters mentioned in “Litanya para sa mga Banal” (Litany for the Holy). In “Ako at si Magdalena” (I and Magdalena), a prostitute sees her reflection on a mirror and is reminded of her New Testament counterpart as well as of the oppression that women suffer in a male-dominated society. A case of hypocrisy is described in “Bakit Ayaw Magsimba ni Magdalena” (Why Magdalena Won’t Go to Mass) in which social restraint prevents a prostitute from attending the ordination of a young priest. He lies prone before God, but she claims that he has lain on top her, too.

In “Lihim ni Mister Lim” (Mister Lim’s Secret), the store owner preys on the unwilling cashier. In “Pamahiin” (Superstition), a girl is victimized by her own grandfather.
