text:
(My Nipa Hut). Published 1941. Author, Jesus Balmori. Manila: Manila Grafica Inc.

This collection of 65 poems, Balmori’s last volume, won the first prize in the Spanish poetry division of the literary contest sponsored by the Philippine Commonwealth in 1940.

Balmori’s subtle but elegant lyricism is manifested in his poems of varied themes: Spain, love, religion, nature, and the Philippine—its people, the landscape, customs and traditions. The poet expresses his profound religiosity in “En Cruz” (On the Cross), “Corazon de Jesus” (Heart of Jesus), “Gratia Plena” (Full of Grace), and “Filipinas ante su Dios” (The Philippines before Her God). His unfailing Hispanism is summarized in “Filipinas a España” (The Philippines to Spain). He compares Spain to the God of creation, when she took into her hands “el barro ardiente del Oriente” (the ardent clay of the Orient) to mould it into “un alma en la vida de una carne de amor” (a soul in the life of a flesh of love). Thus “el poeta indohispano” (the Indo-Hispanic bard, the Filipino) is grateful, dreaming of Spain’s “dulce hermosura” (sweet beauty).

In this collection, Balmori glows with nationalism as he alludes to the country’s separation from Spain. Clearly, a sublime love of country vibrates in “Patria Adorada” (Beloved Country) and in “Reina y Madre” (Queen and Mother), which he concludes in lines ringing with pride:

Soy el caliz de barro donde caen tus lagrimas;

Soy la frente de piedra donde se alza tu aurora;

Soy tu azul estandarte de ilusion y esperanza;

Y soy, por sobre todo, el hombre mas altivo,

El que mas orgulloso puede estar de su raza,

Porque soy filipino! y con mis propias manos

He roto tus cadenas, patria mia adorada!

 

(I am the earthen cup where your tears drop;

I am the firm forehead where your dawn shines;

I am your blue banner of illusion and hope;

And I am, above all, the loftiest man,

That could be the proudest of your race,

Because I am a Filipino! And with my own hands

I broke your chain, beloved country of mine!)

Most of his love poems, such as “Madrigal Galante” (Gallant Madrigal), “Renunciacion” (Renunciation), “ Rosas ” (Roses), and “Despues de Todo” (After All), exalt pain, the sacrifice and suffering that romantic love oftentimes entails. But in the philosophical “Yo Fui tu Divino Maestro” (I Was Your Divine Teacher), Balmori points with pride to what a woman gains after he severs ties with her:

Yo te enseñe a sufrir. La vida tiene espinas

Lo mismo que las rosas. Y todo amor es cruz.

Ahora tienes el alma con heridas divinas

Y con llagas de luz.

 

(I taught you to suffer. Like a rose

Life has thorns. Every love is a cross.

Now your soul has wounds that are divine

And wounds of light.)

On the whole, the entire collection has been cited for extolling the simplicity of life and the noblest ideas of the human race.  Written by Reynaldo Coronel Jr, with notes from E. S. Adolfo

 

Sources

Alinea, Estanislao B. 1964. Historia Analitica de la Literatura Filipino-Hispana. Manila: Imprenta los Filipinos.

Mariñas, Luis. 1974. Literatura Filipina en Castellano. Madrid: Editorial Nacional.

article_title: Minugbo Alang sa Mugbo og Kalipay
text:
(Shorts for the Shortjoyed). Published 2009. Author, Adonis Durado. Translator, Anthony L. Kintanar. With a preface by the author. Cebu City: Asteismus and Bathalad Inc.

The poems in this collection, no more than 10 lines long each, are grouped into 10 cycles, or suites. The opening words of the preface capture both the spirit and form of the collection. There is the promise of urgency, and words that should be capitalized are not. The author’s premise is that its intended readers prefer brief poems—the mubo og kalipay, or the “shortjoyed,” although these were written with as much care as his long poems. Durado also gives a glimpse of his creative process: he challenged himself to write at least one poem every night for three months.

“Hagawhaw sa Kagabhion” (Night Whispers) consists of 31 nocturne poems, each with an image associated with evening, such as the moon, bats, and cicadas. Improbable juxtapositions are used to provoke startling insight; an allusion to the indigenous myth of why the moon forever flees from the sun is made in a pithy poem about father slapping mother.

The five poems that compose “Buakong mga Balak” (Chipped Poems) ruminate on the nature of mirrors and reflections. The five poems in “Simod sa Limod (Mga Tinaguang Balak sa Usa ka Asawa)” (At the Philtrum of Denial [A Wife’s Hidden Verses]) are a disgruntled wife’s responses to her unhappy marriage. “Dulot sa Bukog” (Close to the Bone), with 11 poems, explores the hollowness that a loss leaves behind and pays attention to absence that asserts itself in forms of loosely associated objects: a blind man’s corn cob reminding him of his harmonica; a woman’s blood that stains her white blouse screaming for the earring snatched off her ear; and a tiny puddle’s silence after a typhoon.

One cloud is interpreted three ways in “Balak sa Tulo ka Pasaherong Gadungag Tutok sa Panganod” (Poems of Three Passengers Staring at the Clouds), the three personae being a Buddhist monk, a divorcee, and someone described as the “long-waiting one.” The four poems in “Haranang Kibol” (Short-Tailed Serenade) are interspersed with five closed couplets in a series called “Love Song.” The tender addresses to the beloved in “Love Song” have an eager tone, whereas those in the cycle “Taliwala Nimo ug Ako: Lima ka Haiku” (Between You and Me: Five Haikus) are wistful and yearning. For instance, the image of crows cawing is a measure of the beloved’s distance from the persona.

In “Kulitog sa Pusod” (Poking the Navel) are 11 poems of visceral experiences of longing. Another set of 11 poems in “Tinagurha” (Couplets) vary in subjects, examples of which are a healed wound speaking of the knife that cut it; the luckless raffle draw winners who find no use for their prizes; and a glass regaining its pristine form when emptied. The final section, titled “Mubog Tubol, Mabawg Kigol” (Impatient Turd, Shallow Ass), are mostly composed of metapoems: the Villa-esque “Poem with a Very Short Attention Span” is an emoticon; and the incantatory “Makalibang Unta Ka” (May You Defecate) is a curse cast by the embittered persona on a former beloved.

The untitled poem that does not figure into any of the cycles, referred to as pamaraw (teaser) on the table of contents, introduces to the reader the strength of the short poems by the metaphor of a stone thrown into a lake, uttering “the law of the universe.” The collection uses indigenous forms of Cebuano poetry—garay (verses), tigmo (riddles), and panultihon (proverbs)—but puts traditional themes, such as courtship, love, and loss, in modern situations.  Written by Julian dela Cerna

text:
(Mysteries and Other Poems). Published 2005. Author, J. Neil C. Garcia. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

Misterios and Other Poems consists of three sections: “Poems from Amsterdam: A Cycle,” “Misterios,” and “Uncollected Poems.”

“Poems from Amsterdam: A Cycle” is a lyric sequence of 61 poems, numbered, which make up the bulk of the book. Casual, almost rote, description of scenery is interspersed with the heady philosophical questions. The contrast reinforces the themes of alienation and finding one’s self in all the surrounding foreignness. Here is the self-conscious Filipino poet transplanted and sometimes overwhelmed. He finds solace, escape, and salvation in language. In “XX,” a visit to the doctor highlights the language barrier and makes for a confession of brokenness. “XXIII” contrasts the homosexual lifestyle in Amsterdam, the world’s gay capital, and that in Manila. “XXIX” is spurred by a letter from a former lover. Garcia catalogs the scenes of the city with the eye of a stranger: the consistency of bread, the unfamiliar purring language from the TV set, the tanned bodies of the tall natives. The twist in the end is that the poet has already forgotten this lover.

“Misterios” is another lyric sequence. It reimagines the mysteries of the life and death via Christ’s crucifixion. The 15 poems here are lovely and ambitious renderings, starting with “The Anunciation” and ending with “The Coronation.” The graceful and young Mary asks, “What does it mean to be told God loves you, / at the same time he takes your childhood away?” Jesus Christ is very human, with Garcia darkly painting him with self-doubt and hesitation even right up to the end, in the poem “The Resurrection.”

“Uncollected Poems” consists of 16 poems, among them two sestinas, including one of Garcia’s oft-seen works: “Sestina: For My Father.” The poems here serve to illustrate Garcia’s versatility. Garcia’s language is by turns controlled, gushing, and startling.

This collection illustrates Garcia’s versatility as he writes in the tradition of the Filipino poet, seduced by the glittering cities of the West but still turning his eyes homeward and his bright and burning gaze inward.  Written by Arvin Abejo Mangohig

text:
(My Last Farewell). Written 1896. Author, Jose Rizal. Anthologized in Poesias de Rizal, (Poems of Rizal) compiled by Jaime C. de Veyra, Manila: Bureau of Printing, 1946. Translations into the different local languages and into foreign languages in Doctor Jose Rizal’s Mi Ultimo Adios, compiled by Regino P. Paula, Manila: National Historical Institute, 1989. Among the local languages are Cebuano, Kapampangan, Ilonggo, and Tagalog; among the foreign languages are English, French, German, Hungarian, Chinese, Swedish, and Latin.

This last poem of Rizal was supposedly composed in his prison cell on the eve of his execution in 1896. In 14 rhyming quintillas or five-line stanzas, the poem is a dying person’s stirring declaration of unwavering love for country and of solidarity with all of his patriotic country folk.

In the opening stanzas, the persona bids goodbye to the native land, which is addressed in glorious epithets: “region del sol querida” (clime of the sun carress’d) and “nuestro perdido Eden” (our Eden lost). Declared are the persona’s final hopes: that the country folk remember the persona even in death and that they pray for those who, like the speaker, fought for the country.

No bitterness at the prospect of death is expressed. Instead, with the knowledge that the death is not for naught but for the nation, there is calm resignation (trans. Charles Derbyshire):

… ¡ah, que es hermoso caer por darte vuelo,

morir por darte vida, morir bajo tu cielo,

y en tu encantada tierra la eternidad dormir!

 

(… sweet it is for thee to expire,

To die for thy sake, that thou mayst aspire,

And sleep in thy bosom eternity’s long night!)

The persona’s only desire is that “mis cenizas, antes que vuelvan a la nada, / el polvo de tu alfombra que vayan a formar” (my ashes may carpet thy earthy floor, / Before into nothingness at last they are blown).

Paradoxically, the end of the persona’s own life will mark the beginning of a new life for the country, a dawn. This paradox, as is the persona’s patriotism, is nowhere more evident than in the image in the third stanza in which the persona tells the native land to use his or her blood to dye the rays of the rising sun with. As Rizal’s most popular poem, it is also the most often translated Philippine poem. There are about 15 known translations of the poem in Cebuano alone. Andres Bonifacio, the supremo or chief of the Katipunan, the secret society against Spain, made a Tagalog translation of the poem, called “Pahimakas” (Farewell). Noted writer Nick Joaquin made an English translation titled “Rizal’s Valedictory Address.”

Critics agree that the poem is Rizal’s greatest accomplishment as a poet. Leon Ma. Guerrero notes that “we are assured by authorities in Spanish literature that [the poem] can rank with the best of its kind in that language.” Rafael Palma opines that the patriotic cry has never been more movingly expressed than in this, Rizal’s last poem.  Written by Jonathan Chua, with notes from Ruby Alcantara

article_title: Mostly in Monsoon Weather: Poems New and Revisited
text:
Published 2007. Author, Marne L. Kilates. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

The author’s preface, written in poetic prose, depicts monsoon season as a time for “mooning” and thus explains why it is the poet’s most “fertile period.” The collection itself is divided into two sections, which reflect the country’s two seasons as well as the cyclical nature of Filipino life: “In Dry Season Light” and “Mostly in Monsoon Weather.”

Many of the poems are combinations of narrative and description. In “In Dry Season Light,” some poems, such as “Legacies,” “Tumbrel,” “That Luna Woman,” and “Leo’s Light,” have epigrams about historical or current events that serve as Kilates’s references for his reflections. “That Luna Woman,” for instance, is about the government’s extravagant purchase of Juan Luna’s Parisian Life. Kilates employs a series of rhetorical techniques, questioning both the decision and the interpretation of the painting. But he allows the reader to make his own judgment on the matter.

Memory is a recurring theme in this collection. Using the literal and metaphorical meaning of weather, Kilates presents memory as being dependent on external factors. It plays a significant role in shaping our beliefs and our identity, not only as individuals but also as a nation.

“In Dry Season Light” presents human problems, political, personal, and metaphysical, by means of images of the mundane. There is the shanty on an abandoned lot (“Shanty on a Lot Vacated by a Bank”), male pattern baldness (“Alopecia”), or the changing of hair colors (“Dyeing”). The second part of the collection presents how memory becomes a problem the moment monsoon weather arrives. The author’s preface, written in poetic prose, depicts monsoon season as a time for “mooning” and thus explains why it is the poet’s most “fertile period.” The collection itself is divided into two sections, which reflect the country’s two seasons as well as the cyclical nature of Filipino life: “In Dry Season Light” and “Mostly in Monsoon Weather.”

THE ABDUCTION AND WEDDING OF TWO NEGRITO MAIDENS: A LABIN AGTA NEGRITO EPIC

Published 2003. Chanter, Baket Anag of Maraburab, Alcala, Cagayan. Transcriber and translator, Ernesto Constantino. With a preface by Tsunekazi Moriguchi. Kyoto: Nakanishi Printing Co., Ltd.

The Labin Agta Negritos of Cagayan province have an epic poem called Nanang. The word nanang is also their term for epic poetry. In 1977, Ernesto Constantino recorded Baket Anag as she chanted four cycles, or songs, of the nanang, the first of which he titled “The Abduction and Wedding of Two Maidens.” The second recorded cycle is Nanang: I Taguwasi anna i Innawagan (Epic: Taguwasi and Innawagan), although this cycle was published first, in 2001. The two remaining cycles have yet to be transcribed and translated.

The cycle titled “The Abduction and Wedding of Two Maidens” can be divided into four episodes, each one centering on an abduction: that of Kabugnayan, of the men, of the women, and finally, of Dappit ya Danum. Thus, despite its title, there are actually four abductions. In the first part of this cycle, Ammani is the hero who rescues the abducted maiden, Kabugnayan. He is later aided by Kabugnayan’s brothers, Talimanog and Annibo. Talimanog and Ammani’s sister, Alig, are wed; and so are Ammani and Kabugnayan.

The narrative opens with Ammani asking his sister, Alig, for betel chew before he goes roaming in the sky. Elsewhere, Talimanog asks his sister, Innawagan, the same. Both are gone for years. When Ammani returns, he calls Alig from the yard, and she bids him come into the house. Inside the house, Ammani repairs his spear at the corner of his window but does not take the seat made of pure gold. Ammani asks Alig to make him a betel chew. As Alig splits the betel nut, it cries out with pain. It tells them that its mistress, Kabugnayan, has sent for help because she has been abducted by the big bird, Bannug. Her abductor is forcing her into marriage but, in the meantime, she is being made to clean her abductor’s yard.

Ammani flies off to rescue the abducted maiden. He fights with Pane Nagdombilan, who bars his way at the golden door at the foot of the sky. Ammani summons his angin (inner power) from his G-string. On the fifth try, Ammani finally smashes the door with his angin’s help, and he searches for Bannug. It is at the foot of the sky but the maiden’s abductor, Pane Tatallapan, is at the tenth layer of the sky, where there is great rejoicing because Tatallapan is about to wed the abducted maiden. Ammani assures Tatallapan he comes with good intentions, so Tatallapan offers him a scoop of wine. Ammani introduces himself as Ammani from Donglayon. The wedding guests are suddenly very still.

Meanwhile, Talimanog and Annnibo, who have been walking by the river, stop at Alig’s front yard. She asks them to look for her brother, Ammani. Ammani has gained entry into Pane Tatallapan’s house and finds Kabugnayan, the abducted maiden, underneath a blanket. Ammani tries to persuade her to let him take her to his home in Idonglayong but she hesitates in fear of Pane Tatallapan’s anger. When she finally escapes with him, he happily walks out dancing. Triumphantly, he throws and breaks Tatallapan’s jar of wine, and Tatallapan’s coconut shell rolls on the floor. Tatallapan is angered by Ammani’s deception. Ammani warns Kabugnayan to shield herself behind Pane Tatallapan’s house before he releases his angin in a duel with Tatallapan. Ammani wins the duel. Kabugnayan lights up the foot of the sky with “the side of her midriff” as they travel back home.

Ammani and Kabugnayan arrive at the place of her brother, Talimanog. Pane Tatallapan comes roaring into the scene, and the men engage him in battle. Annibo orders his spear to strike Tatallapan. Kabugnayan is standing quietly where they are fighting. Ammani asks Kabugnayan to light up the river of Idonglayon. She flies up and causes the river to overflow and drown the pursuers. Ammani hacks at them. He takes Tatallapan’s head by the hair, preparing to behead him. Talimanog restrains Ammani, pointing out that the enemy has begged for mercy. Ammani makes Tatallapan ask for forgiveness but Tatallapan stands up and wishes only for his strength back. Ammani and Talimanog arrive at Alig’s front yard with Kabugnayan, and Alig bids them come in.

It is Talimanog’s wedding day. Alig and the people of Nagdombilan are shouting with joy as they gather in Talimanog’s house. Kabugnayan, Asisigtan, and Dappit ya Danum are there. Talimanog makes sure that the chairs are facing each other. In a ceremonious expression of exaggerated humility, he asks the ladies to hack him with their bolos and throw his body in the front yard.

Kabugnayan gifts Alig, now her sister-in-law, with items of apparel, jewelry, and perfume. All the guests, including Pane Nagdombilan and the people of Nagdombilan, each give her a similar set of gifts. They call on Inalay-ayan, the ruler of rainbows, to light up the sky. More guests arrive, including Pane Tatallapan. Talimanog asks Kabugnayan to sit on a chair beside Ammani. Dappit ya Danum wishes for nightfall, and Inalay-ayan reproaches her for covering him with night. Talimanog offers Inalay-ayan and Pane Nagtunungan their seats. Kabugnayan asks Ammani to split a betel nut for the guests’ betel chews, but Ammani needs only a single betel nut to multiply itself for all the guests. Kabugnayan, the bride, serves betel chews to the guests and returns to Ammani’s side. Everyone is shouting with joy. Pane Paglebut ya Langit wishes them well.

The servant worries that not all the wine will be consumed, so Ammani drinks it all up. Gawan plays the tongatong (bamboo musical instrument), Indaw plays the gong, Diparong dances, and Karanayan joins him. Everyone joins in the dancing.

The second part opens with the Kinallinga (enemies) yelling at the foot of the sky. Paguyyawi orders Kanikan (giant python) to capture all the bachelors. Makindaranum (crocodile) will abduct all the maidens. Makindaranum pulls the bachelors away with his tail. At sunset, Kanikan emerges roaring from the riverbank, and passes by the pomelo and banana plantations. It enters the house and swallows up Pane Nagdombilan, Bannanayo, Ammani, Talimanog, and Inalay-ayan.

The third abduction is by Makindaranum the crocodile, who initially threatens to swallow only Kabugnayan, but she and all the maidens sit on its back instead. With the women riding on its back, Makindaranum goes home to the “navel of the river.”

Meanwhile, Kanikan takes its male captives to its master, Nugunug Paguyyawi, who is making decorative incisions on his spear. But the men emerge from Kanikan’s belly. Inalay-ayan and Paguyyawi fight. Paguyyawi then hurls Diparong to the ground. He reveals that Diparong is his father, whom he resents. When his mother Karanayan was pregnant with him, the jealous Diparong had struck Karanayan while she was bathing in the river Idonglayon and had caused her to miscarry. The fetus was Paguyyawi, who floated downriver in a golden bowl, which Alig came upon and covered with fragrant leaves. Kanikan covered him with foam, which was actually Karanayan. Paguyyawi ends by calling his father the night and stating he would have died without other people’s kindness. Talimanog is moved to tears, calls him “allay” (friend), and offers to let himself be killed by Paguyyawi. Paguyyawi desists, saying that it is only because of his father’s rejection that he harbors angry thoughts. He joins the men walking cheerfully back home.

The story of the abduction of the women by the crocodile continues. Discovering that the women have been taken by Makindaranum, the men go to the navel of the river, and Paguyyawi commands the water to part for the women to escape through. Talimanog challenges Pusad a Danum (Navel of the River) to a fight. They wrestle by the riverbank until they bore inside the earth. Amangaw, Pusad a Danum’s spirit, and Namutumukan, Talimanog’s spirit, also fight. The river, having been diverted, roars and overflows. Paguyyawi calls on his mother, Karanayan, for help. Karanayan climbs up the riverbank to Talimanog’s yard.

Meanwhile, the enemies, the Kinallinga, have arrived, vowing to kill the people of Idonglayon, whom they call liars. But the people defeat the Kinallinga, who flee. The people celebrate their victory. Inalay-ayan and Dappit ya Danum dance to the music of Gawan’s tongatong and Indaw’s gong. Inalay-ayan asks Dappit for betel chew. She gives it to him, and Inalay-ayan exclaims that he will die from her betel chew.

Talimanog sends his messenger bird, Dalawesan, to Master Bullalayaw to ask him to prepare the gold that his Master Inalay-ayan needs for his wedding. Dalawesan flies through the vast skies until he tires. He lands on the shoulder of Karanayan, Inalay-ayan’s mother, and tells her to prepare the gold for her son’s wedding. Karanayan hurries toward Inalay-ayan’s house, where the people have gathered for the wedding. Pane Nagdombilan puts her inside his betel chew pouch. When the men arrive at Talimanog’s house, Karanayan emerges from the pouch, as do all the other maidens out of their pouches. Diparong is among the guests, and Talimanog welcomes him. Karanayan and Inalay-ayan reconcile with Diparong.

The fourth abduction is that of Dappit ya Danum during her wedding to Inalay-ayan. The gift giving is proceeding when Bannug swoops in and snatches Dappit away. It has been sent by Pane Namansawan ya Langit to find him a bride who is equal to him. Inalay-ayan pursues them. He pushes his way through a place full of aluwaluwa vines and mist, until he reaches Pane Namansawan’s house. He puts Dappit ya Danum in his betel chew pouch and defeats both Pane Namansawan and Bannug. He beheads Namansawan and throws the head toward “the tree where dead people hang.” The women take Dappit ya Danum out of the betel chew pouch, and the maidens rejoice at her return.  Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero

 

NANANG: I TAGUWASI ANNA I INNAWAGAN

(Epic: Taguwasi and Innawagan). Published 2001. Chanter, Baket Anag. Transcriber and translator, Ernesto Constantino. With a preface by Tsunekazu Moriguchi. Kyoto: Nakanishi Printing Co., Ltd.

Nanang is the term for epic poetry among the Labin Agta Negritos of Cagayan province. Nanang: I Taguwasi anna i Innawagan is one episode of the nanang and the first known Philippine Negrito epic to be published, although another episode, The Abduction and Wedding of Two Negrito Maidens, was recorded first but published two years later, in 2003. Both were chanted by Marcela Tumbali, aka Baket Anag, in 1977 in Maraburab village in the municipality of Alcala, Cagayan. In this episode of the nanang, the heroes are three brothers named Talimanog, Ammani, and Annibo. They have two sisters, Innawagan and Alig, who play an active role in the narrative. A fourth hero, Taguwasi, becomes their brother-in-law after he helps the brothers rescue their sister, Innawagan, from her abductor. Taguwasi’s sister, Sinag, plays a minor part in the rescue.

The epic’s first two lines are the chanter’s acknowledgment of the presence of the hero Talimanog. The action begins with the lady Innawagan’s abduction by the bird Ammalabukkaw. Innawagan is detained at the fifth layer of the sky to be someone’s bride, presumably the sky god Pane Kalimangalnuk ya Langit. Innawagan’s older sister Alig tasks their three brothers—Talimanog, Ammani, and Annibo—to rescue Innawagan. The three brothers fly toward the foot of the sky, lighting it up as they do so. Talimanog instructs Innawagan’s bird Dundunan to free her but Pane Kalimangalnuk foils him. Talimanog’s chest roars, indicating his readiness to do battle. He takes Innawagan out to “the front yard” of the sky.

For many months, the three brothers take turns dueling with Kalimangalnuk ya Langit and his arrow, a metonymy for Kalimangalnuk’s fighting prowess. Ammani falls first and then Annibo. Talimanog’s battle with Kalimangalnuk lasts for years, but he, too, falls.

Fearing for Talimanog, Innawagan sends Talimanog’s bird Dalawesan to her sister Alig for help. Two thorns get in Dalawesan’s way as he travels through the “surroundings of the sky,” and they taunt him to cry. When Dalawesan reaches Alig’s place, he somersaults and perches on her shoulder. He tells Alig of his mission, and she replies that the rescuer is in the place where the sun rises. Dalawesan flies, his tail lighting up the sky. He lands at the foot of the sky but can find no opening.

Sinag is looking out her window, fanning herself. Dalawesan somersaults, lands, and tells her of his mission. Sinag replies that her brother might be able to help but he is out roaming the sky. She packs betel nut chew and her fragrance, a metonymy for her essence, thus her identity, for Dalawesan to give to her brother. Dalawesan sets out in search of Sinag’s brother. He complains of fatigue from wandering all over the sky. Taguwasi, the man he seeks, is sitting and making decorative incisions on his bolo. Dalawesan flies by, fanning Taguwasi’s face. Taguwasi introduces himself, identifying himself as “a person,” and Dalawesan recognizes him as the well-known warrior who will succeed where Innawagan’s brothers have failed: to free her. He offers Innawagan’s hand in marriage if Taguwasi succeeds.

Taguwasi agrees to rescue Innawagan; otherwise, he says, she will be forced to marry her captor by the end of the month. Dalawesan gives Taguwasi his sister Sinag’s betel nut chew and perfume. Taguwasi puts the chew in his mouth, declares it delicious, and is energized to go. Dalawesan again complains of extreme fatigue, perches on Taguwasi’s shoulder, and continually pecks at Taguwasi’s ears.

At the fifth layer of the sky, Pane Nagdombilan, who guards the door made of gold, blocks Taguwasi and Dalawesan. Because Pane Nagdombilan’s eyes are made of earth, Taguwasi knows that he is “not a person”—that is, that Pane Nagdombilan is a supernatural creature. Taguwasi lets Dalawesan rest while he duels with Nagdombilan. He calls upon his angin (spirit-wind) in his G-string to strike the door made of gold, and he prays to the ina nanolay (Mother of Life) for help. Taguwasi’s angin in his chest roars, but neither his arrow, brute strength, nor the wind can budge the two-layered door made of gold. Taguwasi and his angin try again until, at last, they blow the door loose. Taguwasi shuffles his feet and pulls the door up, makes it lie on its side, before he hurls it toward the place where the sun sets. Taguwasi now sends his angin to rest where the night also rests.

The people exclaim how beautiful “the front yard” is. It is Innawagan sitting there, shining like the bright moon. But Talimanog, who has been fighting with Pane Lumutumukanin, aka Kalimangalnuk, is weakening. Taguwasi walks toward Kalimangalnuk, his head bowed and his feet heavy. Kalimangalnuk jeeringly calls him “person” and tells him to hurry up. Taguwasi somersaults and lands in “the front yard.” But Innawagan exclaims that Talimanog has died. She asks Dalawesan accusingly where her rescuer is. The bird points behind him at Taguwasi. Innawagan pleads for his pity and his help, but Taguwasi is too late, for Talimanog has died. Taguwasi reproaches them all for not waiting for him long enough.

With renewed energy, Taguwasi, his chest roaring, resumes his battle with Kalimangalnuk. Asisidtan, Ammani’s sister-in-law, remarks that Taguwasi’s chest is the source of his power but he must also guard against Kalimangalnuk’s arrow. Taguwasi calls upon his angin and prays to Ina Nanolay to send Kalimangalnuk’s arrow away. Again, there is a prolonged battle until Kalimangalnuk weakens.

Taguwasi rescues Innawagan. She ties Ammani and Annibo to her waist with her fragrance and Taguwasi grabs Talimanog. Innawagan takes Ammani’s bolo and she shines like the moon at its fullest. With Talimanog’s arrow, she opens up “a crack at the foot of the sky.” The earth cracks open and she somersaults and lands on it.

Taguwasi turns around and there is Kalimangalnuk again, standing before him, with his allies. Taguwasi and his angin fight Kalimangalnuk in earnest until they hurl him away. Taguwasi and his companions kill all the enemies and hang the headless corpses, which light up the sky.

Taguwasi and his companions are now at Nagdombilan’s place, but so is Kalimangalnuk. Taguwasi pushes Innawagan toward the corner of her door, promising to defeat Kalimangalnuk for certain. Innawagan is reluctant to leave him but she walks along the big river until she reaches home, aka Talimanog’s land. The men at the orange grove catch sight of her. Taguwasi, too, is there and calls to Alig. But Kalimangalnuk reappears and fights with Taguwasi, who does not recognize him and thinks he is “a person.” But Kalimangalnuk reveals his name. Taguwasi beheads him, throws his corpse to the tree where Ammani hangs the dead, and throws his head away.

Alig invites Taguwasi up to their house, where Innawagan is waiting, and a mat made of gold is prepared for Taguwasi. The people rejoice until they realize that Ammani, Talimanog, and Annibo’s fragrance, or spirit, is fading. Innawagan tasks the servants to prepare the mats of gold for her three brothers. Alig brings Ammani back to life by putting betel nut chew into his mouth; Aran (Ammani’s aunt) does the same with Talimanog; and Alugasan (Annibo’s sister-in-law) does the same with Annibo. Alig calls for the river from the “surroundings of the sky” to flow to the middle of the floor of the house for the three brothers to bathe in. One by one, the three brothers jump and frolic in the river and drink its water. They become fully restored.

Meanwhile, Taguwasi’s sisters—Sinag, Kabugnayan (Ammani’s wife), Dapit ya Dannum, and Asisidtan—are searching for their brother “in the surroundings of the sky.” Bananayo, Tarubani, and Kadukallan join them. Talimanog is looking out the window when they reach his yard and he welcomes them in. Talimanog insists that they sit on the seats, poor though these be, instead of on the floor, like servants.

The rites of courtship now commence. Taguwasi’s sisters, Asisidtan and Sinag, humble themselves before Talimanog, who in turn pretends to push them away. Then, it is Talimanog’s turn to be Innawagan’s spokesperson, and Sinag is Taguwasi’s. When the marriage is approved, the people rejoice. Talimanog’s sisters give Innawagan a dowry of skirts, a bracelet, perfume, earrings, and gold. They make her sit beside Taguwasi, and Sinag covers Innawagan with the dowry gifts, though this lasts till nighttime.

The Katallaritan Kinallingas, tiring of the noise, decide to attack the wedding with shields and spears. Led by Pane Namandiyanin, they travel through Talimanog’s coconut and banana groves. On the way, they engage in battle with Nagdombilan and then Nagdugwan, both of whom they defeat. When the Kinallingas reach the wedding reception, Taguwasi defeats them with his arrow and bolo. Taguwasi cuts off the Kinallingas’ heads and throws them to the tree where the dead are hung. At last, Taguwasi and Innawagan sit side by side on the floor. The people celebrate the victory and the ladies marvel at Taguwasi’s unsurpassed prowess.

This epic will strike the reader who is not knowledgeable in its literary conventions and its cultural and metaphysical references as possessing elements of fabulation and a dreamlike structure. It is, certainly, one of the most dazzling and challenging narratives in Philippine literature.  Written by Jay Jomar F. Quintos and Rosario Cruz-Lucero

The servant worries that not all the wine will be consumed, so Ammani drinks it all up. Gawan plays the tongatong (bamboo musical instrument), Indaw plays the gong, Diparong dances, and Karanayan joins him. Everyone joins in the dancing.

The second part opens with the Kinallinga (enemies) yelling at the foot of the sky. Paguyyawi orders Kanikan (giant python) to capture all the bachelors. Makindaranum (crocodile) will abduct all the maidens. Makindaranum pulls the bachelors away with his tail. At sunset, Kanikan emerges roaring from the riverbank, and passes by the pomelo and banana plantations. It enters the house and swallows up Pane Nagdombilan, Bannanayo, Ammani, Talimanog, and Inalay-ayan.

The third abduction is by Makindaranum the crocodile, who initially threatens to swallow only Kabugnayan, but she and all the maidens sit on its back instead. With the women riding on its back, Makindaranum goes home to the “navel of the river.”

Meanwhile, Kanikan takes its male captives to its master, Nugunug Paguyyawi, who is making decorative incisions on his spear. But the men emerge from Kanikan’s belly. Inalay-ayan and Paguyyawi fight. Paguyyawi then hurls Diparong to the ground. He reveals that Diparong is his father, whom he resents. When his mother Karanayan was pregnant with him, the jealous Diparong had struck Karanayan while she was bathing in the river Idonglayon and had caused her to miscarry. The fetus was Paguyyawi, who floated downriver in a golden bowl, which Alig came upon and covered with fragrant leaves. Kanikan covered him with foam, which was actually Karanayan. Paguyyawi ends by calling his father the night and stating he would have died without other people’s kindness. Talimanog is moved to tears, calls him “allay” (friend), and offers to let himself be killed by Paguyyawi. Paguyyawi desists, saying that it is only because of his father’s rejection that he harbors angry thoughts. He joins the men walking cheerfully back home.

The story of the abduction of the women by the crocodile continues. Discovering that the women have been taken by Makindaranum, the men go to the navel of the river, and Paguyyawi commands the water to part for the women to escape through. Talimanog challenges Pusad a Danum (Navel of the River) to a fight. They wrestle by the riverbank until they bore inside the earth. Amangaw, Pusad a Danum’s spirit, and Namutumukan, Talimanog’s spirit, also fight. The river, having been diverted, roars and overflows. Paguyyawi calls on his mother, Karanayan, for help. Karanayan climbs up the riverbank to Talimanog’s yard.

Meanwhile, the enemies, the Kinallinga, have arrived, vowing to kill the people of Idonglayon, whom they call liars. But the people defeat the Kinallinga, who flee. The people celebrate their victory. Inalay-ayan and Dappit ya Danum dance to the music of Gawan’s tongatong and Indaw’s gong. Inalay-ayan asks Dappit for betel chew. She gives it to him, and Inalay-ayan exclaims that he will die from her betel chew.

Talimanog sends his messenger bird, Dalawesan, to Master Bullalayaw to ask him to prepare the gold that his Master Inalay-ayan needs for his wedding. Dalawesan flies through the vast skies until he tires. He lands on the shoulder of Karanayan, Inalay-ayan’s mother, and tells her to prepare the gold for her son’s wedding. Karanayan hurries toward Inalay-ayan’s house, where the people have gathered for the wedding. Pane Nagdombilan puts her inside his betel chew pouch. When the men arrive at Talimanog’s house, Karanayan emerges from the pouch, as do all the other maidens out of their pouches. Diparong is among the guests, and Talimanog welcomes him. Karanayan and Inalay-ayan reconcile with Diparong.

The fourth abduction is that of Dappit ya Danum during her wedding to Inalay-ayan. The gift giving is proceeding when Bannug swoops in and snatches Dappit away. It has been sent by Pane Namansawan ya Langit to find him a bride who is equal to him. Inalay-ayan pursues them. He pushes his way through a place full of aluwaluwa vines and mist, until he reaches Pane Namansawan’s house. He puts Dappit ya Danum in his betel chew pouch and defeats both Pane Namansawan and Bannug. He beheads Namansawan and throws the head toward “the tree where dead people hang.” The women take Dappit ya Danum out of the betel chew pouch, and the maidens rejoice at her return.  Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero
NANANG: I TAGUWASI ANNA I INNAWAGAN
(Epic: Taguwasi and Innawagan). Published 2001. Chanter, Baket Anag. Transcriber and translator, Ernesto Constantino. With a preface by Tsunekazu Moriguchi. Kyoto: Nakanishi Printing Co., Ltd.

Nanang is the term for epic poetry among the Labin Agta Negritos of Cagayan province. Nanang: I Taguwasi anna i Innawagan is one episode of the nanang and the first known Philippine Negrito epic to be published, although another episode, The Abduction and Wedding of Two Negrito Maidens, was recorded first but published two years later, in 2003. Both were chanted by Marcela Tumbali, aka Baket Anag, in 1977 in Maraburab village in the municipality of Alcala, Cagayan. In this episode of the nanang, the heroes are three brothers named Talimanog, Ammani, and Annibo. They have two sisters, Innawagan and Alig, who play an active role in the narrative. A fourth hero, Taguwasi, becomes their brother-in-law after he helps the brothers rescue their sister, Innawagan, from her abductor. Taguwasi’s sister, Sinag, plays a minor part in the rescue.

The epic’s first two lines are the chanter’s acknowledgment of the presence of the hero Talimanog. The action begins with the lady Innawagan’s abduction by the bird Ammalabukkaw. Innawagan is detained at the fifth layer of the sky to be someone’s bride, presumably the sky god Pane Kalimangalnuk ya Langit. Innawagan’s older sister Alig tasks their three brothers—Talimanog, Ammani, and Annibo—to rescue Innawagan. The three brothers fly toward the foot of the sky, lighting it up as they do so. Talimanog instructs Innawagan’s bird Dundunan to free her but Pane Kalimangalnuk foils him. Talimanog’s chest roars, indicating his readiness to do battle. He takes Innawagan out to “the front yard” of the sky.

For many months, the three brothers take turns dueling with Kalimangalnuk ya Langit and his arrow, a metonymy for Kalimangalnuk’s fighting prowess. Ammani falls first and then Annibo. Talimanog’s battle with Kalimangalnuk lasts for years, but he, too, falls.

Fearing for Talimanog, Innawagan sends Talimanog’s bird Dalawesan to her sister Alig for help. Two thorns get in Dalawesan’s way as he travels through the “surroundings of the sky,” and they taunt him to cry. When Dalawesan reaches Alig’s place, he somersaults and perches on her shoulder. He tells Alig of his mission, and she replies that the rescuer is in the place where the sun rises. Dalawesan flies, his tail lighting up the sky. He lands at the foot of the sky but can find no opening.

Sinag is looking out her window, fanning herself. Dalawesan somersaults, lands, and tells her of his mission. Sinag replies that her brother might be able to help but he is out roaming the sky. She packs betel nut chew and her fragrance, a metonymy for her essence, thus her identity, for Dalawesan to give to her brother. Dalawesan sets out in search of Sinag’s brother. He complains of fatigue from wandering all over the sky. Taguwasi, the man he seeks, is sitting and making decorative incisions on his bolo. Dalawesan flies by, fanning Taguwasi’s face. Taguwasi introduces himself, identifying himself as “a person,” and Dalawesan recognizes him as the well-known warrior who will succeed where Innawagan’s brothers have failed: to free her. He offers Innawagan’s hand in marriage if Taguwasi succeeds.

Taguwasi agrees to rescue Innawagan; otherwise, he says, she will be forced to marry her captor by the end of the month. Dalawesan gives Taguwasi his sister Sinag’s betel nut chew and perfume. Taguwasi puts the chew in his mouth, declares it delicious, and is energized to go. Dalawesan again complains of extreme fatigue, perches on Taguwasi’s shoulder, and continually pecks at Taguwasi’s ears.

At the fifth layer of the sky, Pane Nagdombilan, who guards the door made of gold, blocks Taguwasi and Dalawesan. Because Pane Nagdombilan’s eyes are made of earth, Taguwasi knows that he is “not a person”—that is, that Pane Nagdombilan is a supernatural creature. Taguwasi lets Dalawesan rest while he duels with Nagdombilan. He calls upon his angin (spirit-wind) in his G-string to strike the door made of gold, and he prays to the ina nanolay (Mother of Life) for help. Taguwasi’s angin in his chest roars, but neither his arrow, brute strength, nor the wind can budge the two-layered door made of gold. Taguwasi and his angin try again until, at last, they blow the door loose. Taguwasi shuffles his feet and pulls the door up, makes it lie on its side, before he hurls it toward the place where the sun sets. Taguwasi now sends his angin to rest where the night also rests.

The people exclaim how beautiful “the front yard” is. It is Innawagan sitting there, shining like the bright moon. But Talimanog, who has been fighting with Pane Lumutumukanin, aka Kalimangalnuk, is weakening. Taguwasi walks toward Kalimangalnuk, his head bowed and his feet heavy. Kalimangalnuk jeeringly calls him “person” and tells him to hurry up. Taguwasi somersaults and lands in “the front yard.” But Innawagan exclaims that Talimanog has died. She asks Dalawesan accusingly where her rescuer is. The bird points behind him at Taguwasi. Innawagan pleads for his pity and his help, but Taguwasi is too late, for Talimanog has died. Taguwasi reproaches them all for not waiting for him long enough.

With renewed energy, Taguwasi, his chest roaring, resumes his battle with Kalimangalnuk. Asisidtan, Ammani’s sister-in-law, remarks that Taguwasi’s chest is the source of his power but he must also guard against Kalimangalnuk’s arrow. Taguwasi calls upon his angin and prays to Ina Nanolay to send Kalimangalnuk’s arrow away. Again, there is a prolonged battle until Kalimangalnuk weakens.

Taguwasi rescues Innawagan. She ties Ammani and Annibo to her waist with her fragrance and Taguwasi grabs Talimanog. Innawagan takes Ammani’s bolo and she shines like the moon at its fullest. With Talimanog’s arrow, she opens up “a crack at the foot of the sky.” The earth cracks open and she somersaults and lands on it.

Taguwasi turns around and there is Kalimangalnuk again, standing before him, with his allies. Taguwasi and his angin fight Kalimangalnuk in earnest until they hurl him away. Taguwasi and his companions kill all the enemies and hang the headless corpses, which light up the sky.

Taguwasi and his companions are now at Nagdombilan’s place, but so is Kalimangalnuk. Taguwasi pushes Innawagan toward the corner of her door, promising to defeat Kalimangalnuk for certain. Innawagan is reluctant to leave him but she walks along the big river until she reaches home, aka Talimanog’s land. The men at the orange grove catch sight of her. Taguwasi, too, is there and calls to Alig. But Kalimangalnuk reappears and fights with Taguwasi, who does not recognize him and thinks he is “a person.” But Kalimangalnuk reveals his name. Taguwasi beheads him, throws his corpse to the tree where Ammani hangs the dead, and throws his head away.

Alig invites Taguwasi up to their house, where Innawagan is waiting, and a mat made of gold is prepared for Taguwasi. The people rejoice until they realize that Ammani, Talimanog, and Annibo’s fragrance, or spirit, is fading. Innawagan tasks the servants to prepare the mats of gold for her three brothers. Alig brings Ammani back to life by putting betel nut chew into his mouth; Aran (Ammani’s aunt) does the same with Talimanog; and Alugasan (Annibo’s sister-in-law) does the same with Annibo. Alig calls for the river from the “surroundings of the sky” to flow to the middle of the floor of the house for the three brothers to bathe in. One by one, the three brothers jump and frolic in the river and drink its water. They become fully restored.

Meanwhile, Taguwasi’s sisters—Sinag, Kabugnayan (Ammani’s wife), Dapit ya Dannum, and Asisidtan—are searching for their brother “in the surroundings of the sky.” Bananayo, Tarubani, and Kadukallan join them. Talimanog is looking out the window when they reach his yard and he welcomes them in. Talimanog insists that they sit on the seats, poor though these be, instead of on the floor, like servants.

The rites of courtship now commence. Taguwasi’s sisters, Asisidtan and Sinag, humble themselves before Talimanog, who in turn pretends to push them away. Then, it is Talimanog’s turn to be Innawagan’s spokesperson, and Sinag is Taguwasi’s. When the marriage is approved, the people rejoice. Talimanog’s sisters give Innawagan a dowry of skirts, a bracelet, perfume, earrings, and gold. They make her sit beside Taguwasi, and Sinag covers Innawagan with the dowry gifts, though this lasts till nighttime.

The Katallaritan Kinallingas, tiring of the noise, decide to attack the wedding with shields and spears. Led by Pane Namandiyanin, they travel through Talimanog’s coconut and banana groves. On the way, they engage in battle with Nagdombilan and then Nagdugwan, both of whom they defeat. When the Kinallingas reach the wedding reception, Taguwasi defeats them with his arrow and bolo. Taguwasi cuts off the Kinallingas’ heads and throws them to the tree where the dead are hung. At last, Taguwasi and Innawagan sit side by side on the floor. The people celebrate the victory and the ladies marvel at Taguwasi’s unsurpassed prowess.

This epic will strike the reader who is not knowledgeable in its literary conventions and its cultural and metaphysical references as possessing elements of fabulation and a dreamlike structure. It is, certainly, one of the most dazzling and challenging narratives in Philippine literature.  Written by Jay Jomar F. Quintos and Rosario Cruz-Lucero

text:
Published 1956. Author, Ricaredo Demetillo. Quezon City: Guinhalinan Press.

This collection of 38 poems in English was, with a few exceptions, written between 1950 and 1952, around the period that the poet attended the Iowa Poetry Workshop. This fact will help the reader contextualize the images, themes, and avowedly humanist and internationalist sensibility that the young poet was concerned with then.

The poems, most of which work out classic themes in the Greek, Christian, and Middle East mythic traditions, are filtered through a modern sensibility. “Corpethua, Uncover Your Bride” is vintage sample of mythic-modern sensibility of “daedal healings”; of “her hair’s intrigue that enmesh you with fragrance.” There is a strong nature imagery in the poems. “Shrivelling Autumn,” for example, makes the reader dally unhurriedly from images of “bough aspen” to “painted pergolas in the sky of a long gone summer.”

“The Lover’s Death” is an affecting paean for a peasant, although it may well have been written for a peasant of any nationality, not specifically Filipino. It is rescued from sheer sentiment by a deft touch at the last line. Also included are poems that consciously go back to Demetillo’s roots, prefiguring his later collections. “Barrio Weaver,” for instance, a poem anthologized in textbooks, presents images nearer home—bamboo tree shade and the sun over a mountain ridge, giving cheerful, momentary greeting, while children hunt mushrooms in the tropical grass.

In “Sand and the Lolling City,” the longest poem in this collection, the poet explores the rise and fall of civilization. Captured in the poem is a vision on the edge of despair, as the world of the Roman empire comes to an end. But it is a knowing, not helpless, despair of measured contemplation, as the allusion to the messianic Christian hope of the times tempers the inquietude.  Written by Victoria S. Calizo

text:
Published 2003. Author, Romulo P. Baquiran Jr. With an afterword by Fidel Rillo. UP Jubilee Student Edition. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press. Manila Critics Circle’s National Book Award for poetry, 2004.

Onyx is a collection of 56 poems divided into three sections. The first section, “Sa Piging ng Puso” (In the Heart’s Feast), opens with the poem “Paghanap sa Onyx” (Searching for the Onyx), where the quest for the ideal is symbolized by the search for the elusive stone amid the squalor of the city. The pursuit, however, is not romanticized. The persona relates the improbability of success to the miseries of society. Thus, the persona implores his companion not to lose empathy with the surroundings, as losing it would also signify one’s loss of faith in the onyx.

This commitment to the onyx compels the different personas in the succeeding poems to unearth the true nature of their experiences, most of which unfold as various permutations of desire and love. In the second section, “Oyayi ng Kabundukan” (Mountain Lullaby), Baquiran portrays both the beauty and tragedy of the Cordilleras and its people. There are the people’s collective song celebrating their kinship with the mountains and their bounty in “Ayyeng” (Chant); a village elder’s defiant stand against a dam project of the government in “Sal-idummay ni Macli-ing Dulag” (Song of Macli-ing Dulag); the invasion of corporations that exploit and destroy the life of the mountain and its people in “Open Pit Mining”; and a tourist emerging reborn out of a magnificent cave in “Sumaging.” Through these voices, Baquiran weaves together the historical with the personal, geography and culture, and the indigenous with the foreign to create a tapestry of the interconnected narratives of the Cordilleras.

The book’s third section, “Singsing ni Solomon” (Ring of Solomon), alludes to the biblical king’s legendary power and wisdom. Baquiran offers this ring to enable us to listen to familiar flora and fauna speaking about their own being and attributes, often in contrast to the way people perceive them. The result is a work of defamiliarization: the poems present a new way of experiencing and understanding the world of each persona while they reveal the inanity of human actions and existence.

In “Ahas” (Snake), for example, Baquiran reconfigures the serpent’s significance and its relation to people. The persona attributes its sharp senses to its lack of limbs, and juxtaposes its reputation as the originator of sin with people’s inherent ability to do what it pleases. As the poem unfolds, what the reader gleans is a creature of humility and reason that is fearful of man’s freedom.

Baquiran’s versatility proves itself in his use of modernist free verse in some poems, and the traditional rhyme-and-meter form in others. The poems, wrought with acute images and metaphors, possess a degree of lyricism, whether they are written in free verse or are patterned after the rhyme and meter of Tagalog poetry.

In his afterword, Rillo states that an onyx lies embedded in each poem in the collection. That this gem can only be retrieved through the act of close reading speaks of what Onyx attests to: Baquiran’s devotion to Filipino poetry as his craft, and his respect for its readers, to whom he offers his art.  Written by Om Narayan Velasco

article_title: Pagdakop sa Bulalakaw ug Uban Pang Mga Balak
text:
(To Catch the Firebird and Other Poems). Published 2012. Author, Merlie M. Alunan. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

Known for her award-winning poems in English, this collection is Alunan’s first book of Cebuano poetry. Alunan’s Cebuano poems, written over a 10-year period, from 1997 to 2007, are here accompanied by her own English translation. The book also includes the collection that won second place at the Gawad Komisyon ng Wikang Filipino in 2007.

The author’s introduction and afterword serve as bookends to the collection, the first by explaining the rationale for the burden of translation that the author has taken upon herself, and the second by situating the poems—and here in greater detail, the translation process—within the author’s literary autobiography.

In this book, Philippine national culture and history are not only depicted and dramatized in their local, regional specificities—for example, the Balangiga massacre and other representations of Fil-Am relations (Superman, Barbie, and Tarzan)—but also personalized through a persona speaking in the idiom of ordinary people. Regional details (flora and fauna, games, cuisine, customs, and practices) function not merely as the conventional device of “local color” but more as imagery, symbol, and metaphor, so as to evoke personal, cultural, and political tensions in the poems.

The poetry collection is divided into nine sections, each part made up of a suite of poems or a long poem, with the common folk as persona. “Kun Swertihon” (If One Gets Lucky) is made up of seven short interrelated poems about courtship and love using folk imagery. “Kun Mangagalon an Misay” (Cat Seeks a Master) delves into the theme of belongingness and alienation in six poems revolving around domestic pets, family, familiar objects, and friends. “Ang Malitok sa Dila” (What Tongue Can Utter) is a four-part poem on the triumph of poetry despite one’s poverty, with the figure of Cebuano poet Adonis Durado as central figure. “Gikan sa Escrito en Sangre” (From “Escrito en Sangre”) mines the historical narratives surrounding the Balangiga incident during the Philippine-American War through a reimagining in four poems of how Balangiga men and women responded to genocide perpetrated by American soldiers. “Ampatuan, Maguindanao, 23 Nobyembre 2009 A.D.” (Ampatuan, Maguindanao, 23 November 2009 A.D.) is a long poem that rallies the profusion of words to counter how one is struck dumb by unimaginable evil. “Tulay sa Dauis” (Bridge in Dauis) is a three-part piece on the theme of rootedness and dreams. “Suwab sa Bulan” (Sickle Moon) is a four-part poem on love as seen from the eyes of a girl serving palm wine to the men and women gathered at Inay Moring’s store. “Pamato” (Lead Stone), made up of six poems, uses the metaphor of childhood games to examine the concept of home. “Kun Unsaon Pagdakop sa Bulalakaw” (How To Catch the Firebird) is the author’s ars poetica, using the image of taming the mythical firebird as its central metaphor.

The English versions are so competently and creatively transformed from the Cebuano original that they can be read as poems in themselves without reference to the original. Two poems, “Barbie en’ Tarzan” and “Carmelita the Cootie Girl,” are striking for Alunan’s translation of these into an unmistakably Filipino dialect of English. Thus, the poems are clearly identifiable as a part of the two literary traditions in which they belong, which are modern Cebuano poetry and Philippine poetry in English.

This book represents the degree of high achievement that Philippine literature is capable of. It is written in Cebuano, a language that is not the culturally and politically dominant one called the “national language,” yet it expresses the national experience of the Filipino, culturally and historically, precisely because it is rooted in the specifics of a geographic locality.  Written by Jhoanna Lynn Cruz and Rosario Cruz-Lucero

The poetry collection is divided into nine sections, each part made up of a suite of poems or a long poem, with the common folk as persona. “Kun Swertihon” (If One Gets Lucky) is made up of seven short interrelated poems about courtship and love using folk imagery. “Kun Mangagalon an Misay” (Cat Seeks a Master) delves into the theme of belongingness and alienation in six poems revolving around domestic pets, family, familiar objects, and friends. “Ang Malitok sa Dila” (What Tongue Can Utter) is a four-part poem on the triumph of poetry despite one’s poverty, with the figure of Cebuano poet Adonis Durado as central figure. “Gikan sa Escrito en Sangre” (From “Escrito en Sangre”) mines the historical narratives surrounding the Balangiga incident during the Philippine-American War through a reimagining in four poems of how Balangiga men and women responded to genocide perpetrated by American soldiers. “Ampatuan, Maguindanao, 23 Nobyembre 2009 A.D.” (Ampatuan, Maguindanao, 23 November 2009 A.D.) is a long poem that rallies the profusion of words to counter how one is struck dumb by unimaginable evil. “Tulay sa Dauis” (Bridge in Dauis) is a three-part piece on the theme of rootedness and dreams. “Suwab sa Bulan” (Sickle Moon) is a four-part poem on love as seen from the eyes of a girl serving palm wine to the men and women gathered at Inay Moring’s store. “Pamato” (Lead Stone), made up of six poems, uses the metaphor of childhood games to examine the concept of home. “Kun Unsaon Pagdakop sa Bulalakaw” (How To Catch the Firebird) is the author’s ars poetica, using the image of taming the mythical firebird as its central metaphor.

The English versions are so competently and creatively transformed from the Cebuano original that they can be read as poems in themselves without reference to the original. Two poems, “Barbie en’ Tarzan” and “Carmelita the Cootie Girl,” are striking for Alunan’s translation of these into an unmistakably Filipino dialect of English. Thus, the poems are clearly identifiable as a part of the two literary traditions in which they belong, which are modern Cebuano poetry and Philippine poetry in English.

This book represents the degree of high achievement that Philippine literature is capable of. It is written in Cebuano, a language that is not the culturally and politically dominant one called the “national language,” yet it expresses the national experience of the Filipino, culturally and historically, precisely because it is rooted in the specifics of a geographic locality.  Written by Jhoanna Lynn Cruz and Rosario Cruz-Lucero

text:
(Love for the Native Land). Published Mar 1896. Author, Andres Bonifacio, Kalayaan. English translation by Gregorio Nieva in The Revolutionists: Aguinaldo, Bonifacio, Jacinto, edited with an introduction and notes by Teodoro A. Agoncillo. Manila: National Historical Commission, 1973, from the Spanish translation in “Andres Bonifacio” by Epifanio de los Santos in Revista Filipina, Nov 1917.

This poem of 28 dodecasyllabic quatrains, or four-line stanzas of 12 syllables per line, is Bonifacio’s lyrical statement of a love for country that led to the Revolution of 1896. The first stanza states the poem’s thesis in rhetorical questions:

Aling pag-ibig pa ang hihigit kaya

Sa pagkadalisay at pagkadakila

Gaya ng pag-ibig sa tinubuang lupa?

Aling pag-ibig pa? Wala na nga, wala.

 

(Is there any love that is nobler

Purer and more sublime

Than the love of the native country?

What love is? Certainly none.)

The next four stanzas present his arguments supporting this thesis. It is a real love for country that transforms all citizens—treacherous or primitive, poor or ignorant—into noble and respectable persons. No sacrifice is too much for one’s country; blood, wealth, knowledge, endurance, effort, and even life itself—all these are worth giving up for her.

In the next few stanzas, the poet explains why the country deserves such self-sacrificing love. Likening the country to one’s mother, he points out that one’s first sight upon birth is one’s own land upon which the sun shines; that it is the warmth of her embrace that one feels; her fresh breeze that relieves one of the deepest pains.

A description of the country’s beauty and natural resources strengthens this argument and explains why it must not be allowed to fall into the treacherous hands of foreign oppressors.

 

In a series of rhetorical questions, the poem shames the Tagalog for their passivity:

Nasaan ang dangal ng mga Tagalog?

Nasaan ang dugong dapat na ibuhos?

Baya’y inaapi, bakit di kumilos

At natitilihang ito’y mapanood?

 

(Where is the honor of the Tagalog?

Where the blood that should be flowing?

Their country oppressed—why not act

Instead of simply watching her suffer?)

Thus, love for country must inevitably translate into action to defend and protect it; and the poet, in no uncertain terms, makes his call to action:

Hayo na nga kayo, kayong nangabuhay

Sa pag-asang lubos na kaginhawahan

At walang tinamo kundi kapaitan

Hayo na’t ibigin ang naabang Bayan.

 

(Come, all of you, who are alive

You who dream of a life of freedom

And have tasted naught but sorrow

Come and love your unhappy country.)

The lyrics of the poem were set to music by Salvador Jorque, ca 1970, and first recorded by Inang Laya in Pagpupuyos, 1980.  Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero

text:
Transcribed 1997. Chanters, Gem-gem Bagued, Delia Jardinero, and Fernando Lingsa. Transcriber and translator, Paul D. Jagmis Sr, “Pala’isgen: Ang Epiko ng mga Tagbanua” (Pala’isgen: The Epic of the Tagbanua). PhD diss., Holy Trinity College, Puerto Princesa City, Palawan.

The Tagbanwa epic about a hero named Pala’isgen was reconstructed from six episodes chanted by three Tagbanwa persons on separate occasions in three different barangays of the municipality of Aborlan, Palawan. The epic consists of 1,465 lines.

Part 1, “Pala’isgen Visits the People of the Earth,” perfunctorily introduces Pala’isgen’s family: living on the seashore is Magreng, the father whose four sons are Buaya, the eldest; Baybayanen, the second; Pala-isgen, the third; and Liokyangan, the fourth. Pala’isgen and Liokyangan fly above the earth in a biday (boat), and Pala’isgen, seeing the world at war, orders everyone to stop fighting. Peace reigns at last. In part 2, “Pala’isgen Courts Tubod kat Bulawan,” Pala’isgen, accompanied by his brother Liokyangan, travels to Tubod kat Bulawan’s island to court her. She tells him she will defer to her father, Letang Bato. As she says this, the sea sends large waves, and Pala’isgen commands them to retreat so he can pass through. Letang Bato consents to the match. In part 3, “Preparations for Pala’isgen and Tubod’s Wedding,” Pala’isgen demonstrates his magic powers as he uses his talisman to produce the most lavish wedding feast, laid on golden plates and glasses. The people speculate that he must be a diwata (god). In part 4, “Letang Bato Visits Pala’isgen and Tubod’s Home,” Pala’isgen carries his father-in-law on his back as they fly to his home. Seeing the golden contents of his son-in-law’s house, Letang Bato is satisfied that Pala’isgen is a true Diwata.

Part 5, “Pala’isgen’s Battle with the Giants,” is a longer episode. Its narrative elements and characters seem to have been greatly influenced by the Spanish corrido (metrical romance), which has been adapted into the Philippine korido. The episode opens with a quarrel between Pala’isgen and his wife, Tubod kat Bulawan. Pala’isgen goes for a long walk and falls asleep by a tree. In a dream, an old man tells him to go to the source of the wind, where he will receive happy news. Pala’isgen disguises himself as a filthy, smelly beggar and changes his name to Maskinan. He returns home and discovers that a giant has taken his wife. Maskinan sits by the river contemplating how to rescue his wife when a crab tells him that a giant has taken Tubod kat Bulawan to the seventh room of a seventh mountain, and that every room is guarded by a giant. They are fattening up Tubod before they eat her. Pala’isgen sheds his disguise, takes his kris, and whistles for a beautiful bird. The bird warns him to act only just before dawn when the giants will neither see nor smell him. Pala’isgen kills the first six giants and, before proceeding to the seventh room, takes a nap. The old man instructs him in a dream to summon the bumblebee. The bee comes and carries Pala’isgen to Tubod’s prison, from where the couple fly to the place of the source of the wind. They live up on a tree and never quarrel again.

Part 6, “Pala’isgen and His Brothers Fight with Tigre on Mt. Nanlaliban,” is twice as long as parts 1-5 combined. Pala’isgen woos Tubod but she wonders how he will feed her when all he knows is how to do battle. Pala’isgen is enraged at this and transforms into a santermo (Saint Elmo’s fire), with burning eyes. Tubod wishes that he were more like Ruray Karuraynen, who is rolling in wealth. Pala’isgen retorts that if she were a man, she would have flown out the window by now, or would be walking on the fields, with all the trees cut down by his anger. He plants the antenganen, the tree of life and death, in front of her house.

Pala’isgen goes on a quest for his father, Biyarong-Barongan, using his kerchief for a sail, and his large dagger and kris for a helm. He flies for years, until he sights Tigre’s kingdom sprawling in the mountains and his subjects forming a line. From the seashore to the kabagtik (mountain forest of almaciga trees), the doors and windows are facing one another. Pala’isgen sees his father Biyarong-Barongan, whose head is now a window ornament, its golden hair like pouring rice when the breeze passes by.

For five days and nights Pala’isgen rests on top of the coconut tree in front of Tigre of Nanlaliban’s house. Tigre’s daughter sees him and shouts for her father, exclaiming that revenge for Biyarong-Barongan has finally come. Tigre is amused, saying that what alarms her is nothing more than a meal for him to eat. The gong’s sound reaches the seventh mountain, the eighth plateau. The warriors arrive in formation, lined up like a wall, their spears like cogon grass. They mock Pala’isgen’s manhood, and he reddens with anger, like the biyangunan (spirit of one who has been killed violently). He spins his golden shield until only the point of his spear is visible. When he leaps up, 50 are killed; when he lands, another 50 are killed. The girl cries out to her father to help the warriors defeat the man who kills 50 at every leap. His father laughs and mocks his daughter for being afraid of a mere piglet.

Meanwhile, Pala’isgenan’s brother Baybayanen has decided to go in quest of Pala’isgen, who has been gone too long. Tubod kat Bulawan hands him tobacco and betel chew to give to Pala’isgen when Baybayanen finds him. Baybayanen bids the slaves eat first before they pull his biday to the sea. The biday is as big and high as Mount Sundayapen, its peak almost reaching the stars. For a long time, Baybayanen waits to see his biday from his window. But the slaves cannot pull the biday and have all gone home. Baybayanen calls upon his pet balalatok (woodpecker) to pull the biday. Instantly the bird flies, lands on the boat’s pole, and pulls it. It glides like a strand of hair and stops at the dock.

Baybayanen flies on his biday, while his brothers, Piyamituunan and Magundali-dali, travel with him, separately but at the same speed. For five days and nights, they fly in the air. The santermo asks them where they are from, and they reply that that they are from the place where the sun sets.

After a five-day journey, Baybayanen lands on the island of Daragat Pungtudanen (Maiden of the Isle). Baybayanen refuses the maiden’s offer of tobacco and betel chew. The Daragat sends a typhoon to Baybayanen’s biday, which heaves up and down on the waves, their crest almost reaching the stars. The slaves weep helplessly. Even Tagal Manansalan, the best helmsman among all, cannot control the biday. Suddenly they are back at the dock, where they had sailed from. The power of the Maiden of the Isle prevents it from budging.

Piyamituunan loses his way and lands at the isle of Mali-wali. Magundali-dali journeys for a long time until he lands on top of the red coconut tree, which stands in front of Tigre’s house. Here he finds his brother-in-law Pala’isgen, whom he must fight in battle. The maiden sends her pet bee to investigate why the brothers Pala-isgen and Magundali-dali are fighting. The bee sprinkles them with the oil of Tilagdamay, and the two men, recognizing each other, burst into laughter. Magundali-dali gives Pala’isgen the tobacco and betel chew that Tubod kat Bulawan has sent.

Meanwhile, Baybayanen has landed on the Island of Maliwaliw, where everything is reversed. He sees Piyamituunan, whom a whirlwind and a strong typhoon has swept toward this island. Baybayanen stops for drinks with his uncles before he resumes his journey. It lasts for years, until he arrives at the vast country of Tigre of Nanlaliban. He, too, sees his father’s head, now Tigre’s house ornament. Baybayanen opens fire on Tigre’s house with a cannon, and half a wall flies up. Tigre’s family and subjects call for him to return home before they are all exterminated, because Baybayanen and Pala-isgen’s revenge has come. Women are pitiful, the narrator remarks, for they are nothing more than someone’s meal.

Tigre takes up arms against Piyamituunan, Baybayanen, Biyarong-barongan, and Magundali-dali, none of whom can hit him. He mocks them for their incompetence. The battle lasts for years. Exhausted, the four brothers stop fighting and try to come up with a plan to defeat the Tigre. Pala-isgen commands his sword to fly up and drop down on Tigre’s neck. Tigre finally dies.

Later, the brothers come upon Marupandayanen, carving a sheath for his kris. Marupandayanen challenges them to a fighting game. During the prolonged battle, all the crops, including the coconut trees, are felled. The Maiden of the Isle sends her bee to sprinkle them with her magic oil to stop them from fighting, because they are all brothers after all. At this revelation, the six men stop fighting and laugh merrily. Taking their father’s head with them, they all fly home, except Baybayanen, who decides to go by sea. After journeying for years, they arrive at Baybayanen’s dock, from where all the brothers walk home. Pala-isgen is welcomed home by his smiling wife, Tubod kat Bulawan. Their elder brother, Paraparampo, is also there to welcome them.   Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero

text:
(The Panggingge Card Player). Serialized 17 Aug 1912–14 Nov 1912 in El Renacimiento. Author, Lope K. Santos. Included in Puso at Diwa, volume 2, Manila: Limbagan at Litograpya ni Juan Fajardo, 1913. Included in Ang Pangginggera at mga Piling Tula ni Lope K. Santos. Editor, Virgilio Almario, Manila: Balagtas Bicentennial Commission, 1990.

This is a 788-stanza narrative poem subtitled “Alay sa Kababaihang Tagalog” (Dedicated to Tagalog Women). The panggingge is a card game which Santos uses to symbolize not only human frailty expressed as vice, but also the predicament of women trapped in the mores of a conservative society and the strictures of patriarchy.

While the narrative itself ostensibly recounts the travails of a certain woman who remains unnamed throughout, the poet’s addressee is unmistakable in the apostrophe with which the poem begins: “Oy, kung sino ka man” (You, whoever you are). The woman in the poem is a housewife whose devotion to her husband changes soon after her firstborn dies. To cope with loneliness and boredom, she learns to gamble. She gets addicted to it, heedless of her husband’s entreaties. Her husband is also addicted to vice—cockfighting. Marital woes come their way, involving infidelity on her part, jealousy, and separation. Her father and parents-in-law intervene, she is able to overcome her crisis, and she returns to her husband, bearing him another child. She finds work as a sewer, enjoys an improved relationship with her husband who has found gainful employment, and their life improves. But she and husband again get into gambling. The narrative closes on a tragic note. Her child dies as a consequence of her negligence.

The last five stanzas have subheadings and serve as concluding didactic statements from the poet on human foibles and vice. An awkward absolution of women is given. Gambling women should not be blamed, for the real culprit is the “leniency” of their husbands who refuse to exercise “manly” responsibilities over their wives. Included in Puso at Diwa, volume 2, Manila: Limbagan at Litograpya ni Juan Fajardo, 1913. Included in Ang Pangginggera at mga Piling Tula ni Lope K. Santos. Editor, Virgilio Almario, Manila: Balagtas Bicentennial Commission, 1990.

This is a 788-stanza narrative poem subtitled “Alay sa Kababaihang Tagalog” (Dedicated to Tagalog Women). The panggingge is a card game which Santos uses to symbolize not only human frailty expressed as vice, but also the predicament of women trapped in the mores of a conservative society and the strictures of patriarchy.

She gets addicted to it, heedless of her husband’s entreaties. Her husband is also addicted to vice—cockfighting. Marital woes come their way, involving infidelity on her part, jealousy, and separation. Her father and parents-in-law intervene, she is able to overcome her crisis, and she returns to her husband, bearing him another child. She finds work as a sewer, enjoys an improved relationship with her husband who has found gainful employment, and their life improves. But she and husband again get into gambling. (Leyte-Samar Poetry and Drama). Published 1994. Editor and translator, Jaime B. Polo. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

The anthology features poems and plays from Samar and Leyte, both in the original and in translations in Filipino. It contains folk songs and riddles from the collections of Fr Cantius Kobak, Vicente de Veyra, and Agustin El O’Mora; poems by Iluminado Lucente, Francisco Alvarado, Casiano Trinchera, Eduardo Makabenta, Ricardo Octaviano, and Agustin El O’Mora; and four plays.

The poems are arranged by their dates of publication between 1922 and to 1957. Among the poems and folk songs are those with Cebuano titles: “Mag-uuma Kab-oton Ang Kagawasan (Farmers, Reach Out for Freedom), “Datu Tuod Sila” (They Are Truly Wealthy), and “Kababayen-an Makigbisog Ka” (Women, Fight). The poems might have come from the revolutionary movement in Southern Leyte, where the lingua franca is Cebuano.

Love of country, social and political ills, anticolonial sentiments, and the language woes of the Bisaya are the recurrent themes of the selections. Lucente’s “Pag Bangon, Pepe!” (Arise, Pepe!) adjures Jose Rizal to rise from the dead because the country still needs him. “Pilipinas” (Philippines) is an avowal of love for country. The same themes are echoed in Alvarado’s “Pilipinas” and “Nihaga” (after Benedicto Nihaga, a lieutenant executed in 1897 for helping the Katipunan). Trinchera, a feisty critic of society, denounces in his “Napolo nga Istraik” (Ten Strikes) the frailties of society, including misuse of language, gambling, and bribery. Makabenta has several poems decrying the bastardization of the native language. In “Watsamara Yu,” 1957, a humble citizen suffers injustice because of his “Kinatsila nga borgatok” (pidgin Spanish). In “Bakit Ba Natin Tatagalogin” (Why Should We Speak in Tagalog), Makabenta rails against people who speak Tagalog even when they are in the Visayas. El O’Mora’s “Espanya, Amerika, Hapon ngan Han Yinaknan” (Spain, America, Japan and Our Language) denounces the loss of the mother language owing to the desire of the colonizers to teach us their own.

Polo includes two plays by Lucente: An mga Anak han Luha (Children of Sorrow), about a starving father and his daughter who escape arrest by offering their last rooster to the officers; and Mga Retrato han Akon Bungto (Images of My Country). According to Polo’s note, Lucente wrote a play, Abugho, in the 1920s but lost the manuscript in a fire, so he rewrote it and gave it the title that is used in this anthology.

In Norberto Romualdez’s An Anak han Manaranggot (The Palm Sap Gatherer’s Daughter), Ines, the eponymous protagonist, forgives the wrongs done to her by Yayong, her suitor. Balitaw sa Atong Panahon (Balitaw of Our Times), by the collective Bisaya’t Manggagawang Pangkultura, is written in Filipino with a smattering of Waray, Ilonggo, and Cebuano. The thin plot serves as a platform for songs and the balitaw.

Panulaan is not a definitive representation of Lineyte-Samarnon literature. The introduction does not explain the choice of poets included in the anthology, Polo’s translations are inaccurate, and some of the primary texts are handled carelessly. The table of contents gives the titles of the poems in translations in Filipino only. Lucente’s “Ha Akon Tunang Natawhan” (To the Land of My Birth) appears under the title “Ang Lupang Tinubuan” in the table of contents but is given the title “An Iroy nga Tuna” (The Motherland) in the anthology itself. Only two quatrains of the song appear in the book, with no caveat that what is printed is an excerpt.  Written by Merlie M. Alunan and Michael Carlo Villas
