text:
TAUSUG FOLK LITERATURE

Published 1988. Transcriber, Rita Tuban. In Tambara 5 (Dec): 143-71

 

THE PARANG SABIL OF ABDULLA AND PUTLI’ ISARA IN SPANISH TIMES

Published 1973. Chanter, Indah Annura. Transcriber and translator, Mohammad Daud Abdul. Editors, Ricardo Adjawie and Rose Marie Adjawie. In Sulu Studies 2. Revised edition in Voices of Sulu: A Collection of Tausug Oral Traditions. Editor, Gerard Rixhon. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press, 2010.

Parang Sabil is the epic of the Tausug (“people of the current”) of the Sulu archipelago. It consists of songs that celebrate the heroism of legendary warriors and defenders of the Muslim faith. The songs are performed by both men and women, sometimes accompanied by the indigenous bamboo xylophone called gabbang. The musical accompaniment is described as “fast, with moderate pitch which is sometimes high, sometimes low, and with percussive stress” (Tuban 1988, 144).

The etymology of parang sabil reveals its religious nature. It is a combination of the Malay word perang, meaning “war or sword,” and the Arabic word fil sabil-ullah, meaning “in the way of Allah.” Thus, parang sabil means “taking up the sword or going to war in submission to the will of Allah.” The term refers to both the epic and the practice of taking up arms in obedience to Allah.

The epic came into existence during the Spanish period, and it was largely inspired by the spirited Muslim defense of Sulu, the dar ul-Islam, abode of Islam, against the Spaniards and their Christianized mercenaries. The conquest of Jolo by the Spaniards in 1635 instigated a series of unrelenting attacks by local Muslims called sabil to prevent further Spanish inroads. The songs in the epic sprung largely from the Tausug sense of individual or collective notion of martabat or personal honor, pride, self-esteem, and of sipug or shame but also the capacity for virtue in a person. This appears to be borne by the themes of the more popular songs in the epic, such as “Kissa kan Panglima Hassan” (The Song of Panglima Hassan), about the hero who dies while resisting the imposition of taxes, and the “Parang Sabil of Abdulla and Putli’ Isara in Spanish Times,” which revolves around the attempt of the protagonists to avenge Putli Isara’s honor, besmirched by a Spanish soldier.

Some of the more popular legendary heroes of the Tausug are Sali Bangsawan, Jekiri, an outlaw hero, and Panglima Munggona, who fought against the Spaniards and wielded such prowess that he was considered kublan or invincible. He is believed to have been poisoned by his wife.

The most celebrated, however, of the modern Tausug heroes is Panglima Hassan, hero of the historic Battle of Bud Bagsak recounted in “Kissa kan Panglima Hassan.” The song is based on events that happened between Oct 1903 and Mar 1904 in Jolo. The American colonial government imposed taxes and residence certificates on the Tausug, who regarded these as symbols of subjugation and domination. Panglima Hassan, a Tausug leader, led a resistance against the Americans, with more than a thousand kris-wielding Tausug warriors. He made his last stand in a crater of an extinct volcano, Bud Bagsak. He died with 26 bullet wounds.

The song begins during the Holy Month of fasting, and Andung, one of the Tausug leaders, is being tortured for resisting the imposition of the cedula. Antayung, another leader, calls on his Tausug kinsfolk to avenge Andung. A letter seeking support is sent to other Tausug leaders, one of them being Panglima Hassan of Luuk. The leaders consult Sultan Jamalul Kiram II, who says that they will all be imprisoned and they should surrender. Panglima rejects the advice, and the other leaders follow him. They send a letter to the American governor-general, virtually declaring war.

The American forces arrive and send emissary Hadji Butu to call on Panglima Hassan and his army to surrender. The call is brushed aside, and a battle ensues. The better equipped Americans defeat the Tausug. The pro-American sultan again asks Panglima Hassan to surrender, but the latter refuses. In the bitter engagement that follows, Panglima Hassan and his men are killed.

Throughout the song, the hero is characterized as unyielding in his opposition to any form of submission to American rule. He values the interest of the Tausug even above his personal loyalty to the sultan. His fighting prowess and ferocity are replicated in the actions of his Tausug warriors, who in history fought the American forces in Mindanao with such physical courage as it took all of American technological superiority to win the war.

Panglima Hassan is also in the “Parang Sabil of Abdulla and Putli’ Isara in Spanish Times,” although the true heroes in this song are the eponymous lovers and Panglima Hassan’s wife, who is also Putli’ Isara’s mother. The ballad opens with the main problem that the Tausug people face, the establishment of Spanish armed forces in Sulu. The next part introduces the protagonists Putli’ Isara, the lovely and angelic daughter of Panglima, and her betrothed, a brave young man named Abdulla. Before their wedding, Abdulla travels to Sandakan to buy an important pearl, which will be used in their wedding. While he is away, Putli’ Isara asks her father if she can bathe in the river nearby. Panglima, fearing for her safety, forbids it. Putli Isara goes anyway, reasoning that she will be accompanied by her younger brother. But, as Putli’ Isara is bathing in the river, Spanish soldiers appear. Their lieutenant, captivated by Putli’ Isara’s beauty, embraces Putli’ Isara against her will.

Upon arriving home from Sandakan, Abdulla learns of the Spaniard’s assault on his betrothed. He decides to act in the manner prescribed by their religion. Abdulla and Putli’ Isara travel to the Spanish garrison to perform the parang sabil. The lovers are good fighters; they kill the lieutenant and 30 Spanish soldiers. But they, too, are killed. The burak, a flaming half-horse, half-human creature, which fetches Muslims who die for their religion, is seen muzzling the lovers.

Panglima hears of the two lovers’ death, but he refuses to fetch Putli’ Asara’s body. Matagpis, Putli’ Isara’s mother, decides to continue the parang sabil. Putli’ Isara’s younger brother wants to join her but is forbidden by Panglima. At the Spanish garrison, Matagpis, kris in hand, hacks away, killing seven soldiers. In the end, however, she dies, and the burak is seen muzzling Matagpis. Seeing his mother’s soul traveling to heaven on the burak, the younger brother of Putli’ Isara, continues the parang sabil, thus defying his father’s orders. The soldiers capture the boy and take him to Manila. Panglima vainly searches for his lost son and in the end, dies, still hoping to see his captured son.

The “Parang Sabil of Abdulla and Putli’ Isara during Spanish Times” depicts the Tausug’s strong resistance to Spanish conquest. This strife was fuelled by such factors as religion, gender, and race. The image of a woman serenely taking a bath in a river is a motif in the Philippine folk literary tradition. But what distinguishes this Tausug ballad is the Spanish lieutenant’s violation of Putli’ Isara’s honor. Besides this being a metaphor for the violence of colonialism, such a variation on the traditional motif signals the transformation of the Philippine literary tradition wrought by colonization.

The “Parang Sabil of Abdulla and Putli’ Isara in Spanish Times” was banned during the martial law period for being subversive, though the story is set in a time long ago. This situation illustrates the cultural and political currency of historical narratives, myths, and legends.  Written by Edgardo Maranan, Florentino Hornedo, and Jay Jomar F. Quintos

 

Sources

Kiefer, Thomas M. 1968. Tausug Armed Conflicts: The Social Organization of Military Activity in a Philippine Moslem Society. Chicago: University of Chicago.

Manuel, E. Arsenio.1963. “A Survey of Philippine Epics.” Asian Folklore Studies 22:1-76.

Rixhon, Gerard, ed. 1973. “The Parang Sabil of Abdulla and Putli’ Isara in Spanish Times: A Tausug Ballad Sung by Indah Annura.” Sulu Studies, no. 2.

Tuban, Rita. 1988. “The Tausug Parang Sabil.” Tambara 5:153-71.

article_title: Parnasong Tagalog ni A. G. Abadilla
text:
(The Tagalog Parnassus of A. G. Abadilla). Published 1973. Editor, Efren R. Abueg. Manila: MCS Enterprises Inc. Originally published by Abadilla as Parnasong Tagalog in 1949. Revised edition, Malabon, Rizal: Limbagan ng Dalubhasaang Epifanio de los Santos, 1964.

This anthology has two subtitles: “Buhay na Larawan ng Ating Panulaan” (Living Portrait of Our Poetry) and “Katipunan ng mga Piling Akda mula kina Huseng Sisiw at Balagtas hanggang sa Kasalukuyang Panahon ng Pamumulaklak at Pagkaunlad” (A Collection of Selected Poems from Huseng Sisiw and Balagtas to the Present Period of Efflorescence and Development).

This third edition contains two new introductory sections, as well as poems written by younger poets not included in the original edition published by Abadilla himself. Pablo R. Glorioso writes on the role of Abadilla in Tagalog poetry; Efren Abueg’s essay is on the history and development of Tagalog poetry from its precolonial forms to its modernist and politically radicalized voices. The back matter of the book consists of biographical notes about the poets in the anthology, and a bibliography of the most significant poetry books in Tagalog published to the early 1970s.

Parnasong Tagalog presents the poets and their works in chronological order, starting with the latter half of the 19th century. The poems are divided into three sections according to periods: the period of propaganda, in which the works of Francisco Baltazar, aka Balagtas, and Jose de la Cruz, aka Huseng Sisiw, are lumped together with the openly political poetry of Andres Bonifacio, Hermenegildo Flores, Marcelo H. del Pilar, and Jose Rizal; the American period, 1900-1935, which includes Rufino Alejandrino, Emilio Mar. Antonio, Julian Cruz Balmaseda, Jose Esperanza Cruz, Pedro Gatmaitan, Amado V. Hernandez, Jose Corazon de Jesus, Cirio H. Panganiban, Benigno Ramos, Ildefonso Santos, Lope K. Santos, among others; and the period of the group Panitikan, 1936 to the late 1960s, which includes Teodoro Agoncillo, Virgilio Almario, Alejandro G. Abadilla, Lamberto Antonio, Teo S. Baylen, Jose M. Buhain, Andres Cristobal Cruz, Jose F. Lacaba, Ruth Elynia Mabanglo, C. C. Marquez Jr, Rogelio Mangahas, Fernando Monleon, Bienvenido A. Ramos, Pedro L. Ricarte, Rolando S. Tinio, C. M.Vega, and Oscar de Zuñiga.

Abueg’s history of Tagalog poetry situates the works of the poets in proper perspective. He begins by citing oral tradition as the roots of Tagalog poetry, and goes on to cite the changes brought about by Hispanic culture. This anthology has two subtitles: “Buhay na Larawan ng Ating Panulaan” (Living Portrait of Our Poetry) and “Katipunan ng mga Piling Akda mula kina Huseng Sisiw at Balagtas hanggang sa Kasalukuyang Panahon ng Pamumulaklak at Pagkaunlad” (A Collection of Selected Poems from Huseng Sisiw and Balagtas to the Present Period of Efflorescence and Development).

(Apologia of the Brown Race). Published 1993. Author, Ariel Dim. Borlongan. With an afterword by Virgilio S. Almario. Pasig City: Anvil Publishing, Inc.

This is a collection of 46 poems, written in 1982-91. It appears back-to-back with V. E. Nadera Jr’s own poetry collection, Alit: Dalit, Galit, Halit, Malit, Ngalit, Palit at Salit (Quarrel: Psalm, Rent, Gnashing of Teeth, Exchange and Interspersion). The first poem, “Kung ang Pagsinta Ko” (If My Love Were), is a sonnet addressed to a “Luzvimin”—a portmanteau for Luzon, Visayas, and Mindanao—to whom the persona emphatically declares that one must express one’s love by deed and not by mere word. This theme of love for country will sustain the entire collection, as Borlongan uses his poetry to expose stark social realities. The collection’s title poem is an impassioned indictment against multinational corporations—which violently claim the lives and land of its victims—and the generations of Filipinos who mindlessly patronize the products and culture that these industries bring in.

Borlongan’s political rhetoric is expressed in a range of tones, swinging between satire and didacticism, lament and anger, and resignation and defiance. In “Kasulatan sa Pagsasanla” (Deed of Mortgage), the form of a legal document is used to satirize the servitude of the Filipinos to the Americans. In “Sa Likod ng Karimlan” (Behind the Darkness), the persona urges the reader to breathe in the stench of blood of their forefathers killed in the protracted war in the countryside. In “From Saudi with Love,” dark humor creates a casual tone in an overseas Filipino worker’s epistolary account of his hard life in a foreign land.

Borlongan’s background as a media person shows in poems like “Retrato at Teksto” (Photograph and Text); “Channel 4,” on the Marcos-controlled TV station during martial law; “Oda kay Olalia” (Ode to Olalia) on an assassinated labor leader; “Hindi Mo na Sana Isinauli ang Aking Makinilya” (You Should Not Have Returned My Typewriter), which grieves for a dead friend; and “Matapos Mapatay ni Cpl. Tomas Tamayo ang Isang Hindi Kilalang Binatilyo noong Mayo 10, 1989 sa Sta. Cruz, Maynila” (After Cpl Tomas Tamayo Killed an Unknown Young Man on May 10, 1989, at Sta. Cruz, Manila), whose title mimics the style of lead paragraphs of news stories. The longest poem in the collection, “Pagsalubong sa Nanlilisik na Silahis ng Araw” (Meeting the Fierce Sun’s Ray), has news headlines serving as section breaks in a poem depicting a newsman-poet’s daily life. The shortest is the couplet “Obituwaryo sa Isang Sabungero” (Obituary to a Cockfighter).

Sketches of various personas are presented by the poet to illustrate social contradictions. There is the pimp in “Magkakarne sa Ongpin” (Meat Trader in Ongpin); the beggar who is a battered wife in “Dalamhati ng Isang Ina” (Anguish of a Mother); the protest writer who sells out to the system in “Sa Kaharian ng mga Hayop” (In the Kingdom of Animals).

The entire collection consistently reveals the persona’s compassion for the oppressed, his relentless criticism of their oppressors, and his own political convictions. The last poem, “Hangga’t Hindi Lubos ang Kalayaan” (For as Long as There Is No Absolute Freedom), reiterates the Filipinos’ resolve to emancipate themselves from foreign domination.

Almario, in his afterword, observes that Borlongan’s poems are rooted in the aesthetics and sensibilities of Francisco "Balagtas" Baltazar and Jose Corazon de Jesus (aka Huseng Batute), demonstrating his mastery of the Tagalog poetic tradition of rhyme and meter. Some, including those in free verse, are stylistically influenced by the awit, tanaga, and dalit. “Pagpapalit-Anyo” (Changing Appearances), “Sa Nagmamalabis na Bagwis” (To the Excessive Wings), “Ang Kontratista” (The Contractor), and “Karaniwan ang Narinig Mong Pagputok” (The Firing That You Heard Is Common) are either in conformity with or innovations on the caesura and dodecasyllabic lines of the awit. Thus, like Balagtas and Batute, Borlongan demonstrates how he wields language to register the concerns and anxieties of a race and a nation.  Written by Rebecca T. Añonuevo and Om Narayan Velasco

text:
(Passion of the Workers) aka Pulang Pasyon (Red Passion). Published 1936. Author, Lino Gopez Dizon. Manila: Dallosa Press.

The Pasion ding Talapagobra was written by Dizon, a poet and one of the pillars of the 70,000-strong Socialist Party of the Philippines and its peasant arm, the Aguman ding Maldang Talapagobra. The book radicalized the content of the traditional pasyon but retained its traditional form of five lines to a stanza, octosyllabic lines and monorhyme. The book hails Christ as “the first socialist,” but depicts a contemporary conflict and not his life. On one side is the alliance of the powerful: the rich who claim ownership of lands God intended to be equally shared by all; the institutional Church, which has transformed the “body of Christ” into a huge commercial enterprise; and the government, which protects the interests of the wealthy. On the other side are workers: the peasants and laborers who toil but who remain hungry.

The Pulang Pasyon’s “socialist” analysis of these contending classes is based on the indigenized Christian view of a world created by God to be shared in all harmony, love, and equality. The conditions of inequality are the result of greed and evil unleashed by the first original sin. To fight for a change of system is therefore a sacred task and is in accord with God’s will. But it is this view that prevents the Pulang Pasyon from advocating revolution and violence. Instead, it stresses the need for organization and solidarity among the poor, for militancy in pressing for social and political reforms, and finally, for a purification of self, so that through love, compassion, and true brotherhood/sisterhood, justice and equality can finally reign in society.  Written by Teresita G. Maceda

text:
(Candaba Passion) aka Pasyon de la Merced aka El Libro de la Vida: Historia Sagrada con Santas Reflexiones y Doctrinas Morales para la Vida Cristiana en Verso Tagalo (The Book of Life: Sacred History with Pious Reflections and Moral Teachings for the Christian Life Written in Tagalog Verse). Published 1852. Author, Aniceto de la Merced. Manila.

Although the title of the work is in Spanish, the text is in fact a Tagalog pasyon (verse narrative depicting the life, death, and resurrection of Christ), written by de la Merced to replace the Casaysayan nang Pasiong Mahal (The Story of the Holy Passion) or Pasyong Genesis (Genesis Passion), 1814, which, in his opinion, contained doctrinal errors. It is also called the Pasyong Candaba because de la Merced wrote the text while he was vicar forane at Candaba, Pampanga, although de la Merced himself was not from Pampanga but from Norzagaray, Bulacan.

De la Merced presented the manuscript as part of a legal proceeding denouncing the Casaysayan in 1842-43. In his presentation to the Church censors, he noted down a number of errors he found in the Casaysayan and presented his own version of a more correct pasyon. While agreeing with de la Merced’s comments, the church censors did not give him permission to publish his pasyon. Nine years later, in 1852, a printed edition of the text appeared. De la Merced’s comments on the older pasyon made its appearance as a poem, Manga Puna (Criticisms), published in 1906, which some scholars claim is the first example of critical writing in the local language.

There is a discrepancy between the manuscript and printed pasyon text. The stanzas of the manuscript are all in quintillas, or five-line monorhyming stanzas, whereas the printed text uses the plosa or labindalawahin—that is, dodecasyllabic quatrains—for parts narrating the story of the Old Testament. Although this pasyon follows the outline of the Casaysayan, de la Merced fills in omissions he noted in the Casaysayan. Thus, the Old Testament is narrated as a summary, instead of jumping from the narration of the flood into the life of Jesus and Mary, which Casaysayan does.

Perhaps the more important difference is de la Merced’s striving for erudition. In his aral (moral lessons), for instance, he makes clear theological distinctions between imperfect contrition (“atricion”) and perfect contrition (“contricion”); evidently, in the 19th century, Filipino writers took pains to show a sophistication and cosmopolitanism to disprove Spanish derision of the indio (Christianized native). In the conservative and defensive temper of the clergy of his age, de la Merced exhorts the reader to remain loyal to Spain, citing the Filipinos’ indebtedness to the Spanish crown that took pains to support the evangelization of the Philippines and bring to it the light of the Gospel.

In 1935, Pascual Poblete incorporated many stanzas of the Pasyong Candaba into the pasyon he created for the Iglesia Filipina Independiente, titled Patnubay ng Binyagan (Guide for the Baptized [Christian]).  Written by Rene Javellana

text:
(Genesis Passion) aka Pasyong Pilapil (The Passion by Pilapil) aka Pasyong Mahal (Holy Passion) aka Casaysayan nang Pasiong Mahal ni Jesucristong Panginoon Natin na Sucat Ipag-alab nang Puso nang Sinomang Babasa (The Story of the Holy Passion of Our Lord Jesus Christ That Should Inflame the Heart of the Reader). Published 1814. Manila. Various subsequent editions, including one by Margarita del Rosario, 1951, modernizing the orthography of the text and restoring the estropang ligaw (lost strophes) of misplaced stanzas in their proper places. Translated into various Philippine languages.

This is the second and most popular of the Tagalog pasyon, the account of the life, suffering, death, and resurrection of Jesus Christ. Originally known under its longer title, it was also later called Pasyong Genesis because the text begins with the Creation of the World, unlike the earlier pasyon of Gaspar Aquino de Belen, 1703 or 1704, which begins with the Last Supper; Pasyong Pilapil, on the erroneous assumption that ecclesiastical censor Fr Mariano Pilapil wrote the text; and Pasyong Mahal, a contraction of the original title.

Composed of 2,660 stanzas, this pasyon was first brought to the attention of Pilapil on 20 Apr 1814. The manuscript given to him for scrutiny may have been one of many unauthorized texts circulating among the people, who were fond of chanting the pasyon. A month later, it was approved for printing. Examination and publication of an authorized version were deemed necessary for producing a doctrinally safe text for public use. It used the earlier pasyon of Gaspar Aquino de Belen by lifting, directly or with some slight alterations, 570 stanzas from it.

The Casaysayan is the text read, chanted, or sung during the Holy Week pabasa, the public recitation of Christ’s passion and death, and presents the core belief of Catholicism regarding suffering and salvation. The narrative begins with a recounting of original sin, which begins the cycle of redemption. Because of sin, Jesus is sent to be humanity’s savior. He is enfleshed and passes through several stages of life: birth, childhood, adulthood, and death. He is resurrected and sends the Holy Spirit to act as humankind’s guide. The narrative abruptly ends here, and the story picks up several centuries later as Santa Elena searches for and finds the cross on which Jesus died. The creation narrative is completed with the Casaysayan looking forward to the end of the world, when Jesus shall return not as the meek and humble crucified Redeemer but the Righteous Judge of all. The rest of the narrative describes the well-known story of the agony and persecution of Jesus Christ, which culminates with the crucifixion on Calvary, the central act of redemption.

Like the earlier pasyon, the Casaysayan contains aral or lesson, which teaches the Christian reader to imitate Christ. Obedience to God’s will by living an orderly life according to the Commandments and obedience until death are the preconditions for reaping the fruits of salvation. More than any other pasyon, the Casaysayan shaped the Christian Filipinos’ image of Jesus Christ. And because Jesus is presented as a model of the self, it also helped shape the Christian Filipino’s self-image.

The Casaysayan underwent many printings. In the 19th century, it was reprinted in 1826, 1854, 1859, 1867, 1868, 1870, and 1891. It was translated into different Philippine languages, among them Kapampangan, Ilocano, Sambali, Bikol,

Waray, and Ilonggo. The Casaysayan also served as the first text of the early sinakulo performances, or dramatization of the life of Christ, which evolved from the simple pabasa, or reading of the pasyon, to the full-blown enactment on stage.  Written by Rene Javellana

text:
(Things from Pentelicus). Published 1941. Author, Cecilio Apostol. With a prologue by Claro M. Recto. Manila: Manila Grafica Inc. Reprinted, Editorial Hispano-Filipino, 1950.

Pentelicus is a mountain near Athens, Greece. This is a posthumous collection of poems compiled by Jaime C. de Veyra. It includes 41 poems, mostly patriotic in theme or dedicated to the memory of Philippine heroes: six poems honor Jose Rizal; two, Marcelo H. del Pilar; one, Emilio Jacinto; and one, the unknown martyrs.

“A los Martires Anonimos de la Patria” (To the Anonymous Martyrs of the Country), which Apostol recited on 2 Nov 1898 before the grave of Rizal at the Paco Cemetery, is a panegyric to the unknown martyrs of the revolution. The persona invokes the spirits of the fallen patriots, addressed as “Sacerdotes del templo de la Idea / cantores de las glorias de mi Patria (Priests of the temple of Idea / singers of the glories of my Fatherland),” to help him or her find their tombs.

Like many other Filipino poets during American rule, Apostol uses “Idea” to signify “independence,” a word that, indiscriminately used, could cause imprisonment. Thinking that the solitary yellow flowers may be the souls of departed heroes, the persona takes great care to avoid treading on them.

Included in the collection is his best-known poem on Rizal, “Al Heroe Nacional” (To the National Hero), which appeared in an issue of La Independencia commemorating the first National Heroes’ Day, 30 Dec 1898. This poem consists of sapphic sextains (stanzas 1-8, 11) and hendecasyllabic quatrains (stanzas 9-10). The persona assures Rizal that his ideas did not fall on barren soil but have grown into a tree whose shade provides a place of rest for Filipinos. The most celebrated lines of the poem declare the fundamental irony of Rizal’s execution: that “si una bala destrozo tu craneo / tu idea, en cambio, destruyo un imperio” (if a bullet shattered your skull, / your idea, on the other hand, destroyed an empire).

“A Emilio Jacinto” (To Emilio Jacinto), which won a prize in 1914, is considered majestic, as the poem in honor of Apolinario Mabini, “Sobre el Plinto” (On the Plinth), is sublime. The latter poem, purposely composed for the inauguration of the Mabini monument in Batangas in Mar 1915, gave birth to the encomium “Sublime Paralytic” for Mabini.

Apostol also excelled in writing sonnets, like “Paisaje Filipino” (Filipino Scenery), a description of the countryside in summer, which recalls delicate Fernando Amorsolo landscapes. Included also are the philosophical “Lineas Actuales” (Actual Lines) and “Mediodia” (High Noon), the sensuous “La Siesta” (The Afternoon Nap), the majestic “A España Imperialista” (To Imperial Spain), and the angry “Al Yankee”’ (To the Yankee).

Apostol’s mastery of the Spanish language allowed him to pick the choicest words, to create structurally perfect verses, and to fashion a wealth of images to suit the ideas and emotions embodied in his poems without verbosity.  Written by Edgardo Tiamson

Bernad, Miguel, SJ. 1974. “The Poets of the Philippine Revolution.” Philippine Studies 22 (First and Second Quarters): 81-92.

text:
(Profile of a Crest). Published 1957. Author, Manuel Bernabe. Manila: Imprenta de Carmelo Bauermann.

This anthology of 63 Spanish poems showcases the poet’s mastery of style and versatility in meter and theme. Included are elegiac, patriotic, religious, philosophic, epic, lyric, and folkloric poems. Three of the poems won prizes in three different literary contests in 1913. They represent the recurrent themes in Philippine poetry in Spanish: the religious, as in “Himno al Sagrado Corazon de Jesus” (Hymn to the Sacred Heart of Jesus); the patriotic, as in “Zapote”; and Hispanidad or things Spanish, as in “Filipinas a España” (Philippines to Spain).

The book title and the cover showing a rooster’s profile refer to his being an aficionado and a staunch defender of cockfighting. A poem in the book, “Bendito mi Gallo Blanco” (Blessed Be My White Rooster), portrays the excitement and expectations of a cockfighter and gives a poetic description of the rooster. “Filipinas a España” is a song of praise for Spain’s contributions to the Philippines; it is nostalgic for the spiritual affinities with Spain. This homage is restated in another poem, “Clavel de Eternidades” (Carnation of Eternity), which he recited in Madrid’s Teatro de Lara in 1951.

y [Filipinas] os trae, como regalos del Oriente,

los dos soles que bailan en su frente:

la fe de Cristo y el amor a España.

 

(and [Filipinas] brings you, like gifts from the Orient,

Two suns that dance on her forehead:

Christianity and love for Spain.)

Nowhere are the breadth and depth of the poet’s Hispanism more vividly expressed than in the same poem where he pictures himself dying little by little as he leaves Spain.

Also included in the collection are poems with philosophical witticisms: “Semblanza del Capitan Tagalog” (The Semblance of the Tagalog Captain), “Agonias” (Agonies), “Como el Cisne sobre el Agua” (Like the Swan over the Water), and “Vida Bruja” (Witch Life), a sensuous poem.

The patriotic poems in the collection are among the collection’s most popular poems. “Bataan! Corregidor!” speaks of the valiant defense of the last stronghold against the invading Japanese; the ensuing death march is depicted in “La Romeria de la Muerte” (The Pilgrimage of the Dead). The poems praise the Filipino soldiers who suffered and died during World War II and condemn forcefully and vividly the cruelty of the Japanese occupying forces. “Zapote” commemorates the bridge that remains a monument to the bravery of the revolutionaries against Spanish rule.

Since the publication of Perfil de Cresta, Bernabe has been acknowledged by the Hispanist and nationalist Claro M. Recto as Cecilio Apostol’s successor. With it, the golden chapter of Philippine poetry in Spanish ends.  Written by Edgardo Tiamson

 

Sources

Mariñas, Luis. 1974. Literatura Filipina en Castellano. Madrid: Editorial Nacional.

Recto, Claro M. 1985. The Recto Valedictory. Manila: Claro M. Recto Foundation.

text:
(Liberated Innocence). Published 2010. Author, Sze Manchi. Translator, Joaquin Sy. Manila: Kaisa Para Sa Kaunlaran Inc.

The poems in this collection are reflections on domestic life, love, and identity, usually given a diasporic inflection specific to the Chinese Filipino experience.

Among the poems focusing on family are “Sa Kandungan ng Ina” (On a Mother’s Lap), which tells of a family living in a foreign land, and “Tumba-tumba” (Rocking Chair), in which an accomplished patriarch reminisces about his sacrifices as a family man and his struggle with alienation in a foreign land. “Pinakamahusay na Aktor” (Best Actor) is a child’s recollection of how well his father has performed his role as a parent. “Taguan” (Hide and Seek) and “Pagmamahal sa Magulang” (Love for Parents) center on grief over the loss of a beloved family member. “Pinalayang Kamusmusan” (Liberated Innocence) follows a young father’s thoughts as he watches his sons play the same games he used to play as a child.

Sze uses ordinary objects and occurrences as subjects for philosophical reflection. The subject matter in “Elebeytor” (Elevator) symbolizes an ordinary life that only moves from one point to another, stalls, and never stays at the top floor. “Iisang Ugat” (One Origin), “Kakaibang Kwentong Pambata” (A Different Kind of Children’s Story), “Pader” (Wall), and “Ang Buong Buhay” (A Whole Life) share the theme of accepting truth and the reality of aging. In “Digital Clock,” Sze illustrates the effect of time on human life.

Love is the subject of “Ang Hawla at ang Ibon” (The Cage and the Bird), where true love is likened to a cage to which the beloved will always return. "Kwento ng Pag-ibig” (Story of Love) and “Pagdama” (To Feel) explore how differences between lovers create or destroy a relationship. Longing and letting go of past love are evident in “Tula ng Pag-ibig” (Poem of Love).

The diasporic theme is most evident in poems like “Pangungulila sa Bayan” (Longing for the Motherland), which explores nationality, the self, and isolation in a place devoid of the familiar comforts of the simple life in a small town; “Magkaibang Pangungulila” (Different Longings), which illustrates the cultural divide between a Chinese Filipino and a native Filipino; and “Lupang Tinubuan” (Homeland), where a Chinese Filipino waits for the time that he can finally return to his roots.

“Rice Cooker,” “Electric Fan,” “Aircon,” “Electric Razor,” “Flat Iron,” and “Door Bell” are in a distinctly traditional Chinese form, although images from the everyday, domestic life in the Philippines are used so as to convey deep emotion.  Written by Jeffrey Yap

article_title: Pingkian at Apat Pang Aklat ng Tunggalian
text:
(Skirmish and Four Other Books about Conflict). Published 1997. Author, Lamberto E. Antonio. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press. Manila Critics Circle’s National Book Award for poetry, 1998; Gintong Aklat Award for literature, 1998.

A total of 181 poems are in this collection, the author’s third book of poetry. Making up one section of the book is the title poem, about the life of Emilio Jacinto. The other sections of the book are “Beso-Berso” (Kiss-Verse), “Langong Alabok” (Drunken Dust), “Kabalahibo at Kontrapelo” (Close Friends and Dear Enemies), and “Mata-matang Lilim” (Eye-shaped Shadows).

The poems in “Beso-Berso” show the contradictions in Philippine society born out of social inequality. In “Pambusog sa Mata” (Eye Candy), a man describes the daily routine of a wealthy neighbor, who goes to the office in a shiny car, and wonders how she manages to curb her hunger to maintain her youthful figure when just a stone’s throw away from her place are children starving. In “Isang Matrona ang Nagsimba” (A Matron Goes to Church), a well-heeled and bejeweled churchgoer appears to be holy and courteous until the bellman sneezes and snot lands on her ear. She spews the vilest curses heard by the congregation. Antonio’s target in “Halalan na Naman” (It’s Election Time Again) is the traditional politician, kind and decent during the campaign period but corrupt once in power.

The section “Langong Alabok” focuses on the sweet and bitter effects of love. In “Damhin Mo, Mutya Ko” (Feel It, My Muse), a farm boy serenades a country lass, promising her the good life, expressed in images of hard work and bountiful harvests. The versified “Sinulat para Kantahin” (Written to Be Sung) is about the deep pain of a man who gave his all to a woman who loved another. “Blas ng Lagaslas” (Blas of the Splashing Water) is about an ideal husband who becomes a uxoricide when gambling and the death of a firstborn get the better of him.

“Kabalahibo at Kontrapelo” contains mainly Antonio’s nostalgic observations on his own life and those of his town mates in Nueva Ecija. “Ang Silong” (The Lower Floor) and “Ang Babae sa Ilang” (Dead Woman in the Bushes) are character sketches—the first of a poor bachelor who becomes a rich woman’s kept man, the second of a murdered young woman. Some of the most vivid poems in this section are “Kahuli-hulihang Kalabaw” (The Last Carabao), about a carabao who dies of heartbreak from being displaced by machines, and “Gaong” (Pond), about a lovely pond that was the site of the speaker’s memorable childhood experiences.

Aging, memory, and forgetfulnes are the central themes in “Mata-matang Lilim.” “Limang Awit” (Five Songs) expresses faith amid human fragility and unrelenting suffering. In “Tirador” (Sling/Assassin), the speaker remembers a former classmate, Ador, who has become a professional assassin, a far cry from the good-natured, sling-totting boy of the past.

“Pingkian” is a historical verse narrative poem told from the point of view of its youthful protagonist Emilio Jacinto. The poem has 1,396 lines written in dodecasyllabic quatrains with alternating rhymes. Jacinto’s tale follows closely the story of the Philippine Revolution, from the founding of the Katipunan to its continuation under the leadership of Emilio Aguinaldo. The most interesting parts are Antonio’s reimagined rendition of Jacinto’s life, a law student at the University of Santo Tomas who at age 18 joined the Katipunan, its youngest member.

Pingkian shows Antonio’s undiminished skill as a versifier and commentator on the past and on contemporary Philippine life. His early, modernist experimentations are here tempered, his incisive and memorable poetic insights on aging, suffering, love, and hope producing a burnished quality that bespeaks wise maturity.  Written by Romulo Baquiran Jr

text:
Published 1940. Author, Angela Manalang Gloria. Manila: By the author. Revised 1950.

Consisting of 79 poems, this book was an entry in the 1940 Commonwealth Literary Contests, but it lost to Rafael Zulueta da Costa’s Like the Molave and Other Poems. In an interview, the poet herself reveals that the reason that she lost was her use of “objectionable” words like “querida” and “hymen.”

The collection shows that Angela Manalang-Gloria is not only a romantic poet who uses nature images to express personal sentiments as she has always been taken for. Included in the collection are poems of feminine sensibility, such as “Virac” and “April Morning.” In other poems, she explores subjects considered “improper” for a woman to talk about in her time: the physical expression of spiritual love; woman tired of being a sexual object; woman liberated from the preset destiny of having to be married in order to appear normal.

The poem “Soledad” portrays a society of distorted values, which condemns a woman like Soledad—“who loved so well”—by situating “her heaven in the depths of hell.” Another poem, “Heloise to Abelard,” is more pronounced in its protest against the unwarranted interference of society on a couple’s relationship: “If this is sin, then never will I be shriven / who, drunk with hell, now dare the curse of heaven!” The poem “Revolt from Hymen” clearly establishes the poet as one of the first—if not the first—Filipino feminist poets writing in English. It asserts that women should not be reduced to being sexual objects in an act “that marks the flesh no better than a whore’s.”

The revised edition of 1950, intended for schoolchildren, excluded seven poems from the 1940 edition but added four new poems. In 1993, The Complete Poems of Angela Manalang Gloria, edited by Edna Zapanta Manlapaz, restored all the poems and added 30 poems previously uncollected.  Written by David Jonathan Y. Bayot

 

Source

Manlapaz, Edna Z., and Stella Pagsanghan. 1988. “A Feminist Reading of the Poetry of Angela Manalang-Gloria.” Philippine Studies 37 (Fourth Quarter): 389-411.

text:
POEMS 55: THE BEST POEMS OF JOSE GARCIA VILLA AS CHOSEN BY HIMSELF

Published 1962. Author, Jose Garcia Villa. Manila: Alberto S. Florentino.

The poems in this collection, the first of the Peso Books published by Alberto S. Florentino, have been previously published in Villa’s other collections: Have Come, Am Here, 1942; Volume Two, 1949; and Selected Poems and New, 1958.

One striking fact about this collection is its revolutionary content. The love poems are among the first Filipino poems in English to deal openly with sensual love. In one poem, he writes: “Curve of gold above her / In the golden night, / Seventeen times I rose / Creating our child.” The poems also convey unorthodox views about the Divine-human relationship. The poem “In the Chamber of My Philosophy” states, “God must humanize divinity / To be perfected.” Villa thus reverses the hierarchy of the God-person relationship. In “Mostly We Are Mostless,” the persona says that “God is Godless ... I saw God helpless / And headless there. / Until I put my head on Him. / Then he uprose superb.”

Another striking feature of the collection is the playful physical form some poems assume, which highlights the subject of the poems. “The Emperor’s New Sonnet,” for example, consists of the title on a blank page. “The Bashful One” contains only a comma on the lower righthand corner of the page. In “Parenthetical Sonnet,” the page is marked only by a parenthesis.

In the collection, there are many so-called comma poems, in which every word of each line is followed by a comma. According to Villa in Volume Two, the commas help in “regulating the poem’s verbal density and time movement: enabling each word to attain a fuller tonal and sonal value, and the line movement to become more measured.” Some of the poems make use of reversed consonance, a method of rhyming that Villa introduced. In this system, the last sounded consonants of the last syllable of a line are reversed in the last word of the next line; thus, man will rhyme with name. Villa also included an ars poetica of sorts in one of the poems: “First a poem must be magical, / Then musical as a seagull …”

The poems in this collection will be remembered for having started the movement of modernism in Philippine poetry in English. Many of the poems in the collection have been translated into Tagalog by Hilario Francia in 55 Poems, 1988, and Parlement of Giraffes, 1999, edited by John Cowen. Both books contain reproductions of Villa’s line drawings, which complement the poems.  Written by David Jonathan Y. Bayot

article.value: POEMS 55: THE BEST POEMS OF JOSE GARCIA VILLA AS CHOSEN BY HIMSELF
Published 1962. Author, Jose Garcia Villa. Manila: Alberto S. Florentino.

The poems in this collection, the first of the Peso Books published by Alberto S. Florentino, have been previously published in Villa’s other collections: Have Come, Am Here, 1942; Volume Two, 1949; and Selected Poems and New, 1958.

One striking fact about this collection is its revolutionary content. The love poems are among the first Filipino poems in English to deal openly with sensual love. In one poem, he writes: “Curve of gold above her / In the golden night, / Seventeen times I rose / Creating our child.” The poems also convey unorthodox views about the Divine-human relationship. The poem “In the Chamber of My Philosophy” states, “God must humanize divinity / To be perfected.” Villa thus reverses the hierarchy of the God-person relationship. In “Mostly We Are Mostless,” the persona says that “God is Godless ... I saw God helpless / And headless there. / Until I put my head on Him. / Then he uprose superb.”

Another striking feature of the collection is the playful physical form some poems assume, which highlights the subject of the poems. “The Emperor’s New Sonnet,” for example, consists of the title on a blank page. “The Bashful One” contains only a comma on the lower righthand corner of the page. article_title: Poro Point: An Anthology of Lives
text:
Published 1961. Author, Alejandrino G. Hufana. Quezon City: University of the Philippines.

The book brings together poems about various characters in a “mythical” coastal town in Northern Luzon, which together create a modern equivalent of an epic about the Ilocano people. The native son, Geron Munar, is called from his work in the highest office in the land to save Poro Point from oblivion. His deep native roots and his desertion of his role as their poet add the right sense of guilt to qualify him for an insider’s outside view of the culture. His early poems show not only his poetic ability but also his willingness and optimism to help others.

A return to the old tradition is necessary. The camaraderie of the old migration from Ilocos to Poro Point calls for a close relationship between the poet, his subject matter, and his reader. Twenty-five relatives speaking for themselves show their adaptability and ability to take on roles. Munar uses the folk form of the riddle. The answer to each riddle requires a close correspondence in mind and physical sensing between poet and audience. But an inversion of the traditional form is needed for an audience averse to abstractions.

Each poem, as an inverted riddle, first presents the abstract title, the riddle’s answer. Within the poem are given the physical details of the person’s life. The reader’s participation is to understand the abstract title, then to experience the physical details, and finally to acquiesce in Munar’s abstract title.

This closeness to the folk tradition presents a solution to the alienation of the poet and his subject matter from his readers. This alienation must be remedied both in Poro Point and in literature for the place and the writing to survive. Hufana’s style is difficult. The manner in which he puts words together is not germane to the subject matter. He uses American idioms and lays on indigenous material for local color. The language is not the language of the people he portrays. Its significance lies in its epic ambitions, its grand design, and its depiction of a bayan (town).  Written by Lourdes H. Vidal, with notes from Bienvenido L. Lumbera and Cynthia Lumbera

text:
(Black Prose). Published 1996. Author, Mike L. Bigornia. With an introduction by Virgilio S. Almario. Pasig City: Anvil Publishing, Inc. Manila Critics Circle’s National Book Award for poetry, 1997.

This is a collection of prose poems on the themes of creation and creativity, the opposition between light and dark, the role of tradition, the past impinging on the present, the essential contrariness of life, morality, mortality, history, politics, and literature.

Several poems are infused with myth and folklore. In the first poem, “Bestiyaryo” (Bestiary), the diwata (goddess) grants the river’s wish to know the meaning of life by transforming it into a beautiful woman. She sleeps with a man whom she has met in the woods but, come morning, she leaves him stone cold. In “Ang Matanda sa Tabing-dagat” (The Old Man by the Seashore), the old man is about to resurrect the Ilocano’s epic hero, Lam-ang, by re-assembling his bones. “Mula sa Kabilang Buhay” (From the Other Life) recounts the Visayan myth of why people die, with the god Captan lamenting his grandson Pandaguan’s fate. In “Mandragora,” the magical plant saves people from ignorance and poverty. In “Ex Machina,” machine wrestles with imagination. In “Kasal” (Wedding), the tikbalang (half-horse and half-human) is upset by the younger generation’s ignorant and careless use of words.

The book’s other preoccupations are writers and their craft: the difficulties of communing with the muse and the obsession with craft, the labyrinthine paths an artist treads, and the Sisyphian condition of one wishing to forge something from nothing. In “Mga Makata” (Poets), poetry is the act of both replicating and worshipping the image of its creator. In “Banal na Oras” (Holy Hour), a sardonic distinction is made between one who acts like a writer and one who actually practices the discipline of writing. In “Nang Mauso ang Magmakata” (When Being a Poet Became Popular), the poet is a leper who, consumed by his disease, renounces his occupation. In a similar vein are “Ayaw Ulitin ang Sarili” (Unwilling to Repeat Oneself) and “Abrakadabra” (Abracadabra).

The encounter between the high and the lowly is depicted in “Ang Kastilyo” (The Castle). The reclusive lord steps out of his castle for the first time but, upon being met by a rain of curses and stones from the huddled masses, he hastily retreats and locks himself up in his castle room to devote the rest of his life to studying. “Ang Rebelde” (The Rebel) is the tale of a young, courageous warrior, detested by others because he refuses to bow down to authority. His charisma wins him followers, who, fired by his idealism, storm a fortress symbolizing tyranny. However, once he is fully entrenched as the most powerful leader, he becomes a despot himself.

The last work, “Itim” (Black), illustrates the theme of the elusiveness and indeterminacy of life. Black is traditionally associated with death, dissolution, and evil, but here the persona demands an explanation for such associations. The persona argues that light is inconceivable without black, which is the mother of light. In a lyrical defense, he identifies black with purity, boundless depth, silence, transcendence, anonymity, and solstice. Black is galactic in scope, the well-spring of a poet’s inspiration, a vigorous woman and her desires, the multifaceted universe.

In his introduction, Almario provides a history of local prose poetry, tracing it back to the sermons, meditations, and prose classics of Modesto de Castro, Andres Bonifacio, Emilio Jacinto, Alejandro G. Abadilla, and Genoveva Edroza-Matute. Bigornia’s Prosang Itim both continues and enriches the tradition. His prose poems deliberately take recourse to various types of poetry, including proverbs, riddles, dalit, and tanaga. Bigornia’s new configurations induce a heightened sense of a world that is strange and complex, and thus enable the reader to perceive reality in extraordinarily novel ways.  Written by Soledad Reyes, Rebecca T. Añonuevo, and Om Narayan Velasco

text:
Published 2003. Author and Translator, Don Pagusara. Davao City: Davao Writers Guild.

The title of the book is a play on the musical term contrapuntal, or counterpoint, in which independent, if contrasting, musical lines are harmoniously arranged. The 71 Cebuano poems come with the author’s own translations in English, which comprise the book’s second section.

There are a number of counterpoints here: (1) Pagusara’s “daklitpulong”/“briefword,” or preface, explains that he moves from protest poetry, for which he is most known, to the sensuous and erotic; (2) free verse is used as an instrument of social and aesthetic commentary, as well as of paying homage to the indigenous culture of Mindanao; (3) the poems reflect various influences—Romanticism, Latin American surrealism, and Cebuano love songs and riddles; (4) Pagusara situates the commonplace within the dreamlike, drawing images from nature, history, and folklore.

Qontrapuntal is divided into four thematic sequences: “Pamahulagway” / “Imaging on Joys and Pain,” “Mga Kakulian sa Alampat” / “Ordeals of Art,” “Ang Tawo sa Tunga-Tunga” / “Man in Between,” and “Quntrapuntal, Inagos sa Kasingkasing” / “Heart Drops Unedited.”

“Pamahulagway” introduces a lively persona who names indigenous musical instruments and furniture, observes local birds, and makes a reference to the Manuvu epic hero Tuwaang. In “Kolesistektomi”/ “Cholecystectomy” and “Ward 3,” the same persona turns confessional, haunted by prison, rebellion, and sociopolitical unrest. The sequence also contains the poet’s credo: “Kun Ganahan Musulat Ko” / “When Feeling I Write,” which describes poetry as a celebration of nature stimulating the senses and intuition, and not the mere counting of syllables.

In the second sequence, Pagusara addresses his fellow Visayan poets on a recurrent theme in the collection: the aesthetic “ordeal” of Philippine writing in English. A satirical poem using culinary metaphors, “Potaheng Dila” / “A Lengua Menu” describes writers who take pride in painstakingly preparing a favored meat dish, only to have their jaws cramping after chewing on a hard, rubbery tongue, a metaphor for the colonial language. Writing in the first person plural, Pagusara does not absolve himself.

“Paglaglag”/“Genocide” talks about writers who tinker with tools from a foreign workshop and wipe out their own race. “Post-mortem” sees the contemporary Cebuano poet forging a new direction that follows an older tradition reaching back to Humabon’s golden tongue.

The third sequence sounds environmental themes while sustaining Pagusara’s critique of contemporary Philippine politics and literature. Poems such as “Halok sa Bag-ong Milenyo” / “New Millennium Kiss,” “Look sa Talomo” / “Talomo Bay,” and “Panahong Sauloganon” / “Celebratory Season” lament the destruction of the environment along with the erosion of a local culture in the wake of colonialism. “Tribuhanong Awit” / “Tribal Song” denounces a deceitful world order of cultural and material alliances. “Si Baohay Ug Si Amoay” / “The Turtle and the Monkey” recasts a fable as an allegory of former president Joseph Estrada’s downfall. In “Unsaon kaha Pagdakop sa Dila ni Erap?” / “How to Catch the Tongue of Erap?” the speaker proposes to cut out Estrada’s tongue, an instrument of deceit, and feed it to the dogs.

The most erotically charged poems are in the last sequence. In “Hardin sa mga Panganod” / “In Sky-Garden,” a plane ride to Davao City becomes a metaphor for lovemaking. In “Kining Baki sa Akong Dughan” / “Frog in My Breast,” desire is a frog in a man’s breast. Still, Pagusara firmly locates his poetry in Mindanao lore. In the collection’s last poem, “Sa Imong Balay” / “In Your House,” a wood seat has been crafted for the daughters of Lukus-a-babai, the first woman on Earth according to the Bagobos. The same poem describes the story of Tod’bulol, the Tboli epic hero, flowing from a jar inside the beloved’s house. In the book’s title poem, Pagusara takes Jose Garcia Villa to task for not having drunk from the many breasts of the Bagobo goddess, Mebuyan.

The indigenous past is the core of Filipino poetic imagination; the poet who fails to recognize this is an exile in his own land. In Pagusara’s humorous, biting, and lyrical counterpoints, the path for a contemporary Cebuano poetry has been cleared.  Written by John Bengan

text:
(Don Rodrigo de Villas) aka Salita at Buhay na Pinagdaanan ni Don Rodrigo de Villas at ni Doña Jimena sa Kaharian ng Espanya (History and Life Experienced by Don Rodrigo de Villas and Doña Jimena in the Kingdom of Spain). Published 1949.

Attributed to Jose de la Cruz, aka Huseng Sisiw, in the edition put out by Aklatang Modesta Lanuza. Editor, Simplicio F. Bulaklak. Four Tagalog editions. Available in Kapampangan, Bikol, Ilocano, and Ilonggo.

This metrical romance is a retelling of the epic of El Cid Campeador, the Spanish hero of the Reconquista. Rodrigo de Villas is the son of Count Laynes, vice commander of the Spanish army, by a beautiful shepherdess. While still a boy in the village, he accidentally kills a playmate. His mother sends him to the city to look for his father. Count Laynes gladly receives him and sends him to school with his two other sons, Don Pedro and Don Juan. Rodrigo displays extraordinary bravery and strength, killing the ferocious dog of Count Luzano, general of the Spanish army.

One day, Count Laynes sends his three sons to get horses. His kindness to an old beggar earns for Rodrigo the man’s help in acquiring a magic horse. When Rodrigo is 13, his father is humiliated by Count Luzano. Only Rodrigo of the three sons is brave enough to avenge Count Laynes. Rodrigo demands justice from the king and is given permission to confront the general. He goes to Count Luzano’s house and challenges him to a duel. But he also falls in love with the count’s daughter, Jimena. Rodrigo defeats the count, and brings the count’s head as a trophy to his father. Rodrigo is appointed general of the Spanish army. His first official act is to stop the payment of tribute to Turkey. When an emissary arrives to demand the tribute, Rodrigo engages the Turkish forces and routs them.

At first, Jimena is urged to avenge her father, but the king explains that Count Luzano was killed in a fair fight, and suggests that she marry Rodrigo so that the warrior may repay with love the life he took. The wedding takes place, but she continues to be torn between her desire to avenge her father and her love for Rodrigo. In the end she is resigned to her lot.

Rodrigo meets Paderes who, according to a mysterious voice, has been sent by heaven to be Rodrigo’s soldier. The general puts the man second-in-command of the army. With a higantilyo or young giant, they conquer enemy kingdoms, including Gandon the giant’s, and make their captives vassals of Spain. The higantilyo later leaves Rodrigo, but he returns, revealing that he is the spirit of the playmate Rodrigo accidentally killed years before. The spirit requests masses for his soul.

Spain becomes a world power and Catholicism becomes widespread. King Octavio of Spain abdicates in favor of Rodrigo. After he is crowned king, Rodrigo is prompted by a dream to have his mother fetched and wedded to his father. The champion enjoys God’s reward for his goodness—for the old beggar he helped earlier was Christ—and reigns prosperously.

One night, a voice tells him that his end is near. The next day, Rodrigo falls ill and dies. His body is embalmed and preseved. Learning of Rodrigo’s death, the Turks invade Spain. Rodrigo’s subjects set up his body on a horse and take it out to the battlefield. At the sight of him, the Turks are demoralized and are defeated. Giants from Gandon’s captive kingdom prepare to invade Spain. When they arrive, led by Gandon himself, God sends down San Miguel who takes the form of Rodrigo. The hero and the young giant team up anew to defeat the enemy.

The angel admonishes Jimena to be humble and to guard her husband’s honor carefully. He also tells her she will marry again by God’s will. He then crowns Paderes king of Spain, after baptizing him and naming him Federico. Jimena marries Banzon, general of the army, who vows to respect her chastity. Jimena always keeps a dagger on her person “to guard her husband’s honor.” Meanwhile, Federico orders a statue made of Rodrigo on horseback. Placed in the middle of the square near the palace gate, it intimidates the Turks who plan to invade Spain again.

One day, while Jimena is taking a nap, her husband makes the mistake of sitting by her bedside. Suddenly roused, Jimena pulls out her dagger and stabs Ganzon to death. Realizing what she has done, she mourns and gives herself up to the court. The king, however, exonerates her of all blame, telling her to confess her sin and prepare the body for burial. That same day, Jimena falls ill and dies soon after.

Rodrigo de Villas was made into a komedya by Jose de la Cruz, aka Huseng Sisiw, in the 18th century, and into a movie, starring Mario Montenegro, Delia Razon, and directed by Gregorio Fernandez for LVN, 1952.  Written by Damiana Eugenio

 

Source

Eugenio, Damiana. 1987. Awit and Corrido: Philippine Metrical Romances. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

His first official act is to stop the payment of tribute to Turkey. When an emissary arrives to demand the tribute, Rodrigo engages the Turkish forces and routs them.

At first, Jimena is urged to avenge her father, but the king explains that Count Luzano was killed in a fair fight, and suggests that she marry Rodrigo so that the warrior may repay with love the life he took. The wedding takes place, but she continues to be torn between her desire to avenge her father and her love for Rodrigo. In the end she is resigned to her lot.

Rodrigo meets Paderes who, according to a mysterious voice, has been sent by heaven to be Rodrigo’s soldier. The general puts the man second-in-command of the army. With a higantilyo or young giant, they conquer enemy kingdoms, including Gandon the giant’s, and make their captives vassals of Spain. The higantilyo later leaves Rodrigo, but he returns, revealing that he is the spirit of the playmate Rodrigo accidentally killed years before. The spirit requests masses for his soul.

Spain becomes a world power and Catholicism becomes widespread. King Octavio of Spain abdicates in favor of Rodrigo. After he is crowned king, Rodrigo is prompted by a dream to have his mother fetched and wedded to his father. The champion enjoys God’s reward for his goodness—for the old beggar he helped earlier was Christ—and reigns prosperously.

One night, a voice tells him that his end is near. The next day, Rodrigo falls ill and dies. His body is embalmed and preseved. Learning of Rodrigo’s death, the Turks invade Spain. Rodrigo’s subjects set up his body on a horse and take it out to the battlefield. At the sight of him, the Turks are demoralized and are defeated. Giants from Gandon’s captive kingdom prepare to invade Spain. When they arrive, led by Gandon himself, God sends down San Miguel who takes the form of Rodrigo. The hero and the young giant team up anew to defeat the enemy.

The angel admonishes Jimena to be humble and to guard her husband’s honor carefully. He also tells her she will marry again by God’s will. He then crowns Paderes king of Spain, after baptizing him and naming him Federico. Jimena marries Banzon, general of the army, who vows to respect her chastity. Jimena always keeps a dagger on her person “to guard her husband’s honor.” Meanwhile, Federico orders a statue made of Rodrigo on horseback. Placed in the middle of the square near the palace gate, it intimidates the Turks who plan to invade Spain again.

One day, while Jimena is taking a nap, her husband makes the mistake of sitting by her bedside. Suddenly roused, Jimena pulls out her dagger and stabs Ganzon to death. Realizing what she has done, she mourns and gives herself up to the court. The king, however, exonerates her of all blame, telling her to confess her sin and prepare the body for burial. That same day, Jimena falls ill and dies soon after.

Rodrigo de Villas was made into a komedya by Jose de la Cruz, aka Huseng Sisiw, in the 18th century, and into a movie, starring Mario Montenegro, Delia Razon, and directed by Gregorio Fernandez for LVN, 1952.  Written by Damiana Eugenio

text:
(In the East: Life Experienced by King Pilipo and Queen Malaya in the Legendary Golden Island). Published 1928. Author, Jose Corazon de Jesus. Manila: Bahay Palimbagan ni P. Sayo Balo ni Soriano.

SA DAKONG SILANGAN AT MGA TULANG PASALAYSAY NI JOSE CORAZON DE JESUS

(In the East and Other Narrative Poems of Jose Corazon de Jesus). Published 1995. Editor, Virgilio S. Almario. Manila: Sentrong Pangkultura ng Pilipinas and National Commission for Culture and the Arts.

This is an allegorical narrative poem of 13 parts against Spanish and American colonialism. Using the popular form of the metrical romance, de Jesus narrates what has become of the once self-sufficient, peaceful, and free Pulong Ginto (Isle of Gold) with the coming of foreign rulers. Misfortune befalls the kingdom of Haring Pilipo when Reyna Malaya is reported missing. Three of their daughters, Princesses Luningning, Bituin, and Mandiwang, set out to search for their mother with the help of their loved ones—namely, Bayani, Dakila, and Magiting. Lost in the forest, each one shows extraordinary courage and determination in finding Reyna Malaya to bring her back to the ailing Hari. Meanwhile, the kingdom endures untold suffering. Reyna Malaya, kept in a dark castle in the interior of the forest, is abused by the cardinal of the kingdom of King Iberia and Queen Cristina. However, Bayani finds her, and she is eventually freed by a revolution led by him and the two other princes. Once more the family is reunited, and freedom and happiness reign in the kingdom.

Soon, however, another group of foreign rulers, led by Haring Samuel and his sons Prinsipe Dolar and Duke Demokratiko, visits Pulong Ginto. The kingdom of Haring Pilipo, with characteristic hospitality, welcomes and befriends them. Eventually, Haring Samuel, through deceit and manipulation, becomes the actual ruler. Meanwhile, the natives are divided as to how to perceive him and the power he represents. De Jesus ends his narrative with an admonition to the youth to wake up from complacency and realize the truth that the country’s freedom is being consumed, termite-like, by foreigners, and it must be fought for and regained.

Written by de Jesus at the height of his popularity as the “King of the Balagtasan,” this work assumes particular significance as the poet’s contribution to the nationalist and democratic intellectual tradition. Widely known as the purveyor of romantic love, de Jesus is regarded as the “Makata ng Puso” (Poet of Love). With this poem among other major works, he is being rediscovered. In this work, which is very much in the tradition of Francisco "Balagtas" Baltazar, de Jesus wields his talent and popularity to pierce through the pro-Americanism dominant at the time.

In 1995, on the birth centenary of de Jesus, a new edition of the poem was published: Sa Dakong Silangan at mga Tulang Pasalaysay ni Jose Corazon de Jesus (In the East and Other Narrative Poems of Jose Corazon de Jesus), edited by Virgilio S. Almario. Apart from the title poem, the other works in the book are “Ang Sawa” (The Python) and “Ang Kartero” (The Carter), from Mga Dahong Ginto, ca 1916 and 1920; “Gloria,” serialized in Liwayway, 4 Jan–25 Apr 1925, and included in Mga Tulang Ginto, 1958; “Ang Ilaw sa Kapitbahay” (The Neighbor’s Light), serialized in Liwayway, 4 May–9 Aug 1929; “Ang mga Itinapon” (The Discarded), 1930; and “Maruming Basahan” (Dirty Rag), serialized in Sampagita, 3 Jun–26 Aug 1931.

Almario’s introduction situates Jesus’s poems squarely against the sociopolitical context of the powerful movement that Almario labeled balagtasismo in his study Balagtasismo versus Modernismo, 1984. Balagtasismo was a movement of a group of Tagalog poets writing in the first half of the 20th century who emulated the works of Francisco Baltazar. Almario argues that at the start of the 20th century, writers in Tagalog used their writing to liberate themselves from the iniquitous Spanish colonial past, to celebrate their own culture and tradition, and to further cultivate and animate their own writing against the systematic imposition of English and a new way of life that would spell the death of traditional values.

The narratives of de Jesus freely partook of diverse influences from literary traditon, including the duplo, the awit, and korido. The poems published in Liwayway and Sampagita, on the other hand, can be read side by side with the popular novels in the magazines. De Jesus’s narratives deployed the staples and conventions of the popular novel—unrequited love, mistaken identity, dolorous scenes, arch villains, pathetic heroes, and suffering heroines. “Ang Kartero” is a case in point. It revolves around Benito, a poor orphan in a far-flung barrio who is smitten by a beautiful woman to whom he pledges his eternal love. His job as a mailman helps him discover the woman’s treachery as she succumbs to the importunings of a wealthy suitor. Driven by powerful emotions of fury and betrayal, Benito kills the woman and her lover in front of the church. The poem ends with the sight of the young man now totally deranged.

The view that de Jesus was a man immersed in the historical specificities of the first four decades of the 20th century is evident in the poems. Even in stories with love as a theme, the movements in the narrative demonstrate an ongoing dialogue between personal lives and public history. The book is a worthy addition to the growing body of criticism not only in poetry but also in literary criticism. While Almario’s introduction provides a necessary context, the anthology itself gives the reader an opportunity to gain a better appreciation of the multifaceted artistry of Jose Corazon de Jesus.  Written by Rosario Torres-Yu and Soledad Reyes

text:
Published 2002. Author, Allan C. Popa. Quezon City: Amado V. Hernandez Resource Center and High Chair. Manila Critics Circle’s National Book Award for poetry, 2003.

Popa’s third book borrows its title from the Hindu term “samsara,” which pertains to the cycle of life, death, and rebirth. Popa relates these temporal stages of being to various forms of desire, which are constantly straining to escape from the body that is its prison. In Popa’s poems, the self experiences the body with both terror and obstinacy.

In this collection of 52 poems, equally divided between those written in Filipino and those written in English, Popa uses a confessional tone, whether spoken by a first-person or a third-person persona. The first poem, “Matches,” juxtaposes the angelic image of a ring bearer’s stiff posture and even pace with his fixation with burning matches, whose wild flames “he remembers with pleasure.” In “Gift,” the relation is between a lover’s use of “tactile alphabet” that defines the persona’s body and the persona’s own utterances. In “Callas,” different forms of desire intersect in the legendary soprano’s performance: her desire to transform her body, the audience’s hunger for her “passionate singing,” and the voice’s longing to flee the body which contains it. Throughout the first half of the book, the lyric “I” experiences the self from the point of its negation.

The second half of the book consists of poems in Filipino. These offer more contradictions and complexities born out of desire. Noteworthy are the pieces that give voice to the passions of various personas: in “Pasyon ni Heloise” (Passion of Heloise), the virgin offering her body before the altar; in “Pasyon ng Maryoneta” (Passion of a Marionette), a marionette’s spell of seduction and the eventual destruction of her master; in “Pasyon ng Kambal-Tuko” (Passion of the Siamese Twins), the stigma cast upon a pair of Siamese twins; in “Pasyon ng Virago” (Passion of a Virago), a woman’s retaliation to a sexual assault; and in “Pasyon ni Ginsberg” (Passion of Ginsberg), the longing for an absent lover, alluding to Allen Ginsberg’s own failed relationship.

Written in free verse, the poems, despite the potentially explosive nature of their subject matter, are characterized by sparseness of detail and a restrained language that render them ironic and paradoxical. The reader is subtly made aware of the burden of what is unspoken. Tucked in the middle of the second half of the book is his poem “Ars Poetika,” in which Popa states that we can only grope for meaning in “the silences and gaps between objects” (mga katahimikan at patlang sa pagitan ng bagay-bagay). This applies as well to Popa’s poetry, which is what makes for its distinct style.  Written by Om Narayan Velasco

 

Source

Tolentino, Rolando, ed. 2008. Writing to the Future: Poetika at Politika ng Malikhaing Pagsulat. Quezon City: Likhaan: UP Institute of Creative Writing.

text:
aka Keg Sumba neg Sandayo (The Tale of Sandayo). Published 1982. Transcriber, Virgilio Resma. “The Tale of Sandayo,” Kinaadman 4:259-426.

This guman or epic is one of the many folk narratives of the Subanon, a sub-Visayan mountainfolk of the Zamboanga peninsula. It is sung in the Subanon language in communal affairs like the buklog, a feast honoring the gods, or a wake. The tale was recorded and transcribed by Virgilio Resma, a schoolteacher in one of the public schools of Ozamis City, in 1981. He was aided by some Subanon informants and by Epifania M. Alunan. Resma’s principal source for this guman was Perena, a native of Sindangan, Zamboanga del Norte. She was 62 years old when the recording took place in Barrio Pawas. She had learned the epic from her grandmother, Bay Aya. Perena chanted the epic in the evenings for a week, starting at about nine or ten and ending at about three the following morning. She chanted at night to concentrate. To start, she drinks either coconut wine called tuba or a bottle of beer.

This 6,477-line guman is characterized by the repetition of scenes and episodes. These scenes and episodes involve the nearly endless rounds of fighting, the gearing up for a journey, the ritualistic drinking of gasi wine, and the long bouts of sleep. Magic is also integral to the epic. Examples in the epic include flying kerchiefs, talking birds, and physical transformations.

Datu Salaria, the chief of Tubig Liyasan (Waters of Liyasan) is troubled, for his wife Salaong is childless. The couple decide to go bathe in the springs of Liyasan, reputed to be magical. Salaong dips herself seven times into the waters and begins to feel heavy, although she is not pregnant. When she returns home, she applies oil to her hair and combs it. A child falls from her hair. He is named Sandayo.

In a week, he learns to walk; in a month, he asks for his parents’ permission to go on a journey. His father gives him a kalis or sword, and his mother dresses him up in a glittering robe. Before Sandayo departs, he receives a warning from a limmon or wild pigeon, but he ignores it. Sandayo rides his monsala or kerchief and commands the lightning to take him to the center of the sun. While enjoying his mamaq or betel chew, in the sun, he dreams of two ladies: Bae Bolak Sonday and Benobong. They offer him their mamaq, but he accepts only Bolak Sonday’s offer. Awakening, he sets out to look for the waters of Gwalo Leyo and, after two weeks, finds them.

Sandayo easily enchants the two datus of Gwalo Leyo, Daugbolawan and Lemolok, who decide to adopt him. After a week, Lomelok hears sounds from the buklog of Lumanay. Sandayo and the two datus decide to attend the feast; but on their way, Sandayo receives a warning from the limmon. Again, he ignores it.

At the feast, Sandayo meets Bolak Sonday and Benobong, the two ladies he dreamt of. Because most of the datus are enchanted by Bolak Sonday’s beauty, a rivalry among them arises. Bolak Sonday, however, shows affection for Damodianay. Sandayo is jealous. He challenges Damodianay to a duel, which lasts for two years. Among the consequences of this battle is the drying of the sea, causing giant eels to seek refuge ashore and sea nymphs to weep.

In the third year, the god Asog intervenes. Together with his wife Bae Asog, he descends to the earth to end the feud. The gods reveal that the two feuding datus are really twins. Both of them had fallen from the hair of Salaong, but Damondianay was blown away by the wind. Thus, he grew up in the isle of Balakatan. The brothers are reconciled, and they journey to Balakatan.

When Sandayo invites Damodianay to visit their parents in Liyasan, Damodianay refuses because he considers himself the guardian of the hills of Balakatan. To remedy the situation, Sandayo charms Damodianay to sleep. While Damodianay is sleeping, Sandayo cuts sections of the hills of Balakatan from the earth and, with a leap, brings them to Liyasan. Thus, the brothers are reunited with their parents. To celebrate, Datu Salaria beheads seven tinayobos, or female servants, and seven sampilakan, or male servants. After the celebration, Datu Salaria asks Sandayo to accompany his cousins, Daugbolawan and Lomelok, from Tobig Sumina to Manelangan to propose to Bolak Sonday and Benobong.

On the way to Manelangan on board the gadyong or ship, they encounter Bae Pigdindingan. They refuse her offer of mamaq. Insulted, she curses the datus. A wind sweeps over the ship; it becomes an octopus and captures the ship. But Sandayo flings the octopus at Pigdindingan. It clings to her body, killing her at daytime and reviving her at night.

In Manelangan, many datus seek Bolak Sonday’s hand in marriage, but none of them, not even the powerful Datu Lumalab, satisfies the parents of Bolak Sonday. Datu Pombanwa, the father, asks for a sinduko or scythe and an axe. Bae Salagga, the mother asks, among other things, for jars as numerous as the grains of one ganta of millet, a golden bridge connecting the suitor’s house to Bolak Sonday’s room, and a golden trough connecting the sun with her own room. In addition, Bolak Sonday’s nurse asks for a golden comb and a golden loom, among other things. With magic, Sandayo produces the dowry in his cousins’ behalf. He also butchers a great pig for the banquet in his cousins’ behalf.

When Bolak Sonday’s parents accept the cousins, Datu Lumalab and the other datus engage them in battle. During the battle, Sandayo leaves his spear, which fights on its own, and flies to drink from the sweat of the sun. After several months, Sandayo and his cousins defeat Datu Lumalab and the other datus. Using the golden bridge, Sandayo and his cousins return to Sumina, bringing with them the two women.

When Sandayo returns to Liyasan, he falls ill. He sends his monsala to fetch Bolak Sonday and Benobong, but it is too late. Sandayo dies. Bolak Sonday initiates a search for Sandayo’s spirit. She searches the lower world, while Benobong searches the upper world. After roaming for three weeks, the two women meet, each of them frustrated. Benobong then searches for Sandayo’s spirit in the sky, while Bolak Sonday looks around in the world. After two months, the women meet again, still not having found Sandayo’s spirit.

While the women are resting under the bolongis, which is a legendary tree, a sumusom (a small black bird with red eyes) and a dalandaw (a yellow bird with black streak) perch on the tree and start discussing the woman’s state. The birds reveal to them where Sandayo’s spirit is and how the woman may get there. They also leave them some of their feathers, which are transformed into brilliant rings. These light the ladies’ way to Tubig Piksiipan, where Sandayo’s spirit is a captive of amazons.

Riding their monsala, the women command the lightning to bring them to Tubig Piksiipan. Bolak Sonday steals Sandayo’s spirit and changes it into a ring. A battle between the amazons and Bolak Sonday occurs, lasting for two months. Soon, Bolak Sonday and Benobong defeat the amazons. They ride the monsala and command the lightning to transport them to Sandayo’s chamber. There, Bolak Sonday rouses Sandayo, who seems to be asleep. He requests a drink from the sun’s sweat. Bolak Sonday swiftly flies to the sun to obtain a drink in a cup of gold. The drink revives Sandayo. The two women return home.

While cutting a golden betel nut, Bolak Sonday wounds herself. Although the wound is small, it bleeds so much that she dies. Sandayo, summoned by her monsala, initiates the search for Bolak Sonday’s spirit. Together with Lomelok, Mendepasa, and Datu Daugbolawan, Sandayo searches both the upper and the lower worlds.

Once, while he and the datus are resting under a bolongis tree, two birds, a gowak crow and a sumusom, inform them that Bolak Sonday’s spirit is in Katonawan. They give the datus some feathers, which they make into a brilliant ring to illuminate their path. They arrive in Katonawan and find the spirit of Bolak Sonday a captive of the datu. Sandayo fights the datu and frees Bolak Sonday’s spirit. Bolak Sonday is revived.

Sandayo returns to Liyasan where his father holds a blood rite to celebrate his return. After that, Sandayo goes to Tubig Sumina to visit his other cousins. There, his two cousins—Datu Tulog and Pammintoan—request him to help them secure the dowry they need for Datu Tulog to marry Lengotubig. Lengotubig’s parents ask for the same dowry that Datu Pombanwa and Bae Salagga did for Bolak Sonday and Benobong. Using his magic, Sandayo helps them, and Datu Tulog marries Lengotubig.

When Sandayo returns to Liyasan, he dreams that his uncle is preparing a buklog in which his presence is essential. When he awakes, he asks his parents to go with him. He also invites Lomelok, Bolak Sonday, Daugbolawan, Benobong, Mendepesa, Panday Tape, Bae Salangka, and all their children. They ride their monsala to Manelangan, the place of Sandayo’s uncle.

As they hold the buklog, the buklogan or platform slowly rises to heaven. Sandayo promises his servants that he will return to take them to heaven. When the platform has reached the clouds, it descends to the earth. But Sandayo and his relatives have already gone to heaven.  Written by Servando Halili Jr.

 

Source

Resma, Virgilio. 1982. “Keg Sumba neg Sandayo.” Kinaadman 4:259-426.
