She had learned the epic from her grandmother, Bay Aya. Perena chanted the epic in the evenings for a week, starting at about nine or ten and ending at about three the following morning. She chanted at night to concentrate. To start, she drinks either coconut wine called tuba or a bottle of beer.

This 6,477-line guman is characterized by the repetition of scenes and episodes. These scenes and episodes involve the nearly endless rounds of fighting, the gearing up for a journey, the ritualistic drinking of gasi wine, and the long bouts of sleep. Magic is also integral to the epic. Examples in the epic include flying kerchiefs, talking birds, and physical transformations.

Datu Salaria, the chief of Tubig Liyasan (Waters of Liyasan) is troubled, for his wife Salaong is childless. The couple decide to go bathe in the springs of Liyasan, reputed to be magical. Salaong dips herself seven times into the waters and begins to feel heavy, although she is not pregnant. When she returns home, she applies oil to her hair and combs it. A child falls from her hair. He is named Sandayo.

In a week, he learns to walk; in a month, he asks for his parents’ permission to go on a journey. His father gives him a kalis or sword, and his mother dresses him up in a glittering robe. Before Sandayo departs, he receives a warning from a limmon or wild pigeon, but he ignores it. Sandayo rides his monsala or kerchief and commands the lightning to take him to the center of the sun. While enjoying his mamaq or betel chew, in the sun, he dreams of two ladies: Bae Bolak Sonday and Benobong. They offer him their mamaq, but he accepts only Bolak Sonday’s offer. Awakening, he sets out to look for the waters of Gwalo Leyo and, after two weeks, finds them.

Sandayo easily enchants the two datus of Gwalo Leyo, Daugbolawan and Lemolok, who decide to adopt him. After a week, Lomelok hears sounds from the buklog of Lumanay. Sandayo and the two datus decide to attend the feast; but on their way, Sandayo receives a warning from the limmon. Again, he ignores it.

At the feast, Sandayo meets Bolak Sonday and Benobong, the two ladies he dreamt of. Because most of the datus are enchanted by Bolak Sonday’s beauty, a rivalry among them arises. Bolak Sonday, however, shows affection for Damodianay. Sandayo is jealous. He challenges Damodianay to a duel, which lasts for two years. Among the consequences of this battle is the drying of the sea, causing giant eels to seek refuge ashore and sea nymphs to weep.

In the third year, the god Asog intervenes. Together with his wife Bae Asog, he descends to the earth to end the feud. The gods reveal that the two feuding datus are really twins. Both of them had fallen from the hair of Salaong, but Damondianay was blown away by the wind. Thus, he grew up in the isle of Balakatan. The brothers are reconciled, and they journey to Balakatan.

When Sandayo invites Damodianay to visit their parents in Liyasan, Damodianay refuses because he considers himself the guardian of the hills of Balakatan. To remedy the situation, Sandayo charms Damodianay to sleep. While Damodianay is sleeping, Sandayo cuts sections of the hills of Balakatan from the earth and, with a leap, brings them to Liyasan. Thus, the brothers are reunited with their parents. To celebrate, Datu Salaria beheads seven tinayobos, or female servants, and seven sampilakan, or male servants. After the celebration, Datu Salaria asks Sandayo to accompany his cousins, Daugbolawan and Lomelok, from Tobig Sumina to Manelangan to propose to Bolak Sonday and Benobong.

On the way to Manelangan on board the gadyong or ship, they encounter Bae Pigdindingan. They refuse her offer of mamaq. Insulted, she curses the datus. A wind sweeps over the ship; it becomes an octopus and captures the ship. But Sandayo flings the octopus at Pigdindingan. It clings to her body, killing her at daytime and reviving her at night.

In Manelangan, many datus seek Bolak Sonday’s hand in marriage, but none of them, not even the powerful Datu Lumalab, satisfies the parents of Bolak Sonday. Datu Pombanwa, the father, asks for a sinduko or scythe and an axe. Bae Salagga, the mother asks, among other things, for jars as numerous as the grains of one ganta of millet, a golden bridge connecting the suitor’s house to Bolak Sonday’s room, and a golden trough connecting the sun with her own room. In addition, Bolak Sonday’s nurse asks for a golden comb and a golden loom, among other things. With magic, Sandayo produces the dowry in his cousins’ behalf. He also butchers a great pig for the banquet in his cousins’ behalf.

When Bolak Sonday’s parents accept the cousins, Datu Lumalab and the other datus engage them in battle. During the battle, Sandayo leaves his spear, which fights on its own, and flies to drink from the sweat of the sun. After several months, Sandayo and his cousins defeat Datu Lumalab and the other datus. Using the golden bridge, Sandayo and his cousins return to Sumina, bringing with them the two women.

When Sandayo returns to Liyasan, he falls ill. He sends his monsala to fetch Bolak Sonday and Benobong, but it is too late. Sandayo dies. Bolak Sonday initiates a search for Sandayo’s spirit. She searches the lower world, while Benobong searches the upper world. After roaming for three weeks, the two women meet, each of them frustrated. Benobong then searches for Sandayo’s spirit in the sky, while Bolak Sonday looks around in the world. After two months, the women meet again, still not having found Sandayo’s spirit.

While the women are resting under the bolongis, which is a legendary tree, a sumusom (a small black bird with red eyes) and a dalandaw (a yellow bird with black streak) perch on the tree and start discussing the woman’s state. The birds reveal to them where Sandayo’s spirit is and how the woman may get there. They also leave them some of their feathers, which are transformed into brilliant rings. These light the ladies’ way to Tubig Piksiipan, where Sandayo’s spirit is a captive of amazons.

Riding their monsala, the women command the lightning to bring them to Tubig Piksiipan. Bolak Sonday steals Sandayo’s spirit and changes it into a ring. A battle between the amazons and Bolak Sonday occurs, lasting for two months. Soon, Bolak Sonday and Benobong defeat the amazons. They ride the monsala and command the lightning to transport them to Sandayo’s chamber. There, Bolak Sonday rouses Sandayo, who seems to be asleep. He requests a drink from the sun’s sweat. Bolak Sonday swiftly flies to the sun to obtain a drink in a cup of gold. The drink revives Sandayo. The two women return home.

While cutting a golden betel nut, Bolak Sonday wounds herself. Although the wound is small, it bleeds so much that she dies. Sandayo, summoned by her monsala, initiates the search for Bolak Sonday’s spirit. Together with Lomelok, Mendepasa, and Datu Daugbolawan, Sandayo searches both the upper and the lower worlds.

Once, while he and the datus are resting under a bolongis tree, two birds, a gowak crow and a sumusom, inform them that Bolak Sonday’s spirit is in Katonawan. They give the datus some feathers, which they make into a brilliant ring to illuminate their path. They arrive in Katonawan and find the spirit of Bolak Sonday a captive of the datu. Sandayo fights the datu and frees Bolak Sonday’s spirit. Bolak Sonday is revived.

Sandayo returns to Liyasan where his father holds a blood rite to celebrate his return. After that, Sandayo goes to Tubig Sumina to visit his other cousins. There, his two cousins—Datu Tulog and Pammintoan—request him to help them secure the dowry they need for Datu Tulog to marry Lengotubig. Lengotubig’s parents ask for the same dowry that Datu Pombanwa and Bae Salagga did for Bolak Sonday and Benobong. Using his magic, Sandayo helps them, and Datu Tulog marries Lengotubig.

When Sandayo returns to Liyasan, he dreams that his uncle is preparing a buklog in which his presence is essential. When he awakes, he asks his parents to go with him. He also invites Lomelok, Bolak Sonday, Daugbolawan, Benobong, Mendepesa, Panday Tape, Bae Salangka, and all their children. They ride their monsala to Manelangan, the place of Sandayo’s uncle.

As they hold the buklog, the buklogan or platform slowly rises to heaven. Sandayo promises his servants that he will return to take them to heaven. When the platform has reached the clouds, it descends to the earth. But Sandayo and his relatives have already gone to heaven.  Written by Servando Halili Jr.
Source

text:
(A Sheaf of Verses: Ilocano Parnassus). Published 1926. Compiler, Mauro A. Peña and Antonio A. Fogata. Manila: Filipino Publishers.

This book is a collection of pastorals, satires, epigrams, odes, and other forms of poetry by Ilocano poets. The alphabet used in these poems is the old orthography of Ilocano, which is based on the Spanish alphabet; the letters c, q, z, and w are used.

The book is divided into two parts. The first part contains the 82 original works of 22 Ilocano poets: Leona Florentino, Ignacio Villamor, Isabelo de los Reyes, Fr Justo Claudio Fojas, Claro Caluya, Matea de Peralta, Enriqueta de Peralta, Marcelino Crisologo Peña, Pascual Agcaoili, Espiritu Paraiso, Honorio Purugganan, Jose Garvida Flores, Juan A. Abellera, Joaquin B. Ramirez, Leon C. Pichay, Antonio A. Fogata, and Mauro A. Peña.

The second part, titled “Sari-Sari” (Miscellanea), contains translations into Ilocano of some French, Spanish, Italian, German, and Chinese poems, as well as an excerpt from the epic Lam-ang; an old Ilocano ditty “Pamulinawen” (Stonehearted); “Apay-apay?” (Why?), a love poem by Isabelo de los Reyes; and several ancient Ilocano love songs, collectively called “Un-unnoy” (Pleadings).

The translations are Mauro A. Peña’s translation into Ilocano of the Philippine national anthem; “Maudi a Pacada,” Jose F. Tongson’s translation of Jose Rizal’s “Mi Ultimo Adios” (My Last Farewell); “Iriridep ni Ayat” (Love’s Slumber), Isabelo de los Reyes’s translation of a long Spanish poem by Jose Zorrilla; “Adda Iti Uneg Ti Bucsitda” (Inside Their Innards), de los Reyes’s translation of a Chinese poem by Ten Han; “Ni Ayatko” (My Love), de los Reyes’s translation of Dante Alighieri’s poem from the original Italian; “Daldallot” (Ditties), de los Reyes’s translation of a German poem by Enrique Heine; and “Ni Ayat” (Love), Pablo Teoculo’s translation of a French poem by Victor Hugo.

The poems included in the book represent the period commencing from Leona Florentino’s time at the Spanish era up to the first two decades of the 20th century. The poets express their philosophical ideas mostly in metaphorical and symbolic language. They also show a deep religious feeling, writing poems with reference to God and to the saints. Didacticism and moralizing are very evident, although a profound patriotic fervor is also present, especially in the verses that honor the national and local heroes.  Written by Reynaldo Duque

text:
Published 1980. Author, Alfred Yuson. Quezon City: Guaranty Press.

The title of Yuson’s first book of poems hints at the mythological allusiveness and liquidity of his poetic style. Many of the poems have as common denominators a combination of audacious conceit, ironic wordplay, rhetorical argument, and hard-bitten lyricism. Divided into three sections, the book is chronologically rolled backward, with earlier poems like “Sagada, June 1970” appearing last.

The first section has several poems showing how conscious the poet was in traversing the inner and outer stations of both Philippine and American cultures: “Travelogue,” “Ethnic Story,” “Talk Story,” “Filipino in Honolulu,” “Filipino in Frisco,” “Filipino in Chicago,” and “Filipino in New York.” These poems also cast recognizable images of places where the author’s countrymen—wayfarers all—have negotiated a half-home existence: in Honolulu, Filipinas in the flesh trade; in San Francisco, Mang Kardo, an old geezer calculating the pleasures remaining to him after a checkerboard life; in Chicago, Filipino poet Wilfredo Sanchez; and in New York, the poets Erwin (Castillo), Xoce (Jose Garcia Villa), Virginia (Moreno), who is also a cultural writer, and Cecile (Guidote), a doyen of Philippine theater—“all contemporary saints” and Yuson’s choice company. The longest poem in the book, “Travelogue,” is a romantic idyll calling forth places such as Coron, Camiguin, Bolinao, Mambajao, Pulau P’nang, Singapore, the US Midwest, and the seas that circle the globe. The places are recited in litany for a “glad-hopping” pilgrimage with the beloved as well as a “votive for tongue and eye.”

The second section contains pieces that use water or water-related imagery to reflect on poetry itself. In the title poem, the poem is described as a sea serpent: “strange fish” with “eye of crystal.” In the search for poetic truth, prismatic illusion may be the poet’s trade, but beyond the guile, it is “Dance of self. / Sweep of power. / Thread of innocence”; that is, a poem is both clarity and dream. The reverie continues in “Visions of Water,” where the poet affirms his affinity with water, “our third parent / and the truest / one, closest / to betrayals.”

Poems in the third section are shorter lyrics marked by a characteristic rhetorical felicity—private allusion and public meaning playfully chasing each other like wave and shore. There is gripping disharmony in “Love Poem,” where, kicking his partner’s dresser, the persona upsets the order of “the tools and potions of artifice” thereon, which come to resemble “the pieces of [their] argument.” There is also tender worship in “Sagada, June 1970,” where, taking up a book, the persona gazes at “the thrown gold / on your chin, / close by.”

By the 1980s, literary historian and poet Gemino Abad had observed that more Filipino poets were entering into a period of self-confident “creative toil” with the language and felt at home in the two cultures—English and Filipino—in which their sensibilities found a world. The poems in this book are a case in point.  Written by Alex Dacanay

text:
Published 1972. Author, Emmanuel Torres. Mandaluyong: Wherehouse.

Shapes of Silence by poet, professor, and art critic Emmanuel Torres was published in 1972, the year Ferdinand E. Marcos declared martial law. A spiritual tedium haunts the slim volume, like the unspoken ghosts of loved ones mysteriously disappeared.

In the first poem, the representatively surreal “To One Who Would Not Answer,” martial law curfew is personified by children who have stopped playing. Torres’s persona is bothered, paranoid, and pessimistic, like a future desaparecido (a person taken by the military and not seen hence) who knows he may be next. He is wakened from sleep by a cry; he stumbles out like a jailer; and he hears telephones ringing like demons. Of the dictator, Torres describes him as someone “hoarding silence, cutting all wires / [and] designing a dark city ….”

Silence and oppression have overtaken the Philippines; the act of writing is the response. Torres reserves his sharpest darts for satirizing the vagaries of religion. In “Another Invitation to the Pope to Visit Tondo,” the pope “slums” through the lives of the faithful, the masses are left with chances and leftovers, and the workers have holes in their pockets.

The evils of government and capitalism are another target. In “The Oligarchy,” Torres capitalizes “They” and the capitalist “My.” In “At the Factory,” workers warm their machines under the watchful eye of the bundy clock, while the boss daydreams of Swiss banks and hoarding more and more capital. Love is relief in any dystopia, but because it is a world without reassurances, he refuses a lover who begs him to stay with her: one must go out into the world “hazardstumbling.”

In “For One on the Move,” an “old heart must shove off” and even mornings have lost hope. The journey, however, is a reward in itself; hence, the excitement of looking at the horizon “in a zigzag gaze.” The thrilling sonic climax (assonance and consonance) of “zigzag gaze” meets the spiritual and mental conditions of Torres’s everyman. Seeking escape, the mover must move, even just with his eyes, even just phonetically, knowing full well his gaze will be trapped and caught. The victory is in the resistance offered, a contrast to the first poem’s paralysis.

Resistance is almost futile, but whatever efforts were expended in the decimation of artists in those days were met with an art that created Shapes of Silence. It is a grandly devastating record in verse of the Dark Ages of modern-day Philippines. Whatever stoppered malaise or silenced discontent or forced ineloquence that Marcos was able to impose on the rest of country will not be found here. The book is the triumph of art over silence.  Written by Arvin Abejo Mangohig

text:
(Seven Sons of Lara) aka Salita at Buhay na Kahabaghabag na Pinagdaanan ng Pitong Infantes de Lara at ng Kaabaabang Kanilang Ama sa Reynong España (History and Pitiful Life Experienced by the Seven Princes of Lara and by Their Miserable Father in the Kingdom of Spain). Published 1919. Anonymous. Seven known Tagalog editions; the latest is dated 1949. Also in Bikol and Ilocano.

In Spain there live a brother and a sister: Rubio Velasquez and Doña Sancha. Doña Sancha marries Gonzalo de Lara, popularly called Busto de Lara. After giving birth to seven boys all at one time, she dies. Identical in beauty and goodness, the “siete infantes” grow up to be strong, brave and active boys, renowned and feared by the Moors.

Meanwhile Rubio Velasquez marries Doña Lambra. At the wedding, the youngest of the princes quarrels with Lambra, who then asks her husband to avenge her. Don Rubio plots against his brother-in-law and his seven nephews. He advises the king to send Busto de Lara to the Turkish emperor with a letter asking for a truce, but Don Rubio substitutes it with a letter asking the Turkish emperor to kill the bearer. Don Rubio also assures the emperor that he will see to it that the seven princes get killed in battle. Impressed by Busto de Lara’s handsome and robust figure, the Turkish emperor does not kill him but consents to his daughter’s request to make Busto de Lara a slave in her garden. Busto and Princess Hismeña fall in love and the princess becomes pregnant.

Meanwhile, war breaks out between Spain and Turkey and as planned, Rubio Velasquez puts the seven princes at the head of the Spanish army. They are, however, made to fall into a big pit where their heads are chopped off, put into a chest, and sent to King Almanzor in Turkey. At the dinner to celebrate the victory, King Almanzor invites Busto de Lara to sit with them at the table. Recognizing his sons’ heads on the platter, Busto de Lara faints. Upon reviving, he kisses each head and laments over it. The emperor takes pity on him and releases him. After burying his sons’ heads, Busto de Lara leaves the Turkish court.

After Busto de Lara’s departure, Princess Hismeña gives birth to their son, Morada Gonzalo, who shows remarkable strength. At age 13, he hits the king of Arabia’s head with a chessboard and kills him because the latter has called him a bastard. He demands from his mother that she tell him who his father is. The princess tells him and advises him to go to Spain to escape the revenge of the subjects of the king of Arabia and to look for his father.

Morada Gonzalo begins to avenge the death of his seven half-brothers. First, he beheads the four Turkish generals responsible for their death. Then, he beheads Rubio, his captain, and Lambra. With the seven heads, Morada Gonzalo searches for his father, whom he finds sick, still weeping over the loss of his seven sons. Posing as a merchant from Turkey, Morada offers his wares—joy and sorrow—to his father. When the father replies that he would like to buy joy, Morada presents the seven heads on a platter. Busto de Lara is at first shocked at the ghastly spectacle but when Morada explains to him whose heads they are, he becomes happy and gets well. Morada asks that his father redeem his and his mother’s honor by marrying her. Busto de Lara agrees to do so if the princess will embrace Christianity, and Morada promises to persuade his mother to do so.

Accompanied by his father, Morada Gonzalo explains to the king the reason for his slaying Rubio Velasquez and his companions. The king is satisfied to hear that Morada wishes to be converted. Morada then returns to Turkey to fetch his mother. Morada and his mother, disguised as a knight, manage to escape from Turkey and are reunited with Busto de Lara. The king orders a big feast. Morada and his mother are baptized and given Christian names. The wedding of Busto de Lara and Princess Hismeña is, however, interrupted when Turkish troops attack the kingdom. Everybody goes out to fight, including Princess Hismeña, who dons armor and aids her husband, who is being hard-pressed by the Moors. Morada tries to appease King Almanzor’s anger and appeals to the king to be converted to Christianity, but the old man refuses. Busto de Lara and Hismeña join in their pleas, but the king is adamant. Finally, Morada Gonzalo invokes the aid of God and the Blessed Virgin, and miraculously Almanzor yields to captivity and conversion. He is baptized, with King Filipo of Spain as sponsor. His wounds miraculously heal, to the amazement of the Turks, who then also ask to be baptized.

King Filipo invites everyone to his palace, where he formally asks for the hand of Princess Hismeña in marriage to Busto de Lara. The interrupted wedding is completed, making Morada a legitimate child. Prince Morada inherits the Turkish throne, Busto de Lara is crowned king of Spain, and King Almanzor enters a Franciscan monastery.

The derivation from Spanish legend contains the extraordinary motif of the treacherous killing of seven young princes and the presentation of their heads on a platter to their father. Balancing this motif is the revenge motif, in which the young avenger beheads the guilty seven people. The romance also features a boy-hero, whose character is too fanciful even for a romance. Fresh from baptism, he displays incredible knowledge of Christian doctrine when he instructs his grandfather Almanzor in the Christian faith. article.value: (Seven Sons of Lara) aka Salita at Buhay na Kahabaghabag na Pinagdaanan ng Pitong Infantes de Lara at ng Kaabaabang Kanilang Ama sa Reynong España (History and Pitiful Life Experienced by the Seven Princes of Lara and by Their Miserable Father in the Kingdom of Spain). Published 1919. Anonymous. Seven known Tagalog editions; the latest is dated 1949. Also in Bikol and Ilocano.

In Spain there live a brother and a sister: Rubio Velasquez and Doña Sancha. Doña Sancha marries Gonzalo de Lara, popularly called Busto de Lara. After giving birth to seven boys all at one time, she dies. Identical in beauty and goodness, the “siete infantes” grow up to be strong, brave and active boys, renowned and feared by the Moors.

Meanwhile Rubio Velasquez marries Doña Lambra. At the wedding, the youngest of the princes quarrels with Lambra, who then asks her husband to avenge her. Don Rubio plots against his brother-in-law and his seven nephews. He advises the king to send Busto de Lara to the Turkish emperor with a letter asking for a truce, but Don Rubio substitutes it with a letter asking the Turkish emperor to kill the bearer. Don Rubio also assures the emperor that he will see to it that the seven princes get killed in battle. Impressed by Busto de Lara’s handsome and robust figure, the Turkish emperor does not kill him but consents to his daughter’s request to make Busto de Lara a slave in her garden. Busto and Princess Hismeña fall in love and the princess becomes pregnant.

Meanwhile, war breaks out between Spain and Turkey and as planned, Rubio Velasquez puts the seven princes at the head of the Spanish army. They are, however, made to fall into a big pit where their heads are chopped off, put into a chest, and sent to King Almanzor in Turkey. At the dinner to celebrate the victory, King Almanzor invites Busto de Lara to sit with them at the table. Recognizing his sons’ heads on the platter, Busto de Lara faints. Upon reviving, he kisses each head and laments over it. The emperor takes pity on him and releases him. After burying his sons’ heads, Busto de Lara leaves the Turkish court.

After Busto de Lara’s departure, Princess Hismeña gives birth to their son, Morada Gonzalo, who shows remarkable strength. At age 13, he hits the king of Arabia’s head with a chessboard and kills him because the latter has called him a bastard. He demands from his mother that she tell him who his father is. The princess tells him and advises him to go to Spain to escape the revenge of the subjects of the king of Arabia and to look for his father.

Morada Gonzalo begins to avenge the death of his seven half-brothers. First, he beheads the four Turkish generals responsible for their death. Then, he beheads Rubio, his captain, and Lambra. With the seven heads, Morada Gonzalo searches for his father, whom he finds sick, still weeping over the loss of his seven sons. Posing as a merchant from Turkey, Morada offers his wares—joy and sorrow—to his father. When the father replies that he would like to buy joy, Morada presents the seven heads on a platter. Busto de Lara is at first shocked at the ghastly spectacle but when Morada explains to him whose heads they are, he becomes happy and gets well. Morada asks that his father redeem his and his mother’s honor by marrying her. Busto de Lara agrees to do so if the princess will embrace Christianity, and Morada promises to persuade his mother to do so.

Accompanied by his father, Morada Gonzalo explains to the king the reason for his slaying Rubio Velasquez and his companions. The king is satisfied to hear that Morada wishes to be converted. Morada then returns to Turkey to fetch his mother. Morada and his mother, disguised as a knight, manage to escape from Turkey and are reunited with Busto de Lara. The king orders a big feast. article_title: Silungan Baltapa: The Voyage to Heaven of a Sama Hero
text:
Published 2005. Chanter, Binsu Lakbaw. Transcriber, Talib Lim Sangogot. Translators, Nicole Revel, Talib Lim Sangogot, Gerard Rixhon, and Alain Martenot. Paris: Geuthner.

This kata-kata, or sung narrative, is the epic of the Sama Dilaut, aka Sama-Bajau, people of the Sulu archipelago. It was chanted by Manubul Sama singer Binsu Lakbaw in 1997 at South Ubian, Tawi-Tawi. Silungan Baltapa is the epic hero’s name, which means “a place for meditation.”

The epic opens with the hero, his body shining as bright as stars, calling on his servant to prepare for a sea voyage to search for the Island of Mercy and Love, at the place of the Setting Sun. His mother, Ugbusan Sahaya (Source of Light), objects, for she has kept him under his seven-layered gauze canopy all his life to protect him from the natural elements. Silungan declares that only maidens are kept under a gauze canopy all their lives. He and his servant board Jalampa the boat, taking his agung (gong), named Kili-Kili Intan (String of Diamonds), to charm maidens with. The servant rows until they are exhausted, so Silungan summons a typhoon to speed them on their way. After three months they are welcomed into the island home of Mussa Dalmata (Only Pearl). Silungan tells Dalmata stories until they both fall asleep.

Elsewhere, two nuli birds (message carriers) tell Misil Balan (Mighty Steel) that Silungan is stealing his fiancée Dalmata from him. The angry datu is in Dalmata’s residence in an instant. Silungan’s servant and Misil Balan fight for a month until the servant weakens and dies. Silungan Baltapa, too, is no match for Misil Batan. Two nuli birds seek the help of Silungan Baltapa’s sister, Muslim Magkapala (Muslim Lady). In an instant, she stands before Misil Balan, who belittles her because she is a woman. Magkapala waves her sulban (magic scarf), which kills Misil Balan. She then restores Silungan Baltapa’s life with the sulban. At Silungan’s request, she does the same to Misil Balan. The datu declares his obedience to Magkapala from then on.

For the bride-price, Dalmata’s mother demands the Junub Istinja (Tree of Purity), with the blinding glow, standing in the garden of Paradise. Magkapala obtains it for her brother, and so Dalmata and Silungan are wed, amid the recitation of their genealogies and the Forgiveness ritual. After a month, the newlyweds sail to the Island of Love to visit Ugbusan Sahaya, now Dalmata’s mother-in-law. When marauders are about to attack the newlyweds’ ships, Magkapala hovers above the marauders and kicks them overboard. The journey, which would ordinarily last a month, is cut to half a day.

One morning while Dalmata is lying with her head on her husband’s lap and the servant is running a fine-toothed comb through her hair, two birds from the Hereafter fly in carrying a santol fruit. Dalmata craves the fruit, so Silungan scours the Hereafter for it. He encounters two galura (half-human-half-animal creatures), whose giant wings cover half the sky. Silungan defeats the two galura birds in battle and returns home to Dalmata with the fruit. While resting, Dalmata has a premonition of her death.

Dalmata gives birth to a boy, who is immediately able to walk and is given the name, Datu Muhmin (Believing Datu). But Dalmata dies soon afterward. The Qur’an is read, a food offering prepared, and her body bathed and embalmed. She is placed in a “coffin-boat of mirrors with three woven ties of gold” and buried by Baltapa’s window so he can sing to her. At the funeral, Silungan gives away a ganta of gold to each man and imam who comes.

The inconsolable Silungan follows his departed wife to Heaven, with the hope of bringing her back to life. He tests his palkatan (supernatural inner power) by making the clouds move and the ocean dry. He also recites the gumbila to strengthen his power. Silungan Baltapa’s journey to Heaven begins at the Kandala junction, where lies the boundary between Heaven and Hell. He enters Heaven and encounters newborn children desiring to save their parents from sin. He leaves Heaven and sees people who have committed abortion drowning in blood; people who have committed “forbidden acts” drowning in coconut milk; and flirtatious wives being tortured with an iron bar. Silungan arrives at the last level of Kandala, where the Grand Mufti Aulia guards the gates of Heaven. He gives Silungan an heirloom ring, yellow and bluish green, and instructs him to choose only the middle path toward Heaven. Upon entering Heaven, Silungan takes a rest, chews a betel quid, and praises his parents for protecting him from sin. He climbs onto the Judgment Scale, which tips toward Paradise. He climbs down and takes the middle path until he reaches Paradise, the Ultimate Heaven. Being sinless, Silungan skirts the horrors of Hell, which bursts into fire when he utters a magic spell at it.

Dalmata senses Silungan’s presence in Heaven and gets on her horse to meet him by the shade of the Tree. Finally, Silungan and Dalmata are reunited. She instructs him to ask the Most Powerful for permission to return to Earth with her. He appeals to Pakil Sabirulla (the Pakil of Patience-in-God) to give him the power he needs. At the Tree of Felicity in the depths of the ocean, Tuan the God appears, gives him a scarf, and instructs him to wave it over Dalmata to restore her to life.

Silungan is with Dalmata in an instant. They descend to earth separately, Silungan on foot, Dalmata on her horse. But when Silungan is midway down, the horse returns without Dalmata. Silungan wonders if it has all been an illusion. Back on earth, he has Dalmata’s coffin-boat dug up, and he waves the scarf over it, as the Tuan has instructed. Dalmata remains lifeless. He transfers her body from her coffin to the mat and tries again. Finally, Dalmata comes back to life. She embraces her husband, lauds him for being a good example to their people, and vows that they shall never be separated again. Silungan introduces their son, Datu Muhmin, to her. Everyone rejoices and praises Allah.  Written by Jay Jomar F. Quintos

article_title: Siso Sakradang ug Iba Pa nga Mga Siday han Tagoangkan
text:
(Seesaw Up and Down and Other Poems of the Womb). Published 2010. Author, Janis Claire B. Salvacion. Editor and Translator, Merlie M. Alunan. With an introduction by the editor. Manila: National Commission for Culture and the Arts, National Commission on Literary Arts, and Ateneo Institute of Literary Arts and Practices.

Salvacion cuts a lonely path, writing poetry in a language that has so far not produced a tradition of women’s writing. The book contains 39 poems on diverse themes of female sexuality—awakening, desire, identity, motherhood, grief and loss—and brings to the surface ideas and emotions that are usually repressed.

In “Nadakpan Ko Hiya nga Natutok” (I Catch Him Stealing Glances), a young girl responds to the admiring glances of a fellow passenger on a jeepney by separating her thighs a little. In “Ha Akon Inop” (In My Dream), a woman dreams that her lover abandons her after a tryst on a beach, perhaps to return to his wife. She is pained but is also intensely aware of freedom. In “Katutnga” (Middle Hour), a young girl is both fascinated and terrified overhearing her parents having sex.

Salvacion speaks in many voices: a woman ending an impossible love affair in “Nagpakiana Ka” (You Keep Asking), a woman bedeviled by an unforgettable romance in “Topograpiya han Paglimot” (Topography of Forgetting), a wife deciding to end an unfortunate marriage in “Balay-Balay” (Play House). Through these voices, Salvacion leads us into the inner life of everywoman, but particularly into the inner life of the Waray woman.

The physicality of language brings out unique perceptual nuances of experience, textures of emotion that can never be captured by a borrowed medium. The Waray woman speaking in her own language exudes a sensual appeal that is savored at the moment of articulation.

In her introduction to the collection, Alunan describes Salvacion’s writing as “keen as a blade but with the breathless restraint of a trapeze artist.” Salvacion departs from the tradition of Waray versification, and writes in free verse. Thus she frees the language from set formulations and conventions and awakens the intrinsic ambivalences and ambiguities that enrich the simplest utterance. This is seen in “Pangadi ni Otoy San-O Kumaturog Usa ka Gab-I” (Otoy’s Prayer One Night before Going to Bed), where the child realizes that the sign of the cross does not mention the one most important person in his life, the mother. When he asks his mother about it, she tells him, “Pssh … Otoy, katurog, / katurog la anay” (Pssh … Otoy, go to sleep, / go on, go to sleep now).

The title poem, “Siso Sakradang” (Seesaw Up and Down), shows Salvacion’s ability to orchestrate complex and multifarious concepts into a single moment of apprehension. The persona, a mother, sits her child on her two feet and swings her legs up and down, making like a seesaw for the child. She sings a nativized version of the nursery rhyme, “Seesaw, up and down / Tell me the way to London town.” This image collapses history, culture, and the postcultural dilemmas of language loss, reorientations, and accommodation in the particular world of a woman who remembers and foresees the inevitability of her separation from her child. In this poem and in most of this book, Salvacion bravely asserts the woman’s faith in the ability of loyalty and love to hold life and community together.  Written by Merlie M. Alunan

text:
(Calling the Cricket). Published 1972. Author, Rolando S. Tinio. Manila: Heartthrobs & Other Beats.

This collection of poems, written between 1965 and 1972, established Tinio’s reputation as a poet. Tinio was part of a group at Ateneo de Manila in the early 1960s called the bagay (literally, “thing”) poets, whose literary tendency was to develop a minimalist or objectivist approach to the description of poetic material, presumably to avoid commentary or critique through social or political themes.

The poems are characterized by a modern style, with some concession to traditional Tagalog versification. Irony, wit, unusual caesura, unorthodox use of Tagalog words and colloquialisms, unique phraseology, and a consistent irreverence, all combine to imbue Tinio’s poems with folksiness, despite the “newness” of his language, as well as some arcane and foreign allusions.

In his introductory poem “Pauna” (Preface), a veritable ars poetica, he claims, “Wala ritong damdaming / Matangkad pa sa atin, / Tumatayog paghitit / Sa pisi ng hangin” (Here there are no feelings / Taller than ourselves / That grow as we draw on / The rope of the wind). But objectivism is hardly the effect in some of Tinio’s unconventional images. Even the poem “Bagay” (Thing) carries an ominous note: “Sa harapan mo, nakatirik ang bagay / Sa gitna ng hanging halos gumagalaw. / Nagtitimpi. Sa pagkakahalukipkip / Lalo lamang sumisidhi” (Before you stands the thing / In the midst of the near-moving wind. / Keeping its cool. Arms folded, it / Intensifies even more).

The best known of Tinio’s poems is “Ang Burges sa Kanyang Almusal” (The Bourgeois at Breakfast). In his luxurious dining room, a man sits on his claret-colored velvet cushion. No one would suppose that this man has the power to decapitate people on the street. As he gazes at his breakfast, he ignores the morning newspaper, which carries the usual accounts of everyday life: a mother and child run over by a congressman’s son, an innocent person languishing in jail, the victims of fire and flood, and the sorrows of all the other powerless and impoverished people in society.

There are images of human violence on TV in “Combat”; intellectuals coping with everyday life in “Sa Umaga” (In the Morning); the aimlessness of city life in “Sa Abenida” (On Avenida, a Street in Manila); a meditation on summer heat in congested Tondo, where the poet grew up, in “Tag-init sa Tundo” (Summer in Tondo); and wry but sympathetic sketches of common people he encounters in the underprivileged community. Still, despite the range of reflection and the complexity of issues that the poet ends up weaving or unraveling, he admonishes the reader, at the last stanza of “Pauna”: “Sumalampak sa sahig, / Kung maaari’y makinig / Ng awit na sa wari’y / Sitsit ng kuliglig” (Sit yourselves on the floor, / And listen, if you will / To my song which seems to be / But a cricket’s call). The genius of the book lies in its title. “Sitsit ng kuliglig” (the cricket’s call) is transformed into “Sitsit sa Kuliglig” (Calling the Cricket). One may interpret this as a call for sense and sound, meaning as well as magic.  Written by Edgardo Maranan

As he gazes at his breakfast, he ignores the morning newspaper, which carries the usual accounts of everyday life: a mother and child run over by a congressman’s son, an innocent person languishing in jail, the victims of fire and flood, and the sorrows of all the other powerless and impoverished people in society.

There are images of human violence on TV in “Combat”; intellectuals coping with everyday life in “Sa Umaga” (In the Morning); the aimlessness of city life in “Sa Abenida” (On Avenida, a Street in Manila); a meditation on summer heat in congested Tondo, where the poet grew up, in “Tag-init sa Tundo” (Summer in Tondo); and wry but sympathetic sketches of common people he encounters in the underprivileged community. Still, despite the range of reflection and the complexity of issues that the poet ends up weaving or unraveling, he admonishes the reader, at the last stanza of “Pauna”: “Sumalampak sa sahig, / Kung maaari’y makinig / Ng awit na sa wari’y / Sitsit ng kuliglig” (Sit yourselves on the floor, / And listen, if you will / To my song which seems to be / But a cricket’s call). The genius of the book lies in its title. “Sitsit ng kuliglig” (the cricket’s call) is transformed into “Sitsit sa Kuliglig” (Calling the Cricket). One may interpret this as a call for sense and sound, meaning as well as magic.  Written by Edgardo Maranan

article_title: The Smile on Smokey Mountain and Other Poems
text:
Published 1991. Author, Emmanuel Torres. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University, Office of Research and Publications. Manila Critics Circle’s National Book Award for poetry, 1992.

Class guilt is a pervasive theme in this collection of 55 poems. In many of the poems, the persona moves around a metropolis of gleaming skyscrapers and familiar traffic snarls and is reminded at every turn of the casualties of this supposed development, the wretched unnamed characters that people the collection who destabilize the persona’s otherwise comfortable and isolated middle-class existence. Recurring characters are scavengers rummaging through mountains of garbage (“The Smile on Smokey Mountain), beggars accosting stalled cars in intersections (“Alms in Noon Traffic”), and personages like Jose Rizal (“To the Boy Pepe Rizal Whose Slipper Fell into the Water while Cruising on Laguna de Bae”), Imelda Marcos (“In Defense of 3,000 Pairs of Shoes Left Behind in the Palace One February Night”), and even the titular figure in Fernando Amorsolo’s El Ciego (“The Smile on the Yellow Guitar”).

In “Sampaguita Girl,” a young girl raises her garlands before the chrome window of a car snagged in bumper-to-bumper traffic. The ruminating passenger is seized by fear as he imagines the terrifying consequences of his indifference. He speculates: “How long before she tires and falls into / The net of The Alien One / Slumming through the ruins of unanswered prayers.” Sufficiently consumed by guilt, he buys all the garlands the little girl is selling. But somehow the persona realizes that such occasional generosity will not suffice to save the girl. The poignancy of the situation ends in the sincere though futile gesture, implicating, too, the country’s neocolonial status that renders its citizens prey to abuse: “If I could shed more / Than pittance—perhaps tears // Of rage for the lost, or soon-to-be / In the land of the prolific / And the childbaiter / Whose wide, wide, sunlit smile here passes / For hospitality.”

The title piece “The Smile on Smokey Mountain” is an ironic paean to “those who thrive on the edge / Of a crater / Smoldering with the dump of others.” According to the poem, the “barefoot Christ” in the neighborhood’s improvised chapel is “also a Scavenger.” The Christ figure recurs halfway into the collection in “Ways to Consume Christmas,” which pokes fun at the consumerist frenzy that grips the city during the Holidays: “But how to reconcile the fat spending / to a Mass named after one who chose / birth in a cave.” In “Nineteen Views of the Rainbow over Araneta Coliseum,” Torres creates an urban collage using differing characters’ points of view, culminating in the rainbow’s disappearance and, in its stead, “the leaping / Golden Double Arches of McDonald’s / Span their own sky.” The rainbow reappears in “The View from the Fourteenth Floor: Makati West.” The persona’s location, he surmises, “Must be where rainbows end / And prayers are answered.” The height obscures his views of society and the illusion is undermined only when he rips the wall-to-wall carpeting and finds: “It is glistening on the backs of the poor.”

Torres thus succeeds in sustaining this political voice, clear and adamant about his intended audience, a bourgeois and English-speaking crowd that his political musings, social commentary, and expressions of dissatisfaction and anger are supposed to enlighten and shake from indifference. In The Smile on Smokey Mountain and Other Poems, he joins the head of the ranks by resonating a consciously political tone. He defines existence as transcending the boundaries of the private and the personal. It is a poetics of the self, so unsuccessful in isolating itself from the violence that harms and lingers, the rampant misery, and the sustained and seething anger of the rabble that have lost faith in the social order. The poems, in sum, categorically express collective woes and discontent.  Written by Danilo Francisco M. Reyes and Glenn Diaz

text:
Published 1974. Author, Roman A. de la Cruz. Kalibo: Aklan Cultural Heritage.

Song of the Ati-ati is a narrative poem of 609 lines, which vary in length, though most are either heptasyllabic or octosyllabic. The stanzas vary from 5 to 27 lines with no definite rhyming pattern. It is divided into two parts: “The Celebration,” composed of 11 stanzas, and “The Origin,” composed of 43 stanzas.

The first part describes the ritual of preparation for those wishing to join the street revelry that is the Ati-atihan. They paint themselves with soot taken from the bottom of a pot, pan, or coconut husk for them to look like an Ati. They turn ordinary implements like a kettle, rattle, horn, or bottle into noisemakers when they join the crowd, who are making the same “old tune” that they make every year with various instruments: the drum, cans, crowbar, bass drum, and snare. These the revelers punctuate with the shout, “Viva kay Señor Santo Niño!” (Long live the Holy Child).

The second part, inspired by Pedro Monteclaro’s mytho-historical work Maragtas, 1907, narrates the origin of the Ati-atihan. It begins with the first encounter of Panay’s native inhabitants, the Ati and their datu or chief Marikudo, with the 10 Bornean datu, led by Datu Puti, from Shri-Vishaya. The Borneans purchase the lowlands of Panay from the Ati with a gold sarok (wide-brimmed hat) and a batiya (basin). A feast is held after the purchase. As the Ati dance “with flung arms and shuffling feet,” the Borneans imitate them. A year later, Datu Bangkaya orders his people to reenact the sale by smearing their faces and bodies with soot and dancing to the sound of budyong (shell trumpet), gongs, and drums. When the Spaniards come centuries later, they turn the celebration into a religious occasion, with the Santo Niño (Holy Child) as the focal point.

Song of the Ati-ati came 13 years after Ricaredo Demetillo’s Barter in Panay, 1961, and 20 years ahead of Dominador Ilio’s Madia-as, 1994, both of which draw inspiration from the Maragtas. It is, however, dela Cruz’s Song that is the first published poem in English that reproduces the rhythm and beat of the Ati-ati festival, with onomatopoeic words like “bong bong,” “bang bang,” “bagtoe,” “tog tog,” “plak plak,” “clang clang,” and “ting ting.”  Written by John E. Barrios, with notes from Alexander de Juan

text:
Transcribed 2006. Transcriber, Eduardo M. Lapiz, “Sotu Tutul Ttud Bulul: Isang Kwento ni Tud Bulul; Pagsasa-Filipino ng Isang ‘Hlolok’ ng mga T’boli na Inawit Ni Ma’dison”

Kemokul, Tud Bulul’s father, dreams of the destruction of his village of Lem Lunay. To save Lem Lunay, Tud Bulul must trade his sister Kenaban for a shield owned by Datu Busaw, chief of Henluy Mountain. Tud Bulul and Kenaban traverse eight mountains until they reach Henluy. Suddenly a storm breaks out, and the skies are filled with flying busaw (evil spirits). Datu Busaw gives Tud Bulul weapons and clothes in exchange for Kenaban. They hear a warrior’s cry, mocking Tud Bulul for sacrificing Kenaban. Busaw beheads the warrior, and the other busaw feast on the body. Busaw leaves with Kenaban, and Tud Bulul leaves for home. Busaw’s sympathetic sister, Lembenan, plans Kenaban’s escape, but Kenaban is resolute about staying. She pounds rice for Busaw’s guests. At midnight, a huge snake named Datu Lamay, who has been sent by Tud Bulul, gives Kenaban the venomous black part of his liver. She is to mix it with the rice to wreak havoc among the busaw’s party guests. He also gives her his right horn and instructs her to use it to tame the busaw.

The next morning, Busaw falls ill from Kenaban’s concoction. He promises Kenaban her freedom and offers her several gifts if she cures him. Kenaban takes a small bowl, an aromatic root, and the snake’s horn. She prays over these, then smokes Busaw’s body and heals him completely. This causes a character transformation in Busaw, hereafter named Tegingkan Densu Libun, who becomes Tud Bulul’s staunch ally.

For two days he battles with the enemy, Datu Loko Tegedung, a powerful newborn, with the placenta and his umbilical cord still attached. When Kenaban and Lembenan arrive on a horse, Tegedung snatches them. Tud Bulul, astride a horse, and Tegingkan, on a beetle-sized one, must now travel through plains, mountains, forests, and islands to rescue their sisters. Along the way, a series of giant snakes and a dragon join them one after another: Datu Lamay, then Datu Lugod, the dragon Sewaga, and several snakes.

Tud Bulul must slash through the iron mountain of Anggan. But Tud Bulul’s kampilan (cutlass) is only a palm long. Datu Lugod takes the knife’s hilt between his teeth, while Datu Lamay, the blade. They pull it in opposite directions until it stretches up to the sun. Tegingkan attempts to cut the mountain first. Three times he strikes, but his sword only curves down to the middle. It is Tud Bulul who succeeds in splitting the mountain, giving it three strikes. As they continue traveling, they encounter a man walking in his sleep. When the sleeping man does not reply to Tud Bulul’s queries, Tud Bulul strikes him in the nose. The man is Datu Lambon Tungo Mogow, one of Kemokul’s children and therefore Tud Bulul’s brother, who was once offered as a sacrifice. Lambon asks for Tud Bulul’s kimu (personal treasures), but Tud Bulul will grant Lambon’s wish only if he accompanies them in their quest. Lambon does.

They pass through other worlds and several mountains. When they finally arrive in Mebusung, the party divides into groups and they hide in different places. Lambon captures the quake that Tegedung has brought to Lem Lunay. Tud Bulul challenges Tegedung to a fight. From Tegingkan’s shield emanates a force that destroys the town. But the town instantly springs back to life, and Tegedung belittles Tegingkan. Tud Bulul displays his power next and summons quakes from his habiliments and companions. The tremor and conflagration last for seven days, reaching distant lands and demolishing everything. Lambon helps Tegingkan fight the enemy, but they cannot subdue Tegedung. Tud Bulul creates a bamboo trap as big as a mountain, and Tegedung is captured. But Tud Bulul and Tegedung suddenly vanish.

Lambon travels the many levels of the Realm of the Dead in search of Tud Bulul. He meets several characters whom he threatens into helping him. He learns that Tud Bulul is about to forge a pact of friendship with Datu Kayung, chief of the region of the the murdered ones. Under threat, Datu Kayung reveals that the pact has been made, and Tud Bulul has gone home. Lambon demands from Kayung the amulet of Lem Fuyan Koyu Anggan, the warrior killed by Busaw in Henluy, so that Lambon would become part of the pact between Kayung and Tud Bulul. Kayung gives in. Lambon leaps from the place and lands in Lem Lunay, burning everything in his path.

Prodded by his father Kemokul, Tud Bulul calls to Lambon, who expresses his bitterness at Tud Bulul’s abandonment and for leaving him out of the pact with Kayung. Hence, he decides to destroy Lem Lunay and Tud Bulul. Kemokul intervenes and, at his request, Tud Bulul agrees to give what Lambon wants—the twin of Tud Bulul’s gading. Lambon goes up the house, and Kemokul has Tud Bulul share a betel chew with Tegingkan’s sister Lembenan. He does the same with Tegingkan and Tud Bulul’s sister Kenaban. He bids farewell, leaving instructions for everyone, and, with his chosen companions, departs for Kotun Gewolun, where he will spend the rest of his life.  Written by Efmer Agustin

 

Source

Lapiz, Eduardo M. 2006. “Sotu Tutul Tud Bulul (Isang Kwento ni Tud Bulul): Pagsasa-Filipino ng Isang ‘Hlolok’ ng mga T’boli na Inawit ni Ma’Dison.” MA thesis, University of the Philippines Diliman.

article_title: STR: Mga Tula ng Digmang Bayan sa Pilipinas
text:
(STR: Poems of the People’s War in the Philippines). Published 1989. With an introduction by “Gayanggang” and translations in English and Filipino. Kilusan sa Paglilinang ng Rebolusyonaryong Panitikan at Sining sa Kanayunan or LINANG.

Revolutionary poets, from different sectors and regions, impart their praxis through verses in STR, an acronym for “Sa Tagumpay ng Rebolusyon” (Toward the Triumph of the Revolution). The poems overturn the stereotypical image of grim-and-determined, gun-wielding Communist guerrillas, with themes showing different aspects of armed struggle and of life at the countryside.

A recurring theme is the sense of place and geography, where the persona patrols guerrilla zones, investigates bases, or navigates terrains. The titles of Ruth Firmeza’s “Banig” and “Pitso Manok” might be translated mistakenly as “Reed Mat” and “Chicken Breast,” respectively, but actually refer to a town and a mountain that bore witness to the protracted people’s war. Nature is a comrade as well in Wilfredo Gacosta’s “Bundok Bulusan, Ipaliwanag Mo ang Iyong Kahiwagaan” / “Mt. Bulusan, Unfold Your Mystery,” Lucia Makabayan’s “Sagada” and “Pagkilala sa Gubat” / “Knowing the Forest,” Jason Montana’s “Ifugao Revisited,” Servando Magbanua’s “Tomloy: October 2, 1978,” and Kris Montañez’s “Kalikasan” (Nature).

The elegies do not wallow in drama and defeat: In Firmeza’s “Tandaan Mo” / “Remember,” fallen comrades’ sacrifices inspire Red fighters to carry on with the struggle. Gacosta’s “Agosto 5, Hindi Ka Malilimot” / “August 5, You Will Never Be Forgotten,” Emmanuel Lacaba’s “Sa Alaala ni Nick Solana” / “In Memory of Nick Solana” and Magbanua’s “Poem Written beside a Peasant Comrade’s Grave on the First Anniversary of His Death” vow revolutionary justice against class enemies and treacherous counterrevolutionaries.

Historically, STR is situated after the split within the Communist party, hence there are references to “traitors” who betrayed the revolution and shunned rectification. Gacosta’s “Ang mga Kaibigan” / “The Friends” enumerates the desired values of allies and comrades. Makabayan’s “Ina Teresa” / “Mother Teresa,” Magbanua’s “The Legacy” / “Ang Pamana,” and Montañez’s “Pagbubuksan Ka ng Pinto” / “They Will Open Their Doors to You” pay tribute to mass leaders who offer shelter and resources to the guerrillas.

The ravages of nature are metaphors for the enemy’s acts of violence, despite which revolutionary optimism and unfailing hope are expressed in Emil Peña’s “Bagyo”/“Storm,” Firmeza’s Iloko “Dalluyon ti Setiembre” / “Daluyong ng Setyembre” (Tempest of September) and “Pagkatapos ng Unos” / “After the Storm.”

A more complex poem is Lacaba’s “Ulan”/“Rain,” which explores the poetic and the practical functions of rain, as in literature and agriculture. Lacaba, aka the “brown Rimbaud,” shows his sophistication as a petit bourgeois struggling to subdue the interests of his class origin. “Kung Ako’y Mamatay” / “If I Should Die” initially romanticizes and idealizes his imagined burial, with the flags, sickles, hammers, and raised fists of the peasants he served; but he shrugs the idea off, implying that he wouldn’t mind dying traceless and nameless. Middle-class conflict is similarly explored in Gacosta’s “Mga Alaala ng Unang Araw bilang Kadre sa Nayong Tinubuan” / “Memories of My First Day as a Cadre in My Hometown,” Katalino Maylayon’s “Urisip”/“Class-Think,” and Makabayan’s “Banyuhay”/“Metamorphosis.” In Makabayan’s “Sa Amang Naghihinanakit” / “To a Reproachful Father” and Peña’s “Homesick,” cadres must turn their backs on their affluent parents who come from the capitalist and landlord class.

Intimate friends communicate with one another in Makabayan’s “Sabi Nila” / “They Say.” Her “7 Hulyo” / “7 July” celebrates a loved one’s birthday; Montana’s “Celebration” observes the marriage ceremony forged by “proletarian love”; and Lacaba’s “Pagdiriwang”/“Celebration” shows families of different class origins celebrating various occasions, while a member is in the mountains.

Poems with a pedagogical or educational purpose are Gacosta’s “Ang Kabiguan Ay May Pangakong Tagumpay” / “Failure Holds the Promise of Victory” and “Ang Kapalaluan Ay Kaaway ng Tagumpay” / “Arrogance Is the Enemy of Victory,” which offer lessons on success and failure. Maylayon’s “Kani-kaniyang Balon” / “Each to Their Own Water Wells” alludes to Plato’s allegory of the cave, and his “Alam, Ewan at Akala” / “To Know, Not to Know, and to Assume” teaches proper information-gathering and dissemination, the former a lecture on philosophy and the latter, on communication. Offensives are strategized and executed, as recorded in Firmeza’s Ilocano poem “Raut!”/“Reyd!” (Raid!); and Red warriors patrol haciendas, as documented in Magbanua’s “Eastward the Winds of Song” / “Pasilangan ang Ihip ng Kanta.”

This poetry collection serves as a testament to the national democratic movement’s progressive aesthetics as it engages in revolutionary struggle. STR shows that revolutionary cadres know the art of poetry because they know the art of war.  Written by Arbeen Acuña

article.value: (STR: Poems of the People’s War in the Philippines). Published 1989. With an introduction by “Gayanggang” and translations in English and Filipino. Kilusan sa Paglilinang ng Rebolusyonaryong Panitikan at Sining sa Kanayunan or LINANG.

Revolutionary poets, from different sectors and regions, impart their praxis through verses in STR, an acronym for “Sa Tagumpay ng Rebolusyon” (Toward the Triumph of the Revolution). The poems overturn the stereotypical image of grim-and-determined, gun-wielding Communist guerrillas, with themes showing different aspects of armed struggle and of life at the countryside.

A recurring theme is the sense of place and geography, where the persona patrols guerrilla zones, investigates bases, or navigates terrains. The titles of Ruth Firmeza’s “Banig” and “Pitso Manok” might be translated mistakenly as “Reed Mat” and “Chicken Breast,” respectively, but actually refer to a town and a mountain that bore witness to the protracted people’s war. Nature is a comrade as well in Wilfredo Gacosta’s “Bundok Bulusan, Ipaliwanag Mo ang Iyong Kahiwagaan” / “Mt. Bulusan, Unfold Your Mystery,” Lucia Makabayan’s “Sagada” and “Pagkilala sa Gubat” / “Knowing the Forest,” Jason Montana’s “Ifugao Revisited,” Servando Magbanua’s “Tomloy: October 2, 1978,” and Kris Montañez’s “Kalikasan” (Nature).

The elegies do not wallow in drama and defeat: In Firmeza’s “Tandaan Mo” / “Remember,” fallen comrades’ sacrifices inspire Red fighters to carry on with the struggle. Gacosta’s “Agosto 5, Hindi Ka Malilimot” / “August 5, You Will Never Be Forgotten,” Emmanuel Lacaba’s “Sa Alaala ni Nick Solana” / “In Memory of Nick Solana” and Magbanua’s “Poem Written beside a Peasant Comrade’s Grave on the First Anniversary of His Death” vow revolutionary justice against class enemies and treacherous counterrevolutionaries.

Historically, STR is situated after the split within the Communist party, hence there are references to “traitors” who betrayed the revolution and shunned rectification. Gacosta’s “Ang mga Kaibigan” / “The Friends” enumerates the desired values of allies and comrades. Makabayan’s “Ina Teresa” / “Mother Teresa,” Magbanua’s “The Legacy” / “Ang Pamana,” and Montañez’s “Pagbubuksan Ka ng Pinto” / “They Will Open Their Doors to You” pay tribute to mass leaders who offer shelter and resources to the guerrillas.

The ravages of nature are metaphors for the enemy’s acts of violence, despite which revolutionary optimism and unfailing hope are expressed in Emil Peña’s “Bagyo”/“Storm,” Firmeza’s Iloko “Dalluyon ti Setiembre” / “Daluyong ng Setyembre” (Tempest of September) and “Pagkatapos ng Unos” / “After the Storm.”

A more complex poem is Lacaba’s “Ulan”/“Rain,” which explores the poetic and the practical functions of rain, as in literature and agriculture. Lacaba, aka the “brown Rimbaud,” shows his sophistication as a petit bourgeois struggling to subdue the interests of his class origin. “Kung Ako’y Mamatay” / “If I Should Die” initially romanticizes and idealizes his imagined burial, with the flags, sickles, hammers, and raised fists of the peasants he served; but he shrugs the idea off, implying that he wouldn’t mind dying traceless and nameless. Middle-class conflict is similarly explored in Gacosta’s “Mga Alaala ng Unang Araw bilang Kadre sa Nayong Tinubuan” / “Memories of My First Day as a Cadre in My Hometown,” Katalino Maylayon’s “Urisip”/“Class-Think,” and Makabayan’s “Banyuhay”/“Metamorphosis.” In Makabayan’s “Sa Amang Naghihinanakit” / “To a Reproachful Father” and Peña’s “Homesick,” cadres must turn their backs on their affluent parents who come from the capitalist and landlord class.

Intimate friends communicate with one another in Makabayan’s “Sabi Nila” / “They Say.” Her “7 Hulyo” / “7 July” celebrates a loved one’s birthday; Montana’s “Celebration” observes the marriage ceremony forged by “proletarian love”; and Lacaba’s “Pagdiriwang”/“Celebration” shows families of different class origins celebrating various occasions, while a member is in the mountains.

Poems with a pedagogical or educational purpose are Gacosta’s “Ang Kabiguan Ay May Pangakong Tagumpay” / “Failure Holds the Promise of Victory” and “Ang Kapalaluan Ay Kaaway ng Tagumpay” / “Arrogance Is the Enemy of Victory,” which offer lessons on success and failure. Maylayon’s “Kani-kaniyang Balon” / “Each to Their Own Water Wells” alludes to Plato’s allegory of the cave, and his “Alam, Ewan at Akala” / “To Know, Not to Know, and to Assume” teaches proper information-gathering and dissemination, the former a lecture on philosophy and the latter, on communication. Offensives are strategized and executed, as recorded in Firmeza’s Ilocano poem “Raut!”/“Reyd!” (Raid!); and Red warriors patrol haciendas, as documented in Magbanua’s “Eastward the Winds of Song” / “Pasilangan ang Ihip ng Kanta.”

This poetry collection serves as a testament to the national democratic movement’s progressive aesthetics as it engages in revolutionary struggle. STR shows that revolutionary cadres know the art of poetry because they know the art of war.  Written by Arbeen Acuña

Published 1963. Author, Carlos Angeles. With an introduction by Leonard Casper. Manila: Alberto S. Florentino.

This is the first collection of poems that won first prize in the Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature in 1964, the year when the poetry category was first established. It also won for the poet the Republic Cultural Heritage Award in 1964. Some of the poems were previously published in the Evening News Saturday Magazine, Literary Apprentice, and Women’s Weekly Magazine.

In Angeles’s poetry, familiar images are rendered strange so as to convey an emotion or a thought. A favorite line is from “Gabu”: “It is the sea pursues a habit of shores.” This device can produce striking effects, as in “Landscape at Noon”: “ … The sky’s special stone / jewels like pain, the moment’s solitude.” Relying heavily on synaesthesia, Angeles writes about intense passions, such as grief, anxiety, and loneliness suffered by the persona.

In many of his poems, the images used are of a violent nature. In “Landscape II,” for example: “Sun in the knifed horizon bleeds the sky, / Spilling a peacock stain upon the sands, / Across some murdered rocks refuse to die.” Other poems in the collection show similar violent images, such as “Waiting Room,” “Convalescent: Bed No. 2,” “Noon,” “Landscape at Noon,” and “Song.”

There is a tone of sadness and existentialist pessimism in these poems as they present the tension created by the simultaneous presence of polarities in everything: the positive and negative, or the creative and destructive. Dark though the poetic vision may be, this collection of poems dazzles the reader with its brilliant poetic imagery, which resembles, according to Leonard Casper, in his introduction to the book, “the sculpture in seething crystal or gems still pliant with fire.”  Written by David Jonathan Y. Bayot

 

Source

Dimalanta, Ophelia A. 1976. The Philippine Poetic. Manila: Colegio de San Juan de Letran.

text:
SUGBOANONG BALAK / CEBUANO POETRY UNTIL 1940

 

SUGBOANONG BALAK / CEBUANO POETRY 1940-1988

Published 1988. Editors and translators, Erlinda K. Alburo, Vicente Bandillo, Simeon Dumdum Jr, and Resil B. Mojares. With an introduction by Resil B. Mojares, a glossary of terms, and biographical notes on contributors. Cebu: Cebuano Studies Center.

This two-volume anthology of Cebuano poetry ranges from pre-Spanish times to 1988. The editors followed the original spelling of texts as they were written or printed. The first volume begins with samples of folk poems: the harito, tigmo, sanglitanan, garay, saloma, duplo, kulilisi, balitaw, harana, pamalaye, komposo, and birso. The poetry from the 18th century to 1940, generally following regular rhyme-and-meter schemes, consists of religious poems, love poems, patriotic poems, satirical poems, eulogies, philosophical poems, and nature poems. The 18th, 19th, and early 20th centuries are represented by religious poems, like the sonnet to the Blessed Virgin Mary by Tomas de San Geronimo, 1731, and gozos for the Santo Niño, 1888. A secular lyric poem influenced by the medieval European form is Mariano Albao Cuenco’s “Ang Kinabuhi sa Usa ka Bulak” (The Life of a Flower), ca 1905. Some poems of courtly love are Vicente Ranudo’s “Hikalimtan?” (Forget You?), 1906, and “Pag-usara” (Solitude), 1922; Tomas Bagyo’s “Damgo” (Dream), 1907; and Escolastico Morre’s “Sa Daplin sa Usa ka Suba” (On a Riverbank), ca 1910. Patriotic poems are Tomas Bagyo’s “Among Bandila” (Our Flag), 1907; Francisco M. Labrador’s “Alang sa Nangapukan sa Kagabhion” (For Those Who Fell in the Night), ca 1913; and Felipe B. de Leon’s “Ako’y Sundang” (I Am a Bolo), 1935. Two poems that make a social comment are Priscillo Campo’s “Talisay,” 1929; and “Kinabuhing Sugbuanon” (Cebuano Life), 1929. Contemporized adaptations of folk poems are the satirical “Piniliay sa mga Isda” (Election of the Fishes), 1916, by A. Bello; and the lifting “Mga Awit Gikan sa Rosas Pangdan” (Songs from Rosas Pangdan), 1928, by Piux Kabahar. Poems expressing perceptions of woman are Amando Osorio’s “Bitoon sa Akong Yuta” (Star of My Land), 1931, which eulogizes her chastity, beauty, and fragility; and Juan Solon’s “Alang sa mga Inday” (For the Misses), 1928, which cynically describes a woman’s sorry lot if she marries a gambler, womanizer, or wife beater. A poem, however, that asserts the woman-poet’s desire to transcend her human limitations is Gardeopatra Quijano’s “Kon” (If), 1936, as this excerpt shows:

… kon ako mao pa ang hangin,

Oh, hadlaon ko ang mga bulak,

Isabulak ko sa tanang daplin

Ang mga gihay nga mangapulak,

Basin ang kahumot magpabilin,

Sundon ang bahi sa magbabalak.

 

… and if I were the wind,

Oh, I’d tease the flowers,

I’d scatter to all corners

The fallen petals,

So their fragrance would remain

A trail of scent for the poet.

The second volume contains samples that continue the poetic tradition established by the earlier periods; but modernist poems also emerged side by side with traditional forms and began to predominate in the 1970s and 1980s. There are a variety of forms like the sonnet, villanelle, free verse, blank verse, and prose poems. Indirection, emotional restraint, imagism, and more complex metaphors are used in even the earlier love poems, such as Marciano Peñaranda’s “Sa Ikaw Pay Bulak” (When You Were Still a Flower), ca 1940, and Eugenio A. Viacrucis’ “Sa Humot Mong Buhok” (On Your Fragrant Hair), 1954. Subjects covered are sailors and farmers; flora and fauna, such as fireflies, the sampaguita, the narra and the banyan trees; Christ as either the Sacrificial Lamb or the King; poetry and poets; the Filipino Woman (sometimes apostrophized as “Inday”); abstract ideas and human sentiment like life and death, beginning and end, the value of work, anxiety, sorrow, and wild thoughts. But there are poems too about everyday, ordinary things like a key, bowl, or pipe. Some poems wax philosophical over aspects of nature, such as high tide, the breeze, or times of the day like afternoon or evening. There are topics about people that have become part of the Cebuano historic and popular consciousness, like Lapulapu and Yoyoy.

Some poets anthologized in this second volume are Brigido B. Alfar, Elpidio S. Rama, Diosdado G. Alesna, Hilda Montaire, the former president Carlos P. Garcia, Gremer Chan Reyes, Junne Canizares, Ernesto Lariosa, Ricardo I. Patalinjug, Ambrosio Suico, Temistokles Adlawan, Don Pagusara, Robert Pableo Lim, Fe Remotigue, Leo Bob Flores, Melito Baclay, Ester T. Bandillo, and Clovis L. Nazareno.

The significance of this two-volume anthology is that, as an extensive representation of Cebuano poetry, it shows not on Cebuano poetry’s development in theme and form but also its place in the national literary tradition.  Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero

text:
TIKIM KADLUM: SUGIDANON (EPICS) OF PANAY, BOOK 1

Published 2014. Chanters, Federico “Tuohan” Caballero and Teresita “Abyaran” Caballero-Castor. Transcribers and translators, Alicia P. Magos, Anna Razel L. Ramirez, Analina C. Salvador, and Teresita Quezon. With an introduction by Alicia P. Magos and a foreword by Federico “Tuohan” Caballero. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

 

AMBURUKAY: SUGIDANON (EPICS) OF PANAY, BOOK 2

Published 2015. Chanters, Federico “Tuohan” Caballero and Teresita “Abyaran” Caballero-Castor. Transcribers and translators, Alicia P. Magos, Anna Razel L. Ramirez, Analina C. Salvador, and Teresita Quezon. With an introduction by Alicia P. Magos and a foreword by Federico “Tuohan” Caballero. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

The sugidanon are epics of the Panay Bukidnon, aka tumanduk, who are the indigenous inhabitants of the hinterlands of Panay Island. The epics, which are in the language of archaic Karay-a, were recorded by Magos in 1992-94 in the town of Lambunao in the municipality of Calinog, Iloilo. After transcription, these were translated to contemporary Karay-a, Filipino, and English. There is a close resemblance between one episode of Magos’s “Humadapnon” cycle (yet to be published in the Sugidanon Series), and F. Landa Jocano’s Hinilawod: Adventures of Humadapnon (Tarangban I), 2000. In 1992, Magos had recorded “Humadapnon sa Tarangban,” as chanted by Preciosa “Lola Susa” Caballero, who had previously chanted it for F. Landa Jocano. However, Magos later recorded, transcribed, and translated a much longer epic cycle of Humadapnon, consisting of four episodes, and chanted by Lola Susa’s son, Federico Caballero, and this is what she includes in Sugidanon.

On the other hand, a clear distinction between Jocano’s Hinilawod and Magos’s Sugidanon Series is that, in the Hinilawod, the heroes Labaw Donggon, Humadapnon, and Dumalapdap are brothers, whereas in the Sugidanon, Humadapnon is Labaw Donggon’s son-in-law. Taken collectively, the 10 epics in the Sugidanon have characters who are related to each other in different ways but bear identical names, notably Paubari, aka Paiburong, which is the name of Labaw Donggon’s father in one cycle, but also that of Labaw Donggon’s brother in another, and brother-in-law in a third.

Tikum Kadlum begins with the title character, an enchanted dog, leading its master, Datu Paiburong, to a golden bell owned by the monster Makabagting. The angry Makabagting must now be appeased by Datu Paiburong, who offers the lives of his two foster daughters, Matan-ayon and Surangga-on. They are happily received by Amburukay, a muwa (female hermit with supernatural powers) and Makabagting’s sister, who raises the two girls as binukot (kept women) in the forest.

In Amburukay, Buyong Labaw Donggon needs Amburukay’s gold pubic hair to replace the broken string of his heirloom bidya (guitar). He succeeds in obtaining it, unaware that doing so will bind him in marriage to her. Amburukay, however, secretly intends to marry off Matan-ayon and Surangga-on to just such a man.

Forthcoming books of the Sugidanon series are the following:

In “Derikaryong Pada (Book 3),” Sinagnayan wishes to marry Matan-ayon, although Labaw Donggon has already given a derikaryong pada (gold necklace) for her bride-price. Because Labaw Donggon has repeatedly put off marriage, Matan-ayon’s parents and the manighusay (arbiter), named Humadapnon, are willing to marry her off to anyone else who can match Labaw Donggon’s gold necklace for her bride-price.

In “Pahagunong (Book 4),” Padilagang Bulan, Abaw’s apid (second wife) gives Abaw a betel chew that transforms him into a sea turtle. Paubari, Abaw’s brother, dutifully watches over Ayon, as his brother Abaw has instructed. One day, Pahagunon of the upper world comes down on his flying shield to snatch Ayon away, and Paubari loses to him in a long battle.

In “Kalampay (Book 5),” the title character is a crab that transforms itself into an island with betel nut trees to entice Abaw’s wife, Matan-ayon. Its master, Masangladon, then abducts her and takes her to his world beneath the sea. Panday (ironsmith) Katnub Magkaruruan, who is Abaw’s brother-in-law, bores through the giant crab so that Abaw can rescue his wife. Luyong Kabig, the deity of the undersea world, settles the long-drawn battle between Abaw and Masangladon with an arrangement whereby Abaw would return Ayon to Masangladon every seven years.

In “Sinagnayan (Book 6),” Matan-ayon pleads with Labaw Donggon (Abaw) to bring home her sister Pinailog sa Pinggang, who is being held by Sinagnayan. On their way, Abaw must fight with Sarandihon, gatekeeper of the Bangga-an River. Abaw holds his own against Sarandihon’s swarms of bees and flocks of banog (eagle-hawks) but Sarandihon finally kills him with kalayo (fire) and beheads him. Laonsina comes down and reveals that the two are brothers. His life restored by Sarandihon, Abaw proceeds with his quest, which is to take his sister-in-law, Pinailog, from Sinagnayan. Abaw weakens during his long battle with Sinagnayan but Sarandihon comes to his aid killing Sinagnayan’s life force, which is in an egg in the heart of a lion in Minayonmon’s house in the sky. Abaw victoriously sails home but a detour to Madya-as, the place of the afterlife, takes him on another quest.

In “Balanakon (Book 7),” Sarandihon, who resides in the sky world, bars Balanakon from sailing down Bangga-an River, which leads toward Labaw Donggon’s territory. There is a long-drawn battle between them, and Labaw Donggon and Paubari come to Sarandihon’s aid. Balanakon, distracted by the sight of the lovely maiden, Kamaging, is killed. Humadapnon is trying to stop Sarandihon from beheading Balanakon, when Laonsina, goddess of the upper world, intervenes and tells them they are all of the same family tree.

“Humadapnon (Book 8),” is divided into four episodes centering on Humadapnon and Malitong Yawa (Mali). “Tarangban” (Cave) is about Humadapnon’s quest for Malitong Yawa; his imprisonment in a cave by the powerful binukot, Sinagkating Bulawan; and Mali’s reluctant rescue of him. “Pagbalukat ka Biday” is about Humadapnon and Malitong Yawa’s collaboration to recover an heirloom boat that the aswang Paglambuhan has stolen from Mali’s parents. Mali helps Humadapnon to win by distracting Paglambuhan with her beauty. In “Hungaw” (Wedding), Humadapnon is accompanied by Dumalapdap when he asks for Mali’s hand in marriage. Dumalapdap himself is smitten by Mali’s sister, Kinangay, to whom he also proposes marriage. The wedding of Humadapnon and Mali is held. “Ginlawan” begins with Dumalapdap’s courtship of a second woman and shifts to Paglambuhan’s courtship of Malitong Yawa: Dumalapdap is persuaded by his brother Humadapnon to cross the seas to woo Abyang Alon. While he is away, his wife, Kinangay, gives birth. The baby is placed in a basket and floated on the sea toward Dumalapdap. In the absence of the two brothers, Paglambuhan, the aswang, is about to wed Malitong Yawa, when the enraged Humadapnon suddenly appears and kills Mali. Mali’s father, Ginlawodan, appeases him, and Laonsina restores Mali back to life.

“Alayaw (Book 9)” tells the start of Humadapnon’s courtship of Malitong Yawa, daughter of Labaw Donggon and Matan-ayon. He is helped by the alayaw, an enchanted tree, and three messenger birds: Banog, Parupagayong, and Punay.

In “Nagbuhis (Book 10),” Ayon, Abaw’s wife, now an aged woman, is mother of Malitong Yawa. Her frailty compels her to hold a buruhisan ritual, in which she must communicate with her long neglected ancestral spirits. On this occasion, she will also transfer to her daughter Malitong Yawa, aka Mali, the supernatural powers that she inherited from her own mother, the goddess Laonsina. However, Humadapnon, Mali’s husband, forbids her from going because, as Mali will later discover, he has been courting several binukot at the place where the buruhisan ritual is to be held. Mali transforms into a magic pillow and flirts with several men while, at the same time, her grandmother Laonsina takes her up to the sky at her request.

In 2000, chanter Federico “Tuohan” Caballero received the Gawad Manlilikha ng Bayan (GAMABA) award.  Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero
