AMBURUKAY: SUGIDANON (EPICS) OF PANAY, BOOK 2

Published 2015. Chanters, Federico “Tuohan” Caballero and Teresita “Abyaran” Caballero-Castor. Transcribers and translators, Alicia P. Magos, Anna Razel L. Ramirez, Analina C. Salvador, and Teresita Quezon. With an introduction by Alicia P. Magos and a foreword by Federico “Tuohan” Caballero. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

The sugidanon are epics of the Panay Bukidnon, aka tumanduk, who are the indigenous inhabitants of the hinterlands of Panay Island. The epics, which are in the language of archaic Karay-a, were recorded by Magos in 1992-94 in the town of Lambunao in the municipality of Calinog, Iloilo. After transcription, these were translated to contemporary Karay-a, Filipino, and English. There is a close resemblance between one episode of Magos’s “Humadapnon” cycle (yet to be published in the Sugidanon Series), and F. Landa Jocano’s Hinilawod: Adventures of Humadapnon (Tarangban I), 2000. In 1992, Magos had recorded “Humadapnon sa Tarangban,” as chanted by Preciosa “Lola Susa” Caballero, who had previously chanted it for F. Landa Jocano. However, Magos later recorded, transcribed, and translated a much longer epic cycle of Humadapnon, consisting of four episodes, and chanted by Lola Susa’s son, Federico Caballero, and this is what she includes in Sugidanon.

On the other hand, a clear distinction between Jocano’s Hinilawod and Magos’s Sugidanon Series is that, in the Hinilawod, the heroes Labaw Donggon, Humadapnon, and Dumalapdap are brothers, whereas in the Sugidanon, Humadapnon is Labaw Donggon’s son-in-law. Taken collectively, the 10 epics in the Sugidanon have characters who are related to each other in different ways but bear identical names, notably Paubari, aka Paiburong, which is the name of Labaw Donggon’s father in one cycle, but also that of Labaw Donggon’s brother in another, and brother-in-law in a third.

Tikum Kadlum begins with the title character, an enchanted dog, leading its master, Datu Paiburong, to a golden bell owned by the monster Makabagting. The angry Makabagting must now be appeased by Datu Paiburong, who offers the lives of his two foster daughters, Matan-ayon and Surangga-on. They are happily received by Amburukay, a muwa (female hermit with supernatural powers) and Makabagting’s sister, who raises the two girls as binukot (kept women) in the forest.

In Amburukay, Buyong Labaw Donggon needs Amburukay’s gold pubic hair to replace the broken string of his heirloom bidya (guitar). He succeeds in obtaining it, unaware that doing so will bind him in marriage to her. Amburukay, however, secretly intends to marry off Matan-ayon and Surangga-on to just such a man.
Forthcoming books of the Sugidanon series are the following:

In “Derikaryong Pada (Book 3),” Sinagnayan wishes to marry Matan-ayon, although Labaw Donggon has already given a derikaryong pada (gold necklace) for her bride-price. Because Labaw Donggon has repeatedly put off marriage, Matan-ayon’s parents and the manighusay (arbiter), named Humadapnon, are willing to marry her off to anyone else who can match Labaw Donggon’s gold necklace for her bride-price.

In “Pahagunong (Book 4),” Padilagang Bulan, Abaw’s apid (second wife) gives Abaw a betel chew that transforms him into a sea turtle. Paubari, Abaw’s brother, dutifully watches over Ayon, as his brother Abaw has instructed. One day, Pahagunon of the upper world comes down on his flying shield to snatch Ayon away, and Paubari loses to him in a long battle.

In “Kalampay (Book 5),” the title character is a crab that transforms itself into an island with betel nut trees to entice Abaw’s wife, Matan-ayon. Its master, Masangladon, then abducts her and takes her to his world beneath the sea. Panday (ironsmith) Katnub Magkaruruan, who is Abaw’s brother-in-law, bores through the giant crab so that Abaw can rescue his wife. Luyong Kabig, the deity of the undersea world, settles the long-drawn battle between Abaw and Masangladon with an arrangement whereby Abaw would return Ayon to Masangladon every seven years.

In “Sinagnayan (Book 6),” Matan-ayon pleads with Labaw Donggon (Abaw) to bring home her sister Pinailog sa Pinggang, who is being held by Sinagnayan. On their way, Abaw must fight with Sarandihon, gatekeeper of the Bangga-an River. Abaw holds his own against Sarandihon’s swarms of bees and flocks of banog (eagle-hawks) but Sarandihon finally kills him with kalayo (fire) and beheads him. Laonsina comes down and reveals that the two are brothers. His life restored by Sarandihon, Abaw proceeds with his quest, which is to take his sister-in-law, Pinailog, from Sinagnayan. Abaw weakens during his long battle with Sinagnayan but Sarandihon comes to his aid killing Sinagnayan’s life force, which is in an egg in the heart of a lion in Minayonmon’s house in the sky. Abaw victoriously sails home but a detour to Madya-as, the place of the afterlife, takes him on another quest.

In “Balanakon (Book 7),” Sarandihon, who resides in the sky world, bars Balanakon from sailing down Bangga-an River, which leads toward Labaw Donggon’s territory. There is a long-drawn battle between them, and Labaw Donggon and Paubari come to Sarandihon’s aid. Balanakon, distracted by the sight of the lovely maiden, Kamaging, is killed. Humadapnon is trying to stop Sarandihon from beheading Balanakon, when Laonsina, goddess of the upper world, intervenes and tells them they are all of the same family tree.

“Humadapnon (Book 8),” is divided into four episodes centering on Humadapnon and Malitong Yawa (Mali). “Tarangban” (Cave) is about Humadapnon’s quest for Malitong Yawa; his imprisonment in a cave by the powerful binukot, Sinagkating Bulawan; and Mali’s reluctant rescue of him. “Pagbalukat ka Biday” is about Humadapnon and Malitong Yawa’s collaboration to recover an heirloom boat that the aswang Paglambuhan has stolen from Mali’s parents. Mali helps Humadapnon to win by distracting Paglambuhan with her beauty. In “Hungaw” (Wedding), Humadapnon is accompanied by Dumalapdap when he asks for Mali’s hand in marriage. Dumalapdap himself is smitten by Mali’s sister, Kinangay, to whom he also proposes marriage. The wedding of Humadapnon and Mali is held. “Ginlawan” begins with Dumalapdap’s courtship of a second woman and shifts to Paglambuhan’s courtship of Malitong Yawa: Dumalapdap is persuaded by his brother Humadapnon to cross the seas to woo Abyang Alon. While he is away, his wife, Kinangay, gives birth. The baby is placed in a basket and floated on the sea toward Dumalapdap. In the absence of the two brothers, Paglambuhan, the aswang, is about to wed Malitong Yawa, when the enraged Humadapnon suddenly appears and kills Mali. Mali’s father, Ginlawodan, appeases him, and Laonsina restores Mali back to life.

“Alayaw (Book 9)” tells the start of Humadapnon’s courtship of Malitong Yawa, daughter of Labaw Donggon and Matan-ayon. He is helped by the alayaw, an enchanted tree, and three messenger birds: Banog, Parupagayong, and Punay.

In “Nagbuhis (Book 10),” Ayon, Abaw’s wife, now an aged woman, is mother of Malitong Yawa. Her frailty compels her to hold a buruhisan ritual, in which she must communicate with her long neglected ancestral spirits. On this occasion, she will also transfer to her daughter Malitong Yawa, aka Mali, the supernatural powers that she inherited from her own mother, the goddess Laonsina. However, Humadapnon, Mali’s husband, forbids her from going because, as Mali will later discover, he has been courting several binukot at the place where the buruhisan ritual is to be held. Mali transforms into a magic pillow and flirts with several men while, at the same time, her grandmother Laonsina takes her up to the sky at her request.
In 2000, chanter Federico “Tuohan” Caballero received the Gawad Manlilikha ng Bayan (GAMABA) award.  Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero

(Writer). Published 2010. Author, Jaime Jesus U. Borlagdan. Tabaco: Suralista Press.

Sural is the legendary inventor of the Bikol syllabary engraved on marble, and a Suralista is one who follows in Sural’s footsteps, a writer. Suralista is Jaime Jesus Borlagdan’s second book of poems written in the Tabaco variant of Albay Bikol. It is composed of 120 poems divided into four sections, “Ini an mga Buhay Ta” (Our Lives), “Kanta kan Dai Natutunong na Uran” (Song of the Ceaseless Rain), “Hiling Palaog” (Looking In), and “Turog Na an Gabos” (All Are Asleep).

Borlagdan’s poems take the readers back to the time of myths, as in “An Panga” (Jaws), told from the viewpoint of the monster boar killed by Baltog, the first legendary king of Bikol.It is a universe both massive and mysterious, where dogs pray and bay, and where the halas, the Great Serpent, is caressed by the stars. Nevertheless, his language anchors these images to a local and recognizable geography.

The struggle for one to be understood given the different languages in the region is gleaned in “Bikolana” (Bikol Maiden), in which the persona meets a fellow Bikol woman whose language he cannot understand, and “An Estranghero” (The Stranger), in which the title character is welcomed for the word he brings.

There is a rush of metaphors in “Muya Ko Pa an Lawas na Ini?” (Do I Still Want This Body?), where the persona compares the body to a house, vehicle, and clothes. In “Kun Nata Ako Nagbabaklay” (Why I’d Rather Walk), distance is likened to a snake.

History and myth interweave to define the cultural identity of Borlagdan’s community. In “An Istorya Ninda, An Osipon Ta” (Their Story, Our Tale), the poet uses images of “hadi” (king), “krus” (cross), and “espada” (sword) to assert his community’s sovereignty, which, however, he also describes as being permanently wounded by an embedded sword (“may nakatadok na espada”). Thus istorya in the title may also mean “history” and osipon, “myth.”  Written by Tito G. Valiente

(Inscribed in Stone). Published 1991. Author, Teo T. Antonio. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press. Expanded edition, Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press, 1994. Manila Critics Circle’s National Book Award for poetry, 1992.

This collection of 133 poems, written between 1973 and 1988, is a testament to Antonio’s roots, aesthetics, and convictions as a poet. Divided into eight sections, it traces his evolution from his birth as a son of the balagtasan (poetic joust) luminary Emilio Mar Antonio to his development and maturity as a poet who engages with political realities.

Antonio was co-founder of Galian sa Arte at Tula, a literary organization of young writers established a year after the declaration of martial law. Thus, the poems in this collection are representative of the group’s poetics of protest literature.

The book’s preface consists of two poems under the section title, “Habilin at Handog” (Plea and Offering), in which father and son address each other. The first poem, “Supling” (Offspring), published in Liwayway on 22 Nov 1948, was written by the elder Antonio for his son Teo’s second birthday. The second poem, “Pagdalaw sa Nayon Ko” (A Visit to My Hometown), is Teo’s response, acknowledging his own poetry as an extension of his poet-father’s voice (“karugtong na tinig ng amang makata”), and offering his book in fulfillment of his father’s wishes for him to grow up and desire great things for his native land (“Nawa’y lumaki kang bawat gintong nasa / maukol sa iyong tinubuang lupa”).

This recollection provides the cue for the persona’s return to his hometown in Bulacan. Using countryside imagery in the first section, Antonio points out the various contradictions that beset the land. In “Bahay-Kubo” (Nipa Hut), the traditional folk song is infused with sharp wit and humor to satirize how colonizers have plundered the country. In “Anting-Anting” (Talisman), a call is made for a collective search for an amulet to fight “supernatural elements” armed with guns and cannons. In “Hukbong Uhay” (Army of Rice Sheaves), the persona criticizes the unjust relationship between those who own the land and those who till it.

The book’s third section is Antonio’s reaffirmation of poetry’s polemical function. This section’s titular poem, “Sa Harap ng Makinilya” (In Front of the Typewriter), emphasizes the typewriter’s ability to break the silent moments (“nagwawasak ng tahimik na sandali”) and to give form to words that probe and analyze (“salitang nang-uusig, salitang nagsusuri”).

The fifth and sixth sections give sketches of different characters who bear the brunt of social injustice. In “Palakol at Araro” (Axe and Plow), the peasant is urged to will his farming implements to rise against his oppressive condition. In “Tsuper at Makinista” (Driver and Train Operator), the objectivity of a news report and the emotionalism of a poetic apostrophe are interwoven to convey the horror of a collision of bus and train that is caused by government negligence. In “Hindi Mapupuksa ang Laksang Rolando” (A Thousand Rolando Cannot Perish), the murder of Rolando Olalia, a union leader, becomes the symbol of revolt for the oppressed masses.

With his dexterous handling of imagery and use of casual, colloquial speech, the poet exhibits a modernist sensibility that is at home with free verse and with traditional Tagalog forms like the tanaga, dalit, and balagtasan. This synthesis of styles, aesthetics, and material reveals Antonio’s entire repertoire as a poet.

The book’s achievement lies in its illustration of the interconnection and dialectics between the past and the present, countryside and city, self and society, and individuality and social commitment. Thus, the book comes full circle, from the initial challenge posed by the poet’s father to Antonio’s response, both of which are now inscribed in stone.  Written by Om Narayan Velasco

Published 2010. Author, Merlie M. Alunan. Manila: University of Santo Tomas Publishing House. Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature, first prize, poetry in English, 2010.

This collection of 38 poems is divided into six thematic sections—namely, “Empty-handed and Free,” “To Find, to Heal, to Mend,” “What the Heart Desires,” “The Faith of Weeping Clowns,” “The Wanderer’s Gift,” and “The Sun at Our Heels.” The poems are book-ended by two almost-identical poems affirming a personal anthem of life: “Chasing the Rain” and “Chasing the Rain, the Sun at Our Heels.”

The first section magnifies the poet’s reflections on habits and habitations in her country, Singapore, Japan, and the United States. In all these places, Alunan contemplates the order of things in a universe seasoned with flowers (“Higanbana”), animals (“Hedgebrook” and “Cat Patrol”), ghosts and elementals (“Recalling Phoenix Blossom in Jurong East”), and natural scenery.

The second section presents widows, lovers, and other female subjects, who struggle against their milieu or their own self-doubts. The personae of “My Prince in Gold and Vermillion,” “Love Poem,” and “Beyond Light” confront loss in different ways. In the title poem, “Tales of the Spider Woman,” a woman shows the heart’s openness to tenderness and forgiveness, despite the relentless rumors that her town has wrapped around her being.

In the third section, Alunan contemplates the mundane, such as acupuncture (“To Teach a Heart”) and gardening (“The Secret of Plants”), or the existential, such as death (“When I Go”) and suicide (“Suicide in Suite B”).

In the fourth section, Alunan bares her radical edge when she writes about politics and dovetails this with the personal, like in the poem “Ampatuan, Maguindanao, November 23, 2009.” The persona looks relentlessly at the Maguindanao political rivalry that resulted in the massacre of 58 people, 34 of them journalists. The last stanza is in the ancient form of the curse, the shamanic voice hexing in verse the yet unpunished but forever unforgiven perpetrators of the crime. In another poem, “Banquet of Bones, circa 2004-2010 A.D.,” Alunan’s dedicatory subtitle reads: “To my poet friends in this era of despair.” It offers no reprieve from the disasters and privations, whether natural and human-made, except the recalcitrant refrains of poetry.

The poems in the final section depict lives steeped in literature and art: a photographer is commemorated in “Town Photographer”; a dancer is praised in “Dancer”; and poets are remembered in “The Poet’s Notebook,” “The Perfect Line of Poetry,” and “When a Poet Dies.” In all these works, Alunan offers her disciplined poetic medium to celebrate the power of language as well as the humanity that it enriches and is enriched by.

Ultimately, this book emerges from a rich Philippine soil that is the site of realities that may enlighten one’s senses to the promise of a country ravished “by men whose hands / tear at our flesh a hundred thousand ways.” Although the pieces here are largely inflected with a palpable regional register, they do not alienate nor jar even the most urbanized reader, as Alunan shows an astute mastery of the feelings, insights, and undertakings that make up our shared conditions and circumstances.  Written by Oscar T. Serquiña Jr and Marjorie Evasco

text:
Published 1972. Author, Federico Licsi Espino. Manila: By the author.

This collection of poetry consists of an English section, “Tropical Terrain,” which has eight poems; and a Filipino section, “East and West,” which has four poems and five translations.

The first section has the title poem, “Tinikling,” striking the note for the whole collection of the “essential grace” without which “survival / Is impossible.” The next poems “Elias to Ibarra” and “Simoun to Ibarra” express the counterpointing violence:

… pray give [the friar]

Instant martyrdom with the bolo’s shrift

of native steel.

Yea, baptize him with his gore

in the name

Of justice and equality.

 

“Simoun to Ibarra” is a call for revolution:

 

Think of Elias burning under the Christmas Moon:

The flames licking at his thighs,

The heat roasting his thews,

But do not think that he is dead for he is not.

He is Cabesang Tales uprising.

Set in times more contemporary, “Philippine Scenes” takes off from the postcard visions. In Lubugan, Mountain Province, the head-hunting warrior has lost his power, but we are forewarned that “the monsoons breed / Typhoons to lash at chapels of a lowland creed.” Pasay’s Sodom brings to mind, sadly, the time when “her natives thrived on honest barter.” Manila, the ever loyal colonial city of the Spanish, is now a “city where America has spun / her influence like spiderwebs of wire / Or vessels hypertensive with disease.” The final poem in the section, the trilogy “Guest Speakers,” speaks to us in the voices of historian, psychologist, and philosopher.

All end on a despairing note, reaching a crescendo with the philosopher: “I give you, / Like a leprous hand, Being and Nothingness.”

The poems in Filipino address C. M. Vega, Sylvia Plath, W. H. Auden, and Jean Genet. Old age avenging and avenged; suicide’s final understanding; the task eternal of naming the nameless that is poetry; phallic pride and phallic love—Espino focuses his poetry on these. The poets selected for translation are T. S. Eliot, Wallace Stevens, Salvatore Quasimodo, Dylan Thomas, and Miroslav Holub.  Written by Victoria S. Calizo

Set in times more contemporary, “Philippine Scenes” takes off from the postcard visions. article_title: Tinipigan: An Anthology of Waray Literature
text:
(Hidden Treasure: An Anthology of Waray Literature). Published 1995. Editor, Victor N. Sugbo. Manila: National Commission for Culture and the Arts.

The title refers to the fact that the materials collected for this anthology, gathered from museums, libraries, and private collections, are fragile survivors of storms, termites, and general neglect.

The anthology consists of 67 poems by 37 poets, mostly written between 1920 and 1960, and a few written between the 1960s and the 1990s. The earliest poem, dated 1920, is “An Pagpalabi sa Isigkatawo, Kaaway san Pagpaubos” (Outdoing Others Is the Enemy of Humility) by Andikula. In this poem, a husband castigates his wife for her expensive and inappropriate obsession with fashion. Corocod Codcod’s “Mga Pangandoy” (Yearnings), 1922, written in the dodecasyllabic and rhyming quatrain preferred in that period, is about a love-stricken man whose suffering is either eased by a woman’s kindness or made worse by her indifference.

The same poets discovered by Maria Luz Vilches, Gemina Q. Aurillo, and Adelaida L. Filamor in Gregorio Luangco’s anthology Kandabao, 1982, dominate Tinipigan: Casiano Trinchera, Filomeno Singzon, Iluminado Lucente, Eduardo Makabenta, Francisco Alvarado, Vicente I. de Veyra, Tomas Gomez, and Agustin El O’Mora, among others.

Trinchera writes with vigor and stinging sarcasm on an elopement and a civil wedding in “Ginkasal hin Casamiento” (Civil Wedding), unrequited love in “Malingoon nga Gugma” (Treacherous Love), and racial conflict between Chinese and Filipinos in “Iña Wasay” (This Wasay). Lucente picks up the same theme in “Baga Durogas Ngan Baga Tinuod” (Like a Joke That Seems True), where he asserts that the people’s taste for pig slop and their desire to make millionaires of the Chinese in Tacloban account for the persistence of unsanitary restaurants in Tacloban. Lucente’s lyricism is exemplified by the dialogue poem “Hangin Gad La” (It’s Just the Wind), a poem about awakening. Makabenta’s “Despedida kan Kirikay” (Despidida for Kirikay) has a husband telling his wife that she must leave behind fire, water, food, which are his, if she wants to leave him.

Nine of the poems, dated 1975-78, are by anonymous revolutionary poets whose works were collated from the files of Ka Eric Abella and Sergio Amoyo, both of the New People’s Army (NPA). Among these are “Hi Kami an Bahuba” (We Are the Bahuba), “Rebulosyon an Guliat Han Katawhan Yana” (Now the People Shout Revolution), and “Kami Paraguma nga Tinalumpigos” (We Are the Lowly and Oppressed Farmfolk). These poems deal with themes of social injustice and uphold the revolutionary agenda of the NPA.

Sugbo’s choices implicitly define the aesthetic principles of the siday: metrical regularity, well-turned rhymes, wit, and lyricism. The works of these poets may serve as benchmarks of poetic refinement. The book also shows the durability of tradition. It affects the works of later poets such as Vicente Soria de Veyra’s “Testigo” (Witness), 1990; Oskar Muncada Monje’s “Si Mana Corpadia” (Mana Corpadia), 1990; and Maximo Servidad’s “Naghihigugma” (In Love), 1993. They also show the range of themes in Waray poetry.

Sugbo might well be the first literary scholar to articulate the abundance of “ethnographic memoranda” (his own words) in Waray poetry and to set out to discover gems from the pile. The selections in Tinipigan give us a more solid grasp of the Waray poetic sensibility and aesthetic sense.  Written by Merlie M. Alunan

text:
(The Kingdom of Keboklagan). Published 1980. Transcriber, Gaudiosa Martinez Ochotorena, “Ag Tobig nog Keboklagan,” Kinaadman 3:343-543.

This is perhaps one of the oldest guman or epics of the Subanon of Zamboanga in Mindanao. Its contents suggest that it has not been touched by either Christian nor Muslim influences. As with other guman, Ag Tobig nog Keboklagan is chanted during buklog or festivals.

This epic contains many of the same magical elements found in another Subanon epic, Keg Sumba neg Sandayo (The Tale of Sandayo). However, unlike Sandayo, which focuses on the establishment and maintenance of ties, Ag Tobig nog Keboklagan centers on the relationship between the Subanon and the other communities in Mindanao.

Doctor Gaudiosa Ochotorena, a retired administrator of the Western Mindanao State University in Zamboanga City, discovered the epic while she was attending a buklog in Sindangan, Zamboanga del Sur. Ochotorena’s principal source for this guman was an elderly village chanter named Liyos Ambog, born in Barrio Lipakan, Salug, Zamboanga del Norte. She began to chant the epic at early evening, continued into the night, and ended past midnight, pausing for an occasional drink of pangasi rice wine.

Liyos Ambog claimed that she had learned the guman from her mother Anaya. Anaya, in turn, had learned it from her mother, Sapar, who was only six when she learned the song. According to Liyos Ambog, the epic can be sung to another melody and with the accompaniment of Subanon musical instruments.

The guman begins with Timoway’s quandary as to how to support his wife who is about to give birth. He decides to earn money by being a whetter of tools in the neighboring villages. He leaves Sirangan with his assistant Kasangolan and 15 datus. However, their boat refuses to move until Timoway beheads one of his companions.

In the village Batotobig, Datu Sakanbar decides to join Timoway, although his wife, like Timoway’s, is pregnant. While they are cruising, Diwata Pegderaman—the goddess of wind, lightning, and thunder—invites them to her abode to chew mamaq or betel nut. Rejected by the datus, she creates a storm that breaks Timoway’s vessel and kills Timoway and his companions. The broken and now empty vessel returns to Sirangan. Learning about the incident, Timoway’s wife, Balo Libon, cries so intensely that she gives birth to a boy. At this same instance, Sakadanbar’s wife in Batotoy also gives birth to a boy. Balo Libon names her son Taake. He grows quickly, and after seven months, Taake asks about his father. When he is told that his father’s death was not caused by a mortal, he is happy. Learning that his father was a fisher, Taake asks for his father’s hook and line. With the aid of his magic, he establishes himself as an excellent fisher.

One day, Taake, now a young man, asks his mother for clothes to go deep-sea fishing. The request surprises her, for Taake has never asked for clothes. Questioned, he explains that he is embarrassed to be naked in the company of ladies. Balo Libon then grooms her son.

At sea, Taake hooks a fish with golden scales, but it drags him farther and farther away from the shore. The tug-of-war lasts for months, until an eel warns Taake to go home and offers him help to get there. But Taake only kills the eel. A storm develops, and Taake sinks. He sees a shore under the sea and sets foot on it. Finding a horse with his hook-and-line in its mouth, he pursues it with his karisan or sword, but the animal escapes him. Taake has reached Keboklagan.

Taake sees a tower. He climbs a ladder with golden rungs to reach the top of the tower. There, he finds a woman, nearly naked, sewing. Called the Lady of Pintawan, she invites him to chew mamaq. As they chew, their eyes meet and exchange messages of love. Taake courts her for seven days. Finally, the Lady of Pintawan accepts Taake’s offer of marriage. However, the romance is blocked by two men, Towan Salip and Sorotan Domatong, who abhor the idea of the Lady of Pintawan’s marrying a Subanon. The two rally the folks of Keboklagan and urge them to kill Taake. The Lady of Pintoqan, a close friend of the Lady of Pintawan, learns about the plot and flies on her monsala or scarf to the Lady of Pintawan’s place. She advises Taake to take his wife to Sirangan. Taake, however, insists on his innocence and refuses to leave Keboklagan. He fights the people who attack him.

In Sirangan, the datu Tomitib Manaon dreams of a lone Subanon fighting in Keboklagan. When he awakes, he prepares to help Taake, whom he discovers has been away from Sirangan for a long time. Accompanied by two other datus, he proceeds to Keboklagan. Although they lose their way at first, they finally arrive at Keboklagan, following Taake’s route. Tomitib impetuously rushes into battle, killing Sorotan Domatong. Taake reproaches Tomitib for fighting without first asking for the reason for the fight. Saulagya Maola, the datu of Keboklagan and the Lady of Pintawan’s brother, arrives. The ladies of Keboklagan explain to him the cause of the fight. He recalls his promise to his sister that anyone or anything that can climb the ladder with rungs of blades shall be his sister’s husband. Saulagya Maola tells the two datus about the promise, but they insist on fighting. Saulagya, therefore, divides his kingdom between those who decide to fight and those who decide to withdraw from the battle.

Tomitib Manaon asks Saulagya Maola if he can marry the Lady of Pintoqan. But because of his incivility, she rejects Tomitib. Tomitib runs back to the crowd and starts fighting. Datu Liyo-liyo, hearing about the fight, rides his horse and proceeds to the battleground. Datu Liyo-liyo engages Tomitib in a hand-to-hand battle. Eventually, the datu of Sirangan defeats the datu of Keboklagan.

The two datus then proceed to other kingdoms to fight further. First, they challenge the chief of Dibaloy, Datu Bataqelo. Lilang Diwata, his sister, renames Taake Malompyag, or “he who fights in all places.” Taake and Tomitib would have exterminated the whole kingdom had not compassion overtaken them after half of the population had fallen to their sword. In Todongtodong, Taake and Tomitib are invited by its chief to chew mamaq before they start fighting. After the chew, they annihilate the kingdom. The datus then proceed to Walo Sabang, ruled by Egdodan Magsorat and Egdodan Sabagan, who themselves do not fight. Their subjects, however, are sufficient, for they get resurrected after having been killed. Taake tires after seven months of fighting and falls asleep, leaving Tomitib to fight alone. In Taake’s dream, a girl instructs him to disguise himself as Towan Salip Palasti and to go to the tower of Walo Sabang to get magical medicines by which to prevent the enemies from coming back to life. When he awakes, he does as instructed, and he and Tomitib defeat the army of Walo Sabang. At one point in the battle, Tomitib falls dead, but the women of Keboklagan restore him to life.

The massive destruction disturbs the god Asog. He descends to the earth and reprimands the Sirangan. He instructs them to go home and hold a buklog, in which each of them will be given his partner. Asog fans his kerchief, bringing the dead to life. The two datus return to Sirangan, where Taake finds his mother dying of longing for him. He kisses her and she revives. All the datus of the different kingdoms are invited to a buklog, and Asog gives each of them a partner in life.  Written by Servando Halili Jr

 

Source

Ochotorena, Gaudiosa Martinez. 1981. “Ag Tobig nog Keboklagan.” Kinaadman 3:343-543.

text:
(Healing Ritual). Published 2011. Author, Juan Rafael Belgica Jr. Legazpi: Lagdaan ni Sural.

The title of Juan Rafael Belgica Jr’s third book of rawitdawit (Bikol poetry) refers to a Bikol healing ritual. It is a collection of 43 poems in Albay Bikol language. Like his other works of poetry, Toob resounds with biblical allusions, the story of Job in particular.

The collection is divided into eight chapters, and echo of the sequence of the biblical story and also an homage to it. Belgica states that he chose to write about the book of Job not just because it is one of the most poetic works in the Bible but more importantly because it opens up discourses on the Bikol bo-ot or self, which the Bikol value highly. Belgica attempts to interrelate this indigenous reverence for bo-ot as a definition of man, with the character of Job as takeoff point, and how he behaves before, during, and after a difficulty. The poems manifest the various facets of the self: humility, faith, gratitude, acceptance, as well as hatred, anxiety, grievance, and rebellion.

In the poems where God and Job converse, Belgica uses the sonnet form. Other forms, such as the terza rima, are used when Job relates with other characters.

In Toob, Belgica exhibits an expert grasp of traditional form, a sense for the fresh and significant, and a masterly command of the language. Belgica’s diction is scholarly, and a majority of the words he uses are not found in modern speech. However, his extensive knowledge of Bikol makes for rhymes that are unforced and a rhythmic confidence. The book will be an important repository of Bikol terms that exist only in written form.

Toob to the Bikol is a sacrificial healing ritual to God through the use of smoke and fragrance of burnt chicken feathers and herbs. In these poems of unparalleled grace and beauty, Belgica, it may be said, has himself performed a toob, a ritual of praise to Makakamhan (God).   Written by Jaime Jesus U. Borlagdan

article_title: The Tracks of Babylon and Other Poems
text:
Published 1966. Author, Edith L. Tiempo. Denver, Colorado: Allan Swallow Press; reprinted, Quezon City: Giraffe Books, 1988. The poems won first prize at the Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature in 1967.

The publication of Tiempo’s first collection of poetry in the United States is a watershed in Philippine literary history. It extended the readership of modern Philippine literature. The publication also coincided with the Tiempos’ trip abroad to pursue doctoral degrees in literature and creative writing at the University of Denver.

The title poem looks at an old man. His once strong hands embodied bold command over nature, yet they quiver now as he takes a pen to set down his thoughts. The act of writing is tough like the arduous quest for Babylon—literature’s burden similar to the pained search for the lost steps. In pronounced ways, the poem is Tiempo’s ars poetica.

In “The Return,” which is included in many literature textbooks, Tiempo pictures old age as a world conflicted between intense desire and subdued action. An old man longs to recall his youthful exploits but stops in embarrassment, realizing his present condition.

“Mid-Morning for Sheba” draws on both allusion and allegory. Up a slope, a watchful persona witnesses something strange—a girl and a stamping bull. The event alters her perception. The poem stresses the need for a vantage point, a distant perch where one could gauge the course of life with heightened awareness. Ironically, the point of knowing also happens to be a lonely perch.

“Lament for the Littlest Fellow,” which was singled out in the citation for Tiempo’s National Artist award, marries the sonnet’s strict form with existential insight. The piece evokes the tyranny of memory. A wakeful couple remember the infant child they lost. Loss looms over them as the “living cage,” from which humanity, like the caged marmoset that amused the couple at the zoo, struggles in vain to escape.

In “St. Anthony’s Feat,” the poet explores a theological point, the mysterious certainty of faith. A cripple searching for something calls on St. Anthony, the patron of lost things. The object is found. The speaker believes that the saint himself walked to help her, her conviction strengthened by the very fact that she cannot walk.

The 24 poems constitute a formidable collection that introduces readers to Tiempo’s exemplary skills in image and irony, through which she leads readers to insights. Characteristic of the poems is their having a mindful and complex persona; the speaking voice that Tiempo creates evolves into an engaging portrait of sensibility and character.

Her many influences include W. H. Auden, T. S. Eliot, Robert Frost, and William Butler Yeats. The publication of Tiempo’s first collection of poetry in the United States is a watershed in Philippine literary history. It extended the readership of modern Philippine literature. The publication also coincided with the Tiempos’ trip abroad to pursue doctoral degrees in literature and creative writing at the University of Denver.

The title poem looks at an old man. His once strong hands embodied bold command over nature, yet they quiver now as he takes a pen to set down his thoughts. The act of writing is tough like the arduous quest for Babylon—literature’s burden similar to the pained search for the lost steps. In pronounced ways, the poem is Tiempo’s ars poetica.

In “The Return,” which is included in many literature textbooks, Tiempo pictures old age as a world conflicted between intense desire and subdued action. An old man longs to recall his youthful exploits but stops in embarrassment, realizing his present condition.

“Mid-Morning for Sheba” draws on both allusion and allegory. Up a slope, a watchful persona witnesses something strange—a girl and a stamping bull. The event alters her perception. The poem stresses the need for a vantage point, a distant perch where one could gauge the course of life with heightened awareness. Ironically, the point of knowing also happens to be a lonely perch.

“Lament for the Littlest Fellow,” which was singled out in the citation for Tiempo’s National Artist award, marries the sonnet’s strict form with existential insight. The piece evokes the tyranny of memory. A wakeful couple remember the infant child they lost. Loss looms over them as the “living cage,” from which humanity, like the caged marmoset that amused the couple at the zoo, struggles in vain to escape.

In “St. Anthony’s Feat,” the poet explores a theological point, the mysterious certainty of faith. A cripple searching for something calls on St. Anthony, the patron of lost things. The object is found. The speaker believes that the saint himself walked to help her, her conviction strengthened by the very fact that she cannot walk.

Published 2001. Author, Cirilo F. Bautista. Manila: De La Salle University Press.

The book collects The Archipelago, 1970; Telex Moon, 1974; and Sunlight on Broken Stones, 1999. The Archipelago was awarded the first prize, Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature. Telex Moon was awarded the first prize, Palanca Awards; and the Manila Critics Circle’s National Book Award. Sunlight on Broken Stones was awarded the first prize, Centennial Literary Prize, 1998; the Manila Critics Circle’s National Book Award; and the Book Development Association of the Philippines’ Gintong Aklat Award.

This literary achievement, comprising three poetry collections written in a span of 30 years and totalling 9,872 lines, is the longest Filipino poem written in English. Originally published as independent poetry projects,it is made available as a singular poetic vision, an attempt to map out a Filipino cultural heritage from pre-Hispanic years to the EDSA Revolt of 1986.

The Saint Lazarus in the title refers to the Archipelago of Saint Lazarus, which is how the Philippines was referred to in Antonio de Morga’s Sucesos de las Islas Filipinos (Events in the Philippine Islands), 1609. The Archipelago covers the colonization of the Philippine islands and reaches the life of Jose Rizal. Telex Moon focuses more on Rizal’s exile in Dapitan and return to Manila in three movements: the first shows Rizal in the astral plane as he contemplates the city, bewailing a city grown old and cold, inhabited by the patriarchs, the gluttons, the potentates, the charlatans, and so forth; the second recreates Rizal’s idyllic life with Josephine Bracken in Dapitan, with the poet waxing romantic and rhapsodic over love lost and love triumphant even as Rizal chooses kinship with the stars, resigned to his fate, not caring about death; the third focuses once more upon Manila, as telex moon looms bright and glaring, symbol of the city’s materialism and greed, its centrifugal forces effecting a widening gyre, a moral basis of order crumbling, as “the mechanism of faith … shall break the telex moon … to dissolve in the splendid grace of Selfhood.” Finally, Sunlight on Broken Stones begins with the Philippine Revolution of 1896 and reaches the EDSA Revolt of 1986.

Although epic in its scope and material, the trilogy appears as an epic in hindsight. In his foreword to this single-volume work, Bautista writes that even through he wrote numerous poems, these found their way “into a larger corpus of lines… that eventually formed the ocean of an epic.” Unlike a Western or Filipino epic, there appears to be no single heroic figure or group in Trilogy and the historical or mythic event it concerns itself extends to more than 400 years of Philippine history. Its manner is not limited to that of a long epic narrative. It employs dramatic monologues, dialogues, shifting consciousness, and what one associates with lyric poetry, meditations and contemplations. There is no fixed metrical form, but there are observed sonic regularities that aid in distinguishing the sections. The effect is the creation of an extended lyrical voice that provides an inner life similar to the long poems of American poets H. D. (The Trilogy), William Carlos Williams (Paterson), and Ezra Pound (Cantos).

However, some critics point out that the central narratives of The Archipelago and Telex Moon conform with the archetypal journey of a Filipino epic hero’s in terms of structure. In The Archipelago, historical figures like Ferdinand Magellan, Miguel Lopez de Legazpi, Limahong, and Jose Rizal take turns “speaking,” their journeys following the tropes of an archetypal epic journey: departure from a homeland in search of something, undergoing tests, death, and resurrection through Bautista’s poem itself. In Telex Moon, the figure of Rizal replaces the multiple voices of The Archipelago, but he similarly conforms to the pattern of that epic journey: his departure for Dapitan, his death in Bagumbayan, and subsequent poetic resurrection.

Completing the trilogy’s historical project, Sunlight on Broken Stones does not contain a similar journey. Instead there is a consolidation of voices that implicates characters like Ferdinand Marcos, Corazon Aquino, and Cardinal Sin, in addition to Rizal and Andres Bonifacio, who also have monologues. Of the three books, Sunlight has the most metrical regularity with clearly defined five-line stanzas, and with the exception of the opening and closing sections, each section is 20 stanzas long. The effect is that the events recounted and the characters speaking lose individuality, as though the poem were implying that the different events and voices are one. The poem thus mirrors the unison of voices at the EDSA Revolt where it culminates.

Although based on history, Bautista mentions thatit was by the creative treatment of historical data,“through artistic and aesthetic means,” that he was able to write the poem and not recount history or write a biography.  Written by Paolo M. Manalo and Ophelia A. Dimalanta

text:
(Tudbulul 1: Kemokul Has No Son). Transcribed 1996. Chanter, Ramon Kebil. Transcriber and translator into Filipino, Virginia Buhisan. “Tudbulul: Ang Awit ng Matandang Lalaking Tboli bilang Salamin ng Kanilang Lipunan at Kalinangan” (Tudbulul: The Song of a Tboli Elder as a Reflection of Their Society and Culture), PhD diss., University of the Philippines Diliman.

The epic Tud Bulul aka Tudbulul/Todbulol, is the core of Tboli folk literature and the foundation on which Tboli identity rests. The chanting of this epic on important occasions such as weddings may last up to 16 hours, depending on the number of cycles, or songs, that the chanter chooses to perform. The generic title for each song is “Lingon Tuha Logi” (Song of the Elder). Academics refer to it as the “epic of Tud Bulul,” because it bears many of the conventions universally found in epics, and the main hero is Tud Bulul (Buhisan 1996, 57; Lapiz 2006, 47-50).

Every cycle of the Tud Bulul epic includes all or some of the following motifs: “a call to a meeting (usually due to a dream); the statement of the problem to be resolved; sequences composed of several obstacles in the process of solving the problem (this usually entails that Tud Bulul journeys through different lands and realms); the chronicles of their ancestry line; Tud Bulul’s success in resolving the problem; and Tod Bulul’s return to the initial setting of the story” (Buhisan 1996, 57-58). “Kemokul Laendo Nga Logi” (Kemokul Has No Son), consisting of 1,223 lines, was chanted by Ramon Kebil in Lake Sebu and recorded by Virginia Buhisan. It was translated by Myrna Pula into English. From that translation Buhisan made a Filipino translation. The cycle that is summarized here focuses on the circumstances of Tud Bulul’s birth and recounts certain episodes in his childhood and youth.

Kemokul and his wife Lenkonul have grown old together childless. As he chews betel nut, Kemokul expresses a longing to be young again. Lenkonul soon becomes pregnant. Their son is born full grown and already bringing his weapons and material wealth with him. Kemokul names him Tudbulul, or “the datu with a shield in his hand.” Right away, Kemokul wants to teach Tudbulul to swim, hunt, make a bird trap, and other such skills of manhood. One day, he carries Tudbulul in a malong (tube skirt) slung across his chest and goes hunting for the spotted boar. He leaves Tudbulul on a white rock and pursues the boar but it eludes him. When Kemokul returns for him, Tudbulul is gone. He and Lenkonul fear that Tudbulul would perish in the wilds. In his mind’s eye, Kemokul perceives Tudbulul on the back of the spotted boar as they cross the sea and the realms of Kayung and Mugul.

In the next episode of the narration, Kenaban, the princess of the bamboo fields and Tudbulul’s sister, sits outside the house with a folded malong on her head while Tudbulul carries the container of the cooked boar. Envious, Tudbulul asks for something to place on his head, too. He then wants to go upstairs but he is too small. He wails and people help him up. To soothe the crying Tudbulul, Kemokul grants his son’s wish for the lid of a kobong (bamboo water container). But Tudbulul continues to sob, this time because of a premonition. He has seen that he would die in raging floodwaters that would come down upon their house. He wraps the lid of the kobong in his clothes and sets off on a journey.

Datu Sendangan, Tudbulul’s enemy, invites Datu Lintang to visit Tudbulul’s dwelling. Datu Lintang, Tudbulul’s friend, declines for he knows that Tudbulul has a problem and lives a solitary life near a kenalum seedling. Datu Sendangan insists on going. A female horse also wants to go to Tudbulul.

As he journeys on, Tudbulul remains deep in thought about the premonition of his death. He meets Datu Sewaga, the dragon, which allows Tudbulul to take out its tooth to serve as an amulet. Tudbulul next meets Datu Sowu, a snake, which also gives him its tooth for an amulet. Tudbulul arrives at a house, where the resident old woman warns him to avoid the right side of the house. There sleeps an old man who is a busaw (malevolent spirit). Tudbulul ignores the warning and passes through the right side where he meets another old woman, who warns him not to awaken the old man. Despite all the admonitions, Tudbulul goes and tries to wake up the old man by riding on his head, standing on his chest, and finally pulling out a hair from his nose. The old man awakens and furiously tries to cut Tudbulul with his kefilan (cutlass) but Tudbulul’s amulets protect him.

When both have calmed down, Tudbulul asks the old man, who is actually his grandfather, to go with him to Lunay Mogul, aka Lemlunay. The old man assents on condition that Tudbulul guess his true name. Tudbulul does, so the old man gives Tudbulul his horse and sets off for Lunay Mogul with Tudbulul. They hear noises along the way that indicate Datu Sowu and Datu Sewaga’s presence.

They come upon Kesodung and Sobo Bun, who are arguing with the trees about the arrangement of a dowry of horses, golden necklaces, and leaves for a marriage. Tudbulul and Kemokul come upon each other at the wedding. Kemokul jokingly tells Tudbulul that he does not like him being there. Tudbulul then inquires how Kemokul died. Tudbulul persuades Kemokul to accompany him to Lunay Mogul. Tudbulul, Kemokul, and others arrive in Lunay Mogul, where Kenaban prepares a celebration for the return of Tudbulul, Kemokul’s heir.  Written by Michael Jude Tumamac

 

Sources

Buhisan, Virginia. 1966. “Tudbulol: Ang Awit ng Matandang Lalaking Tboli bilang Salamin ng Kanilang Lipunan at Kalinangan.” PhD diss. University of the Philippines Diliman.

Lapiz, Eduardo M. 2006. “Sotu Tutul Tud Bulul (Isang Kwento ni Tud Bulul): Pagsasa-Filipino ng Isang ‘Hlolok’ ng mga T’boli na Inawit ni Ma’Dison.” MA thesis, University of the Philippines Diliman.

text:
(Tudbulul 2: Nga Lindun and Tudbulul). Transcribed 1996. Chanter, Ye Nita. Translator, Virginia Buhisan. “Tudbulul: Ang Awit ng Matandang Lalaking Tboli bilang Salamin ng Kanilang Lipunan at Kalinangan” (Tudbulul: The Song of a Tboli Elder as a Reflection of Their Society and Culture), PhD diss., University of the Philippines Diliman.

The second cycle of the Tboli epic recorded by Buhisan was chanted by Ye Nita in Lake Sebu and consists of 1,165 lines. Nga Lindun, of the second realm of the skies, sends her cloud messengers to ask Tudbulul, aka Semgulang, for a special betel nut. This is a gesture of courtship but, because it is not a woman’s place to initiate courtship, she is also laying a challenge to him. Learning from the cloud messengers that Nga Lindun is a beautiful and powerful woman, Tudbulul complies but, to assert his superiority, sends her a set of demands. First, the betel nut is to be washed. Second, the nut is not be cut in half. Finally, Nga Lindun is to come down from the skies at noon on the second day, or else he would wreak destruction on Nga Lindun’s territory.

Nga Lindun finds the betel nut delicious and decides to go down to Lunay Mogul / Lemlunay, though she now regrets initiating the courtship. Had she waited, Tudbulul would have gone to her on his own. Nga Lindun takes the malong (tube skirt) that Tudbulul had wrapped his gifts in and uses it to wrap a malong of intricate design around her waist.

On her way down to Lunay Mogul, Nga Lindun hears a loud explosion in the mountains and a ball of fire rolls toward her. Inside it is Nga Datu Timbag Lugung, astride his horse. He asks for her hand in marriage but she refuses. She bellittles and mocks him when he shows off the tattoo on his chest, and he seizes her.

From the sky, Nga Lindun’s wooden comb, which is adorned with 17 buttons, drops onto Tudbulul’s feet in Lunay Mogul. The wooden comb recounts Nga Lindun’s misfortune. In a fury, Tudbulul takes his kefilan (kris), kampilan (sword), and other weapons, mounts his horse, and heads for the spot in the mountains where he and Nga Lindun had agreed to meet. He passes by the dominion of Solok Minum, who prepares a bed and a meal for him. Tudbulul refuses to tarry, and Solok Minum, slighted by this discourtesy, wishes that Tudbulul be bitten by a snake or be killed by his own shield. Tudbulul explains his quandary.

Tudbulul sits on a white rock to wait for Nga Lindun. He is actually sitting on his mascot, Ke-unting, who can transform into a white rock or stone. Datu Timbag Lugung comes and stops by Tudbulul’s rock. They exchange greetings and Tudbulul pretends his name is Datu Buling Meyosung. Datu Timbag Lugung sits with Tudbulul on the rock and they chew betel nut together. Datu Timbag Lugung brags of his conquest and Tudbulul, alias Datu Buling Meyosung, threatens him. Datu Timbag Lugung recognizes Tudbulul. Nga Lindun wails in the background. Tudbulul takes his shield and grabs Nga Lindun. He is covered with fire, which is his anting-anting (amulet), because he is a true and honest man. After a prolonged fight, Datu Timbag Lugung finally admits that his weapon cannot penetrate Tudbulul’s anting-anting, and this affirms that whoever commits a falsehood will never triumph. On his eighth attempt, Tudbulul slays Datu Timbag Lugung.  Written by Michael Jude Tumamac

Tudbulul sits on a white rock to wait for Nga Lindun. He is actually sitting on his mascot, Ke-unting, who can transform into a white rock or stone. Datu Timbag Lugung comes and stops by Tudbulul’s rock. They exchange greetings and Tudbulul pretends his name is Datu Buling Meyosung. Datu Timbag Lugung sits with Tudbulul on the rock and they chew betel nut together. Datu Timbag Lugung brags of his conquest and Tudbulul, alias Datu Buling Meyosung, threatens him. Datu Timbag Lugung recognizes Tudbulul. Nga Lindun wails in the background. Tudbulul takes his shield and grabs Nga Lindun. He is covered with fire, which is his anting-anting (amulet), because he is a true and honest man. After a prolonged fight, Datu Timbag Lugung finally admits that his weapon cannot penetrate Tudbulul’s anting-anting, and this affirms that whoever commits a falsehood will never triumph. On his eighth attempt, Tudbulul slays Datu Timbag Lugung.  Written by Michael Jude Tumamac

article_title: Tudbulul 3: Lemfayan Laan Kdaw ne Tudbulul
text:
(Tudbulul 3: Lemfayan under the Sun and Tudbulul). Transcribed 1996. Chanter, Lynda Sagan. Translator, Virginia Buhisan. “Tudbulul: Ang Awit ng Matandang Lalaking Tboli bilang Salamin ng Kanilang Lipunan at Kalinangan” (Tudbulul: The Song of a Tboli Elder as a Reflection of Their Society and Culture), PhD diss., University of the Philippines Diliman.

The third cycle of the Tboli epic recorded by Buhisan was chanted by Lynda Sagan in Lake Sebu and consists of 1,679 lines. One morning, Tudbulul of the tattooed arms tells his eight sisters that he has dreamt of tattoo artist Lemfayan, whom he now desires to visit. His sister Kenaban disapproves, for Lemfayan is already married. Tudbulul protests that he will always be melancholy until he wins her. He puts on his best clothes and calls for his horse, Keunting. Even the horse disapproves, but Tudbulul has his way. Tudbulul bids his sisters to keep Lemlunay in order; otherwise, their enemies will realize that he is away and take advantage of his absence. Kenaban, in turn, reminds Tudbulul to take care; otherwise, only his name would return to Lemlunay. Before leaving, Tudbulul looks into the room of his father Kemokul and his mother Lenkonul.

On his way, Tudbulul rides through the domain of the maiden Solok Minum, who is hoping to be his wife. She prepares her house in anticipation of his visit and sends her sister, Selutan, to inquire of Tudbulul what merrymaking he is off to. Tudbulul evasively replies that he is just looking for a gong and a malong (tube skirt). Solok Minum offers Tudbulul betel chew, which he refuses because he must proceed with his journey. Solok Minum hopes to go with him when he returns to Lemlunay but Tudbulul tactfully lets her down by saying that he is undeserving of her.

Keunting the horse is still reluctant to proceed and Tudbulul agrees that their journey is fraught with danger, but he insists that he will take up any challenge coming his way. Tudbulul meets Datu Bigul But Bulul, who is on his way to Lemlunay. Tudbulul tries to dissuade the datu from proceeding, saying that there are only elderly women there. The datu does not believe Tudbulul, and they fight with shields that shoot out fire and whirlwinds. They also exchange snide comments. After a prolonged battle, Tudbulul lets out a victory cry, mounts Keunting, and continues his journey.

They cross fields of cogon, the place of withered leaves, the gorge of tattoos, and the forest of rings until they are stopped by the sound of gongs. The fearful Keunting reminds Tudbulul of Kenaban’s warning that only their names will return to Lemlunay. They meet Datu Tikel Son Buteng, who says he is on his way to Lemlunay, where only defenseless maidens live. Incensed, Tudbulul shakes his shield, from which shoots out a ball of fire, striking Datu Tikel’s headdress. Datu Botong Bulul appears, interrupts the fight, and says that he will wait for Tudbulul at the gathering. Tudbulul journeys on until he reaches the moving mountains. He sees threadlike smoke coming from the woods. Something sitting on a ladder has a pair of eyes as large as plates, and its face appears to have collided with a large tree or have been flattened like a gong. It demands to know his identity, and Tudbulul obliges. The person blocking his way is Datu Sakung Lembulul. Its nose is as large as a wine jar, its eyes as large as a comb, and in its hand is a stick. The man challenges Tudbulul to guess his name as proof that Tudbulul is really Kemokul and Lenkonul’s son. After a long silence, Tudbulul guesses correctly that the man is Datu Sekung Lembulul. He is the brother of Kemokul, who gave him this house in the faraway mountains because he is a busaw (evil spirit). Tudbulul weeps for joy at having found his uncle, and Datu Sekung Lembulul is glad he has not killed his nephew. He invites Tudbulul in for drinks. The house is full of busaw with glowing eyes, which frighten Keunting. Datu Sekung gives Tudbulul his shield that came from the limuhan (an omen bird) and decorated with flowers, as well as his kris. He advises Tudbulul to disguise himself in humble clothing, to leave all his things behind, including Keunting, and to ride to the gathering on a lowly female carabao. Tudbulul assents, although he declares he will carry his own name into the gathering. He has also heard his uncle, the busaw, being called Mumuy.

When Tudbulul arrives, gongs are playing, many shields are there, and a horse fight is going on. Lemfayen sees Tudbulul and thinks he might be the busaw Mumuy. Tudbulul tethers his carabao to a tree and leans against the shields. Lemfayen gazes at him from head to toe and then prepares a betel chew with extraordinary care. The women chastise her, calling Tudbulul “Fu Lutuy,” which means “the man without wealth or shield.” Lemfayan replies that betel chew is not solely for men with tattooed chests or men with power. She then enters the room where the gongs are kept and puts on her best clothes and finery. Again, she offers Tudbulul her betel chew, but he only reproves her for mocking his manhood, saying he is but a weak, old man with no tattoo on his chest. Lemfayen retorts that she is free to choose her company, but she has already begun to suspect that he might be Tudbulul.

Tudbulul’s carabao is about to move toward him when he commands her to stay quiet lest he be discovered. He sends her back to his uncle, Datu Sekung Lembulul, for his horse, Keunting. In the meantime, the women are laughing and sneering at him. Keunting arrives and kisses Tudbulul’s shield in greeting but Tudbulul asks him not to reveal himself just yet. A ball of fire rolls in and a strong earthquake rocks the land. The merrymaking is suddenly stilled. Keunting makes his appearance, looking magnificent with head of gold and bearing Tudbulul’s paraphernalia. Tudbulul sheds his disguise, and the ball of fire strikes Lemfayan’s hair. The women exclaim in regret at their obtuseness.

Lemfayan’s husband is the powerful Nga Datu Neben Lobun, the datu with the flaming shield and whose head is a meter wide. No one, not even Tudbulul, can defeat him. Declaring that he will not be shaken, Tudbulul asks Lemfayan to dance for him. Nga Datu Neben Lobun angrily asserts his rights as Lemfayen’s husband. Tudbulul delivers a boastful speech and provokes Nga Datu Neben Lobun to a duel, declaring that if he destroys the datu’s shield, he will take Lemfayan back to Lemlunay with him. As their krises and shields clash, the two mock each other, but it is a long, drawn out fight.

Meanwhile, Datu Sakung Lembulul is hurrying to the scene of battle. He stops the fight and reveals that Nga Datu Neben Lobun is his son. The two rivals are therefore first cousins. A woman, he adds, is not worth the fight, for she is but a head of hair; on the other hand, a fight between relatives would bring down a curse on them. Nga Datu Neben Lobun offers Lemfayan to Tudbulul in exchange for Keunting and his large gongs, which contain Tudbulul’s fire. Tudbulul assents, for to refuse would make Nga Datu Neben Lobun’s soul wander aimlessly. Tudbulul sits beside Lemfayan, who offers him betel chew. But if the limuhan bird sings, it bodes ill for the two, and the wedding may not proceed after all.  Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero and Michael Jude Tumamac

text:
(Tudbulul 4: Tudbulul Drowns). Transcribed 1996. Chanter, Sena Kuman. Translator, Virginia Buhisan. “Tudbulul: Ang Awit ng Matandang Lalaking Tboli bilang Salamin ng Kanilang Lipunan at Kalinangan” (Tudbulul: The Song of a Tboli Elder as a Reflection of Their Society and Culture), PhD diss., University of the Philippines Diliman.

The fourth cycle of the Tboli epic recorded by Buhisan was chanted by Sena Kuman in Lake Sebu and consists of 2,310 lines. Tudbulul, aka Semgulang, dreams that he will die when his town Lemlunay is engulfed by fire and sea. He builds a sky-high, defensive stone wall around Lemlunay. One day, from the shade of the kenalum tree, Tudbulul sees the sea rising higher and higher until the water reaches up to the floor of his house. The turbulence lasts for eight days. The waves swallow up Lemlunay, along with Tudbulul and his two sisters, who both float off in another direction.

Tudbulul dies, and his body floats into the navel of the sea, together with his sword, shield, and betel-nut box. The seventh layer, where the navel of the sea lies, breaks into a wail because Tudbulul’s body is caught in it. Three brothers try to swallow Tudbulul’s body by turns but they all fail because Tudbulul is too powerful. The eldest has Tudbulul’s body taken up to his house. His daughter, Kembeyen, prepares the rites of mourning for Tudbulul. For the coffin, she must find a tree with bell-shaped leaves and golden twigs, owned by Bal Biwong. Tudbulul’s elbow jerks up in approval at the sound of the tree’s name.

Because it is not a woman’s place to make a coffin, Kembeyen puts on Tudbulul’s outfit, including his kefilan (kris) and shield. In the guise of Tudbulul, she goes to the seventh layer, where the navel of the sea lies, and there she sees a betel-nut box. She cuts the betel nut with the kris, but the kris slips and hits her pulse. Feeling very ill, she enters Kayung, the realm of those who die violently. She cuts off her pulse and promises to come back for it. She plays the kulintang (bossed gong) to send a message to her father to take care of Tudbulul’s body while she is away.

Datu Beniteng wonders with foreboding why his daughter is going to Kayung, because it is a place where beheaded people go, and not where people would search for a coffin. Kembeyen enters Kayung by cutting down the enchanted macopa tree, whose fruits fall continuously down from the branches. Soon, she sees Datu Kayung, the ruler of that realm, but he does not realize that she is a woman because she looks like Tudbulul. He invites her to his house, where she meets Insa Lenuy, Datu Kayung’s daughter. They sit and chew betel nut together.

As she is about to resume her quest for the tree, Kembeyen promises to meet Insa Lenuy at the top of the mountain on her way home. Kembeyen then proceeds to the moon to get the tree that Bal Biwong owns. It admonishes her to get only the part she needs for the coffin and to return the leaves. Kembeyen measures the wood she needs and returns to the navel of the sea, fetching her pulse, which has transformed into a woman. Between them, they carry the coffin. Insa Lenuy, princess of Kayung, joins them. They place Tudbulul’s body inside the coffin and perform the mourning rites. Tudbulul’s two sisters who had been swept by the flood that killed Tudbulul arrive. Kenaban recognizes her brother, Tudbulul, and so Kembeyen finally learns the dead body’s identity.

Kembeyen and Kenaban hear that Datu Betawi and other men plan to steal Tudbulul’s coffin. Kenaban protects Tudbulul by embracing his coffin. Kembeyen readies her gun. Eight years pass and Kembeyen continues to protect Tudbulul’s body with her gun until all the datus are finally killed by gunfire. The coffin opens and Tudbulul sits up, but he has been transformed into a shield. He thanks his sister Kenaban for her fidelity to him and asks Kembeyen to prepare a betel chew. He bids them return to Lemlunay while he must wander off to restore his good name. Kenaban and the others go home and rebuild Kenalum aka Lemlunay / Lunay Mogul. The women shout with joy and play the gong and hegolung (two-stringed lute).

As Tudbulul wanders, he overhears men joking about him and his death. He appears to them, and the men run away in fear, his shield chasing after them. Tudbulul runs to his house, where he tells his sister Kenaban that he will die again. He will only return to their own realm when he has gotten what his soul needs: his sword in the lake, his shield in the sky, and the chests containing fire and wind. When Tudbulul dies again, the women gather in mourning, and Kenaban consoles them by urging them to help her grant Tudbulul’s wish. Kenaban and the women search relentlessly for months, even at the cost of their health.

Young Heniton is left behind in Lemlunay. She sends the clouds to tell her sisters that Tudbulul’s body is decaying and that they should come home. Heniton journeys to the mountain where her grandmother Duyung lives. Duyung has the weapons and the chests that Tudbulul needs. Duyung makes Heniton stay for months till she feels Heniton is old enough to return to Lemlunay. She travels with Heniton, taking all her wealth with her. Together with the sisters, they go to Tudbulul’s room and they place the quake and fire near his head, and the sword and shield on his chest. After a few hours, Tudbulul comes back to life and everyone celebrates. Duyung tells Tudbulul that the chest will be used as a defense against the creature from the Kayung realm. She also explains that Tudbulul’s misfortunes have been caused by his negligence in his duty to visit his relatives.

Solok Minum of Mount Gemlung comes and Tudbulul asks her to marry him. Everyone gathers together and chews betel nut. Tudbulul is reestablished as the defender of Lemlunay. Kenaban and the other women are also wedded. The celebrations last eight years. Tudbulul’s father, Kemokul, is happy because his clan is reunited.  Written by Michael Jude Tumamac

article_title: Tula at Kuwento ng Katutubong Bukidnon
text:
(Poems and Stories of the Indigenous Bukidnon). Published 1996. Translators, Victorino Saway and Carmen C. Unabia. With a foreword by Bienvenido L. Lumbera and an introduction by Carmen C. Unabia. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

This is an anthology of 62 poems and 38 stories in Binukid, written, recounted, or sung by 17 Bukidnon—a general term given by the Visayans for the mountain people of Mindanao. Although the introduction classifies Bukidnon lyric poetry according to the manner in which it is performed, the book’s contents themselves divide the poetry section by subject matter. There are nature poems, replete with detailed description and startling perspectives. “Kakempet hu Dagat” (The Beauty of the Sea) encompasses the sea’s many dimensions, including its deafening roar and its sunset brilliance, “as if it had been scrubbed from a great flame.” Other elements of nature are analogous to the Bukidnon’s historical experience, personal grief, and cultural practices. In “Nabayaw ha Malidu” (The Sorrowful Sun), the noonday sun weeps at the sight of disunity among the people, who are “like separate strands of hair.”

The animal songs are depictions of the Bukidnon’s condition: there are the mother monkey soothing her child’s hunger, the honey gatherer addressing the bee, and the fish cursing the river for overflowing its banks. The lullabies, besides being pleas to the baby to stop crying and to go to sleep, also express the parent’s apprehensions and good wishes for the baby’s future.

“Si Baybayan” (Baybayan), in the section “Sala ha Tanud hu mga Laas” (Historical Songs about Ancestors), tells of the origin of the kaliga (ritual house), which the creator god commands the baylan (shaman) Baybayan to build. Here, another baylan, Agbangala, is Baybayan’s alter ego, who, as he rides toward the sky in the salimbal (sacred vehicle), is “knifed by lightning” and splinters into innumerable stars.

The section “Mga Sala hu Kagtima, Gagaw, daw Agpatayan” (Songs of Life, Love, and Death) ranges over the emotions that men are capable of: sibling misunderstanding; a man’s eagerness to prove the fierceness of his love with his machete; the timidity of one who cannot confess his love; a datu’s pain over an impossible love; and a man’s boastful offer to undertake death-defying feats to prove his love. On the other hand, the female personas in various poems invariably proffer the betel nut chew as a symbol of the love that their suitors seek.

“Kaamula hu Tag Pangasawa” (Gathering for a Groom-to-Be) is the ritual verbal exchange between the spokespersons of the families of the betrothed couple. “Pangaluambit” (Prayer) consists of two prayers: an appeal to Magbabaya and other spirit-guardians for favors and a chanted litany of thanks at a community celebration. “Mga Sala hu Agpatayan” (Dirges) are expressions of mourning and reflections on the afterlife.

The second half of the anthology consists of prose narratives. Of the six gugud or batbat (historico-mythical tales), three are about the creation of the world, the great flood, and Baybayan’s birth and journey to the sky world. In the mantukaw, tales derived from the Binukid epic poem, Agyu figures prominently.

In a lighter vein are the numskull tales, featuring Walu, Agyu’s cousin, as the antihero. Miscommunication often gets him and his wife Insay into problematic but hilarious situations, with, for example, a honeycomb, a field lizard, a long-clawed hen, and a trio of good-spirited house thieves. Walu’s older, more sober brother Bataay sometimes rescues him but at other times himself makes mischief on Walu. Other nanangen (folktales) are fables, some of which are also trickster tales, and tales about types of people (the piteous child, the childless couple, the envious neighbor, the rich, and the poor). Some tales are apparently derived from the korido (metrical romance), such as “Pagpagayuk daw su Hari” (The Bird and the King), which has many parallels with Ang Ibong Adarna (The Adarna Bird).

This book provides not only knowledge of the Bukidnon’s cosmology, worldview, and codes of right conduct but also proof of the artistic heights that an unfettered literary imagination and deliberate craftsmanship can achieve. A companion anthology is Bukidnon Myths and Rituals, 2000.  Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero and Om Narayan Velasco

article.value: (Poems and Stories of the Indigenous Bukidnon). Published 1996. Translators, Victorino Saway and Carmen C. Unabia. With a foreword by Bienvenido L. Lumbera and an introduction by Carmen C. Unabia. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

This is an anthology of 62 poems and 38 stories in Binukid, written, recounted, or sung by 17 Bukidnon—a general term given by the Visayans for the mountain people of Mindanao. Although the introduction classifies Bukidnon lyric poetry according to the manner in which it is performed, the book’s contents themselves divide the poetry section by subject matter. There are nature poems, replete with detailed description and startling perspectives. “Kakempet hu Dagat” (The Beauty of the Sea) encompasses the sea’s many dimensions, including its deafening roar and its sunset brilliance, “as if it had been scrubbed from a great flame.” Other elements of nature are analogous to the Bukidnon’s historical experience, personal grief, and cultural practices. In “Nabayaw ha Malidu” (The Sorrowful Sun), the noonday sun weeps at the sight of disunity among the people, who are “like separate strands of hair.”

The animal songs are depictions of the Bukidnon’s condition: there are the mother monkey soothing her child’s hunger, the honey gatherer addressing the bee, and the fish cursing the river for overflowing its banks. article_title: Ang Tulisan at Iba Pang Talinghaga
text:
(The Bandit and Other Metaphors). Published 1999. Author, Florentino T. Collantes. With an introduction by Roberto T. Añonuevo. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

Like other Tagalog writers of the 1920s and 1930s, Collantes wrote in the tradition of Francisco "Balagtas" Baltazar and the writers of the propaganda movement. Using his columns in Tagalog newspapers Ang Watawat and Pagkakaisa as outlets for his poetry, he fulfilled the Tagalog poet’s dual role: to delight and to teach.

The book ranges through the topical concerns of the era as he expresses his immediate responses to various events. Upon hearing the news that William Taft is unwell, Collantes, in “Mabuhay si Taft” (Long Live Taft), wishes him a speedy recovery and pleads with him to continue fighting for the Filipinos. On the other hand, he excoriates American individuals and institutions when they transgress Philippine rights and interests: the plans of presidential emissary Carmi A. Thompson to open the country’s pristine lands to foreign exploitation in “Ang Talumpati ni Thompson” (Thompson’s Speech); President Coolidge’s proposal to grant more power to the governor-general in “Mga Tanda ng Pangiinis” (Signs of Suppression); a bill filed in the US Congress proposing to separate Mindanao from the rest of the Philippines in “Tayo’y Magsitutol” (Let’s Oppose); and an American art teacher’s racist slur in “Magnanakaw na Lahat ang mga Filipino” (All Filipinos Are Thieves).

The trespasses of local executives and police are not spared. In “Ordenansa ng Pag-ibig” (Love Ordinance), “Ang Pagmamapuri ng Sekreta’t Pulis” (The Ingratiation of the Plainclothesman and the Police), and “Segunda Senyal Na” (It’s Signal No. 2 Already), he rues how people use their power and influence to harass the poor rather than help them. Other subjects in his poetry include the threat to close down a cabaret, the violent and protracted series of strikes in many factories, murders, the dark side to the carnival season, and poverty-related crimes. “Naglalagablab Na ang Aklasan” (The Strike Is Heating Up) and “Hubaran ang Walang Damit, Dayukdukin ang Nagugutom” (Strip the Naked, Starve the Hungry) are Collantes’s more powerful depictions of the people’s sufferings.

Collantes also exposes the Filipino’s vices and various forms of misbehavior, such as boastfulness in “Mapanirang Puri” (Harmful Honor), fractiousness in “Kay Hirap Tuntunin” (It’s Hard to Apprehend), the tendency of parents to spoil their children in “Ang Kunsintidor” (The Indulgent One), gluttony in “Bunga ng Katakawan” (The Result of Rapacity), and procrastination in “Ang Pangakong Sastre” (The Promised Tailor). Nor does Collantes spare such deeply ingrained customs as pakimkim (dowry) and extravagant and financially draining fiestas.

Collantes’s romantic and personal poetry, for which he is well known, consists of his short, lyrical poems, which use objects in nature as metaphors for various aspects of life, as in “Ang Awit ng mga Ibon” (The Birds’ Song) and “Ang Punongkahoy” (The Tree); and tragic tales of betrayal and love, as in “Pasalubong” (Greeting).

The final section features Collantes’s longer narrative poems, including “Ang Lumang Simbahan” (The Old Church), a tale of the restoration of the people’s reverence for an old, dreaded church after two lovers found treasure buried beneath its altar, and “Ang Tulisan” (The Bandit).

Divided into 11 parts, the titular poem opens with a woman fearful for her husband and their son, Fidel, who have been away for two months to sell their carabaos in Nueva Ecija. She decides to seek Roman, Fidel’s godfather, for help. Roman moved from Calumpit to Gapan after he had been accused as a bandit who had attacked the village. In Gapan, Roman has found himself a wife, but he is suspected of poisoning her for money.

The third and fourth parts depict the stories of Ines and her daughter Adela. After Adela gives birth to Fidel’s child, Ines charges over to Fidel’s house to fight for Adela’s honor. Ines thinks that Fidel has reneged on his promise to marry Adela after he has earned enough from selling the carabaos. When Ines learns from Fidel’s mother that father and son have been missing, her rage turns to grief, and she helps Fidel’s mother prepare for her journey to Gapan.

In the seventh part, Fidel’s mother finds Roman, who informs her that both her son and husband passed by his house on their way to sell their livestock. Roman joins the woman in her search. In the town of Muñoz, they meet a man who bought the last carabao from Fidel and his father. The man recalls that they intended to go to Gapan to visit a kumpare (son’s godfather), who also hails from Bulacan.

The search is abruptly ended when Roman attempts to rape Fidel’s mother. She wounds Roman with a dagger, forcing him to flee into the night. Their paths intersect 18 years later, when Fidel’s child, who has grown up unaware of Roman and his deeds, falls in love with Roman’s niece. Surprised that Roman is still alive, Fidel’s mother dreams of her son. She is told that he and his father were murdered by Roman and were buried near a well by his house in Gapan.

In the final part, she digs up the skeletons of her husband and son. Back in Calumpit, Fidel’s mother confronts Roman, stabs him in the chest, and drags him to face the village chief. After admitting to his crimes, Roman is lynched by the villagers and is left dead, hanging from a mango tree.

Besides providing a comprehensive view of Collantes’s writings, the book demonstrates how the poetic tradition inherited from Balagtas can be a source of in-depth knowledge of and insight into key moments in the nation’s colonial history.  Written by Soledad Reyes and Om Narayan Velasco
