article_title: Turtle Voices in Uncertain Weather: Poems, 1980-1988
text:
Published 1989. Author, Alfrredo Navarro Salanga. Editor, Virgilio S. Almario. With introductions by the editor, Alfred A. Yuson, and Isagani R. Cruz. Manila: Cultural Center of the Philippines.

This collection of poems, written between 1980 and 1988, embodies Salanga’s concerns, insights, and experiences during his most prolific period as a writer and journalist, just before it was cut short by his death in 1988.

The book is divided into several sections. The opening section, “Horns and Cymbals, Carnivals and Volcanoes: A Poem for Many Voices,” has different choruses looking for the “way to the center.” This quest informs the rest of the book.

The poems in the section “Voices Prompted by the News, A Staple Food” open with epigraphs taken from news clippings on various incidents ranging from the atrocious and catastrophic to the inane: an entire village slaughtered by an ousted dictator in “Malabo,” two convicts hanged for raping and killing two young girls in “Warsaw,” a nuclear arms race purportedly for national defense in “Tokyo / New Delhi,” the arrest of a man who was squatting in a family mausoleum in “Brussels.” The details of the news item are skillfully appropriated by Salanga as poetic devices to unravel the complexities and ironies of each event.

Seeing history as essentially authored by colonial subjugation “that moves us away from what we are,” Salanga carefully peels away and brings to light the manifold layers which compose the nation’s narrative in “A Philippine History Lesson.”

In the section “Fragments from the Journal of Obispo Gregorio,” Salanga employs the persona of Gregorio Aglipay, founder of the revolutionary Philippine Independent Church, and uses symbolisms of the Roman Catholic Church to critique the relation between the doctrines of the Western Church and the Spanish colonialist objectives. This section’s last poem, “The Fifth Fragment: The Open Mouth,” alludes to an image of a Christ whose open mouth reveals molars that are “like chalices, and into their cavities fall the blood of his victims.”

Two other sections, “February 1899” and “January 1899,” narrate crucial junctures in the Philippine-American War. Salanga again uses epigraphs as springboards. In “9 February,” the epigraph states that American forces have taken the town of Pasig, but the persona makes a parallelism between the waters of Pasig River and the indomitable spirit of the people, asserting that “no Pasig can ever be captured whole.”

The book also includes poems which are Salanga’s searing commentaries on the most politically charged issues of the 1980s: oppressive feudal relations (“The Landlord,” “The Farmer,” “The Farmer’s Son”); Benigno “Ninoy” Aquino Jr’s assassination (“A Way of Coming Home”); the Escalante Massacre of 1985 (“Memo for Our National Security Carpenters, after Escalante”). These poems made Salanga a significant figure in the protest poetry movement of the period.

Despite its breadth of vision, the collection is likewise very intimate and personal. Interspersed throughout the book are poems that are either addressed or dedicated to Salanga’s colleagues, close friends, and family. The fifth, sixth, and tenth sections—one for each of his three children—convey both the poet’s wonder at and anxieties about fatherhood.

With his masterful handling of language, unconventional enjambments, striking imagery, and visual elements of concrete poetry, Salanga is able to find new ways to impress familiar topics and themes and national issues upon the reader.

“Voices Prompted by the News, A Staple Food,” won first prize, Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature, 1980; “February 1899,” won second prize, Palanca Awards, 1984; “Miscellanea 1984-1985,” won first prize, Palanca Awards, 1985.  Written by Om Narayan Velasco

text:
TUWAANG THE MAIDEN OF THE BUHONG SKY, A COMPLETE SONG FROM THE BAGOBO FOLK EPIC TUWAANG

Published 1958. Transcriber, E. Arsenio Manuel. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

 

TUWAANG ATTENDS A WEDDING

Published 1975. Transcriber, E. Arsenio Manuel. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

Tuwaang is the epic of the Manobo, a group occupying the boundary area of Cotabato, Bukidnon, and Davao in Mindanao, near the areas occupied by the Jangan and Tagbanwa. There are over 50 Tuwaang songs, but thus far, only two songs from the epic have been published. Both are in the Manobo language and are performed during wakes, weddings, thanksgiving rituals, and hunts. The first is Mangovayt Buhong na Langit (The Maiden of the Buhong Sky), recorded by E. Arsenio Manuel and published with an English translation in a journal in 1957. It was published in book form in 1958. A Tagalog translation, Tuwaang: Isang Buong Awit mula sa Epikong Bagobo, ca 1972, was done by Genoveva Edroza-Matute and Epifanio G. Matute. The other song from the epic is Midsakop Tabpopawoy (Tuwaang Attends a Wedding), recorded and published with an English translation by E. Arsenio Manuel in 1975. Manuel’s principal source for the two songs was Saddani Pagayaw, his companion in Davao. Pagayaw dictated the songs on separate occasions. He never sang them, but learned them from one who did, a bard named Inuk, who belonged to a family of epic singers. Inuk, in turn, had learned Midsakop Tabpopawoy from another bard, Itam.

Any song of the Tuwaang epic is introduced by the singer with a proem or prelude, known to the Manobo as the tabbayanon, which, in turn, has two parts: the tabbayanon proper, which elicits interest and often expresses the singer’s loves and dreams, and the bantangon, which announces the beginning of the song proper. The Manobo are especially receptive during epic singing. They express their reactions through the ondaon, in the form of sighs, cries, and yells. Sometimes, their reaction is expressed, within hearing of the singer, in words of appreciation or encouragement, from a simple word or phrase to a complete poetic line.

The first song is about Tuwaang getting himself a wife. He is an artisan adept at making leglets, at engraving finger rings, and at molding chains of gold. One day, he tells his sister that the wind has informed him about the Maiden of the Buhong Sky. She has come to Pinanggayungan, the country of Batooy, but she refuses to talk to any of the gallants there. Although his sister is fearful of what may result, Tuwaang soon gears himself to journey to Batooy’s country. Transported by lightning, bedecked with his warrior’s costume and headdress, and armed like a gallant, he becomes the object of admiration of the maidens of Pinanggayungan. He is received in the house of the Young Man of Pangavukad, who journeys with him to the house of Batooy. There, Tuwaang is received. As he lies sleeping near the Maiden of the Buhong Sky, the Maiden speaks, disrobes, and plucks a strand of Tuwaang’s cowlick. The Maiden tells Tuwaang her story: she has been running away from the Young Man of Pangumanon, a giant whose headdress reaches the clouds, who wants to marry her. Because she rejected him, the Young Man of Pangumanon has burnt her kingdom. Pursued by the giant, she has sought shelter in the earth world.

No sooner has she finished her tale when the Young Man of Pangumanon, enveloped in flames, arrives, killing Batooy’s people. The Young Man of Pangavukad, Tuwaang’s companion, is among the last he slays. Next, he attacks Tuwaang. The two warriors fight, but neither one of them gains an advantage. Shields are smashed, and spears and blades are broken. Then, the Young Man of Pangumanon calls on his pantung, a span-long iron bar endowed with supernatural properties, and coils it around Tuwaang. The pantung bursts into flames, but when Tuwaang raises his right hand, the fire is put out. In turn, Tuwaang calls on his own pantung, a skein of gold. He calls on the wind to fan the flames of his pantung, which engulf the Young Man of Pangumanon and kill him. Tuwaang revives the dead folks by his spittle. Then, riding the lightning, he carries the Maiden on his shoulder to his country in Kuaman. Tuwaang’s sister greets them with betel chew. After resting for five days, a stranger brings death to Tuwaang’s followers and challenges Tuwaang. They fight, and Tuwaang overcomes him. The hero revives his followers and takes another five-day rest. Afterward, he gathers his people to take them to the country of Katusan, the land without death and one of the heavenly layers of the sky world. The people ride the sinalimba, an airboat. Tuwaang places his sister and the Maiden on his shoulders and follows the sinalimba to Katusan.

In the second song, Tuwaang is a wedding guest who becomes the wedding groom. In turn, he thrusts Tuwaang into the earth. Tuwaang sinks to the underworld and speaks to one of the caretakers. The caretaker tells him how to overcome his foe. Resurfacing, Tuwaang asks the Young Man of Sakadna to be his vassal, warning the Young Man that he now knows how to win the battle. The Young Man refuses. After Tuwaang is rejected anew, he summons the golden flute in which the Young Man keeps his life. Because the groom prefers death to enslavement, Tuwaang crushes the flute, thus killing the Young Man of Sakadna.

Once a match is made, the groom’s relatives and parents must raise the bridewealth; otherwise the groom may lose his bride. In Midsakop Tabpopawoy, the redemption of the savakan by Tuwaang, a guest, provides the motivation for Tuwaang to replace the groom. This is the crux of the epic.  Written by E. Arsenio Manuel and Jonathan Chua

There are over 50 Tuwaang songs, but thus far, only two songs from the epic have been published. Both are in the Manobo language and are performed during wakes, weddings, thanksgiving rituals, and hunts. The first is Mangovayt Buhong na Langit (The Maiden of the Buhong Sky), recorded by E. Manuel’s principal source for the two songs was Saddani Pagayaw, his companion in Davao. Pagayaw dictated the songs on separate occasions. He never sang them, but learned them from one who did, a bard named Inuk, who belonged to a family of epic singers. Inuk, in turn, had learned Midsakop Tabpopawoy from another bard, Itam.

Any song of the Tuwaang epic is introduced by the singer with a proem or prelude, known to the Manobo as the tabbayanon, which, in turn, has two parts: the tabbayanon proper, which elicits interest and often expresses the singer’s loves and dreams, and the bantangon, which announces the beginning of the song proper. The Manobo are especially receptive during epic singing. They express their reactions through the ondaon, in the form of sighs, cries, and yells. Sometimes, their reaction is expressed, within hearing of the singer, in words of appreciation or encouragement, from a simple word or phrase to a complete poetic line.

The hero revives his followers and takes another five-day rest. Afterward, he gathers his people to take them to the country of Katusan, the land without death and one of the heavenly layers of the sky world. The people ride the sinalimba, an airboat. article_title: Ulahingan: An Epic of Southern Philippines
text:
Published 1977; 1990; 1992; 1993; and 1994. Five volumes. Chanters: volume 1, Kasama Bangcas, Ampangun Manggung, Langkan, and Santiago Abud; volume 2, Tumatas Mampindaupan and Demetrio Bangcas; volume 3, Pasid Mampayanang and Demetrio Bangcas; volume 4, Gobalia Silay; and volume 5, Pasid Mampayanang, Cayog Mangcambat, and Lumabao Angcondem. Translators: volume 1, Custodio Saliling, Demetrio Bangcas, Abraham Saliling, and Elena G. Maquiso; volume 2, Rose R. Diao and Merlie Alunan-Wensceslao; volume 3, Merlie Alunan and Vicente de Veyra; volume 4, Merlie Alunan, Bienvenido L. Erum, Elena G. Maquiso, and Philips G. Munar Jr; volume 5, Philip G. Munar, Lina Reyes, and Criselda Bonganciso. Transcribers: Custodio Saliling, Demetrio Bangcas, Elena G. Maquiso, Jose Humabad Jr, Manalo Angcondem, Lumabao Angcondem, and Napoleon Bangcas. Dumaguete City: Humanities Publications Series I, Silliman University.

The Ulahingan is the epic of the Livunganen-Arumanen residing in the Libungan river valley in Cotabato del Norte in Mindanao. It is closely related to the epic of Agyu of the Ilianon, because the two tribes used to form one group. It is sung by a tala-ulahingan, or bard, who chews betel nut to sustain himself/herself. It is believed by the Livunganen-Arumanen that Baybayan, the son of the hero Agyu, was the first to perform an ulahing, or heroic chant, and that he now inspires tala-ulahingan to chant stories about Agyu.

The bendigan, or epic, consists of the following parts: an andal or invitation and statement of the purpose; a pamara/pemahra, or invocation; a kepu-unpu-un, or the standard history of Agyu and his relatives; and a sengedurug, or an episode or episodes that continue the story of Agyu and his relatives and can be as numerous and as varied as the tala-ulahingan who sing them. Thus far, 30 sengedurug have been recorded, although hundreds are said to exist. The term “ulahing” means “to chant.” However, the term is used to refer only to the prose rendition of the kepu-unpu-un. The chanting of the sengedurug is called umanen, lungbaten, or uyegingen. The shortest sengedurug that Maquiso recorded lasted three-and-a-half hours; the longest, 18 hours.

 

The first volume of Ulahingan: An Epic of the Southern Philippines contains four different versions of the kepu-unpu-un, with slight variations in details, although the main pattern is the same. Agyu and his relatives are the subject. A conflict develops between them and their rulers, usually the Maguindanaon, because of a forced tribute and the killing of the ruler. They flee, guided by a diwata (spirit-guardian), who promises them immortality after they have overcome various obstacles. They leave behind Mungan, the wife of Banlak who is Agyu’s brother, because she has leprosy. Mungan, however, is the first among them to become immortal. It is she who tells Agyu and the clan to go to Aruman to await the sarimbar/salimbar (magical flying boat), which will take them to paradise. When the appointed day comes, Agyu and his relatives ascend to heaven. A diwata showers them with the oil of immortality and gives them the betel nut of immortality to chew. He blesses them but tells them that the Midlimbag, the Highest God, sends them to live in Nalandangan, an earthly paradise, and not in heaven. That is their reward for enduring and having confidence in the Midlimbag.

However, Baybayan, Agyu’s son, does not join them in Nalandangan. Agyu and his grandfather have decreed that he must circle the world seven times to convert people, as a consequence of his absence from two communal feasts. In his wanderings, Baybayan encounters many adventures, converting many peoples, including Chinese and Muslims. In one episode, his followers run out of food and drink. Baybayan performs the first ulahing by a tree laden with fruits, which drop and turn into linepet, leaf-wrapped rice; a bowl of viand appears beside it. Baybayan and his followers feast on the food, which does not run out. After more wanderings, they are finally flown on a salimbar up to heaven, where they become immortal. Midlimbag gives them powers different from those of Agyu and provides them with another paradise to stay in. He exhorts Baybayan to inspire mortals to perform the ulahing so that they may not forget Agyu.

The sengedurug in volume 1 is “The Visit of Lagabaan to Nalandangan,” a summary of which follows: Nalandangan is the later name of an ancient fortress city, aka Yendang, Menengneng, Libalan, and Newili-an. A chosen people, loved by the Highest God of the sky world, dwell in the fortress city. They have come from Aruman—now identified as a barrio within the municipality of Carmen, North Cotabato—by riding a huge ship. This fact hints that they might have used the Cotabato River and sailed toward some place in northern Mindanao, believed to be Cagayan de Oro City today.

The people build the huge city along the seashore at the river mouth. It is fenced by tree trunks that are taken from various islands of the archipelago and glued together with a python’s saliva. The pillars of Agyu’s house are tree trunks so big that eight persons are needed to link hands around each one and eight persons can lie on top of each. The beams point to the east, their tips decked with statues of reptiles carved with their mouths open, daggerlike teeth exposed. The roof of the house is thatched with mermaid’s hair and the locks of the deity Alimugkat, goddess of the seas; it is also layered with grass from the sky world. On the eaves is a frieze of dazzling, red statues of warriors; and on top of the building are two warriors of gold, each armed with a spear, a shield, and a buckler, both poised for battle. West of the building is a statue of a beautiful maiden washing herself in a stream; in the east, a statue of a golden eagle with wings outspread. The city has a courtyard of silver and a playground of glass. On the battlefield is a mountain of discarded shields and bucklers, spear shafts, and uprooted trees. Scattered around are teeth and skulls. Agyu’s room, called the bengyasan, is coated with paint nine times over. The bathing place of the maidens is fenced by boulders to keep away sharks and crocodiles. The floor is made of silver; the inside wall, of glass. There are bathing places for the married women, for Agyu the hero, and for the young men. They never remove their armors when they bathe.

Nalandangan also has fortifications. Each of the well-known warriors—Kuyasu, nephew of Agyu; Seyluwen, the son; Piglibu, the brother; Banlak/Vanlak, another brother; Nebeyaw, another son; and Agyu—is assigned a fort. Agyu’s fort is built of iron and steel and provided with a cover on which 10 men can perform the sa-ut (war dance). Invaders reach no farther than the opening of the fort.

One morning, Lena/Lono convenes the people to an assembly. Agyu has just wakened from a long sleep and now recounts to the assembly an ominous dream about the darkness and destruction of Nalandangan. Pigyugung/Pemulew, Agyu’s older brother, likewise dreams that invaders have come. But Lena, sure of victory, is unperturbed. When the invader-s arrive, Lena orders the young people to arm themselves, and they do so eagerly. Darkness envelops the fortress of Nalandangan, and Vanlak, the younger brother of Agyu, shouts that he will lead the attack. Agyu’s son, Nebeyew, fights the invaders, who fall like fruit from a tree. But when he raises his arm, a flame comes from it and reveals that the enemy’s magic iron rod is disabling and devouring many of Agyu’s followers.

Lena arms himself, with the orioles hovering over his plume, signifying that his diwata is guiding and protecting him. He instructs his shield and buckler to be firmly rooted to the foundation of the underworld. The enemy’s magic iron rod mocks him with a warning that he might be blown by a storm or swallowed up by a mighty wind. The iron rod withdraws to the sea and then trots back to the battle field, knocking Lena’s shield and buckler to pieces. Lena grapples with the rod and throws it into space. The rod devastates every kingdom that it passes.

The rod returns with a vengeance and tries vainly to gnaw Lena’s slender waist. Lena grabs the rod, and, locked together, they spin, until Lena smashes it against the hardwood trees and the cliff, turning them into a wasteland. Lena’s diwata turns his legs into sharp swords and his limbs into sabers. With them, he splinters the iron monster. A fleet of invading ships appears, carrying a thousand troops and their king. They destroy Yendang, and its people are fettered on the decks of the ships. Lena frees them by simply touching their chains. The people are transported back to the spacious courtyard.

A toddler welcomes the elderly king to Yendang. As the king sits at the portal of the courtyard, he sees his own ships being smashed to pieces. The king only encourages his followers to continue destroying Yendang. Lena drives the invaders back to the seashore. The two warring sides engage in a contest of shouts and banging noises. Then, at Lena’s command, his followers dance the sa-ut as a prelude to the battle. The Yendang warriors of all ages chase the enemies to the mountains and decimate them. The king’s aide plants his shield in the middle of the field, and it becomes a protective cliff for the invading warriors. The shield is knocked away and Delemenen spears the king’s aide.

The king commands his anklets and ringlets to ring the place so that it becomes impenetrable. The king’s shield and buckler grow bigger until they are fastened to the gilded beams of the palace, becoming a blocking cliff. Lena performs the sa-ut and kicks the obstacles away. He presses on the planted shield and buckler of the king, who taunts him. But the shield and the buckler are giving way, like ropes snapping. Lena soon turns them into splinters.

Lena fights with the king and grinds the king’s various weapons to dust. The two wrestle, and a cloud of smoke appears in their midst, but neither one of them yields. Lena hurls himself skyward to take the sipa (ball of the sky), with which he encases the king, who, however, easily frees himself. The king binds Lena’s feet with shackles that are attached to a gigantic tree and a balete tree, whose trunk fastens itself to the land of the dead and the gilded beam of the palace. Lena frees himself and hurls the king into space. But the king returns to the courtyard and binds Lena with the hair of a deity.

Tigyekuwa, Agyu’s first wife, and their son Kumugpa arrive from another land and they come upon the bound Lena. Tigyekuwa’s touch frees him. She also identifies Lena’s adversary as his true father, who has never visited Nalandangan before. The king’s eyes moisten, unable to recognize the multitude of his children, his grandchildren, and his great great grandchildren.

Volume 2 contains two sengedurug. The first, “The Adventures of Impehimbang and Nebeyew,” has a toddler of Nalandangan defeating innumerable enemies, whose king holds the people of Nalandangan captive in the hold of his ship. The second is “Begyasan’s Visit to Insibey,” which centers on the two warrior princesses, Tabagka and Yambungan, who save their chieftain Mendeyawi, aka Agyu, and his warriors from defeat in a battle with invaders. The princess Yambungan then instigates a battle with Agyu himself and his warriors. During their duel, Agyu senses imminent defeat, so he makes a convenient exit by leaving his shield to take his place while he takes a nap under a boulder.

Volume 3 consists of two episodes. In the first, “The Dream of Begyasan,” Nalandangan is invaded by a man-eating, black giant and then by an army of invaders, led by an elderly chieftain. In the end, it is revealed that the giant and elderly chieftain are one and the same, and that he is the ancestor of Agyu and his people, who come to teach them the warrior’s code. In the second, “The Golden Tree,” Begyasan, aka Agyu, pines to death for the golden tree. Pinuklew is tasked to obtain the tree, which is in the realm of Melekdayen. After overcoming many obstacles with his magic amulets, Pinuklew triumphantly returns to Yendang. Revived, Begyasan wants the golden tree returned to its rightful owner, Yambungan. The king of Melekdayen leads an invasion of Udanan, aka Nalandangan, to retrieve the golden tree. Finally, the diwata of peace, Lagabaan, stops the fight with a reprimand for the Melekdayen king and praise for Begyasan, who has rightly recognized Yambungan’s right to the tree.

Volume 4 is a kepu-unpu-un (prologue), which tells the story of the Creation. The Yegpinted (Creator) begins the creation, first, of the multiple layers of the sky and the heavenly bodies. Land is formed when he separates the ocean from the sea. The Yegpinted begins to populate the earth with the creation of Limbagan, the first man, and Imba-al, the first woman. After eating the forbidden fruit, they are punished with a constant hunger, which compels them to wander the earth for food. Mercifully, the Yegpinted sends his secondary gods to help the couple survive. Thus begins the human life of house building, agriculture, procreation, and their attendant anxieties.

Volume 5 gathers three versions of the Creation myth, in which the constant element is the bird that gathers the soil from which the land formations will grow. In the first version, the universe is a collaborative creation of several gods, although they defer to a Supreme Being. The earth’s foundation is a giant iron pillar, but the sun and sky are placed too low until the Supreme Being’s son-in-law raises it. Misery and death plague the human race after the Supreme Being allows the god of evil spirits to live as a human being on earth. Hence, the merciful Supreme Being sends down several spirit guardians, each with a specific function to help people survive in the various aspects of their lives. In the second version, the giant pillar is the earth’s rotating center which is held fast to the sea. Plants are created first to provide medicine for the human race yet to be conceived. The first man and woman are created, but they eat the forbidden fruit and are punished with mortality. The human race multiplies quickly until the Supreme Being sends his ring to call them to an assembly so as to establish institutions of social order: the defining of land boundaries, the selection of leaders, and the duties of each individual to their community. The third version has the Creator sending his ring to call his secondary gods to an assembly, where he commands them to look after the earth. There is a flashback to the details of the creation process. Then the Supreme Being sends his tubao (headdress) to call for a second assembly, in which he assigns each deity to a specific function in keeping the universe in order. The myth ends with the chanter’s song of praise for the Creator’s power and artistry.

An analysis of Maquiso’s Ulahingan is included in the chapter “The Epic” in Paul Zumthor’s Oral Poetry, 1990.  Written by E. Arsenio Manuel and Rosario Cruz-Lucero

Chanters: volume 1, Kasama Bangcas, Ampangun Manggung, Langkan, and Santiago Abud; volume 2, Tumatas Mampindaupan and Demetrio Bangcas; volume 3, Pasid Mampayanang and Demetrio Bangcas; volume 4, Gobalia Silay; and volume 5, Pasid Mampayanang, Cayog Mangcambat, and Lumabao Angcondem. Translators: volume 1, Custodio Saliling, Demetrio Bangcas, Abraham Saliling, and Elena G. Maquiso; volume 2, Rose R. Diao and Merlie Alunan-Wensceslao; volume 3, Merlie Alunan and Vicente de Veyra; volume 4, Merlie Alunan, Bienvenido L. Erum, Elena G. Maquiso, and Philips G. Munar Jr; volume 5, Philip G. Munar, Lina Reyes, and Criselda Bonganciso. Transcribers: Custodio Saliling, Demetrio Bangcas, Elena G. Maquiso, Jose Humabad Jr, Manalo Angcondem, Lumabao Angcondem, and Napoleon Bangcas. Dumaguete City: Humanities Publications Series I, Silliman University.

The Ulahingan is the epic of the Livunganen-Arumanen residing in the Libungan river valley in Cotabato del Norte in Mindanao. It is closely related to the epic of Agyu of the Ilianon, because the two tribes used to form one group. It is sung by a tala-ulahingan, or bard, who chews betel nut to sustain himself/herself. It is believed by the Livunganen-Arumanen that Baybayan, the son of the hero Agyu, was the first to perform an ulahing, or heroic chant, and that he now inspires tala-ulahingan to chant stories about Agyu.

The bendigan, or epic, consists of the following parts: an andal or invitation and statement of the purpose; a pamara/pemahra, or invocation; a kepu-unpu-un, or the standard history of Agyu and his relatives; and a sengedurug, or an episode or episodes that continue the story of Agyu and his relatives and can be as numerous and as varied as the tala-ulahingan who sing them. Thus far, 30 sengedurug have been recorded, although hundreds are said to exist. The term “ulahing” means “to chant.” However, the term is used to refer only to the prose rendition of the kepu-unpu-un. The chanting of the sengedurug is called umanen, lungbaten, or uyegingen. The shortest sengedurug that Maquiso recorded lasted three-and-a-half hours; the longest, 18 hours.

The first volume of Ulahingan: An Epic of the Southern Philippines contains four different versions of the kepu-unpu-un, with slight variations in details, although the main pattern is the same. Agyu and his relatives are the subject. A conflict develops between them and their rulers, usually the Maguindanaon, because of a forced tribute and the killing of the ruler. They flee, guided by a diwata (spirit-guardian), who promises them immortality after they have overcome various obstacles. They leave behind Mungan, the wife of Banlak who is Agyu’s brother, because she has leprosy. Mungan, however, is the first among them to become immortal. It is she who tells Agyu and the clan to go to Aruman to await the sarimbar/salimbar (magical flying boat), which will take them to paradise. When the appointed day comes, Agyu and his relatives ascend to heaven. A diwata showers them with the oil of immortality and gives them the betel nut of immortality to chew. He blesses them but tells them that the Midlimbag, the Highest God, sends them to live in Nalandangan, an earthly paradise, and not in heaven. That is their reward for enduring and having confidence in the Midlimbag.

However, Baybayan, Agyu’s son, does not join them in Nalandangan. Agyu and his grandfather have decreed that he must circle the world seven times to convert people, as a consequence of his absence from two communal feasts. In his wanderings, Baybayan encounters many adventures, converting many peoples, including Chinese and Muslims. In one episode, his followers run out of food and drink. Baybayan performs the first ulahing by a tree laden with fruits, which drop and turn into linepet, leaf-wrapped rice; a bowl of viand appears beside it. Baybayan and his followers feast on the food, which does not run out. After more wanderings, they are finally flown on a salimbar up to heaven, where they become immortal. Midlimbag gives them powers different from those of Agyu and provides them with another paradise to stay in. He exhorts Baybayan to inspire mortals to perform the ulahing so that they may not forget Agyu.

The sengedurug in volume 1 is “The Visit of Lagabaan to Nalandangan,” a summary of which follows: Nalandangan is the later name of an ancient fortress city, aka Yendang, Menengneng, Libalan, and Newili-an. A chosen people, loved by the Highest God of the sky world, dwell in the fortress city. They have come from Aruman—now identified as a barrio within the municipality of Carmen, North Cotabato—by riding a huge ship. This fact hints that they might have used the Cotabato River and sailed toward some place in northern Mindanao, believed to be Cagayan de Oro City today.

The people build the huge city along the seashore at the river mouth. It is fenced by tree trunks that are taken from various islands of the archipelago and glued together with a python’s saliva. The pillars of Agyu’s house are tree trunks so big that eight persons are needed to link hands around each one and eight persons can lie on top of each. The beams point to the east, their tips decked with statues of reptiles carved with their mouths open, daggerlike teeth exposed. The roof of the house is thatched with mermaid’s hair and the locks of the deity Alimugkat, goddess of the seas; it is also layered with grass from the sky world. On the eaves is a frieze of dazzling, red statues of warriors; and on top of the building are two warriors of gold, each armed with a spear, a shield, and a buckler, both poised for battle. West of the building is a statue of a beautiful maiden washing herself in a stream; in the east, a statue of a golden eagle with wings outspread. The city has a courtyard of silver and a playground of glass. On the battlefield is a mountain of discarded shields and bucklers, spear shafts, and uprooted trees. Scattered around are teeth and skulls. Agyu’s room, called the bengyasan, is coated with paint nine times over. The bathing place of the maidens is fenced by boulders to keep away sharks and crocodiles. The floor is made of silver; the inside wall, of glass. There are bathing places for the married women, for Agyu the hero, and for the young men. They never remove their armors when they bathe.

Nalandangan also has fortifications. Each of the well-known warriors—Kuyasu, nephew of Agyu; Seyluwen, the son; Piglibu, the brother; Banlak/Vanlak, another brother; Nebeyaw, another son; and Agyu—is assigned a fort. Agyu’s fort is built of iron and steel and provided with a cover on which 10 men can perform the sa-ut (war dance). Invaders reach no farther than the opening of the fort.

One morning, Lena/Lono convenes the people to an assembly. Agyu has just wakened from a long sleep and now recounts to the assembly an ominous dream about the darkness and destruction of Nalandangan. Pigyugung/Pemulew, Agyu’s older brother, likewise dreams that invaders have come. But Lena, sure of victory, is unperturbed. When the invader-s arrive, Lena orders the young people to arm themselves, and they do so eagerly. Darkness envelops the fortress of Nalandangan, and Vanlak, the younger brother of Agyu, shouts that he will lead the attack. Agyu’s son, Nebeyew, fights the invaders, who fall like fruit from a tree. But when he raises his arm, a flame comes from it and reveals that the enemy’s magic iron rod is disabling and devouring many of Agyu’s followers.

Lena arms himself, with the orioles hovering over his plume, signifying that his diwata is guiding and protecting him. He instructs his shield and buckler to be firmly rooted to the foundation of the underworld. The enemy’s magic iron rod mocks him with a warning that he might be blown by a storm or swallowed up by a mighty wind. The iron rod withdraws to the sea and then trots back to the battle field, knocking Lena’s shield and buckler to pieces. Lena grapples with the rod and throws it into space. The rod devastates every kingdom that it passes.

The rod returns with a vengeance and tries vainly to gnaw Lena’s slender waist. Lena grabs the rod, and, locked together, they spin, until Lena smashes it against the hardwood trees and the cliff, turning them into a wasteland. Lena’s diwata turns his legs into sharp swords and his limbs into sabers. With them, he splinters the iron monster. A fleet of invading ships appears, carrying a thousand troops and their king. They destroy Yendang, and its people are fettered on the decks of the ships. Lena frees them by simply touching their chains. The people are transported back to the spacious courtyard.

A toddler welcomes the elderly king to Yendang. As the king sits at the portal of the courtyard, he sees his own ships being smashed to pieces. The king only encourages his followers to continue destroying Yendang. Lena drives the invaders back to the seashore. The two warring sides engage in a contest of shouts and banging noises. Then, at Lena’s command, his followers dance the sa-ut as a prelude to the battle. The Yendang warriors of all ages chase the enemies to the mountains and decimate them. The king’s aide plants his shield in the middle of the field, and it becomes a protective cliff for the invading warriors. The shield is knocked away and Delemenen spears the king’s aide.

The king commands his anklets and ringlets to ring the place so that it becomes impenetrable. The king’s shield and buckler grow bigger until they are fastened to the gilded beams of the palace, becoming a blocking cliff. Lena performs the sa-ut and kicks the obstacles away. He presses on the planted shield and buckler of the king, who taunts him. But the shield and the buckler are giving way, like ropes snapping. Lena soon turns them into splinters.

Lena fights with the king and grinds the king’s various weapons to dust. The two wrestle, and a cloud of smoke appears in their midst, but neither one of them yields. Lena hurls himself skyward to take the sipa (ball of the sky), with which he encases the king, who, however, easily frees himself. The king binds Lena’s feet with shackles that are attached to a gigantic tree and a balete tree, whose trunk fastens itself to the land of the dead and the gilded beam of the palace. Lena frees himself and hurls the king into space. But the king returns to the courtyard and binds Lena with the hair of a deity.

Tigyekuwa, Agyu’s first wife, and their son Kumugpa arrive from another land and they come upon the bound Lena. Tigyekuwa’s touch frees him. She also identifies Lena’s adversary as his true father, who has never visited Nalandangan before. The king’s eyes moisten, unable to recognize the multitude of his children, his grandchildren, and his great great grandchildren.

Volume 2 contains two sengedurug. The first, “The Adventures of Impehimbang and Nebeyew,” has a toddler of Nalandangan defeating innumerable enemies, whose king holds the people of Nalandangan captive in the hold of his ship. The second is “Begyasan’s Visit to Insibey,” which centers on the two warrior princesses, Tabagka and Yambungan, who save their chieftain Mendeyawi, aka Agyu, and his warriors from defeat in a battle with invaders. The princess Yambungan then instigates a battle with Agyu himself and his warriors. During their duel, Agyu senses imminent defeat, so he makes a convenient exit by leaving his shield to take his place while he takes a nap under a boulder.

Volume 3 consists of two episodes. In the first, “The Dream of Begyasan,” Nalandangan is invaded by a man-eating, black giant and then by an army of invaders, led by an elderly chieftain. In the end, it is revealed that the giant and elderly chieftain are one and the same, and that he is the ancestor of Agyu and his people, who come to teach them the warrior’s code. In the second, “The Golden Tree,” Begyasan, aka Agyu, pines to death for the golden tree. Pinuklew is tasked to obtain the tree, which is in the realm of Melekdayen. After overcoming many obstacles with his magic amulets, Pinuklew triumphantly returns to Yendang. Revived, Begyasan wants the golden tree returned to its rightful owner, Yambungan. The king of Melekdayen leads an invasion of Udanan, aka Nalandangan, to retrieve the golden tree. Finally, the diwata of peace, Lagabaan, stops the fight with a reprimand for the Melekdayen king and praise for Begyasan, who has rightly recognized Yambungan’s right to the tree.

Volume 4 is a kepu-unpu-un (prologue), which tells the story of the Creation. The Yegpinted (Creator) begins the creation, first, of the multiple layers of the sky and the heavenly bodies. Land is formed when he separates the ocean from the sea. The Yegpinted begins to populate the earth with the creation of Limbagan, the first man, and Imba-al, the first woman. After eating the forbidden fruit, they are punished with a constant hunger, which compels them to wander the earth for food. Mercifully, the Yegpinted sends his secondary gods to help the couple survive. Thus begins the human life of house building, agriculture, procreation, and their attendant anxieties.

Volume 5 gathers three versions of the Creation myth, in which the constant element is the bird that gathers the soil from which the land formations will grow. In the first version, the universe is a collaborative creation of several gods, although they defer to a Supreme Being. The earth’s foundation is a giant iron pillar, but the sun and sky are placed too low until the Supreme Being’s son-in-law raises it. Misery and death plague the human race after the Supreme Being allows the god of evil spirits to live as a human being on earth. Hence, the merciful Supreme Being sends down several spirit guardians, each with a specific function to help people survive in the various aspects of their lives. In the second version, the giant pillar is the earth’s rotating center which is held fast to the sea. Plants are created first to provide medicine for the human race yet to be conceived. The first man and woman are created, but they eat the forbidden fruit and are punished with mortality. The human race multiplies quickly until the Supreme Being sends his ring to call them to an assembly so as to establish institutions of social order: the defining of land boundaries, the selection of leaders, and the duties of each individual to their community. The third version has the Creator sending his ring to call his secondary gods to an assembly, where he commands them to look after the earth. There is a flashback to the details of the creation process. Then the Supreme Being sends his tubao (headdress) to call for a second assembly, in which he assigns each deity to a specific function in keeping the universe in order. The myth ends with the chanter’s song of praise for the Creator’s power and artistry.
An analysis of Maquiso’s Ulahingan is included in the chapter “The Epic” in Paul Zumthor’s Oral Poetry, 1990.  Written by E. Arsenio Manuel and Rosario Cruz-Lucero

STUDIES ON KALINGA ULLALIM AND IFUGAW ORTHOGRAPHY

Published 1970. Transcribers, Fr Francis Lambrecht, CICM, and Fr Francisco Billiet, CICM. Baguio City: Catholic School Press.

 

THE KALINGA ULLALIM II

Published 1974. Transcribers, Fr Francis Lambrecht, CICM, and Fr Francisco Billiet, CICM. Baguio City: Igorot Culture Research Studies.

 

ULLALIM BANNA: A KALINGA EPIC, INYULLALIM GAANO LAUDI, IDALUPA, PASIL, KALINGA, PILIPINAS

(Ullalim Banna: A Kalinga Epic, Sung by Gaano Laudi from Dalupa, Pasil, Kalinga, Philippines). Published 2002. Transcriber and editor, Ernesto Constantino. Kyoto: Nakanishi Printing Co., Ltd.

Ullalim is the epic of the Kalinga, a mountain tribe in Luzon. The term ullalim refers to the songs, sung by bards called man-ullalim, which deal with a hero’s exploits, usually involving kayaw, head-hunting raids. Like most epics, the songs feature romance and magic and extol bravery. The singing of the epic is done at night during communal occasions, but private singing is also done to train the young to be future singers of the ullalim.

Several ullalim have been recorded. E. Arsenio Manuel cites a version recorded by Amador Daguio; this, however, was lost in World War II. In 1970, Fr Francisco Billiet, CICM, and Fr Francis Lambrecht, CICM, published four ullalim in Studies on Kalinga Ullalim and Ifugaw Orthography. Their source for two of the four ullalim was a bard from Madukayong; they were assisted by Matilde Daluping. The two other ullalim had been recorded earlier. Fr Rafael Desmedt transcribed Banna’s Heroic Exploits in 1943-44 as it was sung by a blind bard, Ballawig. A similar ullalim had been transcribed by Lucia Manopag, a teacher, on the initiative of Fr Leon Lindemans, as it was sung by Wagiwagan of Taloktok.

Many of the ullalim relate the adventures of Banna. In The Magical Birth of Banna, recorded by Billiet and Lambrecht, Dulaw of Kagayan is betrothed to Ya-u. They follow a betel nut to a feast in Madogyaya, where Dulliyaw of Dulawon falls in love with Dulaw. He intoxicates Ya-u, and while Ya-u is sleeping, he makes Dulaw chew a slice of his betel nut. He informs her that she has just accepted his marriage proposal by sharing his nut, and he promises to come for her the following night. Dulliyaw does so, but a cock crow awakens the villagers. Dulliyaw leaves and kills a man. The villagers pursue him, but he eludes them by climbing a tree. Ya-u calls on the Spanish soldiers of Sakbawan to arrest Dulliyaw. The soldiers, headed by Guwela, capture Dulliyaw and Dulaw, and they imprison the two in Sakbawan.

Three years later, Dulliyaw gives Dulaw another slice of betel nut. But the slice vanishes and reappears in Magobya to Dinanaw, a maiden, after she has bathed in a river. She chews it and becomes pregnant. Three years later, she gives birth to Banna. The boy’s friends tell him that he is the son of the prisoner Dulliyaw, but his mother denies it. Another three years pass; and Banna, now a young man, and his companions are transported to Sakbawan. Banna kills Dulaw, but his companion tells him that Dulliyaw is his father. Father and son return to Magobya riding a beam of light. Banna tells her mother that the man with him is his father. She accepts Dulliyaw’s offer of betel nut, and they rejoice. The next day, the entire village of Magobya is transported to Dulawon where the villagers feast.

Two ullalim, both called The Heroic Exploits of Banna, relate how Banna obtains a wife for himself. In the Ballawig version, Banna falls in love with Laggunawa of Manggawa, a maiden betrothed to Dungdungan. When Banna arrives in Manggawa, Laggunawa welcomes him and, spreading a mat, teases him. Armed with a rifle, Dungdungan returns to Manggawa, having been warned by his father of Laggunawa’s possible infidelity. Banna breaks Dungdungan’s rifle. Dungdungan, in turn, breaks Banna’s cap. Laggunawa steps in to break the fight. She sends each of the men to a kayaw. She will marry the better headhunter.

Banna slaughters the inhabitants of Bibbila. Dungdungan rests, aware that being the legitimate fiancé, he will not lose his claim on Laggunawa whether or not Banna accomplishes his first task. When Banna returns, Dungdungan sends him to kill Uwon, a giant. Banna succeeds. His third task is to kill another giant, Gittam. Having accomplished this, he beheads Banna of Agunawa, a fearful warrior. Seeing that Banna has succeeded in all his exploits, Dungdungan runs away. Banna’s and his men’s shout of victory reaches Dulawon. Dulliyaw, Banna’s father, calls for a feast, inviting the peoples of Manila, Isabela, and Sandangga. From a distance, however, the revellers hear Dungdungan’s shouts. Dulliyaw predicts disorder. Later, the women find a spring dried up, another sign of impending disorder.

Banna and his men meet Dungdungan and his followers in a creek. Dungdungan fires his rifle, burning Dulawon. Awingan, Banna’s brother, bargains with Dungdungan. In exchange for the bride-price that Dungdungan’s father has paid for Laggunawa, Dungdungan gets Banna’s cap and gold. Further, Dinayaw, Banna’s sister, is married to Dungdungan. Peace is restored.

In the Taloktok version, Dungdungan’s betrothed is called Dinayaw. Banna is assigned to kill Sindog of Gayyakayya, and Dungdungan is tasked to kill the giant Gittam. While Banna does his work, Dungdungan boasts of his exploits. He tells Banna to kill Gittam. When Banna returns, Dungdungan sends him to behead Kaluya of Ambanuya, a woman. Dungdungan hopes that Banna will not harm a woman. Dungdungan runs away when he realizes that Banna has accomplished even that. Banna marries Dinayaw, and Dungdungan is invited to the feast. Dungdungan is offered Bagital-yawon, Banna’s sister, whom he readily accepts.

One ullalim, Gonogonaw: A Nonheroic Day in Dulawon, is curious for its lack of action. The word gonogonaw in the title refers to acceptance and the enjoyment of the status quo, even an idle or unadventurous one. Twice, the warriors of Dulawon are prevented from engaging in a kayaw. A deer’s cry, auguring misfortune, stops them. They spend their time tattooing themselves instead. When they find the women newly bathed, they invite the women to a chew. The women, however, protest, because they are not to chew betel nut with men who are on the warpath. Instead, the men bathe themselves in the river. They return home happily with the women.

Billiet and Lambrecht published two more ullalim in 1974 in The Kalinga Ullalim II: Marriage between Enemies and Banna Who Becomes a Python. The first was transcribed by Luica Manopag as it was sung by a female bard of Taloktok, who had learned it from her grandmother. It is about the unwitting reconciliation of two warring tribes.

Separated from his companions after battling a giant, the hero Banna finds himself in Malunawa. There he sleeps until Onnawa, a maiden, arrives and, espying him, falls in love with him. Banna stirs from sleep, and he is speechless with love for Onnawa. But knowing that Onnawa is his father’s enemy, Banna conceals his true identity and calls himself Banawa of Manila. He marries her in her village, Lukiban. Trouble begins when the father Pangdan arrives. He rejects Banna, believing that, since he hails from Manila, he must be poor. Although tempted to redeem himself, Banna refrains from revealing the truth. Pangdan sends him away, but Banna leaves Onnawa his cap and lime tube. Later, Onnawa gives birth to a son. Afraid that her father might harm him, she wraps it in a blanket and sends it afloat in a box with Banna’s lime tube and cap and her own necklace. Mangonombaliyon of Baliwan discovers the infant and raises it as his own. He names the infant Gassingga.

Banna is reunited with his family, but he is filled with thoughts of Onnawa. His mother, however, sends him to court Laggunawa of Magobya. He obeys her, but Suyyaba, Laggunawa’s father, demands of his daughter’s suitors the head of Liddawa of Kayyakayya, his enemy. Although the suitors kill Liddawa’s relatives, they are not able to behead Liddawa himself. Only Banna’s son Gassingga succeeds, and marries Laggunawa. The suitors, including Banna, protest that, by killing Liddawa’s relatives, they have made it easy for Gassingga to behead Liddawa. To settle the imbroglio, Laggunawa sends each of them on a quest. Banna succeeds but Gassingga is swallowed by a python. Mangom-ombaliyon pleads that Banna save his son. Recognizing his cap in Mangom-ombaliyon’s hands, Banna rescues Gassingga. The truth is finally revealed; father and son are reunited. Pangdan softens after Banna’s father offers him gifts as restitution. The two enemies become friends.

Banna Becomes a Python is shorter and more fantastic. After Laggunawa’s love, Banna goes to cut bamboo in Gowa with his friends. His father warns him that the bamboo in Gowa are enchanted, but Banna does not listen. As he strikes a bamboo, it bleeds. Splattered by the blood, Banna slowly becomes a python. Although the villagers and Laggunawa accept him, Banna escapes one night. He slithers to Manila where he finds Dungdungan up a tree getting betel nuts. Banna says he wants to eat Dungdungan. The frightened man chews betel and spits at Banna. Banna becomes a man again. Accompanied by Dungdungan, he returns to the village and marries Laggunawa.

In Ullalim Banna, transcribed by Ernesto Constantino, Banna’s parents, Dalliyaw and Dinnanayan of Durawon, decide that it is time for him to marry, so they send him off to go courting. Banna finds the house of the maiden Laggunawa. When night falls, Banna enters her house through the roof. Laggunawa awakes and, after some hesitation, accepts his offer of betel nut, and they talk through the night. Laggunawa’s father, Suyyaba, and his wife approve of Banna as a prospective son-in-law. But before they marry, Laggunawa asks him to kill the giant Kumaw. The daunting task causes Banna to weep. Stopping at the resting place called Guwa, he thinks of going home, but realizes that the men in his village will taunt him. He proceeds until he reaches a river, where the crocodiles let him walk on their backs up to Baungan.

Banna comes upon Kumaw weaving. He is frightened of Kumaw but he orders his aliwwa (bolo) to kill the giant. He wraps Kumaw’s severed head with the sambaya (blanket). The head continues to shout, so the people from Baungan and Kayyakayya give chase. Banna gets stuck in the middle of the lake in Killayan in Kayyakayya. Big men surround him but they cannot hit him, and the crocodiles fail to eat him. He spends three dry seasons in the lake eluding capture.

Meanwhile, Gallawi of Kabbasila is hunting at Ngawa in the resting place at Ngawangawa. He hears all the shouting in Kayyakayya and rescues Banna by commanding two crows to carry Banna to him. He sprays Banna with betel nut juice to wake Banna up. Banna mistakes Gallawi for Laggunawa and asks him to spray him some more. He is embarrassed when he discovers his error.

Gallawi takes Banna to his village of Kabbasila. Banna weeps, certain that the people are out to kill him to avenge their forefathers. Gallawi’s wife serves Banna rice and basi (sugarcane wine), but Banna refuses to eat except with a maiden. He chooses Gassinu among the maidens and he mixes amaya (love charm) in the rice that they both eat. He asks Gassinu for the bolo, and with one blow, he fells some mango and coconut trees. Everyone approves Banna and Gassinu’s marriage. Banna wants to take Gassinu home to Durawon but she refuses, saying it is too far away.

After three years, Banna’s father Dulliyaw learns that his son is in Kabbasila, and so he and his people go there. Stopping at Mar-unawa, they are met by Banna and the people of Kabbasila, who engage them in battle. Banna’s cousins soon recognize him, and so Galliwa and the people of Kabbasila welcome these red-clad visitors from Durawon with food and gifts of precious jars. But when Gallawi prepares to take Banna and Gassinu home, Dulliyaw disagrees, explaining that Banna is his only child. Gallawi does not object as long as Banna stays with Gassinu, and reasons that there is also the advantage of being related to the rich people of Durawon. At the resting place at Guwa, Banna tells his father about Laggunawa and assures Gassinu that there is no cause for worry.

In the meantime, the Agta tell Laggunawa of Banna’s marriage to Gassinu. Laggunawa goes to Durawon to confront Banna and arrives while a feast is going on. Banna is nonplussed, but Gassinu exchanges harsh words with Laggunawa. Laggunawa asserts her right as the first wife, whereas Gassinu asserts her right to Banna’s life, arguing that it was her father who saved him. Gassinu’s son Baggasingga and Laggunawa’s son Linnawa stop their mothers’ bickering. They suggest that they divide Banna between them, an idea that fuels Gassinu’s anger even more. At dawn, she goes to Magobya and comes upon Laggunawa’s grandchild alone in the house. She then goes straight home to Kabbasila. At sunset, the shout of death is heard. The Agta tell Laggunawa’s son that Gassinu has killed Laggunawa’s grandchild. Laggunawa, weeping, turns to her mother but the older woman admonishes her to keep her peace and vows that there will be no more bloodshed should anyone from Kabbasila ever come. Banna and Laggunawa live together as husband and wife. Written by Jonathan Chua and Efmer Agustin

Published 1974. Transcribers, Fr Francis Lambrecht, CICM, and Fr Francisco Billiet, CICM. Baguio City: Igorot Culture Research Studies.
ULLALIM BANNA: A KALINGA EPIC, INYULLALIM GAANO LAUDI, IDALUPA, PASIL, KALINGA, PILIPINAS
(Ullalim Banna: A Kalinga Epic, Sung by Gaano Laudi from Dalupa, Pasil, Kalinga, Philippines). Published 2002. Transcriber and editor, Ernesto Constantino. Kyoto: Nakanishi Printing Co., Ltd.

Ullalim is the epic of the Kalinga, a mountain tribe in Luzon. The term ullalim refers to the songs, sung by bards called man-ullalim, which deal with a hero’s exploits, usually involving kayaw, head-hunting raids. Like most epics, the songs feature romance and magic and extol bravery. The singing of the epic is done at night during communal occasions, but private singing is also done to train the young to be future singers of the ullalim.

Several ullalim have been recorded. E. Arsenio Manuel cites a version recorded by Amador Daguio; this, however, was lost in World War II. In 1970, Fr Francisco Billiet, CICM, and Fr Francis Lambrecht, CICM, published four ullalim in Studies on Kalinga Ullalim and Ifugaw Orthography. Their source for two of the four ullalim was a bard from Madukayong; they were assisted by Matilde Daluping. The two other ullalim had been recorded earlier. Fr Rafael Desmedt transcribed Banna’s Heroic Exploits in 1943-44 as it was sung by a blind bard, Ballawig. A similar ullalim had been transcribed by Lucia Manopag, a teacher, on the initiative of Fr Leon Lindemans, as it was sung by Wagiwagan of Taloktok.

Many of the ullalim relate the adventures of Banna. In The Magical Birth of Banna, recorded by Billiet and Lambrecht, Dulaw of Kagayan is betrothed to Ya-u. They follow a betel nut to a feast in Madogyaya, where Dulliyaw of Dulawon falls in love with Dulaw. He intoxicates Ya-u, and while Ya-u is sleeping, he makes Dulaw chew a slice of his betel nut. He informs her that she has just accepted his marriage proposal by sharing his nut, and he promises to come for her the following night. Dulliyaw does so, but a cock crow awakens the villagers. Dulliyaw leaves and kills a man. The villagers pursue him, but he eludes them by climbing a tree. Ya-u calls on the Spanish soldiers of Sakbawan to arrest Dulliyaw. The soldiers, headed by Guwela, capture Dulliyaw and Dulaw, and they imprison the two in Sakbawan.

Three years later, Dulliyaw gives Dulaw another slice of betel nut. But the slice vanishes and reappears in Magobya to Dinanaw, a maiden, after she has bathed in a river. She chews it and becomes pregnant. Three years later, she gives birth to Banna. The boy’s friends tell him that he is the son of the prisoner Dulliyaw, but his mother denies it. Another three years pass; and Banna, now a young man, and his companions are transported to Sakbawan. Banna kills Dulaw, but his companion tells him that Dulliyaw is his father. Father and son return to Magobya riding a beam of light. Banna tells her mother that the man with him is his father. She accepts Dulliyaw’s offer of betel nut, and they rejoice. The next day, the entire village of Magobya is transported to Dulawon where the villagers feast.

Two ullalim, both called The Heroic Exploits of Banna, relate how Banna obtains a wife for himself. In the Ballawig version, Banna falls in love with Laggunawa of Manggawa, a maiden betrothed to Dungdungan. When Banna arrives in Manggawa, Laggunawa welcomes him and, spreading a mat, teases him. Armed with a rifle, Dungdungan returns to Manggawa, having been warned by his father of Laggunawa’s possible infidelity. Banna breaks Dungdungan’s rifle. Dungdungan, in turn, breaks Banna’s cap. Laggunawa steps in to break the fight. She sends each of the men to a kayaw. She will marry the better headhunter.

Banna slaughters the inhabitants of Bibbila. Dungdungan rests, aware that being the legitimate fiancé, he will not lose his claim on Laggunawa whether or not Banna accomplishes his first task. When Banna returns, Dungdungan sends him to kill Uwon, a giant. Banna succeeds. His third task is to kill another giant, Gittam. Having accomplished this, he beheads Banna of Agunawa, a fearful warrior. Seeing that Banna has succeeded in all his exploits, Dungdungan runs away. Banna’s and his men’s shout of victory reaches Dulawon. Dulliyaw, Banna’s father, calls for a feast, inviting the peoples of Manila, Isabela, and Sandangga. From a distance, however, the revellers hear Dungdungan’s shouts. Dulliyaw predicts disorder. Later, the women find a spring dried up, another sign of impending disorder.

Banna and his men meet Dungdungan and his followers in a creek. Dungdungan fires his rifle, burning Dulawon. Awingan, Banna’s brother, bargains with Dungdungan. In exchange for the bride-price that Dungdungan’s father has paid for Laggunawa, Dungdungan gets Banna’s cap and gold. Further, Dinayaw, Banna’s sister, is married to Dungdungan. Peace is restored.

In the Taloktok version, Dungdungan’s betrothed is called Dinayaw. Banna is assigned to kill Sindog of Gayyakayya, and Dungdungan is tasked to kill the giant Gittam. While Banna does his work, Dungdungan boasts of his exploits. He tells Banna to kill Gittam. When Banna returns, Dungdungan sends him to behead Kaluya of Ambanuya, a woman. Dungdungan hopes that Banna will not harm a woman. Dungdungan runs away when he realizes that Banna has accomplished even that. Banna marries Dinayaw, and Dungdungan is invited to the feast. Dungdungan is offered Bagital-yawon, Banna’s sister, whom he readily accepts.

One ullalim, Gonogonaw: A Nonheroic Day in Dulawon, is curious for its lack of action. The word gonogonaw in the title refers to acceptance and the enjoyment of the status quo, even an idle or unadventurous one. Twice, the warriors of Dulawon are prevented from engaging in a kayaw. A deer’s cry, auguring misfortune, stops them. They spend their time tattooing themselves instead. When they find the women newly bathed, they invite the women to a chew. The women, however, protest, because they are not to chew betel nut with men who are on the warpath. Instead, the men bathe themselves in the river. They return home happily with the women.

Billiet and Lambrecht published two more ullalim in 1974 in The Kalinga Ullalim II: Marriage between Enemies and Banna Who Becomes a Python. The first was transcribed by Luica Manopag as it was sung by a female bard of Taloktok, who had learned it from her grandmother. It is about the unwitting reconciliation of two warring tribes.

Separated from his companions after battling a giant, the hero Banna finds himself in Malunawa. There he sleeps until Onnawa, a maiden, arrives and, espying him, falls in love with him. Banna stirs from sleep, and he is speechless with love for Onnawa. But knowing that Onnawa is his father’s enemy, Banna conceals his true identity and calls himself Banawa of Manila. He marries her in her village, Lukiban. Trouble begins when the father Pangdan arrives. He rejects Banna, believing that, since he hails from Manila, he must be poor. Although tempted to redeem himself, Banna refrains from revealing the truth. Pangdan sends him away, but Banna leaves Onnawa his cap and lime tube. Later, Onnawa gives birth to a son. Afraid that her father might harm him, she wraps it in a blanket and sends it afloat in a box with Banna’s lime tube and cap and her own necklace. Mangonombaliyon of Baliwan discovers the infant and raises it as his own. He names the infant Gassingga.

Banna is reunited with his family, but he is filled with thoughts of Onnawa. His mother, however, sends him to court Laggunawa of Magobya. He obeys her, but Suyyaba, Laggunawa’s father, demands of his daughter’s suitors the head of Liddawa of Kayyakayya, his enemy. Although the suitors kill Liddawa’s relatives, they are not able to behead Liddawa himself. Only Banna’s son Gassingga succeeds, and marries Laggunawa. The suitors, including Banna, protest that, by killing Liddawa’s relatives, they have made it easy for Gassingga to behead Liddawa. To settle the imbroglio, Laggunawa sends each of them on a quest. Banna succeeds but Gassingga is swallowed by a python. Mangom-ombaliyon pleads that Banna save his son. Recognizing his cap in Mangom-ombaliyon’s hands, Banna rescues Gassingga. The truth is finally revealed; father and son are reunited. Pangdan softens after Banna’s father offers him gifts as restitution. The two enemies become friends.

Banna Becomes a Python is shorter and more fantastic. After Laggunawa’s love, Banna goes to cut bamboo in Gowa with his friends. His father warns him that the bamboo in Gowa are enchanted, but Banna does not listen. As he strikes a bamboo, it bleeds. Splattered by the blood, Banna slowly becomes a python. Although the villagers and Laggunawa accept him, Banna escapes one night. He slithers to Manila where he finds Dungdungan up a tree getting betel nuts. Banna says he wants to eat Dungdungan. The frightened man chews betel and spits at Banna. Banna becomes a man again. Accompanied by Dungdungan, he returns to the village and marries Laggunawa.

In Ullalim Banna, transcribed by Ernesto Constantino, Banna’s parents, Dalliyaw and Dinnanayan of Durawon, decide that it is time for him to marry, so they send him off to go courting. Banna finds the house of the maiden Laggunawa. When night falls, Banna enters her house through the roof. Laggunawa awakes and, after some hesitation, accepts his offer of betel nut, and they talk through the night. Laggunawa’s father, Suyyaba, and his wife approve of Banna as a prospective son-in-law. But before they marry, Laggunawa asks him to kill the giant Kumaw. The daunting task causes Banna to weep. Stopping at the resting place called Guwa, he thinks of going home, but realizes that the men in his village will taunt him. He proceeds until he reaches a river, where the crocodiles let him walk on their backs up to Baungan.

Banna comes upon Kumaw weaving. He is frightened of Kumaw but he orders his aliwwa (bolo) to kill the giant. He wraps Kumaw’s severed head with the sambaya (blanket). The head continues to shout, so the people from Baungan and Kayyakayya give chase. Banna gets stuck in the middle of the lake in Killayan in Kayyakayya. Big men surround him but they cannot hit him, and the crocodiles fail to eat him. He spends three dry seasons in the lake eluding capture.

Meanwhile, Gallawi of Kabbasila is hunting at Ngawa in the resting place at Ngawangawa. He hears all the shouting in Kayyakayya and rescues Banna by commanding two crows to carry Banna to him. He sprays Banna with betel nut juice to wake Banna up. Banna mistakes Gallawi for Laggunawa and asks him to spray him some more. He is embarrassed when he discovers his error.

Gallawi takes Banna to his village of Kabbasila. Banna weeps, certain that the people are out to kill him to avenge their forefathers. Gallawi’s wife serves Banna rice and basi (sugarcane wine), but Banna refuses to eat except with a maiden. He chooses Gassinu among the maidens and he mixes amaya (love charm) in the rice that they both eat. He asks Gassinu for the bolo, and with one blow, he fells some mango and coconut trees. Everyone approves Banna and Gassinu’s marriage. Banna wants to take Gassinu home to Durawon but she refuses, saying it is too far away.

After three years, Banna’s father Dulliyaw learns that his son is in Kabbasila, and so he and his people go there. Stopping at Mar-unawa, they are met by Banna and the people of Kabbasila, who engage them in battle. Banna’s cousins soon recognize him, and so Galliwa and the people of Kabbasila welcome these red-clad visitors from Durawon with food and gifts of precious jars. But when Gallawi prepares to take Banna and Gassinu home, Dulliyaw disagrees, explaining that Banna is his only child. Gallawi does not object as long as Banna stays with Gassinu, and reasons that there is also the advantage of being related to the rich people of Durawon. At the resting place at Guwa, Banna tells his father about Laggunawa and assures Gassinu that there is no cause for worry.

In the meantime, the Agta tell Laggunawa of Banna’s marriage to Gassinu. Laggunawa goes to Durawon to confront Banna and arrives while a feast is going on. Banna is nonplussed, but Gassinu exchanges harsh words with Laggunawa. Laggunawa asserts her right as the first wife, whereas Gassinu asserts her right to Banna’s life, arguing that it was her father who saved him. Gassinu’s son Baggasingga and Laggunawa’s son Linnawa stop their mothers’ bickering. They suggest that they divide Banna between them, an idea that fuels Gassinu’s anger even more. At dawn, she goes to Magobya and comes upon Laggunawa’s grandchild alone in the house. She then goes straight home to Kabbasila. At sunset, the shout of death is heard. The Agta tell Laggunawa’s son that Gassinu has killed Laggunawa’s grandchild. Laggunawa, weeping, turns to her mother but the older woman admonishes her to keep her peace and vows that there will be no more bloodshed should anyone from Kabbasila ever come. Banna and Laggunawa live together as husband and wife. Written by Jonathan Chua and Efmer Agustin

Published 2012. Author, Edel Garcellano. With a foreword by Neferti Tadiar. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

The image that best captures what this collection of poems is about is that which appears on the cover of the book: a cheap teddy bear which has been patched up several times so that its original form is no longer recognizable. The teddy bear represents Philippine historical writing—its many gaps, patchworks, and revisions—as something that is wholly unrecognizable from the actual facts.

The collection consists of poem sequences and a few stand-alone poems. The sequences are structured like a spiral: Garcellano poses a social or existential problem; the poems in the sequence then show how these problems affect certain segments of society and are connected to other events and people who seem so far away from the center. In “Same Old, Same Old,” a sequence of 18 poems, Garcellano examines the aftermath of the Maguindanao Massacre. The first poem of the sequence has an unidentified persona in a coffee shop weary that yet another disaster has occurred and finally resigned to the idea that the world “from Millennium One / has really been insane.” The sequence moves on to the scene of the crime: a journalist’s routine is abruptly and permanently interrupted; a wife waits for her husband’s body to be recovered so that her family can “move on.”

Next come poems that express skepticism about the justice system and describe the public’s apathy, for “from Magsaysay to GMA … deaths are daily fare.” A group of poems reflect on impermanence, the world becoming a place where everything will “slowly dissolve / like a cube of ice / in a wine glass” and memory “is always a brutal joke.” Late in the sequence are poems that review crimes perpetuated elsewhere in the world: pedophilia among the clergy in Dublin, wars fought in the name of religion in the Middle East, and the massacre of 15,000 in the Khmer Rouge. The prison guard defends himself: he is “just a small fry / who diligently followed orders.” The penultimate poem takes the reader back to present-day Philippines on the brink of another election and muses on the prospect—or illusion—of change. The short final poem is almost a cry of desperation: where does one get off the mad ride of the world?

Garcellano skillfully moves from present to past, and in and out of the country. The suggestion is that no matter how horrible the crime, human memory tends to forget, except for those directly affected, to whom “moving on” is merely an illusion. The perpetrators either escape or show no remorse, and the rest, though they have had enough, find no exit.

The poet uses a similar structure in the other poems: the title poem itself, “Vanishing History,” which is about the half-truths and lies that make up social, national, and personal histories; “Statements,” about people’s use of fantasies to enliven the ordinariness of life; and “The Survivors,” about people trying to pick up the pieces after losing loved ones and their old lives.

In the midst of these socially relevant sequences, one can also find Garcellano’s musings on art, poetry, and aesthetics. The collection illustrates how Philippine history has been rewritten so many times. Garcellano warns that the truth about the important events in our nation is in danger of being forgotten.  Written by Jose Miguel Arguelles

text:
(SU GESALAN NU NGA SUBAANEN DI MELAUN TINUBIGAN): CENTRAL SUBANEN ORAL AND WRITTEN LITERATURE

Published 2002. Written and recounted by 30 Subanen. Translator and annotator, Felicia Brichoux. With an introduction by Hazel Wriggleworth, a foreword by Isagani R. Cruz, and drawings by Darwin Bayani. Special monograph issue, Philippine Journal of Linguistics, no. 42. Manila: Linguistic Society of the Philippines.

The book is a bilingual anthology of central Subanon collective and personal histories, speeches, tales and legends, poetry and song, incantations, explication, codes of conduct in various guises—in one instance, even in epistolary form. Foremost of the 30 raconteurs and writers who contributed to the book is Timu’ay (Chief) Ansulat Promon. Two appendices provide, in painstaking detail, an index of cultural elements in the texts and in the content footnotes and an index of all central Subanen digital texts archived by the Summer Institute of Linguistics. Besides the list of references specifically used in the book, a linguistic and ethnographic bibliography of central Subanen is also included. Darwin Bayani’s illustrations consist of different types of animal traps, ranging from bird and pig snares to fish traps; significant parts of the betel nut palm; festive scenes; and the beklug ceremonial platform, which is the central venue for the ritual performance of Subanon life. The book is in Subanon and in English translation, and is replete with content footnotes explaining historical, semantic, and cultural references, which not only are necessary but also provide several possible readings.

There are 14 sections. The first, “Subanen Life along the Rivers,” consists of two long poems presenting in line after line of pithy imagery the inextricable connection between geography, history, and culture. The other sections are (2) etiological tales, or explanations of nature and natural phenomena; (3) myths and legends; (4) explications of good manners and right conduct; (5) marriage customs; (6) ancient and contemporary customs and practices; (7) arbitration practices; (8) invisible beings and the shaman, called belian; (9) two “heirloom stories”; (10) narratives of recent history; (11) recreation pieces, which include riddles and nonsense tales; (12) poetry, song, and music; (13) trickster tales; and (14) the origins of river names.

The function of a people’s literature is not only to affirm virtuousness but also to deplore shortcomings. Self-recrimination is implied in the creation myth that explains how laziness causes the Subanen’s flat nose, and quick action causes the American’s more prominent proboscis. The comic mode of Subanen literature derives from this predominant tone of impish self-mockery. The impact of these accounts is created by such devices as dramatization of abstract ideas through action and dialog, suspense within a series of cliffhangers, and narrative detail to set tone and atmosphere. The book is rich with beautiful figures of speech. Famine is described as the condition of being “swallowed by a crocodile”; good fortune is “the crocodile spitting us out.” The Subanen wish for a long, healthy life is the prayer that “you will be agile enough to walk along a sugarcane leaf.”

In her introduction, Brichoux states that the book will please a wide range of readers: the general scholar, the linguist, the anthropologist, the student of literature. It is a treasure trove for all Filipinos as well, for it is the literary and intellectual tradition in which they can be rooted, so that they may find themselves one with this voice of many rivers in the archipelagic nation called the Philippines.  Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero
