text:
ORAL AND WRITTEN ESSAYS ON THE CULTURE AND WORLD VIEW OF THE MANOBO

Published 2005. Written and recounted by Manuel Arayam et al. Translator, Ena E. Arayam et al. Editor, Melchor Bayawan, with an introduction by Ena E. Arayam, a foreword by Gloria M. Mudanza, and illustrations by Melchor Bayawan. Summer Institute of Linguistics. Manila: Linguistics Society of the Philippines.

The short essays, anecdotes, legends, myths, folktales, poems, and songs in this book were contributed by 14 writers and raconteurs representing the subtribe called the Obo Manobo, also variously named Kidapawan Manobo and Bagobo. They are the collective “voice from Mt. Apo” as they recount and explain their history, codes of conduct, and way of life. As are most of the books published by the Summer Institute of Linguistics, this is a bilingual book, Manobo and English, with a wealth of content footnotes, a glossary, and two appendices demonstrating a linguistic analysis of a Manobo text and selected grammatical units.

There are various ways by which the pieces in this anthology may be classified. Molen’s introduction groups them thematically thus: (1) the supernatural world, (2) getting along with one another, and (3) finding sustenance. The first theme shows how major events in an individual’s life, such as childbirth, planting, house building, illness, or burial, are marked by rituals “to appease the wrath of evil spirits.” The second theme stresses the importance of harmonious social relationships, especially within one’s family. The third theme, finding and preparing food, has always been the Manobo’s daily preoccupation, only the means and methods having altered with the passing of time.

The three aforementioned themes are divided into more specific topics in the book’s table of contents—namely, (1) lifecycle, (2) social values, (3) the home, (4) livelihood, (5) getting along with others, (6) getting along with spirits, (7) getting along with nature, (8) leisure and beauty, and (9) stories, songs, and poetry.

The chapter titled “Lifecycle” contains short expositions on stages of life as the Manobo live them: from childbirth, marriage, the taking of an additional wife, divorce, death, widowhood, to the afterlife. Social values, of which the second chapter consists, are orally transmitted in the form of payas (giving advice).

Coexistence, or “getting along” as the titles of the next three chapters put it, is defined on three levels: with one’s fellows, with spirits, and with nature. Codes of conduct and beliefs in spirits are validated by narrative examples taken from either historical anecdotes or the narrators’ immediate personal experiences. Personal eyewitness accounts can also function not only as authentic history or biography but also as parables.

The last chapter, “Stories, Songs and Poetry” are an addition to the treasury of creation myths and trickster tales for folk-literature compilers. Trickster tales involve popular characters like the monkey and turtle, Tilandok (aka Pilandok) and the giant, the hawk and the hen; the lesser-known whistler bird and the cat, Pituy and Otatat. Then there are Sunni, the archetypal wise hero, and his opposite, Wou, the archetypal numskull.

As a source of Manobo traditional knowledge, A Voice from Mt. Apo possesses an encyclopedic range of information, ranging from its pantheon of gods to its underworld spirits, hence extending over invisible and visible orders of reality. Myth, legend, historical reminiscence, and actual history interweave to form a completely accurate picture of a community that only its members can fully understand and therefore relay.  Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero

article.value: ORAL AND WRITTEN ESSAYS ON THE CULTURE AND WORLD VIEW OF THE MANOBO

Published 2005. Written and recounted by Manuel Arayam et al. Translator, Ena E. Arayam et al. Editor, Melchor Bayawan, with an introduction by Ena E. Arayam, a foreword by Gloria M. Mudanza, and illustrations by Melchor Bayawan. Summer Institute of Linguistics. Manila: Linguistics Society of the Philippines.

The short essays, anecdotes, legends, myths, folktales, poems, and songs in this book were contributed by 14 writers and raconteurs representing the subtribe called the Obo Manobo, also variously named Kidapawan Manobo and Bagobo. They are the collective “voice from Mt. Apo” as they recount and explain their history, codes of conduct, and way of life. As are most of the books published by the Summer Institute of Linguistics, this is a bilingual book, Manobo and English, with a wealth of content footnotes, a glossary, and two appendices demonstrating a linguistic analysis of a Manobo text and selected grammatical units.

There are various ways by which the pieces in this anthology may be classified. Molen’s introduction groups them thematically thus: (1) the supernatural world, (2) getting along with one another, and (3) finding sustenance. The first theme shows how major events in an individual’s life, such as childbirth, planting, house building, illness, or burial, are marked by rituals “to appease the wrath of evil spirits.” The second theme stresses the importance of harmonious social relationships, especially within one’s family. The third theme, finding and preparing food, has always been the Manobo’s daily preoccupation, only the means and methods having altered with the passing of time.

The three aforementioned themes are divided into more specific topics in the book’s table of contents—namely, (1) lifecycle, (2) social values, (3) the home, (4) livelihood, (5) getting along with others, (6) getting along with spirits, (7) getting along with nature, (8) leisure and beauty, and (9) stories, songs, and poetry.

The chapter titled “Lifecycle” contains short expositions on stages of life as the Manobo live them: from childbirth, marriage, the taking of an additional wife, divorce, death, widowhood, to the afterlife. Social values, of which the second chapter consists, are orally transmitted in the form of payas (giving advice).

Coexistence, or “getting along” as the titles of the next three chapters put it, is defined on three levels: with one’s fellows, with spirits, and with nature. Codes of conduct and beliefs in spirits are validated by narrative examples taken from either historical anecdotes or the narrators’ immediate personal experiences. Personal eyewitness accounts can also function not only as authentic history or biography but also as parables.

The last chapter, “Stories, Songs and Poetry” are an addition to the treasury of creation myths and trickster tales for folk-literature compilers. Trickster tales involve popular characters like the monkey and turtle, Tilandok (aka Pilandok) and the giant, the hawk and the hen; the lesser-known whistler bird and the cat, Pituy and Otatat. Then there are Sunni, the archetypal wise hero, and his opposite, Wou, the archetypal numskull.

As a source of Manobo traditional knowledge, A Voice from Mt. Apo possesses an encyclopedic range of information, ranging from its pantheon of gods to its underworld spirits, hence extending over invisible and visible orders of reality. Myth, legend, historical reminiscence, and actual history interweave to form a completely accurate picture of a community that only its members can fully understand and therefore relay.  Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero

article_title: Waray Literature: An Anthology of Leyte-Samar Writings
text:
Published 1982. Editor, Gregorio C. Luangco. Tacloban City, Philippines: Divine Word University Press.

An anthology of 56 titles, the book is divided into three parts: “Folk and Pre-colonial Period,” “Spanish-American Period,” and “Modern Period.” Luangco does not date his periods.

Part 1 contains riddles from the compilation of Maria Luz Vilches; proverbs from Nenita Tamayo’s; three folktales, or susumaton, told by Gertrudes Pasta, Consorcio Cartel, and Benito Prejula; seven popular folk songs with their notations; and the summaries of two epics, Datong Somangga y Bubu nga Huamianun (Dato Somangga and Bubu nga Huamianun) and Cabungao y Bubu nga Ginbuna (Cabungao and Bubu nga Ginbuna). The summaries of the epics, or epoyas, are culled from Fr Cantius Kobak’s annotations of the works of the 17th-century Jesuit chronicler, Francisco Alcina.

The first epoya tells of Datong Somangga’s courtship of Huamianon, a beautiful but arrogant princess. She sends him off to get slaves for her from nearby islands, and he always comes back victorious. When she continues to hold him off, he gets piqued and unravels her hair bun, to her great shame. This forces her to make him a betel chew, signifying her acceptance of his suit. The other epic tells of the lovers Cabungao and Ginbuna. Cabungao goes off to war but his family insults the woman in his absence. She goes away with her slaves to a remote island. Cabungao eventually finds her after many tale-worthy adventures.

Part 2 may actually refer to the years between 1880 and 1950. These years are characterized by the appearance of local Spanish-language and Bisaya publications like Eco de Samar y Leyte. Jaime de Veyra’s “Tandaya or Candaya,” originally in Spanish, is a peroration on the history of the old names of Samar and Leyte. Norberto Romualdez’s “Cantar que Compromiso” (To Sing Is Such a Quandary) asks, “In what language should I sing?” The intellectuals of the time displayed their love of and pride in their language and culture by deliberately writing in Waray. Luangco presents some popular writers and their works from Eco de Samar y Leyte: Iluminado Lucente’s love songs “Dinumdum Ko Ikaw” (I Think of You) and “Panhayhay” (Sighs), both a lover’s plaint about a woman’s infidelity; Casiano Trinchera’s “Malingoon nga Gugma” (Treacherous Love), which laments the perfidy of beautiful women. An astute observer of the social and political scene, Trinchera attacks the habit of kowtowing to important personages in “An mga Is-Is” (The Sycophants). Love of home, of one’s country, or of a bucolic place was a favorite theme, as in de Veyra’s “Laylay sin Palun-on” (Song of a Palo Native), and Makabenta’s “Busay ha Tulaan” (Tulaan Waterfall). Lucente’s “Ha Pangpang han Daguitan” (By the Banks of the Daguitan River) and Alvarado’s “Sa May’ Lalawtion” (By Lalawiton) are meditations on the human condition.

The rise of English in public life and the adoption of a national language might have contributed to the decline of interest in writing in Waray. Part 3 shows only two writers, Agustin El O’Mora and Ricardo Octaviano, each of whom has a poem titled “Tuba” (Palm Wine). In both poems, the tuba speaks and advises its patrons how to drink without bringing trouble upon themselves and their community. Except for El O’Mora’s use of lowercase letters à la e. e. cummings in “Paghingadtu han Bulan” (Journey to the Moon), both poets retain the rhyme and meter, stanza form, and the tone and attitude of the poetry of the earlier period.

The drama is represented by Romualdez’s An Anak han Manaranggot (The Tuba Gatherer’s Daughter), Iluminado Lucente’s Diri Daraga, Diri Balo, Diri Inasaw-an (Not a Maiden, Not a Widow, Not a Wife), and El O’Mora’s Leyte, Puro han Kasiyahanan (Leyte, Isle of Firsts).

Only writers from Leyte are presented in the book. These gaps notwithstanding, Waray Literature: An Anthology of Leyte-Samar Writing contributes tremendously to the sparse scholarship on Waray literature.  Written by Merlie M. Alunan and Michael Carlo Villas

article_title: Yang Mangngagaw: An Epic of the Mandaya of Caraga, Davao Oriental
text:
(The Taking by Force: An Epic of the Mandaya of Caraga, Davao Oriental). Published 1999. Chanters, Madugilay Madanlo and Beniang Punto. Recorded by Genevieve T. Jorolan.

Transcribers and translators into Visayan, Laurencio Mandenancil and Josefa Piamonte. Translator into English from the Visayan, Jorolan. Tambara, vol. 16.

The Mandaya is an ethnic group, generally located in the mountains of Davao Oriental, although some reside in Compostela and New Bataan, Davao del Norte. Seven other Mandaya epics have been identified, although these may also be taken as hullobaton (narratives), which are lengthy episodes of the larger dawot (epic). These seven dawot or hullobaton are Sadya na Yalabo (The Banishment of Sadya), Yangagaw si Dilam (Dilam Takes Tibay’s Betrothed by Force), Syukli si Obang (The Abduction of Obang), Pyalid si Sadya (Dilam Uses Storm to Abduct Sadya), Maylan (Maylan’s Death and Resurrection), Yubolla si Daymon (Daymon Goes to War), and Gambong (Gambong and His Ornamental Tree).

Yang Mangngagaw (The Taking by Force) is a Mandaya dawot that is sung by magdadawot (epic singers) in Caraga, Davao Oriental. It consists of 2,020 lines and can be divided into 10 episodes, based on its story line and scene changes. One of the epic conventions immediately obvious in this piece is the use of many names for one character.

The first episode introduces the epic hero and the epic problem. The hero is Maynabong nal Layag (The Handsome One), aka Sabong of Kadigi, aka Kyabadbaran (The South). The epic problem is Sabong’s desire for Sadya of Ullaynun, aka Bullawanun (The Golden Place). The epic opens with Sabong in his home at Kadigi sewing his red clothes, which he embroiders with orange and yellow stitches. Its misbehavior frustrates him and so he hacks it into shreds with his bolo. Asked by his brothers Lanus and Luntad what troubles him, Sabong tells them that he desires Inung Masadyang Kilat, aka Sadya, the sister of Dyuyan in Ullaynun. But Sadya is already betrothed to Ombang, brother of Tibay, from Byadbadan. Sabong and his brothers summon their sister Malimbungon na Panday (Beautiful Wise Maiden), aka Linimbong, from her room.

In Ullaynun, Sadya, and her two sisters, Omal-lag sa Maglimbay and Magallowaing Samtan, are getting dressed to go outside and walk toward their digpi (room), which is forbidden to everyone else. Many obstacles along the way discourage trespassers. The door creaks when it is opened, thus alerting Al-lag the diwata (spirit guardian) who bars Sadya at the door should she attempt to leave the room.

The scene shifts back to Kadigi, where Linimbong is helping her brother Sabong look his best as he prepares for the journey to Byadbaran to court Sadya. His hair, which reaches down to the floor is “as thick as bamboo” so that only a flute can comb it. She applies oil to his hair and combs it into seven braids. When he tells her that he has decided to take for his wife a woman already betrothed, she advises him to cover his fingers with many rings, put a necklace on, and wear jewelled anklets. From among his many red garments in the golden chest, she chooses a vest and a golden belt for him to wear. He takes his spear and shield and his brothers follow suit.

Lanus and Luntad, dressed in their best finery, follow their brother Sabong toward the boat. They walk past the women’s garden of betel trees and flowers. Sabong rows and steers the boat through eight rivers dangerously filled with whirlpools and rocks. But when they reach Ullaynun, the water is very calm and deep, the sand sparkles, and the rocks are as numerous as ants. Red garments, bolos, shields, flowers, yellow strands from the dye tree are floating on the water. Trees as many as the strands of a head of hair fill the air with the scent of their flowers. So numerous are the flowers they can be picked from across the shore of Ullaynun and made into belts.

They walk past the women’s abaca farm and grove of betel nut trees, through eight rivers filled with flowers, over sequined fences, past the dye tree tied with jewels and plants to secure them against storms. Sabong picks a flower from Sadya’s garden and vows that she is the only flower that he will ever pick even if he were to crawl under her house. A noisy gathering in the house where Sadya lives is in progress; her brothers are hosting her prospective brothers- and sisters-in-law from Byadbadan. Ombang’s eldest brother, Tibay, and Sadya’s eldest brother, Dagyo, are conversing loudly; jars and glasses break; drunken people come and go with their braids undone. Dagyo’s slave notices the brothers from Kadigi standing in the yard but when she warns Dagyo, he likens her to the limukon (omen bird), which gives false warnings. The brothers from Kadigi are treated with the utmost courtesy, with inquiries about their journey and offers of betel chew. Each brother is invited to sit beside a host brother who is most like him: Lanus sits beside Dyuyan; Sabong, after some hesitation, sits beside Dallmun; and Luntad is honored with a spot in Dagyo’s room. Asked how far they have come, Luntad replies that the “distance is between two guitar strings.”

The gestures of hospitality continue. Sadya and her three sisters are summoned from their room to welcome the guests. Then they go back to their room for betel chew despite much difficulty because of the obstacles along the way. Dagyo goes down to fetch a jar of wine. Returning, he throws the jar at the wall, and Dyuyan catches it but its contents spill out. Dagyo fetches another jar and offers wine to his own sisters, who refuse. Dagyo drinks wine with the brothers from Kadigi. He then asks for more wine, this time for his other set of guests, the sisters of Tibay and Ombang from Byadbadan. But it is Luntad who offers the wine, first, to the eldest sister, Ballobaynun nam Bullan. When she refuses, her younger sister, Salingkugon sa Baybay, takes it and drinks. Luntad pleads with Ballobaynun nam Bullan to drink the wine, claiming to prefer death to despair should she refuse. And so she accepts the wine. At first Salingkugon sa Baybay goes to Makaway, brother of Dagyo, but offers the wine instead to Luntad. He takes hold of her hand; and her necklace, heavy with pure gold, falls as his hands begin to move.

Manggob, aka Dyumabok Manginsawan, brother of Tibay and Ombang, fetches Sadya from her room. Her spirit-guard, Omal-lag sa Maglimbay, does not stand in her way. But first, Sadya oils her hair and combs it; she shaves her brows with a sharp knife, places 65 to a hundred rings on her fingers, takes a necklace and winds it around her neck seven or eight times. She is reminded to keep the honor of Ullaynun unstained because it is what she will take with her to Byadbadan.

Dyumabok Manginsawan, aka Manggob, brother of Tibay and Ombang, has been guarding the door of Sadya’s room in case she tries to escape. Now he holds her by the shoulder as she emerges. The first item that she asks for her dowry is a wash basin for her lady companion.

Makailaw sa Baybay (Light of the Shore), aka Ilaw sang Kasiglluman (Light in the Dark), another sister of Tibay and Ombang, is yet unaware that Sadya has been called out of her room by her brother Dyuyan. It is Dyuyan who is tasked with determining the bride-price, or dowry, of his sister Sadya. Ombang, the bagani (warrior) to whom she is betrothed, gives Dyuyan seven necklaces. Sadya is about to leave her room when Ballobaynun nam Bullan, Ombang’s sister, has a premonition and holds her back. She fears that Sadya might stumble and fall, and that is a bad omen. Dallmun, aka Mallapog, Sadya and Dagyo’s brother, is impervious to all this; he enters Sadya’s room, lies on the red mat, and falls fast asleep. Sadya now emerges from her room, mindful of the danger of stumbling. The first obstacle she encounters is the jar of wine blocking her door. She rues her difficulties and wishes she could simply break the jar, but that would be a bad omen. Manggob, Ombang’s brother, drinks all the wine in the jar and breaks it. His sisters become angry with him because this will raise Sadya’s bride-price. Sadya now asks for the necklace of Makailaw sa Baybay, Ombang’s sister, who pleads with her not to take it. But Makailaw’s brother promises Sadya the necklace she desires. The dowry now fully given, Sadya emerges and sits on the red mat. Ballobaynun pleads with her brother to prevent Sadya from facing west, because that is a bad omen. She notices with foreboding that her brother Ombang is reluctant to sit and talk with Sadya. Ballobaynun compares herself to the limokon whose prophecies must be heeded.

Meanwhile, Sabong is hatching up a plan to win Sadya for himself. He will ask her whether she prefers the tree standing toward the west and blooming with bolos or the tree fully adorned and topped by a flower. He will tell her about his boat, which is shaped like a crocodile or dragon and its interior filled with carvings. The men of both Byadbadan and Ullaynun are distracted by a crowd of warriors who have docked, ready to do battle. The house trembles. Sabong grabs his chance; he embraces, kisses, and caresses Sadya. She struggles and screams so loudly her brother fears that it might summon their dead parents. Sabong moves to escape, and Tibay’s sisters scramble out of his way. Ombong vows that he will marry Sadya anyway. Nevertheless, now brought to shame, Sadya continues to wail loudly.

Tibay and Sabong engage in a battle of spears and angry words until the house pleads with them to take their fight outside. Lanus calls to his brother Luntad for them to help their brother Sabong. But Luntad, now smitten with Tibay’s sister, Salingkugon sa Baybay, takes her hand, and the pair stand in the middle of the fight. An outraged Tibay pulls her away and the fight continues interminably. Finally, Tibay goes to his sister Aybay and bids her sit beside Ubang ng Pagkallayon of Kadigi. Reproached by Aybay for his involvement in the fight, Ubang lays the blame on both his brother Sabong and her brother Tibay. Ubang takes Aybay into the middle of the fight, and the brothers from Kadigi stop fighting at the sight of her beauty. Tibay decides it is time to discuss a truce.

In Sabang, Maglipig Mal-langitnin, aka Lipig, the diwata of peace, is awakened by his sister Biya Domallaiyak. She urges him to go down to earth and stop the fight by revealing to the warriors that they are all brothers from Ullaynun. On earth many spears whiz by Lipig and they break as he steps on them. The destruction of the garden and the sight of flowers strewn on the ground sadden him. He separates the ocean from the sea, thus causing the waves to crash against the rocks. Seeing the impending flood, Tibay calls a halt to the war. Lanus hesitates, wondering at the sincerity of the call. Lipig identifies himself as Lanus’s brother; they come from the same father, Dyabongan. Their father had him thrown into the sea because of his ugliness and he was washed up in the place of the gods. He admonishes all the brothers to share betel chew and let peace reign.  Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero

Dyumabok Manginsawan, aka Manggob, brother of Tibay and Ombang, has been guarding the door of Sadya’s room in case she tries to escape. Now he holds her by the shoulder as she emerges. The first item that she asks for her dowry is a wash basin for her lady companion.

Makailaw sa Baybay (Light of the Shore), aka Ilaw sang Kasiglluman (Light in the Dark), another sister of Tibay and Ombang, is yet unaware that Sadya has been called out of her room by her brother Dyuyan. It is Dyuyan who is tasked with determining the bride-price, or dowry, of his sister Sadya. Ombang, the bagani (warrior) to whom she is betrothed, gives Dyuyan seven necklaces. Sadya is about to leave her room when Ballobaynun nam Bullan, Ombang’s sister, has a premonition and holds her back. She fears that Sadya might stumble and fall, and that is a bad omen. Dallmun, aka Mallapog, Sadya and Dagyo’s brother, is impervious to all this; he enters Sadya’s room, lies on the red mat, and falls fast asleep. Sadya now emerges from her room, mindful of the danger of stumbling. The first obstacle she encounters is the jar of wine blocking her door. She rues her difficulties and wishes she could simply break the jar, but that would be a bad omen. Manggob, Ombang’s brother, drinks all the wine in the jar and breaks it. His sisters become angry with him because this will raise Sadya’s bride-price. Sadya now asks for the necklace of Makailaw sa Baybay, Ombang’s sister, who pleads with her not to take it. But Makailaw’s brother promises Sadya the necklace she desires. The dowry now fully given, Sadya emerges and sits on the red mat. Ballobaynun pleads with her brother to prevent Sadya from facing west, because that is a bad omen. She notices with foreboding that her brother Ombang is reluctant to sit and talk with Sadya. Ballobaynun compares herself to the limokon whose prophecies must be heeded.

Meanwhile, Sabong is hatching up a plan to win Sadya for himself. He will ask her whether she prefers the tree standing toward the west and blooming with bolos or the tree fully adorned and topped by a flower. He will tell her about his boat, which is shaped like a crocodile or dragon and its interior filled with carvings. The men of both Byadbadan and Ullaynun are distracted by a crowd of warriors who have docked, ready to do battle. The house trembles. Sabong grabs his chance; he embraces, kisses, and caresses Sadya. She struggles and screams so loudly her brother fears that it might summon their dead parents. Sabong moves to escape, and Tibay’s sisters scramble out of his way. Ombong vows that he will marry Sadya anyway. Nevertheless, now brought to shame, Sadya continues to wail loudly.

Tibay and Sabong engage in a battle of spears and angry words until the house pleads with them to take their fight outside. Lanus calls to his brother Luntad for them to help their brother Sabong. But Luntad, now smitten with Tibay’s sister, Salingkugon sa Baybay, takes her hand, and the pair stand in the middle of the fight. An outraged Tibay pulls her away and the fight continues interminably. Finally, Tibay goes to his sister Aybay and bids her sit beside Ubang ng Pagkallayon of Kadigi. Reproached by Aybay for his involvement in the fight, Ubang lays the blame on both his brother Sabong and her brother Tibay. Ubang takes Aybay into the middle of the fight, and the brothers from Kadigi stop fighting at the sight of her beauty. Tibay decides it is time to discuss a truce.

In Sabang, Maglipig Mal-langitnin, aka Lipig, the diwata of peace, is awakened by his sister Biya Domallaiyak. She urges him to go down to earth and stop the fight by revealing to the warriors that they are all brothers from Ullaynun. On earth many spears whiz by Lipig and they break as he steps on them. The destruction of the garden and the sight of flowers strewn on the ground sadden him. He separates the ocean from the sea, thus causing the waves to crash against the rocks. Seeing the impending flood, Tibay calls a halt to the war. Lanus hesitates, wondering at the sincerity of the call. Lipig identifies himself as Lanus’s brother; they come from the same father, Dyabongan. Their father had him thrown into the sea because of his ugliness and he was washed up in the place of the gods. He admonishes all the brothers to share betel chew and let peace reign.  Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero
